Remark 2.1.4. Writing these proofs diagrammatically, we see that the ad-
junction isomorphisms are given by homeomorphisms in our context of topological
categories.
We specialize to ex-spaces (or ex-G-spaces), in the rest of the section. Observe
that the Ô¨Åber (f‚àóX)b is the space of sections Ab ‚àí‚ÜíXb of p: Xb ‚àí‚ÜíAb.
Remark 2.1.5. If f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB is an open map and X is in U , then f‚àóX is in
U and UA(f ‚àóY, X) ‚àº= UB(Y, f‚àóX) for Y ‚ààU , by [96, 1.5].
Example 2.1.6. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be an inclusion. Then f ‚àóY is the restriction
of Y to A and f!X = B ‚à™A X is obtained by expanding the section from A to B and
composing the projection X ‚àí‚ÜíA with f. The ex-space f‚àóX over B is analogous
to the prolongation by zero of a sheaf over A. The Ô¨Åber (f‚àóX)b is Xa if a ‚ààA and a
point {b} otherwise. To see this from the deÔ¨Ånition, recall that Map(‚àÖ, K) is a point
for any space K and that MapB(A, X)b = Map(Ab, Xb). As a set, f‚àóX ‚àº= B ‚à™A X,
but the topology is quite diÔ¨Äerent. It is devised so that the map Y ‚àí‚Üíf‚àóf ‚àóY that
restricts to the identity on Ya for a ‚ààA but sends Yb to {b} for b /‚ààA is continuous.
Example 2.1.7. For b ‚ààB, let b also denote the map ‚àó‚àí‚ÜíB that sends ‚àóto
B; we may view this as the case A = {b} of the previous example. Then b‚àóY is the
Ô¨Åber Yb, and we write Kb and bK for the spaces b!K and b‚àóK over B associated to
a based space K. In the equivariant case, we must take the isotropy group Gb into
account. Let Àúb: G/Gb ‚àí‚ÜíB be the induced map of orbits, so that Àúb maps G/Gb
onto the orbit Gb. We shall reinterpret the functors Àúb‚àó, Àúb! and Àúb‚àóas an equivariant
Ô¨Åber functor and its left and right adjoints in Example 2.3.12 below.
Example 2.1.8. Let r: B ‚àí‚Üí‚àóbe the unique map. We shall use the letter
r with this meaning throughout the book. For a based space X and an ex-space
E = (E, p, s) over B, we have
r‚àóX = B √ó X,
r!E = E/s(B),
and
r‚àóE = Sec(B, E),
where Sec(B, E) is the space of maps t: B ‚àí‚ÜíE such that p ‚ó¶t = id, with
basepoint the section s. These elementary base change functors are the key to using
parametrized homotopy theory to obtain information in ordinary homotopy theory.
Let Œµ: r!r‚àó‚àí‚Üíid and Œ∑: id ‚àí‚Üír‚àór! be the counit and unit of the adjunction
(r!, r‚àó). Then r!r‚àóX ‚àº= B+‚àßX and Œµ is r+‚àßid, while r‚àór!E = B√óE/s(B) and Œ∑ has
coordinates p and the quotient map E ‚àí‚ÜíE/s(B). Thus r!r‚àór!E ‚àº= B+ ‚àßE/s(B)
and r!Œ∑: r!E ‚àí‚Üír!r‚àór!E is the ‚ÄúThom diagonal‚Äù E/s(B) ‚àí‚ÜíB+ ‚àßE/s(B). If
p: E ‚àí‚ÜíB is a spherical Ô¨Åbration with section, such as the Ô¨Åberwise one-point
compactiÔ¨Åcation SŒΩ of a vector bundle ŒΩ, then r!E is the Thom complex of p.

32
2. CHANGE FUNCTORS AND COMPATIBILITY RELATIONS
Remark 2.1.9. Although our main interest will be in the sectioned theory, we
shall occasionally use the analogous base change functors on categories of parame-
trized objects without sections, especially in Chapter 18. The deÔ¨Ånitions are similar
but a bit simpler. For a map f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB, we can always deÔ¨Åne the Ô¨Årst two of the
functors
f! : C /A ‚àí‚ÜíC /B,
f ‚àó: C /B ‚àí‚ÜíC /A,
f‚àó: C /A ‚àí‚ÜíC /B,
and we can deÔ¨Åne the third whenever C /B is cartesian closed. The Ô¨Årst is given by
composing the projection of an object in C /A with the map f to obtain a projection
to B, and the other two are deÔ¨Åned by the same pullbacks as the corresponding
functors in the sectioned case. We again get two pairs of adjoint functors, (f!, f ‚àó)
and (f ‚àó, f‚àó). The results of the following section go through just as well in this
simpler setting.
2.2. Compatibility relations
The term ‚Äúcompatibility relation‚Äù has been used in algebraic geometry in the
context of Grothendieck‚Äôs six functor formalism in sheaf theory that relates base
change functors to tensor product and internal hom functors. We describe how the
analogous, but simpler, formalism appears in our categories of ex-objects.
We recall some language. We are especially interested in the behavior of base
change functors with respect to closed symmetric monoidal structures that, in our
topological context, are given by smash products and function objects. Relevant
categorical observations are given in [62].
We say that a functor T : B ‚àí‚ÜíA
between closed symmetric monoidal categories is closed symmetric monoidal if
(2.2.1)
TSB ‚àº= SA ,
T(X ‚àßB Y ) ‚àº= TX ‚àßA TY,
and
TFB(X, Y ) ‚àº= FA (TX, TY ),
where SB, ‚àßB and FB denote the unit object, product, and internal hom of B, and
similarly for A . These isomorphisms must satisfy appropriate coherence conditions
relating to the unit, associativity and commutativity isomorphisms in A and B.
In the language of [62], the following result states that any map f of base spaces
gives rise to a ‚ÄúWirthm¬®uller context‚Äù, which means that the functor f ‚àóis closed
symmetric monoidal and has both a left adjoint and a right adjoint.
Proposition 2.2.2. If f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB is a map of base G-spaces, then the functor
f ‚àó: GKB ‚àí‚ÜíGKA is closed symmetric monoidal. Therefore, by deÔ¨Ånition and
implication, f ‚àóS0
B ‚àº= S0
A and there are natural isomorphisms
f ‚àó(Y ‚àßB Z) ‚àº= f ‚àóY ‚àßA f ‚àóZ,
(2.2.3)
FB(Y, f‚àóX) ‚àº= f‚àóFA(f ‚àóY, X),
(2.2.4)
f ‚àóFB(Y, Z) ‚àº= FA(f ‚àóY, f ‚àóZ),
(2.2.5)
f!(f ‚àóY ‚àßA X) ‚àº= Y ‚àßB f!X,
(2.2.6)
FB(f!X, Y ) ‚àº= f‚àóFA(X, f ‚àóY ),
(2.2.7)
where X is an ex-G-space over A and Y and Z are ex-G-spaces over B.
Proof. The isomorphism f ‚àóS0
B ‚àº= S0
A is evident since f ‚àó(B √ó K) ‚àº= A √ó K for
based G-spaces K. The isomorphism (2.2.3) is obtained by passage to quotients

2.2. COMPATIBILITY RELATIONS
33
from the evident homeomorphism
(Y √óB A) √óA (Z √óB A) ‚àº= (Y √óB Z) √óB A
As explained in [62, ¬ß¬ß2, 3], the isomorphism (2.2.3) is equivalent to the isomorphism
(2.2.4), and it determines natural maps from left to right in (2.2.5), (2.2.6), and
(2.2.7) such that all three are isomorphisms if any one is.
By a comparison of
deÔ¨Ånitions, we see that the categorically deÔ¨Åned map in (2.2.5), which is denoted
Œ± in [62, 3.3], coincides in the present situation with the map, also denoted Œ±, on
[22, p. 167]. As explained on [22, p. 178], in the point-set topological framework
that we have adopted, that map Œ± is a homeomorphism.
‚ñ°
Remark 2.2.8. Only the very last statement refers to topology. The categor-
ically deÔ¨Åned map Œ± should quite generally be an isomorphism in analogous con-
texts, but we have not pursued this question in detail. An alternative self-contained
proof of the previous proposition is given in Remark 2.5.8 below by using Proposi-
tion 2.2.11 to prove (2.2.6) instead of (2.2.5). In that argument, the only non-formal
ingredient is the fact that the functor D √óB (‚àí) commutes with pushouts.
The categorical situation here entails a vast variety of coherence diagrams re-
lating the given data. We shall much later need two examples, and it is convenient
to insert them here. The following observation will play a minor role in ¬ß20.3, but
is of independent conceptual interest.
Remark 2.2.9. Applying (2.2.3) and (2.2.6), we obtain isomorphisms
Y ‚àßB f!f ‚àóZ ‚àº= f!(f ‚àóY ‚àßA f ‚àóZ) ‚àº= f!f ‚àó(Y ‚àßB Z).
The counit f!f ‚àó‚àí‚Üíid of the adjunction (f!, f ‚àó) induces maps from the left and
right terms to Y ‚àßB Z, and the evident diagram commutes, so that these induced
maps agree under the isomorphism.
Similarly, applying (2.2.4) and (2.2.7), we
obtain isomorphisms
FB(Y, f‚àóf ‚àóZ) ‚àº= f‚àóFA(f ‚àóY, f ‚àóZ) ‚àº= FB(f!f ‚àóY, Z).
The unit id ‚àí‚Üíf‚àóf ‚àóand counit f!f ‚àó‚àí‚Üíid of our adjunctions induce maps from
FB(Y, Z) to the left and right terms, and the evident diagram commutes, so that
these induced maps agree under the isomorphism.
The following more technical observation about the categorically deÔ¨Åned iso-
morphism Œ± in (2.2.5) will play a key role in the proof of the Ô¨Åberwise duality
theorem of ¬ß15.1.
Remark 2.2.10. Let f ‚àó: B ‚àí‚ÜíA be any symmetric monoidal functor. We
are thinking of a base change functor, but the observation is general. The map

is deÔ¨Åned to be the adjoint of
f ‚àóFB(X, Y ) ‚àßA f ‚àóX ‚àº= f ‚àó(FB(X, Y ) ‚àßB X)
f ‚àóev / f ‚àóY.

2.3. CHANGE OF GROUP AND RESTRICTION TO FIBERS
35
2.3. Change of group and restriction to Ô¨Åbers
This section begins the study of equivariant phenomena that have no non-
equivariant counterparts. In particular, using a conceptual reinterpretation of the
adjoints of the Ô¨Åber functors (‚àí)b, we relate restriction to subgroups to restriction to
Ô¨Åbers. Recall that subgroups of G are understood to be closed and Ô¨Åx an inclusion
Œπ: H ‚äÇG throughout this section. Parametrized theory gives a convenient way of
studying restriction along Œπ without changing the ambient group from G to H.
Proposition 2.3.1. The category GKG/H of ex-G-spaces over G/H is equiv-
alent to the category HK‚àóof based H-spaces.
Proof. The equivalence sends an ex-G-space (Y, p, s) over G/H to the H-
space p‚àí1(eH) with basepoint the H-Ô¨Åxed point s(eH). Its inverse sends a based
H-space X to the induced G-space G √óH X, with the evident structure maps.
‚ñ°
More formally, recall that there are ‚Äúinduction‚Äù and ‚Äúcoinduction‚Äù functors Œπ!
and Œπ‚àófrom H-spaces to G-spaces that are left and right adjoint to the forgetful
functor Œπ‚àóthat sends a G-space Y to Y regarded as an H-space. Explicitly, for an
H-space X,
(2.3.2)
Œπ!X = G √óH X
and
Œπ‚àóX = MapH(G, X).
The latter is the space of maps of (left) H-spaces, with (left) action of G induced
by the right action of G on itself. Similarly, when X is a based H-space, we have
the based analogues
(2.3.3)
Œπ!X = G+ ‚àßH X
and
Œπ‚àóX = FH(G+, X).
With this notation, some familiar natural isomorphisms take the forms
Œπ!(Œπ‚àóY √ó X) ‚àº= Y √ó Œπ!X
and
Œπ‚àóMap(Œπ‚àóY, X) ‚àº= Map(Y, Œπ‚àóX)
(2.3.4)
and, in the based case,
Œπ!(Œπ‚àóY ‚àßX) ‚àº= Y ‚àßŒπ!X
and
Œπ‚àóF(Œπ‚àóY, X) ‚àº= F(Y, Œπ‚àóX).
(2.3.5)
By the uniqueness of adjoints, or inspection of deÔ¨Ånitions, we see that these familiar
change of groups functors are change of base functors along r: G/H ‚àí‚Üí‚àó.
Corollary 2.3.6. The change of group and change of base functors associated
to Œπ and r agree under the equivalence of categories between HK‚àóand GKG/H:
Œπ‚àó‚àº= r‚àó,
Œπ! ‚àº= r!,
and
Œπ‚àó‚àº= r‚àó.
We can generalize this equivalence of categories, using the following deÔ¨Ånitions.
We have a forgetful functor Œπ‚àó: GKB ‚àí‚ÜíHKŒπ‚àóB. It doesn‚Äôt have an obvious left
or right adjoint, but we have obvious analogues of induction and coinduction that
involve changes of base spaces. The Ô¨Årst will lead to a description of Œπ‚àóas a base
change functor and thus as a functor with a left and right adjoint.
Definition 2.3.7. Let A be an H-space and X be an H-space over A. DeÔ¨Åne
Œπ! : HKA ‚àí‚ÜíGKŒπ!A by letting Œπ!X be the G-space G √óH X over Œπ!A = G √óH A.
DeÔ¨Åne Œπ‚àó: HKA ‚àí‚ÜíGKŒπ‚àóA by letting Œπ‚àóX be the G-space MapH(G, X) over
Œπ‚àóA = MapH(G, A).

be the counit and unit of the (Œπ!, Œπ‚àó) adjunction. The following result says that
ex-H-spaces over an H-space A are equivalent to ex-G-spaces over the G-space Œπ!A.

2.4. Normal subgroups and quotient groups
Observe that any homomorphism Œ∏: G ‚àí‚ÜíG‚Ä≤ factors as the composite of a
quotient homomorphism Œµ, an isomorphism, and an inclusion Œπ. We studied change
of groups along inclusions in the previous section. Here we consider a quotient
homomorphism œµ: G ‚àí‚ÜíJ of G by a normal subgroup N. We still have a restriction
functor
œµ‚àó: JKA ‚àí‚ÜíGKœµ‚àóA,

(‚àí)/N : GKB ‚àí‚ÜíJKB/N

these last two functors are left and right adjoint to œµ‚àó, but in general change of base
must enter in order to obtain such adjunctions. The following observation follows
directly by inspection of the deÔ¨Ånitions.

We have the following analogue of Proposition 2.3.11, but to state its last part
we Ô¨Årst recall the following standard deÔ¨Ånition [79, 4.2.2] and Ô¨Åx a convention to

Definition 2.4.2. A G-space P is principal if the action of G is free and the
translation map œÑ : Orb(P) ‚àí‚ÜíG is continuous, where Orb(P) = {(x, gx)} ‚äÇP √óP
and œÑ(x, gx) = g. A principal G-bundle is a principal G-space P and a projection
p: P ‚àí‚ÜíB such that B is homeomorphic under P to P/G. Henceforward, we
adopt the convention that all given free actions are understood to be principal. By
Remark 3.1.8 below, this holds automatically if G is compact or, more generally,
the action of G is proper.

Remark 2.4.5. This leads to a useful alternative description of the functor
Œπ! : HKA ‚àí‚ÜíGKŒπ!A, where A is an H-space and Œπ!A = G √óH A, as a composite of

Consider ex-H-spaces X over A as (G √ó H)-spaces with G acting trivially and let
œµ: G√óH ‚àí‚ÜíH be the projection. By inspection of deÔ¨Ånitions, Œπ!X = (œÄ‚àóŒµ‚àóX)/H.
Since G √ó A is an H-free (G √ó H)-space, we conclude from the previous result that
Œπ!X ‚àº= (p‚àóœÄ‚àóŒµ‚àóX)H, where p: G √ó A ‚àí‚ÜíG √óH A = Œπ!A is the quotient map.
2.5. The closed symmetric monoidal category of retracts
Let B be a topologically bicomplete full subcategory of a topologically bicom-
plete category C .
We are thinking of U ‚äÇK or GU ‚äÇGK .
We have the
category of retracts CB. The objects of CB are the retractions B
s
‚àí‚ÜíX
p
‚àí‚ÜíB
with B ‚ààB and X ‚ààC , abbreviated (X, p, s) or just X. The morphisms of CB are
the evident commutative diagrams. When B = C , this is just a diagram category
for the evident two object domain category.
The importance of the category CB is apparent from its role in DeÔ¨Ånition 2.1.1:
focus on this category is natural when we consider base change functors. In our
examples, B and C are enriched and topologically bicomplete over the appropriate
category of spaces, U for B and K for C . For a space K ‚ààK , the tensors ‚àí√ó K
and cotensors Map(K, ‚àí) applied to retractions give retractions, and we have the
adjunction homeomorphisms
(2.5.1)
CB(X √ó K, Y ) ‚àº= K (K, CB(X, Y )) ‚àº= CB(X, Map(K, Y )).
Now restrict attention to GKGU .
Lemma 2.5.2. The category GKGU is topologically bicomplete.
Proof. Since we have tensors and cotensors, by (2.5.1), it suÔ¨Éces to show that
GKGU is bicomplete. As a diagram category, GKGK is certainly bicomplete. Since
limits in GU are constructed in GK , it follows directly that GKGU is complete.
Colimits in GU are obtained by applying the weak HausdorÔ¨Écation functor w to
colimits in GK . Using Proposition 1.5.4, it follows by direct veriÔ¨Åcation of the
universal property that colimits in GK on total spaces paired with colimits in GU
on base spaces specify colimits in GKGU .
‚ñ°
The category GKGU is closed symmetric monoidal under an external smash
product functor, denoted X ‚äºY , and an external function ex-space functor, denoted
¬ØF(Y, Z). If X, Y , and Z are ex-spaces over A, B, and A √ó B, respectively, then
X ‚äºY is an ex-space over A √ó B and ¬ØF(Y, Z) is an ex-space over A. We have
(2.5.3)
GKA√óB(X ‚äºY, Z) ‚àº= GKA(X, ¬ØF(Y, Z)),
which gives the required adjunction in GKGU . It specializes to parts of (1.4.2) when
A or B is a point. The ex-space X ‚äºY is the evident Ô¨Åberwise smash product, with
(X ‚äºY )(a,b) = Xa ‚àßYb. The Ô¨Åber ¬ØF(Y, Z)a is FB(Y, Za), where Za is the ex-space
over B whose Ô¨Åber Za,b over b is the inverse image of (a, b) under the projection
Z ‚àí‚ÜíA√óB. Rather than describe the topology of the ex-space ¬ØF(Y, Z) directly, we
will shortly give alternative descriptions of X ‚äºY and ¬ØF(Y, Z) in terms of internal
smash products and internal function ex-spaces. The commutativity isomorphism
of the external smash product is evident, but it requires comment because it will
play an important and subtle role later on.

The evident interchange map Œ≥ is the commutativity isomorphism of the exter-

It is illuminating conceptually to go further and consider group actions from
an external point of view. For groups H and G, an H-space A, and a G-space B,
we have an evident external smash product
(2.5.11)
‚äº: HKA √ó GKB ‚Üí(H √ó G)KA√óB.

that this deÔ¨Ånition leads to another (‚äº, ¬ØF) adjunction.
When H = G, the diagonal ‚àÜ: G ‚àí‚ÜíG √ó G is a closed inclusion since G
is compactly generated. We can pull back along ‚àÜ, and then our earlier external
smash product X ‚äºY over the G-space ‚àÜ‚àó(A √ó B) is given in terms of (2.5.11) as
the pullback ‚àÜ‚àó(X ‚äºY ). Note that, by Proposition 2.3.10, ‚àÜ‚àóhere can be viewed
as a base change functor.

CHAPTER 3
Proper actions, equivariant bundles and Ô¨Åbrations
Introduction
Proper actions by locally compact groups are well-behaved actions whose iso-
tropy groups are compact. All actions by compact Lie groups are proper, and an
action of a discrete group is proper if and only if it is properly discontinuous. We
discuss proper actions of locally compact groups in ¬ß3.1.
In ¬ß3.2, we describe a class of equivariant bundles that will play an important
role in Parts IV and V. Starting from a principal bundle P ‚àí‚ÜíB = P/Œ† (with
appropriate equivariance) and an associated bundle E = P √óŒ† F ‚àí‚ÜíB, we show
how to insert ex-spaces over F Ô¨Åberwise into the functor P √óŒ† (‚àí) to obtain ex-
spaces over E in ¬ß3.3, and we show that this ‚Äúbundle construction‚Äù gives a closed
symmetric monoidal functor that commutes with base change functors. This sets
the stage for the deÔ¨Ånition and use of a spectrum level analogue, starting in ¬ß15.4.
In a diÔ¨Äerent direction, we generalize Waner‚Äôs equivariant versions [168] of
Milnor‚Äôs results about spaces of the homotopy types of CW complexes in ¬ß3.4, and
we generalize classical theorems of Dold and StasheÔ¨Äabout Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations in
¬ß3.5. We also recall an important but little known result of Steinberger and West
that relates Serre and Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations. We deÔ¨Åne equivariant quasiÔ¨Åbrations in
¬ß3.6.
3.1. Proper actions of locally compact groups
For appropriate generality and technical convenience, we let G be a locally
compact topological group whose underlying topological space is compactly gen-
erated. Local compactness means that the identity element, hence any point, has
a compact neighborhood. We see from Proposition 1.6.1 that G is HausdorÔ¨Äand,
since all compact subsets are closed, it follows that each neighborhood of any point
contains a compact neighborhood.
Remark 3.1.1. We comment on the assumptions we make for G. If G is any
topological group whose underlying space is in K , then an action of G on X in
K may not come from an action in T op. The point is that the product G √ó X in
K is deÔ¨Åned by applying the k-iÔ¨Åcation functor to the product G √óc X in T op,
and not every action G √ó X ‚àí‚ÜíX need be continuous when viewed as a function
G √óc X ‚àí‚ÜíX. However, when G is locally compact, G √óc X is already in K by
Proposition 1.6.1, and k-iÔ¨Åcation is not needed. There is then no ambiguity about
what we mean by a G-space, and we need not worry about reÔ¨Åning the topology
on products with G.
Another reason for restricting to locally compact groups is that many useful
properties of proper actions only hold in that case. In the literature, such results
43

44
3. PROPER ACTIONS, EQUIVARIANT BUNDLES AND FIBRATIONS
are usually derived for actions on HausdorÔ¨Äspaces, but we shall see that weak
HausdorÔ¨Ägenerally suÔ¨Éces.
We begin with some standard equivariant terminology.
Definition 3.1.2. Let X be a G-space and let H ‚äÇG.
(i) An H-tube U in X is an open G-invariant subset of X together with a G-map
œÄ: U ‚àí‚ÜíG/H. If x ‚ààU and H = Gx, then U is a tube around x. A tube is
contractible if œÄ is a G-homotopy equivalence.
(ii) An H-slice S in X is an H-invariant subset such that the canonical G-map
G √óH S ‚àí‚ÜíGS ‚äÇX is an embedding onto an open subset. Then GS is
an H-tube with S = œÄ‚àí1(eH). Conversely, if (U, œÄ) is an H-tube in X, then
S = œÄ‚àí1(eH) is an H-slice and U = GS. On isotropy subgroups, we then
have Gy = Hy ‚äÇH for all y ‚ààS, but equality need not hold. If x ‚ààS and
H = Gx, then S is a slice through x.
(iii) We say that X has enough slices if every point x ‚ààX is contained in an
H-slice for some compact subgroup H. This implies that every point x has
compact isotropy group, but in general it does not imply that there must be
a slice through every point x.
(iv) A G-numerable cover of X is a cover {Uj} by tubes such that there exists a
locally Ô¨Ånite partition of unity by G-maps Œªj : X ‚àí‚Üí[0, 1] with support Uj.
The following is the equivariant generalization of [48, 6.7].
Proposition 3.1.3. Any G-CW complex admits a G-numerable cover by con-
tractible tubes.
Proof. The proof given by Dold [48] in the nonequivariant case goes through
with only a minor change in the initial construction, which we sketch. From there,
the technical details are unchanged. Let Xn be the n-th skeletal Ô¨Åltration of a G-
CW complex X. Let ÀôXn denote the subspace obtained by deleting the central orbits
(G/H √ó0 for a cell of orbit type G/H) of all n-cells in Xn and let rn : ÀôXn ‚àí‚ÜíXn‚àí1
denote the obvious retract. Starting from the interior en = G/H √ó (Dn ‚àíSn‚àí1) of
a Ô¨Åxed n-cell, deÔ¨Åne V m
n
inductively for m ‚â•n by setting V n
n = en and V m+1
n
=
r‚àí1
m+1(V m
n ). Then the union V ‚àû
n
= S
m‚â•n V m
n
is a contractible tube, where the
projection to G/H is induced by the projection of en to G/H.
‚ñ°
We now give the deÔ¨Ånition of a proper group action in K . We shall see that
the deÔ¨Ånition could equivalently be made in U . For further details, but in T op,
see for example [24,47]. Recall that a continuous map is proper if it is a closed map
with compact Ô¨Åbers.
Definition 3.1.4. A G-space X in GK is proper (or G-proper) if the map
Œ∏: G √ó X ‚àí‚ÜíX √ó X
speciÔ¨Åed by Œ∏(g, x) = (x, gx) is proper.
We warn the reader that this deÔ¨Ånition is not quite the standard one.
We
are working in the category K , and the product X √ó X on the right hand side
is the k-space obtained by k-ifying the standard product topology on X √óc X. In
T op there are various other notions of a proper group action; see [12] for a careful
discussion.
They all agree for actions of locally compact groups on completely
regular spaces. If X is proper, then the isotropy groups Gx are compact since they

3.1. PROPER ACTIONS OF LOCALLY COMPACT GROUPS
45
are the Ô¨Åbers Œ∏‚àí1(x, x). Moreover, since points are closed subsets of G, the diagonal
‚àÜX = Œ∏({e} √ó X) must be a closed subset of X √ó X and thus X must be weak
HausdorÔ¨Ä. This means that proper G-spaces must be in U . Since G is locally
compact, we have the following useful characterizations.
Proposition 3.1.5. For a G-space X in GK the following are equivalent.
(i) The action of G on X is proper.
(ii) The isotropy groups Gx are compact and for any point (x, y) ‚ààX √ó X and
any neighborhood U of Œ∏‚àí1(x, y) in G√óX, there is a neighborhood V of (x, y)
in X √ó X such that Œ∏‚àí1(V ) ‚äÇU.
(iii) The isotropy groups Gx are compact and for any (x, y) ‚ààX √ó X and any
neighborhood U of {g | gx = y} in G, there is a neighborhood V of (x, y) such
that
{g ‚ààG | ga = b for some (a, b) ‚ààV } ‚äÇU.
(iv) The space X is weak HausdorÔ¨Äand every point (x, y) ‚ààX √ó X has a neigh-
borhood V such that
{g ‚ààG | ga = b for some (a, b) ‚ààV }
has compact closure in G.
Proof. This holds by essentially the same proof as [12, 1.6(b)]. One must
only keep in mind that we are now working in K rather than in T op and adjust
the argument accordingly.
‚ñ°
Corollary 3.1.6. If G is discrete, then a G-space X is proper if and only if
any point (x, y) ‚ààX √ó X has a neighborhood V such that
{g ‚ààG | ga = b for some (a, b) ‚ààV }
is Ô¨Ånite.
Corollary 3.1.7. If G is compact, then any G-space in GU is proper. More
generally, if Œì = G √ó Œ†, where G is compact and Œ† is locally compact, then any
Œ†-free Œì-space in ŒìU is proper.
Remark 3.1.8. Recall DeÔ¨Ånition 2.4.2 and let G act freely on X. Since the
Ô¨Åbers of Œ∏ are points, the action is proper if and only if Œ∏ is a closed map. Since Œ∏
is injective, it is then a homeomorphism onto its image. However, its image is the
domain Orb(X) of the translation map œÑ, and œÑ is the composite œÄ ‚ó¶Œ∏‚àí1, where
œÄ : G √ó X ‚àí‚ÜíG is the projection. Therefore œÑ : Orb(X) ‚àí‚ÜíG is necessarily
continuous, as required by our standing convention on free actions, when G acts
freely and properly on X. This always holds when X is in GU and G is compact.
Remark 3.1.9. There is an alternative description of the set displayed in
Proposition 3.1.5 that may clarify the characterization. DeÔ¨Åne
œÜ: G √ó X √ó X ‚àí‚ÜíX √ó X
by œÜ(g, x, y) = (gx, y). For V ‚äÇX √ó X, let œÜV be the restriction of œÜ to G √ó V
and let œÄ: G √ó V ‚àí‚ÜíG be the projection, which is an open map since G √ó V has
the product topology. Then the displayed set is œÄœÜ‚àí1
V (‚àÜX). If X √ó X = X √óc X,
then the condition in Proposition 3.1.5 is equivalent to the more familiar one that
any two points x and y in X have neighborhoods Vx and Vy such that
{g ‚ààG | gVx ‚à©Vy Ã∏= ‚àÖ}

3. PROPER ACTIONS, EQUIVARIANT BUNDLES AND FIBRATIONS
has compact closure in G.
Proposition 3.1.10. Proper actions satisfy the following closure properties.
(i) The restriction of a proper action to a closed subgroup is proper.
(ii) An invariant subspace of a proper G-space is also proper.
(iii) Products of proper G-spaces are proper.
(iv) If X is a proper HausdorÔ¨ÄG-space in GK and C is a compact HausdorÔ¨Ä
G-space, then the G-space Map(C, X) is proper.
(v) An H-space S is H-proper if and only if G √óH S is G-proper.
Proof. The Ô¨Årst three are standard and elementary; see for example [47,
I.5.10]. The Ô¨Åfth is [12, 2.3]. We prove (iv). We must show that the map
Œ∏: G √ó Map(C, X) ‚àí‚ÜíMap(C, X) √ó Map(C, X)
is proper, which amounts to showing that it is closed and that the isotropy groups
Gf are compact for f ‚ààMap(C, X). For the latter, let {gi} be a net in Gf and
Ô¨Åx c ‚ààC. Note that f(gic) = gif(c). Since C is compact, we can assume by
passing to a subnet that {gic} converges to some ¬Øc ‚ààC. Let V be a neighborhood
of (f(c), f(¬Øc)) such that
B = {g ‚ààG | ga = b for some (a, b) ‚ààV }
has compact closure. Since C is compact, C √óC √óMap(C, X) has the usual product
topology. Since the map
C √ó C √ó Map(C, X) ‚àí‚ÜíX √ó X
that sends (c, d, f) to (f(c), f(d)) is continuous and the net {c, gic, f} converges to
(c, ¬Øc, f), the net {(f(c), f(gic))} = {(f(c), gif(c))} must converge to (f(c), f(¬Øc)). It
follows that a subnet of {gi} lies in B and therefore has a converging sub-subnet.
To show that Œ∏ is closed, let A be a closed subset of G √ó Map(C, X) and let
{(fi, gifi)} be a net in Œ∏(A) that converges to (f, F). We must show that (f, F) is
in Œ∏(A). For c ‚ààC, the net {g‚àí1
i
c} has a subnet that converges to some ¬Øc, by the
compactness of C, so we may as well assume that the original net converges to ¬Øc.
Let V be a neighborhood of (f(¬Øc), F(c)) such that
B‚Ä≤ = {g ‚ààG | ga = b for some (a, b) ‚ààV }
has compact closure. By continuity and the compactness of C, there is a compact
neighborhood K1√óK2 of (¬Øc, c) that (f, F) maps into V . Since {(fi, gifi)} converges
to (f, F), there is an h such that (fi, gifi)(K1 √ó K2) ‚äÇV for i ‚â•h. It follows that
there is a k ‚â•h such that (fi(g‚àí1
i
c), gifi(g‚àí1
i
c)) ‚ààV for all i ‚â•k.
Then the
subnet {gi}i‚â•k is contained in B‚Ä≤ and therefore has a sub-subnet that converges
to some g ‚ààG.
We have now seen that our original net {(gi, fi)} in A has a
subnet {(gij, fij)} that converges to (g, f), and (g, f) ‚ààA since A is closed. By the
continuity of Œ∏, {Œ∏(gi, fi)} must converge to (f, F) = Œ∏(g, f) ‚ààŒ∏(A). In this last
statement, we are using the uniqueness of limits, which we ensure by requiring X
and C to be HausdorÔ¨Ä.
‚ñ°
The following theorem of Palais [136], as generalized by Biller [12], is funda-
mental. Those sources work in T op, but the arguments work just as well in U .
Theorem 3.1.11 (Palais). Let X be a G-space in GU .
(i) If X has enough slices, then it is proper.

3.2. PROPER ACTIONS AND EQUIVARIANT BUNDLES
47
(ii) Conversely, if X is completely regular and proper, then it has enough slices.
(iii) If G is a Lie group and X is completely regular and proper, then there is a
slice through each point of X.
Proof. Part (i) is given by [12, 2.4]. Part (iii) is given by [136, 2.3.3]. Part
(ii) is deduced from part (iii) in [12, 2.5].
‚ñ°
3.2. Proper actions and equivariant bundles
We introduce here the equivariant bundles to which we will apply our basic
foundational results in Part IV. The applications there will focus on compact Lie
groups, but we need greater generality in Part V. As we explain, Theorem 3.1.11 al-
lows us to generalize some basic results about such bundles from actions of compact
Lie groups to proper actions of locally compact groups.
Let Œ† be a normal subgroup of a locally compact group Œì such that Œì/Œ† = G
and let q: Œì ‚àí‚ÜíG be the quotient homomorphism. By a principal (Œ†; Œì)-bundle
we mean the quotient map p: P ‚àí‚ÜíP/Œ† where P is a Œ†-free Œì-space such that Œì
acts properly on P. It follows that the induced G-action on B = P/Œ† is proper. If
F is a Œì-space, then we have the associated G-map E = P √óŒ†F ‚àí‚ÜíP √óŒ†‚àó‚àº= P/Œ†,
which we say is a Œì-bundle with structure group Œ† and Ô¨Åber F.
For compact Lie groups, bundles of this form are studied in [92], which gen-
eralizes the study of the classical case Œì = G √ó Œ† given in [91]. In view of Corol-
lary 3.1.7, the classical case works equally well when G but not necessarily Œ† is
compact. A summary and further references are given in [118, Chapter VII]. We
recall an observation about bundles of this sort.
Lemma 3.2.1. For b ‚ààB, the action of Œì on F induces an action of the isotropy
group Gb on the Ô¨Åber Eb through a homomorphism œÅb : Gb ‚àí‚ÜíŒì such that q ‚ó¶œÅb is
the inclusion Gb ‚àí‚ÜíG and Eb is Gb-homeomorphic to œÅ‚àó
bF.
Proof. Choose z ‚ààP such that œÄ(z) = b. The isotropy group Œìz intersects Œ†
in the trivial group, and q maps Œìz isomorphically onto Gb. Let œÅb be the composite
of q‚àí1 : Gb ‚àí‚ÜíŒìz and the inclusion Œìz ‚àí‚ÜíŒì. Since the subspace {z}√óF of P √óF
is Œìz‚Äìinvariant and maps homeomorphically onto Eb on passage to orbits over Œ†,
the conclusion follows. Note that changing the choice of z changes œÅb by conjugation
by an element of Œ† and changes the identiÔ¨Åcation of Eb with F correspondingly.
‚ñ°
Bundles should be locally trivial. When P is completely regular, local triviality
is a consequence of Theorem 3.1.11(iii), just as in the case when Œì is a compact
Lie group [92, Lemma 3], and this justiÔ¨Åes our bundle-theoretic terminology. Note
that if P is completely regular, then so is B = P/Œ†.
Lemma 3.2.2. A completely regular principal (Œ†; Œì)-bundle P is locally trivial.
That is, for each b ‚ààB, there is a slice Sb through b and a homeomorphism

3.3. The bundle construction
In ¬ß15.4 we will introduce a bundle construction on parametrized spectra that
will play a central role in Parts IV and V. We consider the underlying space level
bundle construction here. We retain the notations of the previous section, so that
P is a proper Œ†-free Œì-space, E = P √óŒ† F for a Œì-space F, and B = P/Œ†.
Applying the functor P √óŒ† (‚àí) to retracts gives the functor
PF : ŒìKF ‚àí‚ÜíGKE.
Thus, for an ex-Œì-space K over F, the ex-G-space P √óŒ† K over P √óŒ† F has section
and projection induced by the section and projection of K.
Observe that if F
is a smooth manifold and SœÑ is the sphere bundle obtained by Ô¨Åberwise one-point
compactiÔ¨Åcation of the tangent bundle of F, then PF SœÑ is the G-bundle of spherical
tangents along the Ô¨Åber associated to p: E ‚àí‚ÜíB.
The bundle construction has good formal properties. For example, we have the
following observation.
Lemma 3.3.1. The functor PF : ŒìKF ‚àí‚ÜíGKE is both a left and a right ad-
joint.
Proof. Let œÄ: P √ó F ‚àí‚ÜíF be the projection. Clearly PF is the composite
of œÄ‚àó: ŒìKF ‚àí‚ÜíŒìKP √óF and (‚àí)/Œ†: ŒìKP √óF ‚àí‚ÜíGKE. Certainly œÄ‚àóis both a
left and a right adjoint and (‚àí)/Œ† is a left adjoint. By Proposition 2.4.4, (‚àí)/Œ†
coincides with the right adjoint (‚àí)Œ† ‚ó¶p‚àó, where p is the quotient map P √ó F ‚àí‚Üí
P √óŒ† F = E.
‚ñ°
For b ‚ààB, we have the Ô¨Åber Gb-space Eb. The following observation, which is
immediate by inspection from Lemma 3.2.1, shows what happens if we apply the
bundle construction and then restrict it to obtain an ex-Gb-space over Eb.
Lemma 3.3.2. Fix b ‚ààB. Let Œπ: Gb ‚àí‚ÜíG and œÅb : Gb ‚àí‚ÜíŒì be the inclusion
and the homomorphism of Lemma 3.2.1. Let b: ‚àó‚àí‚ÜíB and ib : Eb ‚àí‚ÜíE denote

‚ñ°
3.4. Spaces of the homotopy types of G-CW complexes
In this section, we recall and generalize the equivariant version of Milnor‚Äôs re-
sults [128] about spaces of the homotopy types of CW complexes. For compact
Lie groups, Waner formulated and proved such results in [168, ¬ß4]. With a few ob-
servations, his proofs generalize to deal with proper actions by general Lie groups.
We Ô¨Årst note the following immediate consequence of Proposition 3.1.3 and Theo-
rem 3.1.11.
Theorem 3.4.1. For any locally compact group G, a G-CW complex is proper
if and only if it is constructed from cells of the form G/K√óDn, where K is compact.
We also note the following recent ‚Äútriangulation theorem‚Äù of Illman [80, The-
orem II]. It is this result that led us to try to generalize some of our results from
compact Lie groups to general Lie groups, and it is also this result that forces us
to now restrict from general locally compact groups to Lie groups. We recall that
the classical deÔ¨Ånition of a Lie group [30, p. 129] includes all discrete groups (even
though they need not be second countable).
Theorem 3.4.2 (Illman). If G is a Lie group that acts smoothly and properly
on a smooth manifold M, then M has a G-CW structure.
Many of our applications of this result are based on the following observation.
Lemma 3.4.3. If H and K are closed subgroups of a topological group G and
K is compact, then the diagonal action of G on G/H √ó G/K is proper.
Proof. The proof given in [47, I.5.16] that G acts properly on G/K generalizes
directly. Set X = G/H √ó G. Let G act diagonally from the left and let K act on
the second factor from the right. Note that these actions commute. It suÔ¨Éces to
show that Œ∏: G√óX ‚àí‚ÜíX √óX is proper. Indeed, consider the commutative square
G √ó X

Œ∏
/ X √ó X

G √ó X/K
¬ØŒ∏
/ X/K √ó X/K.

52
3. PROPER ACTIONS, EQUIVARIANT BUNDLES AND FIBRATIONS
The right vertical map is proper and the left vertical map is surjective. Therefore,
by [47, VI.2.13], the bottom horizontal map is proper if the top horizontal map is
proper. Since X is a free G-space, Œ∏ is proper if and only if the image Im(Œ∏) is a
closed subspace of X √ó X and the map œÜ: Im(Œ∏) ‚àí‚ÜíG speciÔ¨Åed by œÜ(x, gx) = g
is continuous. The diagonal subspace of G/H √ó G/H is closed, and its preimage
under the map Œ∂ : X √ó X ‚àí‚ÜíG/H √ó G/H speciÔ¨Åed by
Œ∂((xH, y), (¬ØxH, ¬Øy)) = (¬Øyy‚àí1xH, ¬ØxH)
is precisely Im(Œ∏), which is therefore closed. The function œÜ is the restriction to
Im(Œ∏) of the continuous map Œ¶: X √ó X ‚àí‚ÜíG speciÔ¨Åed by
Œ¶((xH, y), (¬ØxH, ¬Øy)) = ¬Øyy‚àí1
and is therefore continuous.
‚ñ°
We shall also make essential use of the following corollary of Theorem 3.4.2.
Corollary 3.4.4. If X is a proper G-CW complex, then, viewed as an H-space
for any closed subgroup H of G, X has the structure of an H-cell complex.
Proof. Each cell G/K √ó Dn has K compact.
Since G acts smoothly and
properly on the smooth manifold G/K, the closed subgroup H also acts smoothly
and properly. We use the resulting H-CW structure on all of the cells to obtain
an H-cell structure. It is homotopy equivalent to an H-CW complex obtained by
‚Äúsliding down‚Äù cells that are attached to higher dimensional ones, but we shall not
need to use that.
‚ñ°
Theorem 3.4.5 (Milnor, Waner). Let G be a Lie group and (X; Xi) be an n-ad
of closed sub-G-spaces of a proper G-space X. If (X; Xi) has the homotopy type of
a G-CW n-ad and (C; Ci) is an n-ad of compact G-spaces, then (X; Xi)(C;Ci) has
the homotopy type of a G-CW n-ad.
Proof. We only remark how the proof of Waner for the case of actions by
a compact Lie group generalizes to the case of proper actions by a Lie group.
DeÔ¨Åne a G-simplicial complex to be a G-CW complex such that X/G with the
induced cell structure is a simplicial complex.
In [168, ¬ß5], Waner proves that
any G-CW complex is G-homotopy equivalent to a colimit of Ô¨Ånite dimensional
G-simplicial complexes and cellular inclusions and that a G-space dominated by
a G-CW complex is G-homotopy equivalent to a G-CW complex. The arguments
apply verbatim to any topological group G.
The rest of the argument requires two key lemmas. In [168, 4.2], Waner deÔ¨Ånes
the notion of a G-equilocally convex, or G-ELC, G-space. The Ô¨Årst lemma says
that every Ô¨Ånite dimensional G-simplicial complex is G-ELC. The essential starting
point is that orbits are G-ELC, the proof of which uses the Lie group structure just
as in [168, p.358] in the compact case. From there, Waner‚Äôs proof [168, ¬ß6] goes
through unchanged. The second says that any completely regular, G-paracompact,
G-ELC, proper G-space is dominated by a G-CW complex. When G is compact
Lie, this is proven in [168, ¬ß7].
However, the hypothesis on G is only used to
guarantee the existence of enough slices, hence the proof holds without change for
proper actions of Lie groups, indeed of locally compact groups.
The rest of the proof goes as in [128, Theorem 3]. One only needs to make two
small additional observations. First, if a G-simplicial complex K has the homotopy
type of a proper G-space X, then it is proper. This holds since if f : K ‚àí‚ÜíX is a

3.5. SOME CLASSICAL THEOREMS ABOUT FIBRATIONS
53
homotopy equivalence, then Gk ‚äÇGf(k) is compact. Second, for an n-ad (K; Ki)
of G-simplicial complexes and a compact n-ad (C; Ci), (X; Xi)(C;Ci) is proper since
it is a subspace of the proper G-space XC; see (i) and (iv) of Proposition 3.1.10.
Since it is also completely regular, G-paracompact, and G-ELC, it is dominated by
a G-CW complex, and the result follows from the steps above.
‚ñ°
3.5. Some classical theorems about Ô¨Åbrations
A basic principle of parametrized homotopy theory is that homotopical infor-
mation is given on Ô¨Åbers. We recall two relevant classical theorems about Hurewicz
Ô¨Åbrations and a comparison theorem relating Serre and Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations. We
begin with Dold‚Äôs theorem [48, 6.3]. The nonequivariant proof in [111, 2.6] is gen-
eralized to the equivariant case in Waner [169, 1.11]. Waner assumes throughout
[169] that G is a compact Lie group, but that assumption is not used in the cited
proof.
Theorem 3.5.1 (Dold). Let G be any topological group and let B be a G-space
that has a G-numerable cover by contractible tubes. Let X ‚àí‚ÜíB and Y ‚àí‚ÜíB be
Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations. Then a map X ‚àí‚ÜíY over B is a Ô¨Åberwise G-homotopy equiv-
alence if and only if each Ô¨Åber restriction Xb ‚àí‚ÜíYb is a Gb-homotopy equivalence.
We next recall and generalize a classical result that relates the homotopy types
of Ô¨Åbers to the homotopy types of total spaces.
Nonequivariantly, it is due to
StasheÔ¨Ä[155] and, with a much simpler proof, Sch¬®on [143]. The generalization to
the equivariant case, for compact Lie groups, is given by Waner [169, 6.1]. With
Theorems 3.5.1, 3.4.5 and 3.4.2 in place, Sch¬®on‚Äôs argument generalizes directly to
give the following version. Since the result plays an important role in our work and
the argument is so pretty, we can‚Äôt resist repeating it in full.
Theorem 3.5.2 (StasheÔ¨Ä, Sch¬®on). Let G be a Lie group and B be a proper
G-space that has the homotopy type of a G-CW complex. Let p: X ‚àí‚ÜíB be a
Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration. Then X has the homotopy type of a G-CW complex if and only
if each Ô¨Åber Xb has the homotopy type of a Gb-CW complex.
Proof. First assume that X has the homotopy type of a G-CW complex. For
b ‚ààB, let Œπ: Gb ‚àí‚ÜíG be the inclusion and consider the Gb-map Œπ‚àóp: Œπ‚àóX ‚àí‚ÜíŒπ‚àóB
of Gb-spaces. It is still a Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration, as we see by using the left adjoint
G √óGb (‚àí) of Œπ‚àó. By Corollary 3.4.4, Œπ‚àóX and Œπ‚àóB have the homotopy types of
Gb-CW complexes.
Factor Œπ‚àóp through the inclusion into its mapping cylinder
i: Œπ‚àóX ‚àí‚ÜíMŒπ‚àóp. Since Gb is compact, it follows from Theorem 3.4.5 that the
homotopy Ô¨Åber Fbi = (MŒπ‚àóp; {b}, Œπ‚àóX)(I;0,1) has the homotopy type of a Gb-CW
complex. Since Fbi is homotopy equivalent to FbŒπ‚àóp, by the gluing lemma, and
FbŒπ‚àóp is homotopy equivalent to the Ô¨Åber Xb, this proves the forward implication.
For the converse, assume that each Ô¨Åber Xb has the homotopy type of a Gb-
CW complex. Let Œ≥ : ŒìX ‚àí‚ÜíX be a G-CW approximation of X. The mapping
path Ô¨Åbration of Œ≥ gives us a factorization of Œ≥ as the composite of a G-homotopy
equivalence ŒΩ : ŒìX ‚àí‚ÜíNŒ≥ and a Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration q: NŒ≥ ‚àí‚ÜíX. We may view

54
3. PROPER ACTIONS, EQUIVARIANT BUNDLES AND FIBRATIONS
q as a map of Ô¨Åbrations over B.
NŒ≥
q
/
p‚ó¶q

p
~~~~~~~~
B
The Ô¨Åbers of p ‚ó¶q have the homotopy types of Gb-CW complexes by the Ô¨Årst part
of the proof, since ŒìX is a G-CW complex, and the Ô¨Åbers of p have the homotopy
types of Gb-CW complexes by hypothesis. Comparison of the long exact sequences
associated to p ‚ó¶q and p gives that q restricts to a Gb-homotopy equivalence on
each Ô¨Åber. Noting that we can pull back a numerable cover by contractible tubes
along a homotopy equivalence B ‚àí‚ÜíB‚Ä≤, where B‚Ä≤ is a G-CW complex, it follows
from Theorem 3.5.1 that q is a homotopy equivalence.
‚ñ°
Although it no longer plays a role in our theory, the following little known
result played a central role in our thinking. It shows that the dichotomy between
Serre and Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations diminishes greatly over CW base spaces. It is due to
Steinberger and West [156], with a correction by Cauty [29].
Theorem 3.5.3 (Steinberger and West; Cauty). A Serre Ô¨Åbration whose base
and total spaces are CW complexes is a Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration.
We believe that this remains true equivariantly for compact Lie groups, and it
certainly remains true for Ô¨Ånite groups. Before we understood the limitations of
the q-model structure, we planned to use this result to relate our model theoretic
homotopy category of ex-spaces over a CW complex B to a classical homotopy
category deÔ¨Åned in terms of Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations and thereby overcome the problems
illustrated in Counterexample 0.0.1. Such a comparison is still central to our theory,
and it is this result that convinced us that such a comparison must hold.
3.6. QuasiÔ¨Åbrations
For later reference, we recall the deÔ¨Ånition of quasiÔ¨Åbrations. Here G can be
any topological group.
Definition 3.6.1. A map p: E ‚àí‚ÜíY in K is a quasiÔ¨Åbration if the map of
pairs p: (E, Ey) ‚àí‚Üí(Y, y) is a weak equivalence for all y in Y . A map p: E ‚àí‚ÜíY
in K /B or KB is a quasiÔ¨Åbration if it is a quasiÔ¨Åbration on total spaces. A G-map
p: E ‚àí‚ÜíY is a quasiÔ¨Åbration if each of its Ô¨Åxed point maps pH : EH ‚àí‚ÜíY H is a
nonequivariant quasiÔ¨Åbration.
The condition that p: (E, Ey) ‚àí‚Üí(Y, y) is a weak equivalence means that for
all e ‚ààEy the following two conditions hold.
(i) p‚àó: œÄn(E, Ey, e) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄn(Y, y) is an isomorphism for all n ‚â•1.
(ii) For any x ‚ààE, p(x) is in the path component of y precisely when the path
component of x in E intersects Ey. In other words, the sequence
œÄ0(Ey, e) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄ0(E, e) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄ0(Y, y)
of pointed sets is exact.

3.6. QUASIFIBRATIONS
55
Warning 3.6.2. In contrast to the usual treatments in the literature, we do not
require p to be surjective and therefore œÄ0(E, e) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄ0(Y, y) need not be surjective.
Hurewicz and, more generally, Serre Ô¨Åbrations are examples of quasiÔ¨Åbrations, and
they are not always surjective, as the trivial example {0} ‚àí‚Üí{0, 1} illustrates.
Model categorically, one point is that the initial map ‚àÖ‚àí‚ÜíY is always a Serre
Ô¨Åbration since the empty lifting problem always has a solution.
The deÔ¨Ånition of a quasiÔ¨Åbration is arranged so that the long exact sequence
of homotopy groups associated to the triple (E, Ey, e) is isomorphic to a long exact
sequence
¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ ‚àí‚ÜíœÄn+1(Y, y) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄn(Ey, e) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄn(E, e) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄn(Y, y) ‚àí‚Üí¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ ‚àí‚ÜíœÄ0(Y, y).
We say that a G-space over B is quasiÔ¨Åbrant if its projection is a quasiÔ¨Åbration,
and we have the following useful observation.
Lemma 3.6.3. Let in : En ‚àí‚ÜíEn+1 be a sequence of inclusions of quasiÔ¨Åbrant
G-spaces over B. Then colim En is a quasiÔ¨Åbrant G-space over B.
Proof. The essential point is that we are dealing with a Ô¨Åxed base space and,
for b ‚ààB, the Ô¨Åber over b of colim En is homeomorphic to the colimit of the Ô¨Åbers
over b of the En. Since any basepoint of a Ô¨Åber lies in one of the terms and since
colimits of long exact sequences are exact, the conclusion follows directly from the
deÔ¨Ånition of a quasiÔ¨Åbration.
‚ñ°


Part II
Model categories and parametrized
spaces


Introduction
In Part III, we shall develop foundations for parametrized equivariant stable
homotopy theory. In making that theory rigorous, it became apparent to us that
substantial foundational work was already needed on the level of ex-spaces. That
work is of considerable interest for its own sake, and it involves general points about
the use of model categories that should be of independent interest. Therefore, rather
than rush through the space level theory as just a precursor of the spectrum level
theory, we have separated it out in this more leisurely and discursive exposition.
In Chapter 4, which is entirely independent of our parametrized theory, we give
general model theoretic background, philosophy, and results. In contrast to the
simplicial world, we often have both a classical h-type and a derived q-type model
structure in topologically enriched categories, with respective weak equivalences the
homotopy equivalences and the weak homotopy equivalences. We describe what is
involved in verifying the model axioms for these two types of model structures.
In Chapter 5, we describe how the parametrized world Ô¨Åts into this general
framework. There are several diÔ¨Äerent h-type model structures on our categories
of parametrized G-spaces, with diÔ¨Äerent homotopy equivalences based on diÔ¨Äerent
choices of cylinders. These mesh in unexpected ways. Understanding of this partic-
ular case leads us to a conceptual axiomatic description of how the classical h-type
homotopy theory and the q-type model structure must be related in order to be
able to do homotopy theory satisfactorily in a topologically enriched category.
In Chapter 6, we work nonequivariantly and develop our preferred ‚Äúq-type‚Äù
model category structure, the ‚Äúqf-model structure‚Äù, on the categories K /B and
KB. This chapter is taken directly from the second author‚Äôs thesis [152].
In Chapter 7, we give the equivariant generalization of the qf-model struc-
ture and begin the study of the resulting homotopy categories by discussing those
adjunctions that are given by Quillen pairs. There is another new twist here in
that we need to use many Quillen equivalent qf-type model structures. In fact,
this is already needed nonequivariantly in the study of base change along bundles
f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB.
In Chapter 8, we discuss ex-Ô¨Åbrations and an ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation func-
tor that better serves our purposes than model theoretic Ô¨Åbrant approximation in
studying those adjunctions that are not given by Quillen pairs. In Chapter 9, we
describe our parametrized homotopy categories in terms of classical homotopy cat-
egories of ex-Ô¨Åbrations and use this description to resolve the issues concerning base
change functors and smash products that are discussed in the Prologue.
59


CHAPTER 4
Topologically bicomplete model categories
Introduction
In ¬ß4.1, we describe a general philosophy about the role of diÔ¨Äerent model
structures on a given category C . It is natural and important in many contexts,
and it helps to clarify our thinking about topological categories of parametrized
objects. In particular, we advertise a remarkable unpublished insight of Mike Cole.
It is a pleasure to thank him for keeping us informed of his ideas. We describe how
a classical ‚Äúh-type‚Äù model structure and a suitably related Quillen ‚Äúq-type‚Äù model
structure, can be mixed together to give an ‚Äúm-type‚Äù model structure such that
the m-equivalences are the q-equivalences and the m-Ô¨Åbrations are the h-Ô¨Åbrations.
This is a completely general phenomenon, not restricted to topological contexts.
In ¬ß¬ß4.2 and 4.3, we describe classical structure that is present in any topo-
logically bicomplete category C . Here we follow up a very illuminating paper of
Schw¬®anzl and Vogt [144]. There are two classes of (Hurewicz) h-Ô¨Åbrations and two
classes of h-coÔ¨Åbrations, ordinary and strong. Taking weak equivalences to be ho-
motopy equivalences, the ordinary h-Ô¨Åbrations pair with the strong h-coÔ¨Åbrations
and the strong h-Ô¨Åbrations pair with the ordinary h-coÔ¨Åbrations to give two in-
terrelated model like structures. For each choice, all of the axioms for a proper
topological model category are satisÔ¨Åed except for the factorization axioms, which
hold in a weakened form. To prove that C is a model category, it suÔ¨Éces to prove
one of the factorization axioms since the other will follow. Again, the theory can
easily be adapted to other contexts than our topological one.
We signal an ambiguity of nomenclature. In the model category literature, the
term ‚Äúsimplicial model structure‚Äù is clear and unambiguous, since there is only
one model structure on simplicial sets in common use. In the topological context,
we understand ‚Äútopological model structures‚Äù to refer implicitly to the h-model
structure on spaces for model structures of h-type and to the q-model structure on
spaces for model structures of q-type. The meaning should always be clear from
context.
In ¬ß4.4, we give another insight of Cole, which gains power from the work
of Schw¬®anzl and Vogt. Cole provides a simple hypothesis that implies the miss-
ing factorization axioms for an h-model structure of either type on a topologically
bicomplete category C . When we restrict to compactly generated spaces, the hy-
pothesis applies to give an h-model structure on U . In K , this seems to fail, and
we give a streamlined version of Str√∏m‚Äôs original proof [160], together with his proof
that the strong h-coÔ¨Åbrations in K are just the closed ordinary h-coÔ¨Åbrations. This
works in exactly the same way for the categories GK and GU , where G is any
(compactly generated) topological group.
61

62
4. TOPOLOGICALLY BICOMPLETE MODEL CATEGORIES
In ¬ß4.5, we describe how to construct compactly generated q-type model struc-
tures, giving a slight variant of standard treatments. In particular, GK and GU
have the usual q-model structures in which the q-equivalences are the weak equiva-
lences and the q-Ô¨Åbrations are the Serre Ô¨Åbrations. Again, G can be any topological
group. However we only know that the model structure is G-topological when G is
a compact Lie group.
4.1. Model theoretic philosophy: h, q, and m-model structures
The point of model categories is to systematize ‚Äúhomotopy theory‚Äù. The ho-
motopy theory present in many categories of interest comes in two Ô¨Çavors. There is
a ‚Äúclassical‚Äù homotopy theory based on homotopy equivalences, and there is a more
fundamental ‚Äúderived‚Äù homotopy theory based on a weaker notion of equivalence
than that of homotopy equivalence. This dichotomy pervades the applications, re-
gardless of Ô¨Åeld. It is perhaps well understood that both homotopy theories can be
expressed in terms of model structures on the underlying category, but this aspect
of the classical homotopy theory has usually been ignored in the model theoretical
literature, a tradition that goes back to Quillen‚Äôs original paper [139]. The ‚Äúclassi-
cal‚Äù model structure on spaces was introduced by Str√∏m [160], well after Quillen‚Äôs
paper, and the ‚Äúclassical‚Äù model structure on chain complexes was only introduced
explicitly quite recently, by Cole [34] and Schw¬®anzl and Vogt [144].
Perhaps for this historical reason, it may not be widely understood that these
two model structures can proÔ¨Åtably be used in tandem, with the h-model structure
used as a tool for proving things about the q-model structure. This point of view is
implicit in [61,105,106], and a variant of this point of view will be essential to our
work. In the cited papers, the terms ‚Äúq-Ô¨Åbration‚Äù and ‚Äúq-coÔ¨Åbration‚Äù were used
for the Ô¨Åbrations and coÔ¨Åbrations in the Quillen model structures, and the term
‚Äúh-coÔ¨Åbration‚Äù was used for the classical notion of a Hurewicz coÔ¨Åbration speciÔ¨Åed
in terms of the homotopy extension property (HEP). The corresponding notion
of an ‚Äúh-Ô¨Åbration‚Äù deÔ¨Åned in terms of the covering homotopy property (CHP) is
fortuitously appropriate1. Just as the ‚Äúq‚Äù is meant to suggest Quillen, the ‚Äúh‚Äù
is meant to suggest Hurewicz, as well as homotopy.
It is logical to follow this
idea further (as was not done in [61, 105, 106]) by writing q-Ô¨Åbrant, q-coÔ¨Åbrant,
h-Ô¨Åbrant, and h-coÔ¨Åbrant for clarity. Following this still further, we should also
write ‚Äúh-equivalence‚Äù for homotopy equivalence and ‚Äúq-equivalence‚Äù for (Quillen)
weak equivalence. The relations among these notions are as follows in all of the
relevant categories C :
h-equivalence
=‚áí
q-equivalence
h-coÔ¨Åbration
‚áê=
q-coÔ¨Åbration
h-coÔ¨Åbrant
‚áê=
q-coÔ¨Åbrant
h-Ô¨Åbration
=‚áí
q-Ô¨Åbration
h-Ô¨Åbrant
=‚áí
q-Ô¨Åbrant
Therefore, the identity functor is the right adjoint of a Quillen adjoint pair
from C with its h-model structure to C with its q-model structure. It follows that
we have an adjoint pair relating the classical homotopy category, hC say, to the
1However, the notation conÔ¨Çicts with the notation often used for Dold‚Äôs notion of a weak or
‚Äúhalb‚Äù-Ô¨Åbration. We shall make no use of that notion, despite its real importance in the theory
of Ô¨Åbrations. We do not know whether or not it has a model theoretic role to play.

4.2. STRONG HUREWICZ COFIBRATIONS AND FIBRATIONS
63
derived homotopy category qC = Ho C . This formulation packages standard in-
formation. For example, the Whitehead theorem that a weak equivalence between
cell complexes is a homotopy equivalence, or its analogue that a quasi-isomorphism
between projective complexes is a homotopy equivalence, is a formal consequence
of this adjunction between homotopy categories.
Recently, Cole [36] discovered a profound new way of thinking about the di-
chotomy between the kinds of model structures that we have been discussing. He
proved the following formal model theoretic result.
Theorem 4.1.1 (Cole). Let (Wh, Fibh, Cofh) and (Wq, Fibq, Cofq) be two mo-
del structures on the same category C . Suppose that Wh ‚äÇWq and Fibh ‚äÇFibq.
Then there is a mixed model structure (Wq, Fibh, Cofm) on C . The mixed coÔ¨Å-
brations Cofm are the maps in Cofh that factor as the composite of a map in Wh
and a map in Cofq. An object is m-coÔ¨Åbrant if and only it is h-coÔ¨Åbrant and of the
h-homotopy type of a q-coÔ¨Åbrant object. If the h and q-model structures are left or
right proper, then so is the m-model structure.
By duality, the analogue with the inclusion Fibh ‚äÇFibq replaced by an inclu-
sion Cofh ‚äÇCofq also holds. In the category of spaces with the h and q-model
structures discussed above, the theorem gives a mixed model structure whose m-
coÔ¨Åbrant spaces are the spaces of the homotopy types of CW-complexes.
This
m-model structure combines weak equivalences with Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations, and it
might conceivably turn out to be as important and convenient as the Quillen model
structure. It is startling that this model structure was not discovered earlier.
The pragmatic point is two-fold. On the one-hand, there are many basic results
that apply to h-coÔ¨Åbrations and not just q-coÔ¨Åbrations. Use of h-coÔ¨Åbrations limits
the need for q-coÔ¨Åbrant approximation and often clariÔ¨Åes proofs by focusing atten-
tion on what is relevant. Many examples appear in [61,105,106], where properties
of h-coÔ¨Åbrations serve as scaÔ¨Äolding in the proof that q-model structures are in fact
model structures. We shall formalize and generalize this idea in the next chapter.
On the other hand, there are many vital results that apply only to h-Ô¨Åbrations
(Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations), not to q-Ô¨Åbrations (Serre Ô¨Åbrations). For example, a local
Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration is a Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration, but that is not true for Serre Ô¨Åbrations.
The mixed model structure provides a natural framework in which to make use of
Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations in conjunction with weak equivalences. While we shall make no
formal use of this model structure, it has provided a helpful guide to our thinking.
The philosophy here applies in algebraic as well as topological contexts, but we
shall focus on the latter.
4.2. Strong Hurewicz coÔ¨Åbrations and Ô¨Åbrations
Fix a topologically bicomplete category C throughout this section and the next.
With no further hypotheses on C , we show that it satisÔ¨Åes most of the axioms for
not one but two generally diÔ¨Äerent proper topological h-type model structures. We
alert the reader to the fact that we are here using the term ‚Äúh-model structure‚Äù
in a generic sense.
When we restrict attention to parametrized spaces, we will
use the term in a diÔ¨Äerent speciÔ¨Åc sense derived from the h-model structure on
underlying total spaces. The material of these sections follows and extends material
in Schw¬®anzl and Vogt [144].
We have cylinders X √ó I and cocylinders Map(I, X). When C is based, we
focus on the based cylinders X ‚àßI+ and cocylinders F(I+, X). In either case, these

64
4. TOPOLOGICALLY BICOMPLETE MODEL CATEGORIES
deÔ¨Åne equivalent notions of homotopy, which we shall sometimes call h-homotopy.
We will later use these and cognate notations, but, for the moment, it is convenient
to introduce the common notations Cyl(X) and Cocyl(X) for these objects. There
are obvious classes of maps that one might hope would specify a model structure.
Definition 4.2.1. Let f be a map in C .
(i) f is an h-equivalence if it is a homotopy equivalence in C .
(ii) f is a Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration, abbreviated h-Ô¨Åbration, if it satisÔ¨Åes the CHP in
C , that is, if it has the right lifting property (RLP) with respect to the maps
i0 : X ‚àí‚ÜíCyl(X) for X ‚ààC .
(iii) f is a Hurewicz coÔ¨Åbration, abbreviated h-coÔ¨Åbration, if it satisÔ¨Åes the HEP
in C , that is, if it has the left lifting property (LLP) with respect to the maps
p0 : Cocyl(X) ‚àí‚ÜíX.
These sometimes do give a model structure, but then the h-coÔ¨Åbrations must
be exactly the maps that satisfy the LLP with respect to the h-acyclic h-Ô¨Åbrations,
and dually. In general, that does not hold. We shall characterize the maps in C
that do satisfy the LLP with respect to the h-acyclic h-Ô¨Åbrations and, dually, the
maps that satify the RLP with respect to the h-acyclic h-Ô¨Åbrations. For this, we
need the following relative version of the above notions.
Definition 4.2.2. We deÔ¨Åne strong Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations and coÔ¨Åbrations.
(i) A map p: E ‚àí‚ÜíY is a strong Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration, abbreviated ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbration, if
it satisÔ¨Åes the relative CHP with respect to all h-coÔ¨Åbrations i : A ‚àí‚ÜíX, in
the sense that a lift exists in any diagram

(i) f is an h-Ô¨Åbration if and only if it has the RLP with respect to the map

The ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrations and ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations admit similar characterizations. These were
taken as deÔ¨Ånitions in [144, 2.4].
Lemma 4.2.4. Consider maps i: A ‚àí‚ÜíX and p: E ‚àí‚ÜíY .
(i) The map p: E ‚àí‚ÜíY is an ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbration if and only if it has the RLP with
respect to the canonical map Mi ‚àí‚ÜíCyl(X) for any h-coÔ¨Åbration i : A ‚ÜíX;
this holds if and only if the canonical map Cocyl(E) ‚ÜíNp has the RLP with
respect to all h-coÔ¨Åbrations.
(ii) The map i : A ‚ÜíX is an ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration if and only if it has the LLP with
respect to the canonical map Cocyl(E) ‚àí‚ÜíNp for any h-Ô¨Åbration p : E ‚ÜíY ;
this holds if and only if the canonical map Mi ‚ÜíCyl(X) has the LLP with
respect to all h-Ô¨Åbrations.
Observe that the map i0 : X ‚àí‚ÜíCyl(X) is an ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration and the map p0 :
Cocyl(X) ‚àí‚ÜíX is an ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbration. Since the cylinder objects associated to initial
objects are initial objects, ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrations are in particular h-Ô¨Åbrations. Similarly, ¬Øh-
coÔ¨Åbrations are h-coÔ¨Åbrations. Observe too that every object is both ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrant
and ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrant, hence both h-coÔ¨Åbrant and h-Ô¨Åbrant.
We shall see in ¬ß4.4 that these distinctions are necessary in K but disappear
in U , where the h and ¬Øh notions coincide. Even there, however, the conceptual
distinction sheds light on classical arguments.
The results of this section and the next are quite formal.
Amusingly, the
main non-formal ingredient is just the use in the following proof of the fact that
{0, 1} ‚ÜíI has the LLP with respect to all h-acyclic h-Ô¨Åbrations, which follows
easily from Proposition 4.3.5(ii) below.
Lemma 4.2.5. Let i: A ‚àí‚ÜíX and p: E ‚àí‚ÜíB be maps in C .
(i) If i is an h-acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbration, then i is the inclusion of a strong deformation
retraction r: X ‚àí‚ÜíA.
(ii) If i is the inclusion of a strong deformation retraction r : X ‚ÜíA, then i is a
retract of Mi ‚ÜíCyl(X).
(iii) If p is an h-acyclic h-Ô¨Åbration, then p is a strong deformation retraction.
(iv) If p is a strong deformation retraction, then p is a retract of Cocyl(E) ‚àí‚ÜíNp.
Proof. The last two statements are dual to the Ô¨Årst two. For (i), since the
h-equivalence i is an h-coÔ¨Åbration, application of the HEP shows that i has a
homotopy inverse r : X ‚ÜíA such that ri = idA. Since {0, 1} ‚àí‚ÜíI has the LLP
with respect to h-acyclic h-Ô¨Åbrations, an adjunction argument shows that p(0,1) has
the RLP with respect to h-coÔ¨Åbrations. Thus a lift exists in the diagram on the

4.3. Towards classical model structures in topological categories
We now have two candidates for a classical model structure on C based on
the h-equivalences. We can either take the h-Ô¨Åbrations and the ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations or
the h-coÔ¨Åbrations and the ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrations. The following result shows that all of the
axioms for a proper topological model category are satisÔ¨Åed except that, in general,
only a weakened form of the factorization axioms holds.
Theorem 4.3.1. The following versions of the axioms for a proper topological
model category hold.
(i) The classes of h-coÔ¨Åbrations, ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations, h-Ô¨Åbrations and ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrations are
closed under retracts.
(ii) Let i be an h-coÔ¨Åbration and p be an h-Ô¨Åbration. The pair (i, p) has the lifting
property if i is strong and p is h-acyclic or if p is strong and i is h-acyclic.
(iii) Any map f : X ‚ÜíY factors as

where p is an ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbration and s has a retraction that is an h-acyclic ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbration.
(iv) Let i : A ‚ÜíX be an h-coÔ¨Åbration and p : E ‚ÜíB be an h-Ô¨Åbration, where i
or p is strong. Then the map
C ‚ñ°(i, p) : C (X, E) ‚ÜíC (A, E) √óC (A,B) C (X, B)
induced by i and p is an h-Ô¨Åbration of spaces. It is h-acyclic if i or p is acyclic
and it is an ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbration if both i and p are strong.
(v) The h-equivalences are preserved under pushouts along h-coÔ¨Åbrations and pull-
backs along h-Ô¨Åbrations.
Proof. Part (i) is clear since all classes are deÔ¨Åned in terms of lifting prop-

izations of part (iii) are the standard ones. We consider the Ô¨Årst. The evident

We must prove that g is an h-equivalence. By (ii), we can factor f as a composite
of an h-acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbration and a map that has a section which is an h-acyclic h-
coÔ¨Åbration. Since pushouts preserve h-acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbrations, we may assume that
f has a section s: B ‚àí‚ÜíA that is an h-acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbration. We then obtain the
diagram on the right. Its left back rectangle is a pushout, as is the outer back
rectangle, and therefore the right back rectangle is also a pushout. This implies
that the bottom square is a pushout. The map s‚Ä≤ is an h-acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbration since
s is one, and therefore p is an h-equivalence. The map f ‚Ä≤ is also h-acyclic since it
has the h-acyclic section s‚Ä≤. Just as we could assume that f has a section that is
an h-acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbration, we Ô¨Ånd that we may assume that p has a section t that
is an h-acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbration and is a map under A. Chasing pushout diagrams, we
Ô¨Ånd that g is a retract of f ‚Ä≤ and is therefore an h-equivalence.
‚ñ°
The following result is the pairing theorem of [144, 2.7 and 3.6]. We shall not
repeat the proof, which consists of careful but formal adjunction arguments. Its
general statement is framed so as to apply to cartesian products in the unbased
situation, smash products in the based situation, and tensors in either situation.
Theorem 4.3.2 (Schw¬®anzl and Vogt). Let A , B, and C be topologically bi-
complete categories and let
T : A √ó B ‚àí‚ÜíC ,
U : A op √ó C ‚àí‚ÜíB,
and V : Bop √ó C ‚àí‚ÜíA
be continuous functors that satisfy adjunctions
C (T(A, B), C) ‚àº= B(B, U(A, C)) ‚àº= A (A, V (B, C)).

68
4. TOPOLOGICALLY BICOMPLETE MODEL CATEGORIES
Let i: A ‚àí‚ÜíX be an h-coÔ¨Åbration in A , j : B ‚àí‚ÜíY be an h-coÔ¨Åbration in B,
and p: E ‚àí‚ÜíZ be an h-Ô¨Åbration in C .
(i) Assume that i or j is strong. Then the map
T(A, Y ) ‚à™T (A,B) T(X, B) ‚àí‚ÜíT(X, Y )
induced by i and j is an h-coÔ¨Åbration in C . It is h-acyclic if i or j is h-acyclic
and it is strong if both i and j are strong.
(ii) Assume that j or p is strong. Then the map
V (Y, E) ‚àí‚ÜíV (B, E) √óV (B,Z) V (Y, Z)
induced by j and p is an h-Ô¨Åbration in A . It is h-acyclic if j or p is h-acyclic
and it is strong if both j and p are strong.
As Schw¬®anzl and Vogt observe, these results imply that the canonical map
Mi ‚àí‚ÜíCyl(X) is an h-acyclic ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration for any h-coÔ¨Åbration i : A ‚àí‚ÜíX
and, dually, the canonical map Cocyl(X) ‚àí‚ÜíNp is an h-acyclic ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbration for
any h-Ô¨Åbration p : E ‚àí‚ÜíY .
Together with Lemma 4.2.5 and the retract and
factorization axioms of Theorem 4.3.1, this implies that all of the various classes of
maps are characterized by the expected lifting properties, just as if we had actual
model categories.
Proposition 4.3.3. The following characterizations hold.
(i) The h-Ô¨Åbrations are the maps that have the RLP with respect to the h-acyclic
¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations and the h-acyclic ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations are the maps that have the LLP
with respect to the h-Ô¨Åbrations.
(ii) The h-coÔ¨Åbrations are the maps that have the LLP with respect to the h-acyclic
¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrations and the h-acyclic ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrations are the maps that have the RLP with
respect to the h-coÔ¨Åbrations.
(iii) The ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrations are the maps that have the RLP with respect to the h-acyclic
h-coÔ¨Åbrations and the h-acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbrations are the maps that have the LLP
with respect to the ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrations.
(iv) The ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations are the maps that have the LLP with respect to the h-acyclic
h-Ô¨Åbrations and the h-acyclic h-Ô¨Åbrations are the maps that have the RLP with
respect to the ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations.
To show that C has an h-type model structure, it suÔ¨Éces to prove the factor-
ization axioms, and it is unnecessary to prove them both.
Lemma 4.3.4. For either proposed h-model structure, if one of the factorization
axioms holds, then so does the other.
Proof. For deÔ¨Åniteness, consider the case of h-Ô¨Åbrations and ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations.
By Theorem 4.3.1(ii), we can factor any map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY as the composite of an
¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration i: X ‚àí‚ÜíMf and an h-equivalence r: Mf ‚àí‚ÜíY . Suppose that we
can factor r as the composite of an h-acyclic ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration j : Mf ‚àí‚ÜíZ and an
h-Ô¨Åbration q: Z ‚àí‚ÜíY . Then q must be h-acyclic, hence f = q ‚ó¶(j ‚ó¶i) factors f as
the composite of an ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration and an h-acyclic h-Ô¨Åbration.
‚ñ°
A homotopy X ‚àí‚ÜíY in C can be speciÔ¨Åed by a path h: I ‚àí‚ÜíC (X, Y ). If
i: A ‚àí‚ÜíX and p: Y ‚àí‚ÜíB are maps in C , then we say that h is a homotopy

AND U

relative to i or corelative to p if the composite

/ C (X, Y )
C (i,Y )/ C (A, Y )
or
I
h
/ C (X, Y )
C (X,p)/ C (X, B)
is constant. When i or p is understood, we also refer to these as homotopies under A
or over B. The following result is well known and holds in any (based) topologically
bicomplete category.
Proposition 4.3.5. Let f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY be an h-equivalence.
(i) If i: A ‚àí‚ÜíX and j : A ‚àí‚ÜíY are h-coÔ¨Åbrations such that j = f ‚ó¶i, then f
is an h-equivalence under A.
(ii) If p: Y ‚àí‚ÜíB and q: X ‚àí‚ÜíB are h-Ô¨Åbrations such that q = p ‚ó¶f, then f is
an h-equivalence over B.
Proof. For (i), see for example [121, p.44]. The proof there, although written
for spaces, goes through without change. Part (ii) follows by a dual proof.
‚ñ°
Remark 4.3.6. The current section, as well as the previous and the follow-
ing one, applies verbatim to the G-topologically bicomplete G-categories of ¬ß10.2,
where G is any topological group. Of course, (KG,B, GKB) is an example. The
only changes occur in Theorem 4.3.1(iv), where one must take the arrow G-spaces
CG(‚àí, ‚àí) rather than the non-equivariant spaces GC (‚àí, ‚àí), and in Theorem 4.3.2,
where the adjunction hypothesis requires a similar equivariant interpretation. See
¬ß10.3 for a discussion of G-topological model G-categories.
4.4. Classical model structures in general and in K and U
Again, Ô¨Åx a topologically bicomplete category C .
Independent of the work
of Schw¬®anzl and Vogt [144], Cole [35] proved a general result concerning when
C has an h-type model structure.
As we now see is inevitable, the core of his
argument concerns the veriÔ¨Åcation of one of the factorization axioms. That requires
a hypothesis.
Hypothesis 4.4.1. Let jn : Zn ‚àí‚ÜíZn+1 and qn : Zn ‚àí‚ÜíY be maps in C
such that qn+1 ‚ó¶jn = qn and the jn are h-acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbrations. Let Z = colim Zn
and let q: Z ‚àí‚ÜíY be obtained by passage to colimits. Then the canonical map
colim Nqn ‚àí‚ÜíNq is an isomorphism in C .
Theorem 4.4.2 (Cole). If C is a topologically bicomplete category which satis-
Ô¨Åes Hypothesis 4.4.1, then the h-equivalences, h-Ô¨Åbrations, and ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations spec-
ify a proper topological h-model structure on C .
Proof. It suÔ¨Éces to show that a map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY factors as the composite of
an h-acyclic ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration j : X ‚àí‚ÜíZ and an h-Ô¨Åbration q: Z ‚àí‚ÜíY . Let Z0 = X
and q0 = f. Inductively, given qn : Zn ‚àí‚ÜíY , construct the following diagram, in
which Zn+1 is the displayed pushout.

The dual version of Theorem 4.4.2 admits a dual proof.
Theorem 4.4.3. If C is a topologically bicomplete category which satisÔ¨Åes the
dual of Hypothesis 4.4.1, then the h-equivalences, ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrations, and h-coÔ¨Åbrations
specify a proper topological h-model structure on C .
From now on, we break the symmetry by focusing on h-Ô¨Åbrations and ¬Øh-
coÔ¨Åbrations. These give model structures in K and U . Everything in the rest
of the section works equally in GK and GU . The following theorem combines
several results of Str√∏m [158‚Äì160].
Theorem 4.4.4 (Str√∏m). The following statements hold.
(i) The h-equivalences, h-Ô¨Åbrations, and ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations give K a proper topolog-
ical h-model structure. Moreover, a map in K is an ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration if and only
if it is a closed h-coÔ¨Åbration.
(ii) The h-equivalences, h-Ô¨Åbrations, and ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations give U a proper topologi-
cal h-model structure. Moreover, a map in U is an ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration if and only
if it is an h-coÔ¨Åbration.
Proof. Theorem 4.4.2 applies to prove the Ô¨Årst statement in (ii), but it does
not seem to apply to prove the Ô¨Årst statement in (i). The reasons are explained in
Remark 1.6.4. Taking Z = Y I and p = p0 there, the comparison map Œ± specializes
to the map colim Nfn ‚àí‚ÜíNf of Hypothesis 4.4.1. It may be that Œ± is a homeo-
morphism in this special case, but we do not have a proof. It is a homeomorphism
when we work in U . The characterization of the ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations in U follows from
Lemma 1.6.2 and their characterization in K .
For (i), we give a streamlined version of Str√∏m‚Äôs original arguments that uses
the material of the previous section to prove both statements together. We proceed
in four steps. The Ô¨Årst step is Str√∏m‚Äôs key observation, the second and third steps
give the second statement, and the fourth step proves the needed factorization
axiom. Consider an inclusion i: A ‚àí‚ÜíX.
Step 1. By Str√∏m‚Äôs [158, Thm. 3], if i is the inclusion of a strong deformation
retract and there is a map œà: X ‚àí‚ÜíI such that œà‚àí1(0) = A, then i has the LLP
with respect to all h-Ô¨Åbrations. By Proposition 4.3.3(i), this means that i is an
h-acyclic ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration.
Step 2. If i is an h-coÔ¨Åbration, then the canonical map j : Mi ‚àí‚ÜíX √ó I is
an h-acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbration and therefore, by Lemma 4.2.5, the inclusion of a strong
deformation retract. If i is closed, then (X, A) is an NDR-pair and there exists
œÜ: X ‚àí‚ÜíI such that œÜ‚àí1(0) = A. DeÔ¨Åne œà: X √óI ‚àí‚ÜíI by œà(x, t) = tœÜ(x). Then
œà‚àí1(0) = Mi. Applying Step 1, we conclude that j has the LLP with respect to
all h-Ô¨Åbrations. By Lemma 4.2.4, this means that i is an ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration.
Step 3. We can factor any inclusion i as the composite
