There are several further results of Str√∏m about h-coÔ¨Åbrations that deserve to
be highlighted. In order, the following results are [159, Theorem 12], [160, Lemma
5], and [159, Corollary 5].
Proposition 4.4.5. If p: E ‚àí‚ÜíY is an h-Ô¨Åbration and the inclusion X ‚äÇY
is an ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration, then the induced map p‚àí1(X) ‚àí‚ÜíE is an ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration.
Proposition 4.4.6. If i: A ‚àí‚ÜíB and j : B ‚àí‚ÜíX are maps in K such that
j and j ‚ó¶i are h-coÔ¨Åbrations, then i is an h-coÔ¨Åbration.
Proposition 4.4.7. If an inclusion A ‚äÇX is an h-coÔ¨Åbration, then so is the
induced inclusion ¬ØA ‚äÇX.
In view of the characterization of ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations in Theorem 4.4.4, it is natural
to ask if there is an analogous characterization of ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrations. Only the following
suÔ¨Écient condition is known. It is stated without proof in [144, 4.1.1], and it gives
another reason for requiring the base spaces of ex-spaces to be in U .
Proposition 4.4.8. An h-Ô¨Åbration p: E ‚àí‚ÜíY with Y ‚ààU is an ¬Øh-Ô¨Åbration.
Proof. Let k: A ‚àí‚ÜíX be an h-acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbration and let j : A ‚àí‚ÜíX
be the induced inclusion.
By Propositions 4.4.7 and 4.4.6, j and the inclusion
i: A ‚äÇA are h-coÔ¨Åbrations. By Lemma 4.2.5(i), k is the inclusion of a deformation
retraction r: X ‚àí‚ÜíA and the deformation restricts to a homotopy from (i ‚ó¶r) ‚ó¶j
to the identity on A. It follows that j and hence also i are h-acyclic. Since j is
an h-acyclic ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration, it has the LLP with respect to p, and we see by a little
diagram chase that it suÔ¨Éces to verify that i has the LLP with respect to p. Factor
p as the composite of s: E ‚àí‚ÜíNp and q: Np: ‚àí‚ÜíY , as usual. Since q is an
¬Øh-Ô¨Åbration, (i, q) has the lifting property, and it suÔ¨Éces to show that (i, s) has the
lifting property. Suppose given a lifting problem f : A ‚àí‚ÜíE and g: A ‚àí‚ÜíNp
such that s ‚ó¶f = g ‚ó¶i. Note that s(e) = (e, cp(e)) for e ‚ààE, where cy denotes the
constant path at y. Since Y is weak HausdorÔ¨Ä, the constant paths give a closed
subset of Y I and Np = Y I √óY E is a closed subset of Y I √ó E. Therefore s(E) is
closed in Np. We conclude that
g(A) ‚äÇg(A) = s(f(A) ‚äÇs(E) = s(E),
which means that there is a lift A ‚àí‚ÜíE.
‚ñ°

72
4. TOPOLOGICALLY BICOMPLETE MODEL CATEGORIES
4.5. Compactly generated q-type model structures
We give a variant of the standard procedure for constructing q-type model
structures. The exposition prepares the way for a new variant that we will explain
in ¬ß5.4 and which is crucial to our work. Although our discussion is adapted to
topological examples, C need not be topological until otherwise speciÔ¨Åed.
We
Ô¨Årst recall the small object argument in settings where compactness allows use of
sequential colimits.
Definition 4.5.1. Let I be a set of maps in C .
(i) A relative I-cell complex is a map Z0 ‚àí‚ÜíZ, where Z is the colimit of a
sequence of maps Zn ‚àí‚ÜíZn+1 such that Zn+1 is the pushout Y ‚à™X Zn of a
coproduct X ‚àí‚ÜíY of maps in I along a map X ‚àí‚ÜíZn.
(ii) I is compact if for every domain object X of a map in I and every relative
I-complex Z0 ‚àí‚ÜíZ, the map colim C (X, Zn) ‚àí‚ÜíC (X, Z) is a bijection.
(iii) An I-coÔ¨Åbration is a map that satisÔ¨Åes the LLP with respect to any map that
satisÔ¨Åes the RLP with respect to I.
Lemma 4.5.2 (Small object argument). Let I be a compact set of maps in C ,
where C is cocomplete. Then any map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY in C factors functorially as a
composite
X
i
/ W
p
/ Y
such that p satisÔ¨Åes the RLP with respect to I and i is a relative I-cell complex and
therefore an I-coÔ¨Åbration.
Definition 4.5.3. A model structure on C is compactly generated if there are
compact sets I and J of maps in C such that the following characterizations hold.
(i) The Ô¨Åbrations are the maps that satisfy the RLP with respect to J, or equiv-
alently, with respect to retracts of relative J-cell complexes.
(ii) The acyclic Ô¨Åbrations are the maps that satisfy the RLP with respect to I, or
equivalently, with respect to retracts of relative I-cell complexes.
(iii) The coÔ¨Åbrations are the retracts of relative I-cell complexes.
(iv) The acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations are the retracts of relative J-cell complexes.
The maps in I are called the generating coÔ¨Åbrations and the maps in J are called
the generating acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations.
Remark 4.5.4. The term ‚Äúcompactly generated‚Äù is non-standard. Compactly
generated model categories whose coÔ¨Åbrations are eÔ¨Äective monomorphisms [73,
10.9.1] are examples of cellular model categories, which are themselves examples of
coÔ¨Åbrantly generated model categories. In our topological context, it is immediate
that all coÔ¨Åbrations f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB that we encounter are eÔ¨Äective monomorphisms,
since the condition asserts in eÔ¨Äect that A is the intersection of the two copies of B in
B ‚à™A B. Cellular model categories are speciÔ¨Åed in terms of a more general notion of
compactness that encodes the cardinality conditions required to carry out the small
object argument [73, 11.4.1] in contexts, such as BousÔ¨Åeld localization, where the
sequential small object argument does not apply. Everything that we say about
compactly generated topological model categories applies equally well to cellular
topological model categories. We have restricted to the compactly generated case
for simplicity and because the examples that we consider here are of this type.

4.5. COMPACTLY GENERATED q-TYPE MODEL STRUCTURES
73
We Ô¨Ånd it convenient to separate out properties of classes of maps in a model
category, starting with the weak equivalences.
Definition 4.5.5. A subcategory of C is a subcategory of weak equivalences if
it satisÔ¨Åes the following closure properties.
(i) All isomorphisms in C are weak equivalences.
(ii) A retract of a weak equivalence is a weak equivalence.
(iii) If two out of three maps f, g, g ‚ó¶f are weak equivalences, so is the third.
Theorem 4.5.6. Let C be a bicomplete category with a subcategory of weak
equivalences. Let I and J be compact sets of maps in C . Then C is a compactly
generated model category with generating coÔ¨Åbrations I and generating acyclic coÔ¨Å-
brations J if the following two conditions hold:
(i) (Acyclicity condition) Every relative J-cell complex is a weak equivalence.
(ii) (Compatibility condition) A map has the RLP with respect to I if and only if
it is a weak equivalence and has the RLP with respect to J.
Proof. This is the formal part of Quillen‚Äôs original proof of the q-model struc-
ture on topological spaces and is a variant of [75, 2.1.19] or [73, 11.3.1]. The Ô¨Å-
brations are deÔ¨Åned to be the maps that satisfy the RLP with respect to J. The
coÔ¨Åbrations are deÔ¨Åned to be the I-coÔ¨Åbrations and turn out to be the retracts of
relative I-cell complexes. The retract axioms clearly hold and, by (ii), the coÔ¨Åbra-
tions are the maps that satisfy the LLP with respect to the acyclic Ô¨Åbrations, which
gives one of the lifting axioms. The maps in J satisfy the LLP with respect to the
Ô¨Åbrations and are therefore coÔ¨Åbrations, which veriÔ¨Åes something that is taken as
a hypothesis in the versions in the cited sources. Applying the small object argu-
ment to I, we factor a map f as a composite of an I-coÔ¨Åbration followed by a map
that satisÔ¨Åes the RLP with respect to I; by (ii), the latter is an acyclic Ô¨Åbration.
Applying the small object argument to J, we factor f as a composite of a relative
J-cell complex that is a J-coÔ¨Åbration followed by a Ô¨Åbration. By (i), the Ô¨Årst map
is acyclic, and it is a coÔ¨Åbration because it satisÔ¨Åes the LLP with respect to all
Ô¨Åbrations, in particular the acyclic ones. Finally, for the second lifting axiom, if we
are given a lifting problem with an acyclic coÔ¨Åbration f and a Ô¨Åbration p, then a
standard retract argument shows that f is a retract of an acyclic coÔ¨Åbration that
satisÔ¨Åes the LLP with respect to all Ô¨Åbrations.
‚ñ°
Using the following companion to DeÔ¨Ånition 4.5.5, we codify the usual pattern
for verifying the acyclicity condition.
Definition 4.5.7. A subcategory of a cocomplete category C is a subcategory
of coÔ¨Åbrations if it satisÔ¨Åes the following closure properties.
(i) All isomorphisms in C are coÔ¨Åbrations.
(ii) All coproducts of coÔ¨Åbrations are coÔ¨Åbrations.
(iii) If i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a coÔ¨Åbration and f : X ‚àí‚ÜíZ is any map, then the pushout
j : Z ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚à™X Z of i along f is a coÔ¨Åbration.
(iv) If X is the colimit of a sequence of coÔ¨Åbrations in : Xn ‚àí‚ÜíXn+1, then the
induced map i: X0 ‚àí‚ÜíX is a coÔ¨Åbration.
(v) A retract of a coÔ¨Åbration is a coÔ¨Åbration.
In more general contexts, (iv) should be given a transÔ¨Ånite generalization, but
we shall not have need of that. Note that if a subcategory of coÔ¨Åbrations is deÔ¨Åned
in terms of a left lifting property, then all of the conditions hold automatically.

74
4. TOPOLOGICALLY BICOMPLETE MODEL CATEGORIES
Lemma 4.5.8. Let C be a cocomplete category together with a subcategory of
coÔ¨Åbrations, denoted g-coÔ¨Åbrations, and a subcategory of weak equivalences, satis-
fying the following properties.
(i) A coproduct of weak equivalences is a weak equivalence.
(ii) If i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY is an acyclic g-coÔ¨Åbration and f : X ‚àí‚ÜíZ is any map, then
the pushout j : Z ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚à™X Z of i along f is a weak equivalence.
(iii) If X is the colimit of a sequence of acyclic g-coÔ¨Åbrations in : Xn ‚àí‚ÜíXn+1,
then the induced map i: X0 ‚àí‚ÜíX is a weak equivalence.
If every map in a set J is an acyclic g-coÔ¨Åbration, then every relative J-cell complex
is a weak equivalence.
We emphasize that, in practice, the g-coÔ¨Åbrations need not be the model
category coÔ¨Åbrations and may or may not be the intrinsic h-coÔ¨Åbrations or ¬Øh-
coÔ¨Åbrations. They serve as convenient scaÔ¨Äolding for proving the model axioms.
Remark 4.5.9. The properties listed in Lemma 4.5.8 include some of the ax-
ioms for a ‚ÄúcoÔ¨Åbration category‚Äù given by Baues [8, pp 6, 182].
However, our
purpose is to describe features of categories that are more richly structured than
model categories, often with several relevant subcategories of coÔ¨Åbrations, rather
than to describe deductions from axiom systems for less richly structured categories,
which is his focus. The g-coÔ¨Åbrations in Lemma 4.5.8 need not be the coÔ¨Åbrations
of any coÔ¨Åbration category or model category.
The q-model structures on K and U are obtained by Theorem 4.5.6, taking
the q-equivalences to be the weak equivalences, that is, the maps that induce iso-
morphisms on all homotopy groups, and the q-Ô¨Åbrations to be the Serre Ô¨Åbrations.
Similarly, in K‚àóand T , a based map is a q-equivalence or q-Ô¨Åbration if its underly-
ing unbased map is so. We also have the equivariant generalization, which applies
to any topological group G. We introduce the following notations, which will be
used throughout.
Definition 4.5.10. Nonequivariantly, let I and J denote the set of inclusions
i: Sn‚àí1 ‚àí‚ÜíDn (where S‚àí1 is empty) and the set of maps i0 : Dn ‚àí‚ÜíDn √ó I.
Equivariantly, let I and J denote the set of all maps of the form G/H √ó i, where
H is a (closed) subgroup of G and i runs through the maps in the nonequivariant
sets I and J. In the based categories K‚àóand GK‚àówe continue to write I and J
for the sets obtained by adjoining disjoint base points to the speciÔ¨Åed maps.
A map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY of G-spaces is said to be a weak equivalence or Serre Ô¨Åbra-
tion if all Ô¨Åxed point maps f H : XH ‚àí‚ÜíY H are weak equivalences or Serre Ô¨Åbra-
tions. Just as nonequivariantly, we also call these q-equivalences and q-Ô¨Åbrations.
Observe that q-equivalences are deÔ¨Åned in terms of the equivariant homotopy groups
œÄH
n (X, x) = œÄn(XH, x) for H ‚äÇG and x ‚ààXH and that q-Ô¨Åbrations are deÔ¨Åned in
terms of the RLP with respect to the cells in J.
If X0 ‚àí‚ÜíX is a relative I or J-cell complex, then X/X0 is in GU and
Lemma 1.6.5 gives all that is needed to verify the compactness hypothesis in Def-
inition 4.5.1(ii). Taking the g-coÔ¨Åbrations to be the h-coÔ¨Åbrations, Lemma 4.5.8
applies to verify the acyclicity condition of Theorem 4.5.6. With considerable sim-
pliÔ¨Åcation, our veriÔ¨Åcation of the compatibility condition for the qf-model structure
in Chapter 6 specializes to verify it here.

4.5. COMPACTLY GENERATED q-TYPE MODEL STRUCTURES
75
Nonequivariantly, the q-model structure is discussed in [56, ¬ß8] and, with some-
what diÔ¨Äerent details, in [75, 2.4]. Equivariantly, a detailed proof of the following
result is given in [105, III¬ß1]. The argument there is given for based G-spaces, in
GT , but it works equally well for unbased G-spaces, in GK .
Theorem 4.5.11. For any G, GK is a compactly generated proper model cate-
gory whose q-equivalences, q-Ô¨Åbrations, and q-coÔ¨Åbrations are the weak equivalences,
the Serre Ô¨Åbrations, and the retracts of relative G-cell complexes. The sets I and
J are the generating q-coÔ¨Åbrations and the generating acyclic q-coÔ¨Åbrations, and
all q-coÔ¨Åbrations are ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations. If G is a compact Lie group, then the model
structure is G-topological.
The notion of a G-topological model category is deÔ¨Åned in the same way as
the notion of a simplicial or topological model category and is discussed formally in
¬ß10.3 below. The point of the last statement is that if H and K are subgroups of a
compact Lie group G, then G/H √óG/K has the structure of a G-CW complex. By
Theorem 3.4.2, this remains true when G is a Lie group and H and K are compact
subgroups. We shall see how to use this fact model theoretically in Chapter 7.
Remark 4.5.12. In Theorem 4.5.11, the generating acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations are
actually ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations that are inclusions of deformation retracts. A pushout of a
coproduct of such maps is again such a map, the inclusion of the initial term in a
sequential colimit of such maps is another such, and so is a retract of such a map.
We conclude that every acyclic q-coÔ¨Åbration is an ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration that is an inclusion
of a deformation retract. Thus, implicitly, the classical q-type model structures
are built directly from the underlying h-type model structures.
As soon as we
work in the parametrized context, this structure will disappear. Our generating
acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations over B will be given by deformation retracts on total spaces,
but the retractions will not be maps over B. Therefore direct arguments with weak
equivalences that are wholly unnecessary in the classical case will be essential to
our work, especially when we turn to the stable theory.


CHAPTER 5
Well-grounded topological model categories
Introduction
It is essential to our theory to understand the interrelationships among the
various model structures that appear naturally in the parametrized context, both
in topology and in general.
This understanding leads us more generally to an
axiomatization of the properties that are required of a good q-type model structure
in order that it relate well to the classical homotopy theory on a topological category.
The obvious q-model structure on ex-spaces over B does not satisfy the axioms, and
in the next chapter we will introduce a new model structure, the qf-model structure,
that does satisfy the axioms.
As we recall in ¬ß5.1, any model structure on a category C induces a model
structure on the category of objects over, under, or over and under a given object
B. When C is topologically bicomplete, so are these over and under categories.
They therefore have their own intrinsic h-type model structures, which diÔ¨Äer from
the one inherited from C . This leads to quite a few diÔ¨Äerent model structures on
the category CB of objects over and under B, each with its own advantages and
disadvantages. Letting B vary, we also obtain a model structure on the category
of retracts. We shall only be using most of these structures informally, but the
plethora of model structures is eye opening.
In ¬ß5.2, we focus on spaces and compare the various classical notions of Ô¨Åbra-
tions and coÔ¨Åbrations that are present in our over and under categories. Although
elementary, this material is subtle, and it is nowhere presented accurately in the
literature. In particular, we discuss h-type, f-type and fp-type model structures,
where f and fp stand for ‚ÄúÔ¨Åberwise‚Äù and ‚ÄúÔ¨Åberwise pointed‚Äù. For simplicity, we
discuss this material nonequivariantly, but it applies verbatim equivariantly.
The comparisons among the q, h, f, and fp classes of maps and model struc-
tures guide our development of parametrized homotopy theory. We think of the
f-notions as playing a transitional role, connecting the fp and h-notions. In the
rest of the chapter, we work in a general topologically bicomplete category C , and
we sort out this structure and its relationship to a desired q-type model structure
axiomatically.
Here we shift our point of view. We focus on three basic types of coÔ¨Åbrations
that are in play in the general context, namely the Hurewicz coÔ¨Åbrations determined
by the cylinders in C , the ground coÔ¨Åbrations that come in practice from a given
forgetful functor to underlying spaces, and the q-type model coÔ¨Åbrations. The Ô¨Årst
two are intrinsic, but we think of the q-type coÔ¨Åbrations as subject to negotiation. In
KB, the Hurewicz coÔ¨Åbrations are the fp-coÔ¨Åbrations and the ground coÔ¨Åbrations
are the h-coÔ¨Åbrations, which is in notational conÔ¨Çict with the point of view taken
in the previous chapter.
77

78
5. WELL-GROUNDED TOPOLOGICAL MODEL CATEGORIES
In ¬ß¬ß5.3 and 5.4, we ignore model theoretic considerations entirely. We describe
how the two intrinsic types of coÔ¨Åbrations relate to each other and to colimits and
tensors, and we explain how this structure relates to weak equivalences.
These
ideas are made precise by the notions of ‚Äúwell-grounded objects‚Äù and of a ‚Äúground
structure‚Äù in a topologically bicomplete category and of a subcategory of ‚Äúwell-
grounded weak equivalences‚Äù in a category with a ground structure.
We deÔ¨Åne the notion of a ‚Äúwell-grounded model structure‚Äù in ¬ß5.5. We believe
that this notion captures exactly the right blend of classical and model categorical
homotopical structure in topological situations. It describes what is needed for a q-
type model structure in a topologically bicomplete category to be compatible with
its intrinsic h-type model structure and its ground structure. Crucially, the q-type
coÔ¨Åbrations should be ‚ÄúbicoÔ¨Åbrations‚Äù, meaning that they are both Hurewicz coÔ¨Å-
brations and ground coÔ¨Åbrations. We illustrate the usefulness of the axiomatization
in ¬ß5.6. We show that the elementary classical theory of long exact sequences as-
sociated to coÔ¨Åber sequences, homotopy colimits, and lim1 exact sequences applies
in any well-grounded model category.
A clear understanding of the desiderata for a good q-type model structure
reveals that the obvious over and under q-model structure is essentially worthless
for serious work in parametrized homotopy theory. This will lead us to introduce
the new qf-model structure, with better behaved q-type coÔ¨Åbrations, in the next
chapter. The formalization given in ¬ß¬ß5.3‚Äì5.6 might seem overly pedantic were it
only to serve as motivation for the deÔ¨Ånition of the qf-model structure. However, we
will encounter exactly the same structure in Part III when we construct the level and
stable model structures on parametrized spectra. We hope that the formalization
will help guide the reader through the rougher terrain there.
We note parenthetically that there is still another interesting model structure
on the category of ex-spaces over B, one based on local considerations. It is due
to Michelle Intermont and Mark Johnson [81]. We shall not discuss their model
structure here, but we are indebted to them for illuminating discussions.
It is
conceivable that their model structure could be used in an alternative development
of the stable theory, but that has not been worked out. Their structure suÔ¨Äers the
defects that it is not known to be left proper and that, with their deÔ¨Ånition of weak
equivalences, homotopy equivalences of base spaces need not induce equivalences of
homotopy categories.
We focus mainly on the nonequivariant context in this chapter, but G can be
any topological group in all places where equivariance is considered.
5.1. Over and under model structures
Recall from ¬ß1.2 that, for any category C and object B in C , we let C /B and
CB denote the categories of objects over B and of ex-objects over B. We also have
the category B\C of objects under B. If C is bicomplete, then so are C /B, B\C
and CB. We begin with some general observations about over and under model
categories before returning to topological categories.
We have forgetful functors U : C /B ‚àí‚ÜíC and V : CB ‚àí‚ÜíC /B. The Ô¨Årst is
left adjoint to the functor that sends an object Y to the object B √ó Y over B:
(5.1.1)
C (UX, Y ) ‚àº= C /B (X, B √ó Y ).

5.1. OVER AND UNDER MODEL STRUCTURES
79
The second is right adjoint to the functor that sends an object X over B to the
object X ‚®øB over and under B:
(5.1.2)
CB(X ‚®øB, Y ) ‚àº= C /B (X, V Y ).
We interpolate some discussion of notation. It has been the custom since the
beginnings of topology to use the same letter for a bundle and for its underlying
total space.
In line with this, the literature of parametrized homotopy theory
systematically uses the notation X+ for the union X ‚®øB of a space X over B
with a disjoint section. It seems to us that these standard abuses of notation hide
structure and seriously obscure the literature of the subject. For example, they
force one to the identity ‚Äúr!X+ = X+‚Äù, where X is a space over B with disjoint
section on the left and its total space with a disjoint basepoint on the right. In line
with this, we adopt the following notational convention throughout this book.
Notation 5.1.3. For a space (X, p) over B, we use the notation X ‚®øB and
(X, p)+ interchangeably for the space over and under B obtained by adjoining a
disjoint section to (X, p). We shall reserve the notation X+ for the union of a space
X and a disjoint basepoint, so that r!(X, p)+ = X+.
Returning to our general discussion, we observe that, as a composite of a left
and a right adjoint, the total object functor UV : CB ‚àí‚ÜíC does not enjoy good
formal properties.
This obvious fact plays a signiÔ¨Åcant role in our work.
For
example, it limits the value of the model structures on CB that are given by the
following result.
Proposition 5.1.4. Let C be a model category. Then C /B, B\C , and CB
are model categories in which the weak equivalences, coÔ¨Åbrations, and Ô¨Åbrations
are the maps over B, under B, or over and under B which are weak equivalences,
Ô¨Åbrations, or coÔ¨Åbrations in C . If C is left or right proper, then so are C /B, B\C ,
and CB.
Proof. As observed in [75, p. 5] and [56, 3.10], the statement about C /B
is a direct veriÔ¨Åcation from the deÔ¨Ånition of a model category. By the self-dual
nature of the axioms, the statement about B\C is equivalent.
The statement
about CB follows since it is the category of objects under (B, id) in C /B. The last
statement holds since pushouts and pullbacks in these over and under categories
are constructed in C .
‚ñ°
When considering q-type model structures, we start with a compactly generated
model category C . Using the adjunctions (5.1.1) and (5.1.2), we then obtain the
following addendum to Proposition 5.1.4.
Proposition 5.1.5. If C is a compactly generated model category, then C /B
and CB are compactly generated. The generating (acyclic) coÔ¨Åbrations in C /B are
the maps i such that Ui is a generating (acyclic) coÔ¨Åbration in C . The generating
(acyclic) coÔ¨Åbrations in CB are the maps i ‚®øB where i is a generating (acyclic)
coÔ¨Åbration in C /B.
We now return to the case when C is topologically bicomplete. Then it has the
resulting ‚Äúclassical‚Äù, or h-type, structure that was discussed in ¬ß4.3 and ¬ß4.4. If our
philosophy in ¬ß4.1 applies to C , then it also has q and m-structures and the cate-
gories C /B and CB both inherit over and under model structures that are related

80
5. WELL-GROUNDED TOPOLOGICAL MODEL CATEGORIES
as we discussed there. However, since C is topologically bicomplete, so is C /B by
Proposition 1.2.8, and CB is based topologically bicomplete by Proposition 1.2.9.
These categories therefore have classical h-type structures when they are regarded
in their own right as topologically bicomplete categories. To Ô¨Åx notation and avoid
confusion we give an overview of all of these structures.
We start with the h-classes of maps in C that are given in DeÔ¨Ånition 4.2.1 and
Lemma 4.2.4. As in our discussion of spaces, we work assymmetrically, ignoring the
¬Øh-Ô¨Åbrations and focusing on the candidates for h-type model structures given by
the h-Ô¨Åbrations and ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations. We agree to use the letter h for the inherited
classes of maps in C /B and CB, although that contradicts our previous use of h
for the classical classes of maps in an arbitrary topologically bicomplete category,
such as C /B or CB. We shall resolve that ambiguity shortly by introducing new
names for the classes of ‚Äúclassical‚Äù maps in those categories.
Definition 5.1.6. A map g in C /B is an h-equivalence, h-Ô¨Åbration, h-co-
Ô¨Åbration, or ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration if Ug is such a map in C .
A map g in CB is an h-
equivalence, h-Ô¨Åbration, h-coÔ¨Åbration, or ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration if V g is such a map in C /B
or, equivalently, UV g is such a map in C .
The ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations are h-coÔ¨Åbrations, but not conversely in general. Since the
object ‚àóB = (B, id, id) is initial and terminal in CB, an object of CB is h-coÔ¨Åbrant
(or ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrant) if its section is an h-coÔ¨Åbration (or ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration) in C . It is h-
Ô¨Åbrant if its projection is an h-Ô¨Åbration in C .
In C /B, we have the notion of a homotopy over B, deÔ¨Åned in terms of X √óB I
or, equivalently, MapB(I, X). The adjective ‚ÄúÔ¨Åberwise‚Äù is generally used in the
literature to describe these homotopies. See, for example, the books [42, 83] on
Ô¨Åberwise homotopy theory. To distinguish from the h-model structure, we agree
to write f rather than h for the Ô¨Åberwise specializations of DeÔ¨Ånition 4.2.1 and
Lemma 4.2.4. To avoid any possible confusion, we formalize this, making use of
Proposition 4.3.3.
Definition 5.1.7. Let g be a map in C /B.
(i) g is an f-equivalence if it is a Ô¨Åberwise homotopy equivalence.
(ii) g is an f-Ô¨Åbration if it satisÔ¨Åes the Ô¨Åberwise CHP, that is, if it has the RLP
with respect to the maps i0 : X ‚àí‚ÜíX √óB I for X ‚ààC /B.
(iii) g is an f-coÔ¨Åbration if it satisÔ¨Åes the Ô¨Åberwise HEP, that is, if it has the LLP
with respect to the maps p0 : MapB(I, X) ‚àí‚ÜíX.
(iv) g is an ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration if it has the LLP with respect to the f-acyclic f-Ô¨Åbrations.
A map g in CB is an f-equivalence, f-Ô¨Åbration, f-coÔ¨Åbration, or ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration if
V g is one in C /B.
Again, ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations are f-coÔ¨Åbrations, but not conversely in general. The-
orem 4.4.2 often applies to show that the f-Ô¨Åbrations and ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations deÔ¨Åne
an f-model structure on C /B and therefore, by Proposition 5.1.4, on CB. As is
always the case for an intrinsic classical model structure, every object of C /B is
both f-coÔ¨Åbrant and ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrant as well as f-Ô¨Åbrant. While this is obvious from
the deÔ¨Ånitions, it may seem counterintuitive. It does not follow that every object
of CB is f-coÔ¨Åbrant since the two categories have diÔ¨Äerent initial objects.
In CB, we also have the notion of a homotopy over and under B, deÔ¨Åned in
terms of X ‚àßB I+ or, equivalently, FB(I+, X). The adjective ‚ÄúÔ¨Åberwise pointed‚Äù is

5.1. OVER AND UNDER MODEL STRUCTURES
81
used in [42,83] to describe these homotopies. Again, for notational clarity, we agree
to write fp rather than h for the Ô¨Åberwise pointed specializations of DeÔ¨Ånition 4.2.1
and Lemma 4.2.4, and we formalize this to avoid any possible confusion.
Definition 5.1.8. Let g be a map in CB.
(i) g is an fp-equivalence if it is a Ô¨Åberwise pointed homotopy equivalence.
(ii) g is an fp-Ô¨Åbration if it satisÔ¨Åes the Ô¨Åberwise pointed CHP, that is, if it has
the RLP with respect to the maps i0 : X ‚àí‚ÜíX ‚àßB I+.
(iii) g is a fp-coÔ¨Åbration if it satisÔ¨Åes the Ô¨Åberwise pointed HEP, that is, if it has
the LLP with respect to the maps p0 : FB(I+, X) ‚àí‚ÜíX.
(iv) g is an fp-coÔ¨Åbration if it has the LLP with respect to the fp-acyclic fp-
Ô¨Åbrations.
Again, fp-coÔ¨Åbrations are fp-coÔ¨Åbrations, but not conversely in general, and
Theorem 4.4.2 often applies to show that the fp-Ô¨Åbrations and fp-coÔ¨Åbrations de-
Ô¨Åne an fp-model structure on CB. We summarize some general formal implications
relating our classes of maps.
Proposition 5.1.9. Let C , C /B and CB be topologically bicomplete categories
with h, f, and fp-classes of maps deÔ¨Åned as above. Then the following implications
hold for maps in CB.
fp-equivalence
=‚áí

=‚áí

fp-coÔ¨Åbration
‚áê=

‚áë
‚áë

‚áê=
¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration

=‚áí

‚áê=
h-Ô¨Åbration
Moreover, every object of CB is both fp-Ô¨Åbrant and fp-coÔ¨Åbrant.
Proof. Trivial inspections of lifting diagrams show that an h-Ô¨Åbration is an
f-Ô¨Åbration, an f-coÔ¨Åbration is an fp-coÔ¨Åbration, and an ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration is an fp-
coÔ¨Åbration. Use of the adjunctions (5.1.1) and (5.1.2) shows that an f-coÔ¨Åbration
is an h-coÔ¨Åbration, an ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration is an ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbration, and an fp-Ô¨Åbration is an f-
Ô¨Åbration. The last statement holds since Ô¨Åberwise pointed homotopies with domain
or target B are constant at the section or projection of the target or source.
‚ñ°
Remark 5.1.10. Assume that these classes of maps deÔ¨Åne model structures.
Then the implications in Proposition 5.1.9 lead via Theorem 4.1.1 and its dual
version to two new mixed model structures on CB, one with weak equivalences the
f-equivalences and Ô¨Åbrations the fp-Ô¨Åbrations and one with weak equivalences the
h-equivalences and coÔ¨Åbrations the ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations.
The category CB of retracts introduced in ¬ß2.5 suggests an alternative model
theoretic point of view. We give the basic deÔ¨Ånitions, but we shall not pursue this
idea in any detail. Again, Theorem 4.4.2 often applies to verify the model category
axioms. Note that the intrinsic homotopies are given by homotopies of total objects
over and under homotopies of base objects.
Definition 5.1.11. Assume that CB is topologically bicomplete and let g be
a map in CB.
(i) g is an r-equivalence if it is a homotopy equivalence of retractions.

82
5. WELL-GROUNDED TOPOLOGICAL MODEL CATEGORIES
(ii) g is an r-Ô¨Åbration if it satisÔ¨Åes the retraction CHP, that is, if it has the RLP
with respect to the maps i0 : X ‚àí‚ÜíX √ó I for X ‚ààCB.
(iii) g is an r-coÔ¨Åbration if it satisÔ¨Åes the retraction HEP, that is, if it has the LLP
with respect to the maps p0 : Map(I, X) ‚àí‚ÜíX.
(iv) g is an ¬Ør-coÔ¨Åbration if it has the LLP with respect to the r-acyclic r-Ô¨Åbrations.
Remark 5.1.12. The initial and terminal object of CB are the identity retrac-
tions of the initial and terminal objects of B and every object is both r-coÔ¨Åbrant
and r-Ô¨Åbrant.
It might be of interest to characterize the retractions for which
the map ‚àóB ‚àí‚Üí(X, p, s) induced by s is an r-coÔ¨Åbration or for which the map
(X, p, s) ‚àí‚Üí‚àóB induced by p is an r-Ô¨Åbration. By specialization of the lifting prop-
erties, an ex-map over B that is an r-coÔ¨Åbration or r-Ô¨Åbration is an fp-coÔ¨Åbration
or fp-Ô¨Åbration in CB, but we have not pursued this question further.
5.2. The specialization to over and under categories of spaces
Now we take C to be K or U . We discuss the relationships among our various
classes of Ô¨Åbrations and coÔ¨Åbrations in this special case, and we consider when the
f and fp classes of maps give model structures. Everything in this section applies
equally well equivariantly.
We Ô¨Årst say a bit about based spaces, which are ex-spaces over B = {‚àó}.
Here the fact that ‚àóis a terminal object greatly simpliÔ¨Åes matters.
All of the
f-notions coincide with the corresponding h-notions, and our trichotomy reduces
to the familiar dichotomy between free (or h) notions and based (or fp) notions.
Recall that a based space is well-based, or nondegenerately based, if the inclusion
of the basepoint is an h-coÔ¨Åbration. Every based space is fp-coÔ¨Åbrant, and an
fp-coÔ¨Åbration between well-based spaces is an h-coÔ¨Åbration [160, Prop. 9]. Every
based space is fp-Ô¨Åbrant, and an h-Ô¨Åbration of based spaces satisÔ¨Åes the based CHP
with respect to well-based source spaces. Of course, the over and under h-model
structure diÔ¨Äers from the intrinsic fp-model structure.
None of the reverse implications in Proposition 5.1.9 holds in general. We gave
details of that result since it is easy to get confused and think that more is true
than we stated.
Scholium 5.2.1. On [42, p. 66], it is stated that a Ô¨Åberwise pointed coÔ¨Åbration
which is a closed inclusion is a Ô¨Åberwise coÔ¨Åbration. That is false even when B
is a point, since it would imply that every point of a T1-space is a nondegenerate
basepoint. On [42, p. 69], it is stated that a Ô¨Åberwise pointed map (= ex-map) is
a Ô¨Åberwise pointed Ô¨Åbration if and only if it is a Ô¨Åberwise Ô¨Åbration. That is also
false when B is a point, since the unbased CHP does not imply the based CHP.
However, as for based spaces, the reverse implications in parts of Proposi-
tion 5.1.9 often do hold under appropriate additional hypotheses.
Proposition 5.2.2. The following implications hold for an arbitrary topologi-
cally bicomplete category C .
(i) A map in C /B between h-Ô¨Åbrant objects over B is an h-equivalence if and
only if it is an f-equivalence.
(ii) An ex-map between f-coÔ¨Åbrant ex-objects over B is an f-equivalence if and
only if it is an fp-equivalence.

5.2. THE SPECIALIZATION TO OVER AND UNDER CATEGORIES OF SPACES
83
Proof. The Ô¨Årst part follows from Proposition 4.3.5(ii) since an f-equivalence
in C /B is the same as an h-equivalence over B in C . The second part follows
similarly from Proposition 4.3.5(i) since an fp-equivalence in CB is the same as an
f-equivalence under B in C /B.
‚ñ°
The following results hold for spaces. We are doubtful that they hold in general.
Proposition 5.2.3. The following implications hold in both GK and GU .
(i) An ex-map between ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrant ex-spaces is an f-coÔ¨Åbration if and only if it
is an fp-coÔ¨Åbration.
(ii) An ex-map whose source is ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrant is an f-Ô¨Åbration if and only if it is an
fp-Ô¨Åbration.
Proof. Part (ii) is [42, 16.3]. Part (i) is stated on [160, p. 441] and the proof
given there for based spaces generalizes using the following lemma.
‚ñ°
It is easy to detect f-coÔ¨Åbrations by means of the following result, whose proof
is the same as that of the standard characterization of Hurewicz coÔ¨Åbrations (e.g.
[121, p. 43]; see also [158, Thm. 2], [159, Lem. 4] and [42, 4.3]).
Lemma 5.2.4. An inclusion i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY in K /B is an f-coÔ¨Åbration if and
only if (Y, X) is a Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair in the sense that there is a map u: Y ‚àí‚ÜíI
such that X ‚äÇu‚àí1(0) and a homotopy h: Y √óB I ‚àí‚ÜíY over B such that h0 = id,
ht = id on X for 0 ‚â§t ‚â§1, and h1(y) ‚ààX if u(y) < 1. A closed inclusion
i : X ‚àí‚ÜíY in K /B is an ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration if and only if the map u above can be
chosen so that X = u‚àí1(0).
We introduce the following names here, but we defer a full discussion to ¬ß8.1.
Definition 5.2.5. An ex-space is said to be well-sectioned if it is ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrant.
An ex-space is said to be ex-Ô¨Åbrant or, synonomously, to be an ex-Ô¨Åbration if it is
both ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrant and h-Ô¨Åbrant. Thus an ex-Ô¨Åbration is a well-sectioned ex-space
whose projection is an h-Ô¨Åbration.
The term ex-Ô¨Åbrant is more logical than ex-Ô¨Åbration, since we are deÔ¨Åning a
type of object rather than a type of morphism of KB, but the term ex-Ô¨Åbration
goes better with Serre and Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration and is standard in the literature. We
have the following implication of Propositions 5.1.9 and 5.2.2. It helps explain the
usefulness of ex-Ô¨Åbrations.
Corollary 5.2.6. Let g be an ex-map between ex-Ô¨Åbrations over B.
(i) g is an h-equivalence if and only if g is an f-equivalence, and this hold if and
only if g is an fp-equivalence.
(ii) g is an f-coÔ¨Åbration if and only if g is an fp-coÔ¨Åbration, and then g is an
h-coÔ¨Åbration.
(iii) g is an f-Ô¨Åbration if and only if g is an fp-Ô¨Åbration, and this holds if g is an
h-Ô¨Åbration.
Remark 5.2.7. The model theoretic signiÔ¨Åcance of ex-Ô¨Åbrations over B is un-
clear.
They are Ô¨Åbrant and coÔ¨Åbrant objects in the mixed model structure on
ex-spaces over B whose weak equivalences are the h-equivalences and whose coÔ¨Å-
brations are the ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations. However, the converse fails since there are well-
sectioned f-Ô¨Åbrant ex-spaces that are f-equivalent to h-Ô¨Åbrant ex-spaces, hence
are mixed Ô¨Åbrant, but are not themselves h-Ô¨Åbrant.

84
5. WELL-GROUNDED TOPOLOGICAL MODEL CATEGORIES
The previous remark anticipated the following result on over and under model
structures in the categories of spaces and ex-spaces over B. Note that Lemma 1.6.2
applies to K /B and KB as well as to K to show that both f-coÔ¨Åbrations and
fp-coÔ¨Åbrations are inclusions which are closed when the total spaces are in U .
Theorem 5.2.8. The following statements hold.
(i) The f-equivalences, f-Ô¨Åbrations, and ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations give K /B a proper topo-
logical model structure. Moreover, a map in K /B is an ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration if and
only if it is a closed f-coÔ¨Åbration.
(ii) The f-equivalences, f-Ô¨Åbrations, and ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations give U /B a proper topo-
logical model structure. Moreover, a map in U /B is an ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration if and
only if it is an f-coÔ¨Åbration.
(iii) The fp-equivalences, fp-Ô¨Åbrations, and fp-coÔ¨Åbrations give UB an fp-model
structure.
(iv) The r-classes of maps give the category UU of retracts a proper topological
r-model structure.
Proof. Apart from the factorization axioms, the model structures follow from
the discussion in 4.3. In particular, the lifting axioms, the properness, and the
topological property of all of these model structures are given by Theorem 4.3.1.
In (ii), (iii), and (iv), the factorization axioms follow from Theorem 4.4.2 since
the argument in Remark 1.6.4 veriÔ¨Åes Hypothesis 4.4.1.
The rest of (i) can be
proven by direct mimicry of the proof of Theorem 4.4.4, using Lemma 5.2.4, and
the characterization of the ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations in (ii) follows.
‚ñ°
Remark 5.2.9. We do not know whether or not KB is an fp-model category or
whether the fp-coÔ¨Åbrations in KB are characterized as the closed fp-coÔ¨Åbrations.
We also do not know whether or not KU is an r-model category. The problem here
is related to the fact that, while the sections of ex-spaces are always inclusions,
they need not be closed inclusions unless the total spaces are in U . Steps 1 and 3
of the proof of Theorem 4.4.4 fail in KB, and we also do not see how to carry over
Str√∏m‚Äôs original proofs in [159,160]. Theorem 4.3.1 still applies, giving much of the
information carried by a model structure. Observe too that if i: A ‚àí‚ÜíX is a map
of well-sectioned ex-spaces over B, then i is an fp-coÔ¨Åbration if and only if it is an
f-coÔ¨Åbration, by Proposition 5.2.2(iii). For ex-spaces that are not well-sectioned,
we have little understanding of fp-coÔ¨Åbrations, even when B is a point. We also
have little understanding of fp-coÔ¨Åbrations that are not f-coÔ¨Åbrations.
There is a certain tension between the fp and h-notions, with the f-notions
serving as a bridge between the two. Fiberwise pointed homotopy is the intrinsically
right notion of homotopy in KB, hence the fp-structure is the philosopically right
classical h-type model structure on KB, or at least on UB. It is the one that is
naturally related to Ô¨Åber and coÔ¨Åber sequences, the theory of which works formally
in any based topologically bicomplete category in exactly the same way as for based
spaces, as we will recall in ¬ß5.6. A detailed exposition in the case of ex-spaces is
given in [42,83,84].
However, with h replaced by fp, we do not have the implications that we
emphasized in the general philosophy of ¬ß4.1. In particular, with the over and under
q-model structure, q-coÔ¨Åbrations need not be fp-coÔ¨Åbrations and fp-Ô¨Åbrations need
not be q-Ô¨Åbrations, let alone h-Ô¨Åbrations. The q-model structure is still related to

5.3. WELL-GROUNDED TOPOLOGICALLY BICOMPLETE CATEGORIES
85
the h-model structure as in ¬ß4.1, but this does not serve to relate the q-model
structure to parametrized Ô¨Åber and coÔ¨Åber sequences in the way familiar from the
nonparametrized context. This already suggests that the q-model structure might
not be appropriate in parametrized homotopy theory. In the following four sections,
we explore conceptually what is required of a q-type model structure to connect it
up with the intrinsic homotopy theory in a topologically bicomplete category.
5.3. Well-grounded topologically bicomplete categories
Let C be a topologically bicomplete category in either the based or the unbased
sense; we use the notations of the based context. In our work here, and in other
topological contexts, C is topologically concrete in the sense that there is a faithful
and continuous forgetful functor from C to spaces. In practice, appropriate ‚Äúground
coÔ¨Åbrations‚Äù can then be speciÔ¨Åed in terms of underlying spaces. These coÔ¨Åbrations
should be thought of as helpful background structure in our category C .
To avoid ambiguity, we use the term ‚ÄúHurewicz coÔ¨Åbration‚Äù, abbreviated no-
tationally to cyl-coÔ¨Åbration, for the maps that satisfy the HEP with respect to the
cylinders in C . We also have the notion of a strong Hurewicz coÔ¨Åbration, which we
abbreviate notationally to cyl-coÔ¨Åbration. For example, the cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations in K ,
K /B, and KB are the h-coÔ¨Åbrations, the f-coÔ¨Åbrations, and the fp-coÔ¨Åbrations,
respectively, and similarly for cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations. As we have seen, it often happens
that cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations between suitably nice objects of C , which we shall call ‚Äúwell-
grounded‚Äù, are also ground coÔ¨Åbrations. We introduce language to describe this
situation. The following deÔ¨Ånitions codify the behavior of the well-grounded objects
with respect to the cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations, colimits, and tensors in C . It is convenient to
build in the appropriate equivariant generalizations of our notions, although we
defer a formal discussion of G-topologically bicomplete G-categories to ¬ß10.2; see
DeÔ¨Ånition 10.2.1. The examples in ¬ß1.4 give the idea.
Definition 5.3.1. An unbased space is well-grounded if it is compactly gener-
ated. A based space is well-grounded if it is compactly generated and well-based.
The same deÔ¨Ånitions apply to G-spaces for a topological group G.
Let C be a topologically bicomplete category.
Definition 5.3.2. A full subcategory of C is said to be a subcategory of well-
grounded objects if the following properties hold.
(i) The initial object of C is well-grounded.
(ii) All coproducts of well-grounded objects are well-grounded.
(iii) If i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration and f : X ‚àí‚ÜíZ is any map, where X, Y ,
and Z are well-grounded, then the pushout Y ‚à™X Z is well-grounded.
(iv) The colimit of a sequence of cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations between well-grounded objects is
well-grounded.
(v) A retract of a well-grounded object is well-grounded.
(vi) If X is a well-grounded object and K is a well-grounded space, then X ‚àßK
(X √ó K in the unbased context) is well-grounded.
When C is G-topologically bicomplete, we replace spaces by G-spaces in (vi).
Definition 5.3.3. A ground structure on C is a (full) subcategory of well-
grounded objects together with a subcategory of coÔ¨Åbrations, called the ground
coÔ¨Åbrations and denoted g-coÔ¨Åbrations, such that every cyl-coÔ¨Åbration between

86
5. WELL-GROUNDED TOPOLOGICAL MODEL CATEGORIES
well-grounded objects is a g-coÔ¨Åbration. A map that is both a g-coÔ¨Åbration and a
cyl-coÔ¨Åbration is called a bicoÔ¨Åbration.
Thus a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration between well-grounded objects is a bicoÔ¨Åbration. The
need for focusing on bicoÔ¨Åbrations and the force of the deÔ¨Ånition come from the
following fact.
Warning 5.3.4. In practice, (iii) often fails if i is a g-coÔ¨Åbration between well-
grounded objects that is not a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration, as we shall illustrate in ¬ß6.1. In
particular, in GKB with the canonical ground structure described below, it can
already fail for an inclusion i of I-cell complexes, where I is the standard set of
generators for the q-coÔ¨Åbrations.
In the next chapter, we will construct a q-type model structure for GKB with a
set of generating coÔ¨Åbrations to which the following implication of DeÔ¨Ånitions 4.5.7
and 5.3.2 applies.
Lemma 5.3.5. Let I be a set of cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations between well-grounded objects
and let f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY be a retract of a relative I-cell complex W ‚àí‚ÜíZ. Then f is a
bicoÔ¨Åbration. If W is well-grounded, then so are X, Y , and Z.
Our categories of equivariant parametrized spaces have canonical ground struc-
tures. Recall that the classes of f and ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations in GU /B and GUB coincide.
Definition 5.3.6. A space over B is well-grounded if its total space is com-
pactly generated. An ex-space over B is well-grounded if it is well-sectioned and
its total space is compactly generated. In both GK /B and GKB, deÔ¨Åne the g-
coÔ¨Åbrations to be the h-coÔ¨Åbrations.
Note that the only distinction between well-sectioned and well-grounded ex-
spaces is the condition on total spaces. The distinction is relevant when we consider
relative I-cell complexes X0 ‚àí‚ÜíX in GKB. If X0 is well-sectioned, then so is X,
whereas X/X0 is an I-cell complex and is therefore well-grounded for any X0.
Proposition 5.3.7. These deÔ¨Ånitions specify ground structures on GK /B and
on GKB.
Proof. For GK /B, the Hurewicz coÔ¨Åbrations are the f-coÔ¨Åbrations, and
these are h-coÔ¨Åbrations.
It is standard that GU /B has the closure properties
speciÔ¨Åed in DeÔ¨Ånition 5.3.2.
For GKB, the Hurewicz coÔ¨Åbrations are the fp-
coÔ¨Åbrations. Between well-sectioned ex-spaces, these are f-coÔ¨Åbrations and there-
fore h-coÔ¨Åbrations by Proposition 5.2.3(i).
Parts (i)‚Äì(v) of DeÔ¨Ånition 5.3.2 are
clear since well-sectioned means ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrant, which is a lifting property. Finally we
consider part (vi). Recall that X ‚àßB K can be constructed as the pushout of the
diagram of spaces
B
(X √ó ‚àó) ‚à™(B √ó K)
o
/ X √ó K ,
which also gives the pushout in the category of spaces over B. By the equivariant
version of the NDR-pair characterization of f-coÔ¨Åbrations in Lemma 5.2.4, these
spaces are f-coÔ¨Åbrant and the inclusion on the right is an f-coÔ¨Åbration.
This
implies that X ‚àßB K is f-coÔ¨Åbrant.
‚ñ°

5.4. WELL-GROUNDED CATEGORIES OF WEAK EQUIVALENCES
87
5.4. Well-grounded categories of weak equivalences
The following deÔ¨Ånition describes how the weak equivalences and the ground
structure are related in practice.
Definition 5.4.1. Let C be a topologically bicomplete category with a given
ground structure. A subcategory of weak equivalences in C is well-grounded if the
following properties hold (where acyclicity refers to the weak equivalences).
(i) A homotopy equivalence is a weak equivalence.
(ii) A coproduct of weak equivalences between well-grounded objects is a weak
equivalence.
(iii) (Gluing lemma)
Assume that the maps i and i‚Ä≤ are bicoÔ¨Åbrations and the
vertical arrows are weak equivalences in the following diagram.
Y

X


f
/ Z


i‚Ä≤
o
f ‚Ä≤
/ Z‚Ä≤
Then the induced map of pushouts is a weak equivalence.
In particular,
pushouts of weak equivalences along bicoÔ¨Åbrations are weak equivalences.
(iv) (Ladder lemma) Let X and Y be the colimits of sequences of bicoÔ¨Åbrations
in : Xn ‚àí‚ÜíXn+1 and jn : Yn ‚àí‚ÜíYn+1 such that both X/X0 and Y/Y0 are
well-grounded. If f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY is the colimit of a sequence of compatible weak
equivalences fn : Xn ‚àí‚ÜíYn, then f is a weak equivalence. In particular, if
each in is a weak equivalence, then the induced map i: X0 ‚àí‚ÜíX is a weak
equivalence.
(v) For a map i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY of well-grounded objects in C and a map j : K ‚àí‚ÜíL
of well-grounded spaces, i‚ñ°j is a weak equivalence if i is a weak equivalence
or j is a weak equivalence (that is, a q-equivalence of spaces).
Here, in the based context, i‚ñ°j is the evident induced map
(X ‚àßL) ‚à™X‚àßK (Y ‚àßK) ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚àßL.
In practice, the conditions that we have speciÔ¨Åed are stronger than consideration
of left proper q-type model category structures might lead one to expect. However,
(v) is both stronger and weaker than one might expect.
Remark 5.4.2. Condition (v) holds as stated for most of the examples we
consider, but in Theorem 24.3.1 we shall encounter an example where K and L
must be restricted to be CW complexes. Note that condition (v) does not involve
coÔ¨Åbrations at all, and its veriÔ¨Åcation depends on the particular nature of the
tensor functor ‚àß. This condition describes what actually holds, but, unfortunately,
it is not well related to the question of whether or not a model structure on C
is topological. The problem is that the model theoretic coÔ¨Åbrations to which we
would like to apply the axiom need not have well-grounded source objects, and it is
unclear whether or not (v) holds with unrestricted source objects even when i and j
are bicoÔ¨Åbrations. (This is already unclear to us when C = T ). It is crucial to the
usefulness of (iii) and (iv) to the study of model structures that the bicoÔ¨Åbrations
that appear in them are not required to have well-grounded source objects.

88
5. WELL-GROUNDED TOPOLOGICAL MODEL CATEGORIES
The gluing lemma implies that acyclic bicoÔ¨Åbrations are preserved under push-
outs, as of course holds for pushouts of acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations in model categories.
The special case mentioned in (iii) corresponds to the left proper axiom in model
categories. As there, it can be used to prove the general case of the gluing lemma
provided that we have suitable factorizations.
Lemma 5.4.3. Assume the following hypotheses.
(i) Weak equivalences are preserved under pushouts along bicoÔ¨Åbrations.
(ii) Every map factors as the composite of a bicoÔ¨Åbration and a weak equivalence.
Then the gluing lemma holds.
Proof. We use the notations of DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1(iii) and proceed in three cases.
If f and f ‚Ä≤ are both weak equivalences, then, by (i), so are the horizontal arrows
in the commutative diagram

and the two out of three property imply that Y ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚à™X X‚Ä≤, Y ‚à™X X‚Ä≤ ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚Ä≤,
Y ‚à™X Z ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚à™X Z‚Ä≤, and Y ‚à™X Z‚Ä≤ ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚Ä≤‚à™X‚Ä≤ Z‚Ä≤ are weak equivalences. Composing
the last two, Y ‚à™X Z ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚Ä≤ ‚à™X‚Ä≤ Z‚Ä≤ is a weak equivalence.
To prove the general case, construct the following commutative diagram.

Here we Ô¨Årst factor f as the composite of a bicoÔ¨Åbration and a weak equivalence
¬Øf and then deÔ¨Åne a map ¬Øf ‚Ä≤ by the universal property of pushouts. By hypothesis

Remark 5.4.4. Clearly the previous result applies to any categories of weak
equivalences and coÔ¨Åbrations that satisfy (i) and (ii). The essential point is that,
in practice, we often need bicoÔ¨Åbrations in order to verify (i).
Similarly, but more simply, the following observation reduces the veriÔ¨Åcation
of DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1(v) to special cases. Here we assume that C is based.

Together with Lemma 5.3.5, the notion of a well-grounded category of weak
equivalences encodes a variant of Lemma 4.5.8 that often applies when the latter
does not.
Lemma 5.4.6. If J is a set of acyclic cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations between well-grounded
objects, then all relative J-cell complexes are weak equivalences.
Proof. This follows from (ii), (iii), and (iv) of DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1, together with
the observation that if X0 ‚àí‚ÜíX is a relative J-cell complex, then X/X0 is a J-cell
complex and is therefore well-grounded, so that (iv) applies.
‚ñ°
There is an analogous reduction of the problem of determining when a functor
preserves weak equivalences.
Lemma 5.4.7. Let F : C ‚àí‚ÜíD be a functor between topologically bicomplete
categories that come equipped with subcategories of well-grounded weak equivalences
with respect to given ground structures. Let J be a set of acyclic cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations
between well-grounded objects in C . Assume that F has a continuous right adjoint
and that F takes maps in J to weak equivalences between well-grounded objects.
Then F takes a retract of a relative J-cell complex to an acyclic map in D.
Proof. The functor F preserves cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations since it has a continuous right
adjoint and hence FJ consists of acyclic cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations between well-grounded ob-
jects. The conclusion follows from Lemma 5.4.6, the fact that left adjoints commute
with colimits, and (ii)‚Äì(iv) of DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1.
‚ñ°

90
5. WELL-GROUNDED TOPOLOGICAL MODEL CATEGORIES
The following classical example is implicit in the literature.
Proposition 5.4.8. The q-equivalences in GK are well-grounded with respect
to the ground structure whose well-grounded objects are the compactly generated
spaces and whose g-coÔ¨Åbrations are the h-coÔ¨Åbrations.
Proof. Parts (i), (ii), and, here in the unbased case, (v) of DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1
are clear, and (iv) follows easily from Lemma 1.6.5.
The essential point is the
gluing lemma of (iii). By passage to Ô¨Åxed point spaces, it suÔ¨Éces to prove this
nonequivariantly. Using the gluing lemma for the proper h-model structure on K ,
we see that f and f ‚Ä≤ can be replaced by their mapping cylinders. Then the induced
map of pushouts is the map of double mapping cylinders induced by the original
diagram. This map is equivalent to a map of excisive triads, and in that case the
result is [117, 1.3], whose proof is corrected in [173].
‚ñ°
Proposition 5.4.9. The q-equivalences in GK /B and GKB are well-grounded
with respect to the ground structures of Proposition 5.3.7. In these cases, one need
only assume that the relevant maps in the gluing and colimit lemmas are ground
coÔ¨Åbrations (= h-coÔ¨Åbrations), not both ground and Cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations.
Proof. We verify this for GKB. Part (i) of DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1 holds since any fp-
equivalence is a q-equivalence and part (iii) follows directly from the gluing lemma
in GK . For part (ii), the total space of ‚à®BXi is the pushout in GK of
B
‚®øB
o
/ ‚®øXi.
Since the Xi are well-grounded, the map on the right is an h-coÔ¨Åbration, hence
(ii) also follows from the gluing lemma in GK . In part (iv), the relevant quotient
in GKB is given by the pushout, X/BX0, of the diagram ‚àóB ‚Üê‚àíX0 ‚àí‚ÜíX.
Since X/BX0 is well-grounded, the quotient total space is in U and one can apply
Lemma 1.6.5 just as on the space level. Finally consider (v). As in the proof of
Proposition 5.3.7(vi), X ‚àßB K can be constructed as the pushout of the following
diagram of f-coÔ¨Åbrant spaces over B.
B

The inclusion on the right is an f-coÔ¨Åbration. By the gluing lemma in GK , the
functor X ‚àßB K preserves q-equivalences in both variables since the functor X √ó K
evidently does so.
‚ñ°
5.5. Well-grounded compactly generated model structures
Let C be a topologically bicomplete category or, equivariantly, a G-topologically
bicomplete G-category. In the notion of a ‚Äúwell-grounded model structure‚Äù, we for-
mulate the properties that a compactly generated model structure on C should
have in order to mesh well with the intrinsic Cyl-structure on C described in ¬ß4.3.
When C has such a model structure, and when the classical Cyl-structure actually
is a model structure, the identity functor on C is a Quillen left adjoint from the
well-grounded model structure to the Cyl-model structure. Thus this notion gives
a precise axiomatization for the implementaton of the philosophy that we adver-
tised in ¬ß4.1. We begin with a variant of Theorem 4.5.6. Recall the deÔ¨Ånitions
of a ground structure from DeÔ¨Ånitions 5.3.2 and 5.3.3, of a subcategory of well-
grounded weak equivalences from DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1, and of a compact set of maps
from DeÔ¨Ånition 4.5.1.

5.6. PROPERTIES OF WELL-GROUNDED MODEL CATEGORIES
91
Theorem 5.5.1. Let C be a topologically bicomplete category with a ground
structure, a subcategory of well-grounded weak equivalences, and compact sets I
and J of maps that satisfy the following conditions.
(i) (Acyclicity condition) Every map in J is a weak equivalence.
(ii) (Compatibility condition) A map has the RLP with respect to I if and only if
it is a weak equivalence and has the RLP with respect to J.
(iii) Every map in I and J is a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration between well-grounded objects.
Then C is a compactly generated model category with generating sets I and J of
coÔ¨Åbrations and acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations. Every coÔ¨Åbration is a bicoÔ¨Åbration and every
coÔ¨Åbrant object is well-grounded. A pushout of a weak equivalence along a bicoÔ¨Å-
bration is a weak equivalence and, in particular, the model structure is left proper.
The model structure is topological or, equivariantly, G-topological if the following
condition holds.
(iv) i‚ñ°j is a relative I-cell complex if i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a map in I and j : K ‚àí‚ÜíL
is a map in J (that is, in the set I of generating coÔ¨Åbrations of spaces or
G-spaces), and i‚ñ°j is a relative J-cell complex if i is in I and j is in J or if
i is in J and j is in I.
Proof. By Lemma 5.4.6, Theorem 4.5.6 applies to verify the model axioms.
Condition (iii) implies the statements about coÔ¨Åbrations and coÔ¨Åbrant objects by
Lemma 5.3.5, and the gluing lemma implies the statement about pushouts of weak
equivalences.
In the last statement, j is in the set I of generating coÔ¨Åbrations
or the set J of generating acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations in the relevant category of (based
or unbased) spaces, as speciÔ¨Åed in DeÔ¨Ånition 4.5.10. By passage to coproducts,
pushouts, sequential colimits, and retracts, (iv) implies that i‚ñ°j is a coÔ¨Åbration if
i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a coÔ¨Åbration in C and j : K ‚àí‚ÜíL is a q-coÔ¨Åbration of spaces (or
G-spaces) and is acyclic if either i or j is so, which means that the model structure
is topological.
‚ñ°
Remark 5.5.2. We emphasize the fundamental diÔ¨Äerence between the acyclic-
ity conditions stated in Theorem 4.5.6 and in Theorem 5.5.1. In the applications
of the former, it is the veriÔ¨Åcation of the acyclicity of J-cell complexes that is
problemmatic, but in the latter our axiomatization has built in that veriÔ¨Åcation.
Remark 5.5.3. The conclusions of Theorem 5.5.1 still hold if in (iii) we only re-
quire cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations, rather than cyl coÔ¨Åbrations. The stronger assumption holds
in all examples we know, and it is needed to implement our philosophy comparing
h-type and q-type model structures via a Quillen adjunction. Note, however, that
the theorem holds whether or not the homotopy equivalences, ¬Ø
cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations, and
cyl-Ô¨Åbrations actually specify an h-type model structure.
Definition 5.5.4. A compactly generated model structure on C is said to be
well-grounded if it is right proper and satisÔ¨Åes all of the hypotheses of the preceding
theorem. It follows that C is proper and topological or, equivariantly, G-topological.
5.6. Properties of well-grounded model categories
Assume that C is a well-grounded model category throughout this section. To
derive properties of its homotopy category HoC , we must sort out the relationship
between homotopies deÔ¨Åned in terms of cylinders and homotopies in the model

92
5. WELL-GROUNDED TOPOLOGICAL MODEL CATEGORIES
theoretic sense, which we call ‚Äúmodel homotopies‚Äù. We adopt the following slightly
non-standard deÔ¨Ånition of [56, 4.2].
Definition 5.6.1. A cylinder object for X is an object Y together with maps
i0 : X ‚àí‚ÜíY , i1 : X ‚àí‚ÜíY and p: Y ‚àí‚ÜíX such that pi0 = id = pi1 and p is a
weak equivalence; Y is a good cylinder object if the map i: X ‚®øX ‚àí‚ÜíY given by
i0 and i1 is a coÔ¨Åbration; Y is a very good cylinder object if, further, p is a Ô¨Åbration.
Of course, the cylinder objects Cyl(X) in C have maps i0, i1 : X ‚àí‚ÜíCyl(X)
and p: Cyl(X) ‚àí‚ÜíX. Since tensors with spaces preserve homotopies in the space
variable, i0 (or i1) and p are inverse homotopy equivalences. DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1(i)
ensures that p is therefore a weak equivalence. Thus Cyl(X) is a model theoretic
cylinder object in C . It need not be a good cylinder object. As pointed out in [56, p.
90], this already fails for spaces, where the inclusion X ‚®øX ‚àí‚ÜíX √ó I need not be
a q-coÔ¨Åbration unless X is q-coÔ¨Åbrant. Note however that i: X ‚®øX ‚àí‚ÜíCyl(X) is
a Cyl-coÔ¨Åbration for any X, by Theorem 4.3.2.
Remark 5.6.2. The standard deÔ¨Ånition of cylinder objects in [73, 75, 139] re-
quires i to be a coÔ¨Åbration.
An alternative deÔ¨Ånition of ‚Äúgood cylinders‚Äù that
includes all standard cylinders in the category of spaces is given in [144].
We record the following observations.
Lemma 5.6.3. Consider maps f, g: X ‚àí‚ÜíY in C .
(i) If f is homotopic to g, then f is left model homotopic to g.
(ii) If X is coÔ¨Åbrant, then Cyl(X) is a good cylinder object.
(iii) If X is coÔ¨Åbrant and Y is Ô¨Åbrant, then f is homotopic to g if and only if f is
left and right model homotopic to g.
Proof. Part (i) is [56, 4.6], part (ii) follows from DeÔ¨Ånition 5.3.2(iii), and part
(iii) follows from [56, 4.23].
‚ñ°
Let [X, Y ] denote the set of morphisms X ‚àí‚ÜíY in HoC and let œÄ(X, Y )
denote the set of homotopy classes of maps X ‚àí‚ÜíY . Recall the following fact,
which holds in any model category [75, I.2.10(ii)].
Lemma 5.6.4. The natural map œÄ(X, Y ) ‚àí‚Üí[X, Y ] is a bijection if X is coÔ¨Å-
brant and Y is Ô¨Åbrant.
We use this to obtain homotopy category conclusions from elementary classical
arguments with homotopy classes of maps. In all of the following results, we trans-
port conclusions obtained by standard arguments with morphism sets œÄ(X, Y ) in
the classical homotopy category hC to conclusions in the homotopy category HoC
by assuming that Y is Ô¨Åbrant and applying coÔ¨Åbrant approximation to the variable
X. The essential point is to check that coÔ¨Åbrant approximation preserves the con-
structions we consider. The well-groundedness of C gives exactly what is needed
for these veriÔ¨Åcations. We assume that C is based in the rest of the section.
Lemma 5.6.5 (CoÔ¨Åber sequence lemma). Consider the coÔ¨Åber sequence
X ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚àí‚ÜíCf ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£X ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£Y ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£Cf ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£2X ‚àí‚Üí¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑
of a map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY between well-grounded objects. For any object Z, the induced
sequence
¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ ‚àí‚Üí[Œ£n+1X, Z] ‚àí‚Üí[Œ£nCf, Z] ‚àí‚Üí[Œ£nY, Z] ‚àí‚Üí[Œ£nX, Z] ‚àí‚Üí¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ ‚àí‚Üí[X, Z]

5.6. PROPERTIES OF WELL-GROUNDED MODEL CATEGORIES
93
of pointed sets (groups left of [Œ£X, Z], Abelian groups left of [Œ£2X, Z]) is exact.
Proof. As usual, giving I the basepoint 1, we deÔ¨Åne
CX = X ‚àßI,
Œ£X = X ‚àßS1,
and
Cf = Y ‚à™f CX.
If X is coÔ¨Åbrant, then X is well-grounded and X ‚àí‚ÜíCX is a coÔ¨Åbration and
therefore a bicoÔ¨Åbration. If X and Y are coÔ¨Åbrant, then so is Cf, as one sees by
solving the relevant lifting problem by Ô¨Årst using that Y is coÔ¨Åbrant, then using
that X ‚àí‚ÜíCX is a coÔ¨Åbration, and Ô¨Ånally using that Cf is a pushout. Thus,
taking Z to be Ô¨Åbrant, the conclusion follows in this case from the sequence of
homotopy classes of maps
¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ ‚àí‚ÜíœÄ(Œ£X, Z) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄ(Cf, Z) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄ(Y, Z) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄ(X, Z),
which is proven to be exact in the same way as on the space level.
If X and
Y are not coÔ¨Åbrant, let Qf : QX ‚àí‚ÜíQY be a coÔ¨Åbrant approximation to f.
The gluing lemma applies to give that the canonical map CQf ‚àí‚ÜíCf is a weak
equivalence. Therefore the conclusion follows in general from the special case of
coÔ¨Åbrant objects.
‚ñ°
Warning 5.6.6. While the proof just given is very simple, it hides substantial
subtleties.
It is crucial that coÔ¨Åbrant objects X be well-grounded, so that the
cyl-coÔ¨Åbration X ‚àí‚ÜíCX is a bicoÔ¨Åbration and the gluing lemma applies.
Of course, the group structures are deÔ¨Åned just as classically. The pinch maps
S1 ‚àº= I/{0, 1} ‚àí‚ÜíI/{0, 1
2, 1} ‚àº= S1 ‚à®S1
and
I ‚àí‚ÜíI/{ 1
2, 1} ‚àº= I ‚à®S1
induce pinch maps
Œ£X ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£X ‚à®Œ£X
and
Cf ‚àí‚ÜíCf ‚à®Œ£X
that give Œ£X the structure of a cogroup object in HoC and Cf a coaction by
Œ£X; Œ£2X is an abelian cogroup object for the same reason that higher homotopy
groups are abelian.
Therefore [Œ£X, Z] is a group, [Cf, Z] is a [Œ£X, Z]-set, and
[Œ£X, Z] ‚àí‚Üí[Cf, Z] is a [Œ£X, Z]-map.
Lemma 5.6.7 (Wedge lemma). For well-grounded objects Xi and any object Z
in C , [‚®øXi, Z] ‚àº= Œ†[Xi, Z].
Proof. Since a coproduct of weak equivalences between well-grounded objects
is a weak equivalence, we see that a coproduct of coÔ¨Åbrant approximations of well-
grounded objects is a coÔ¨Åbrant approximation.
‚ñ°
Similarly, we can develop the elementary theory of classical homotopy colimits.
It would take us too far aÔ¨Åeld to go into full details of what should be standard
arguments, but we give a sketch since we cannot Ô¨Ånd our preferred development in
the literature.

g: W ‚àí‚ÜíY between well-grounded objects and any object Z, there is a natural

Definition 5.6.10. The classical homotopy coequalizer C(f, g), or mapping
torus, of a pair of parallel maps f, g: X ‚àí‚ÜíY is the homotopy pushout of the sum
f + g: X ‚®øX ‚àí‚ÜíY (which restricts to f and g on the two copies of X) and the
codiagonal ‚àá: X ‚®øX ‚àí‚ÜíX.
Algebraic inspection from Lemma 5.6.9 gives the following calculation.
Lemma 5.6.11 (Mapping torus lemma). For maps f, g: X ‚àí‚ÜíY between well-
grounded objects and any object Z, there is a surjection from [C(f, g), Z] to the
equalizer of the maps f ‚àóand g‚àófrom [Y, Z] to [X, Z]. Its kernel is isomorphic to
the set of orbits of [Œ£X, Z] under the right action of [Œ£Y, Z] speciÔ¨Åed by
xy = (Œ£f)‚àó(y)‚àí1x(Œ£g)‚àó(y).
Definition 5.6.12. The classical homotopy colimit or telescope Tel Xn of maps
fn : Xn ‚àí‚ÜíXn+1 is the homotopy coequalizer of the identity map and the coprod-
uct of the fn, both being self maps of the coproduct of the Xn.
We shall often use the alternative notation hocolim Xn for Tel Xn. Algebraic
inspection from Lemma 5.6.9 gives a lim1 exact sequence.
Lemma 5.6.13 (Telescope lemma). For a sequence of maps fn : Xn ‚àí‚ÜíXn+1
between well-grounded objects and any object Y , there is an exact sequence of pointed
sets
‚àó‚àí‚Üílim1 [Œ£Xn, Y ] ‚àí‚Üí[Tel Xn, Y ] ‚àí‚Üílim [Xn, Y ] ‚àí‚Üí‚àó.
Lemma 5.6.14 (Lim1 lemma). Let X be the colimit of a sequence of cyl-
coÔ¨Åbrations in : Xn ‚àí‚ÜíXn+1 between well-grounded objects. Then there is a nat-
ural weak equivalence Tel Xn ‚àí‚ÜíX and a resulting lim1 exact sequence for the
calculation of [X, Y ].

Proof. By a standard direct comparison, the telescope Tel Xn is isomorphic to
colim Tn, where the Tn, together with a ladder of weak equivalences jn : Xn ‚àí‚ÜíTn
and rn : Tn ‚àí‚ÜíXn, are constructed inductively by setting T0 = X0 and letting
jn+1 and rn+1 be the maps of pushouts induced by the following diagram.
