Remark 5.6.15. Let C be an arbitrary pointed model category with (for sim-
plicity) a functorial cylinder construction Cyl. If X is coÔ¨Åbrant, let Œ£X denote the
quotient Cyl(X)/(X ‚à®X). Quillen [139] constructed a natural cogroup structure
on Œ£X in HoC . For a coÔ¨Åbration X ‚àí‚ÜíY between coÔ¨Åbrant objects, he also
constructed a natural coaction of Œ£X on the quotient Y/X. One can then deÔ¨Åne
coÔ¨Åber sequences in HoC just as in the homotopy category of a topological model
category, and one can deÔ¨Åne Ô¨Åber sequences dually.
The coÔ¨Åber sequences and Ô¨Åber sequences each give HoC a suitably weakened
form of the notion of a triangulation, called a ‚Äúpretriangulation‚Äù [75,139], and they
are suitably compatible. If HoC is closed symmetric monoidal one can take this a
step further and formulate what it means for the pretriangulation to be compatible
with that structure, as was done in [124] for triangulated categories.
However,
proving the compatibility axioms from this general point of view would at best be
exceedingly laborious, if it could be done at all.
These purely model theoretic constructions of the suspension and looping func-
tors Œ£ and ‚Ñ¶are more closely related to the familiar topological constructions than
might appear. The homotopy category of any model category is enriched and biten-
sored over the homotopy category of spaces (obtained from the q-model structure)
[55,75], and the suspension and loop functors are given by the (derived) tensor and
cotensor with the unit circle. That is, Œ£X ‚âÉX ‚àßS1 and ‚Ñ¶X ‚âÉF(S1, X).
This general point of view is not one that we wish to emphasize. For topological
model categories, the structure described in this section is far easier to deÔ¨Åne and
work with directly, as in classical homotopy theory, and we have axiomatized what
is required of a model structure in order to allow the use of such standard and
elementary classical methods. In our topological context, the homotopy category
HoC is automatically enriched over HoK‚àóand (Œ£, ‚Ñ¶) is a Quillen adjoint pair that
descends to an adjoint pair on homotopy categories that agrees with the purely
model theoretic adjoint pair just described.
The crucial point for our stable work is that a large part of this structure exists
before one constructs the desired model structure. It can therefore be used as a
tool for carrying out that construction. This is in fact how stable model categories
were constructed in [61,105,106], but there the compatibility between q-type and

96
5. WELL-GROUNDED TOPOLOGICAL MODEL CATEGORIES
h-type structures was too evident to require much comment. The key step in our
construction of the stable model structure on parametrized spectra in Chapter 12
is to show that coÔ¨Åber sequences induce long exact sequences on stable homotopy
groups. That will allow us to verify that the stable equivalences are suitably well-
grounded, and from there the model axioms follow as in the earlier work just cited.

CHAPTER 6
The qf-model structure on KB
Introduction
In this chapter, we introduce and develop our preferred q-type model structure,
namely the qf-model structure. It is a Quillen equivalent variant of the q-model
structure that has fewer, and better structured, coÔ¨Åbrations. For clarity of exposi-
tion, we work nonequivariantly in this chapter, which is taken from [152].
We begin by comparing the homotopy theory of spaces and the homotopy
theory of ex-spaces over B, starting with a comparison of the q-model structures
that we have on both. In the category K of spaces, we have the familiar situation
described in ¬ß4.1. The homotopy category HoK that we care about is deÔ¨Åned in
terms of q-equivalences, the intrinsic notion of homotopy is given by the classical
cylinders, and, since all spaces are q-Ô¨Åbrant, the category HoK is equivalent to
the classical homotopy category hKc of q-coÔ¨Åbrant spaces (or CW complexes).
Since the q-coÔ¨Åbrations are h-coÔ¨Åbrations, the q-model structure and the h-model
structure on K mesh smoothly. Indeed, the classical and model theoretic homotopy
theory have been used in tandem for so long that this meshing of structures goes
without notice. In particular, although coÔ¨Åber and Ô¨Åber sequences are deÔ¨Åned in
terms of the h-model structure while the homotopy category is deÔ¨Åned in terms of
the q-model structure, the compatibility seems automatic.
Now consider the category KB. The homotopy category HoKB that we care
about is deÔ¨Åned in terms of q-equivalences of total spaces, but we need some justiÔ¨Å-
cation for making that statement. A map of q-Ô¨Åbrant ex-spaces is a q-equivalence of
total spaces if and only if all of its maps on Ô¨Åbers are q-equivalences. This reformula-
tion captures the idea that the homotopical information in parametrized homotopy
theory should be encoded on the Ô¨Åbers, and it is such Ô¨Åberwise q-equivalences that
we really care about. It is only for q-Ô¨Åbrant ex-spaces, or ex-spaces whose projec-
tions are at least quasiÔ¨Åbrations, that the homotopy groups of total spaces give the
‚Äúright answer‚Äù. There are three notions of homotopy in sight, h, f, and fp. The
last of these is the intrinsic one deÔ¨Åned in terms of the relevant cylinders in KB,
and HoKB is equivalent to the classical homotopy category hKBcf of q-coÔ¨Åbrant
and q-Ô¨Åbrant objects, deÔ¨Åned with respect to fp-homotopy. It is still true that
q-coÔ¨Åbrations are h-coÔ¨Åbrations. However, it is not true that q-coÔ¨Åbrations are fp-
coÔ¨Åbrations, and it is the latter that are intrinsic to coÔ¨Åber sequences. The classical
and model theoretic homotopy theory no longer mesh.
Succinctly, the problem is that the q-model structure is not an example of a
well-grounded compactly generated model category. The task that lies before us
is to Ô¨Ånd a model structure which does satisfy the axioms that we set out in ¬ß5.5
and therefore can be used in tandem with the fp-structure to do parametrized
homotopy theory. Before embarking on this, we point out the limitations of the
97

98
6. THE qf-MODEL STRUCTURE ON KB
q-model structure more explicitly in ¬ß6.1. There are two kinds of problems, those
that we are focusing on in our development of the model category theory, and the
more intrinsic ones that account for Counterexample 0.0.1 and which cannot be
overcome model theoretically.
Ideally, to deÔ¨Åne the qf-model structure, we would like to take the qf-coÔ¨Åbra-
tions to be those q-coÔ¨Åbrations that are also f-coÔ¨Åbrations. However, with that
choice, we would not know how to prove the model category axioms. We get closer
if we try to take as generating sets of coÔ¨Åbrations and acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations those
generators in the q-model structure that are f-coÔ¨Åbrations, but with that choice
we still would not be able to prove the compatibility condition Theorem 5.5.1(ii).
However, using this generating set of coÔ¨Åbrations and a subtler choice of a generat-
ing set of acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations, we obtain a precise enough homotopical relationship
to the q-equivalences that we can prove the cited compatibility. The construction of
the qf-model structure is given in ¬ß6.2, but all proofs are deferred to the following
three sections.
6.1. Some of the dangers in the parametrized world
We introduce notation for the generating (acyclic) coÔ¨Åbrations for the q-model
structures on K /B and KB. These maps are identiÔ¨Åed in Proposition 5.1.5, start-
ing from the sets I and J in K speciÔ¨Åed in DeÔ¨Ånition 4.5.10. We then make some
comments about these maps that help explain the structure of our theory.
Definition 6.1.1. For maps i: C ‚àí‚ÜíD and d: D ‚àí‚ÜíB of (unbased) spaces,
we have the restriction d‚ó¶i: C ‚àí‚ÜíB and may view i as a map over B. We agree to
write i(d) for either the map i viewed as a map over B or the map i‚®øid: C ‚®øB ‚àí‚Üí
D‚®øB of ex-spaces over B that is obtained by taking the coproduct with B to adjoin
a section. In either K /B or KB, deÔ¨Åne IB to be the set of all such maps i(d) with
i ‚ààI, and deÔ¨Åne JB to be the set of all such maps j(d) with j ‚ààJ. Observe that
in KB, each map in JB is the inclusion of a deformation retract of spaces under,
but not over, B.
Warning 6.1.2. We cannot restrict the maps d to be open here. That is one
of the reasons we chose KB over O‚àó(B) in ¬ß1.3.
Warning 6.1.3. The maps in IB and JB are clearly not f-coÔ¨Åbrations, only
h-coÔ¨Åbrations. Looking at the NDR-pair characterization of f-coÔ¨Åbrations given in
Lemma 5.2.4, we see that, with our arbitrary projections d, there is in general no
way to carry out the required deformation over B. Since the maps in IB and JB
are maps between well-sectioned spaces, they cannot be fp-coÔ¨Åbrations in general,
by Proposition 5.2.3(i).
Remark 6.1.4. Observe that the maps i in IB or JB are closed inclusions
in U , so that those maps in IB or JB which are f-coÔ¨Åbrations are necessarily
¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations and therefore both ¬Ø
fp-coÔ¨Åbrations and ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations, by Proposi-
tion 5.1.9 and Theorem 5.2.8.
Warning 6.1.3 shows that the q-model structure is not well-grounded since
its generating (acyclic) coÔ¨Åbrations are not fp-coÔ¨Åbrations. This may sound like a
minor technicality, but that is far from the case. We record an elementary example.
Counterexample 6.1.5. Let B = I and deÔ¨Åne an ex-map i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY over I
by letting X = {0} ‚®øI, Y = I ‚®øI, and i be the inclusion. The second copies of I

6.1. SOME OF THE DANGERS IN THE PARAMETRIZED WORLD
99
give the sections, and the projections are given by the identity map on each copy of
I. This is a typical generating acyclic q-coÔ¨Åbration, and it is not an fp-coÔ¨Åbration.
Let Z be the pushout of i and p: X ‚àí‚ÜíI, where the latter is viewed as a map
of ex-spaces over I. Then Z is the one-point union I ‚à®I obtained by identifying
the points 0. The section I ‚àí‚ÜíZ is not an f-coÔ¨Åbration, so that Z is not well-
sectioned. The same is true if we replace Y by Y ‚Ä≤ = {1/(n + 1) | n ‚ààN} ‚®øI and
obtain Z‚Ä≤. The map Z‚Ä≤ ‚àí‚ÜíCIZ‚Ä≤ of Z‚Ä≤ into its cone over I is not an h-coÔ¨Åbration
(and therefore not a q-coÔ¨Åbration).
Thus we cannot apply the classical gluing lemma to develop coÔ¨Åber sequences,
as we did in ¬ß5.6. This and related problems prevent use of the q-model structure
in a rigorous development of parametrized stable homotopy theory. For example,
consider q-Ô¨Åbrant approximation. If we have a map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY with q-Ô¨Åbrant
approximation Rf : RX ‚àí‚ÜíRY , there is no reason to believe that CBRf is q-
equivalent to RCBf.
We are about to overcome model-theoretically the problems pointed out in the
warnings above. Turning to the intrinsic problems that must hold in any q-type
model structure, we explain why the base change functor f ‚àóand the internal smash
product cannot be Quillen left adjoints.
Warning 6.1.6. If f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB is a map and d: D ‚àí‚ÜíB is a disk over B, we
have no homotopical control over the pullback A √óB D ‚àí‚ÜíA in general.
Warning 6.1.7. In sharp contrast to the nonparametrized case, the generating
sets do not behave well with respect to internal smash products, although they do
behave well with respect to external smash products. We have
(D ‚®øA) ‚äº(E ‚®øB) ‚àº= (D √ó E) ‚®ø(A √ó B).
If the projections of D and E are d and e, then the projection of D √ó E is d √ó e.
However, if A = B, then
(D ‚®øB) ‚àßB (E ‚®øB) ‚àº= (d √ó e)‚àí1(‚àÜB) ‚®ø(A √ó B).
We have no homotopical control over the space (d √ó e)‚àí1(‚àÜB) in general.
This has the unfortunate consequence that, when we go on to parametrized
spectra in Part III, we will not be able to develop a homotopically well-behaved
theory of point-set level parametrized ring spectra. However, we will be able to
develop a satisfactory point-set level theory of parametrized module spectra over
nonparametrized ring spectra.
As a Ô¨Ånal warning of problems ahead, we observe that the Ô¨Åniteness (or com-
pactness) of our generating cells is no longer present on Ô¨Åbers after Ô¨Åbrant approx-
imation, which throws out some of our intuitions. This observation will imply that
Ô¨Ånite cell spectra are generally not dualizable in the traditional Ô¨Åberwise sense.
We will develop a quite diÔ¨Äerent duality theory, Costenoble‚ÄìWaner duality, under
which they are dualizable in Chapter 18.
Warning 6.1.8. No matter what q-type model structure one considers, the
generating cells are not Ô¨Åbrant. Let (Dn, p) be a disk over B and let ( ÀúB, q) be the
universal cover of B. Lift p to a map Àúp: Dn ‚àí‚ÜíÀúB. If B = K(œÄ, 1), then Àúp is
an equivalence and ( ÀúB, q) is a Ô¨Åbrant approximation to (Dn, p). For example, if
B = S1, then R is a Ô¨Åbrant approximation of any disk over B, and the derived

100
6. THE qf-MODEL STRUCTURE ON KB
Ô¨Åber is Z. We can adjoin a disjoint section to form an ex-space (Dn, p)+ over B,
and ( ÀúB, q)+ is a Ô¨Åbrant approximation to it in the category of ex-spaces over B.
6.2. The qf model structure on the category K /B
Rather than start with a model structure on K to obtain model structures
on K /B and KB, we can start with a model structure on K /B and then apply
Proposition 5.1.4 to obtain a model structure on KB. This gives us the opportunity
to restrict the classes of generating (acyclic) coÔ¨Åbrations present in the q-model
structure on K /B to ones that are f-coÔ¨Åbrations, retaining enough of them that
we do not lose homotopical information. This has the eÔ¨Äect that the generating
(acyclic) coÔ¨Åbrations are f-coÔ¨Åbrations between well-grounded spaces over B, as
is required of a well-grounded model structure. Such maps have closed images,
hence are ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations, and therefore all of the coÔ¨Åbrations in the resulting model
structure on K /B are ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations.
We call the resulting model structure the ‚Äúqf-model structure‚Äù, where f refers
to the Ô¨Åberwise coÔ¨Åbrations that are used and q refers to the weak equivalences.
The latter are the same as in the q-model structure, namely the weak equivalences
on total spaces, or q-equivalences.
This model structure restores us to a situa-
tion in which the philosophy advertised in ¬ß4.1 applies, with the q and h-model
structures on spaces replaced by the qf and f-model structures on spaces over B.
Since f-coÔ¨Åbrations in KB are fp-coÔ¨Åbrations, by Proposition 5.1.9, the philoso-
phy also applies to the qf and fp-model structures on KB, or at least on UB (see
Theorem 5.2.8 and Remark 5.2.9).
We need some notations and recollections in order to describe the generating
(acyclic) qf-coÔ¨Åbrations and the qf-Ô¨Åbrations.
Notation 6.2.1. For each n ‚â•1, embed Rn‚àí1 in Rn = Rn‚àí1 √ó R by sending
x to (x, 0). Let en = (0, 1) ‚ààRn. For n ‚â•0, deÔ¨Åne the following subspaces of Rn.

With these deÔ¨Ånitions in place, we have the following theorem.
Recall the
deÔ¨Ånition of a well-grounded model category from DeÔ¨Ånition 5.5.4 and recall from
Propositions 5.3.7 and 5.4.9 that we have ground structures on K /B and KB with
respect to which the q-equivalences are well-grounded. Also recall the deÔ¨Ånition of
a quasiÔ¨Åbration from DeÔ¨Ånition 3.6.1.

102
6. THE qf-MODEL STRUCTURE ON KB
Theorem 6.2.5. The category K /B of spaces over B is a well-grounded model
category with respect to the q-equivalences, qf-Ô¨Åbrations and qf-coÔ¨Åbrations. The
sets If
B and Jf
B are the generating qf-coÔ¨Åbrations and the generating acyclic qf-
coÔ¨Åbrations.
All qf-coÔ¨Åbrations are also ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations and all qf-Ô¨Åbrations are
quasiÔ¨Åbrations.
Using Proposition 5.1.4 and Proposition 5.1.5, we obtain the qf-model structure
on KB. We deÔ¨Åne a qf-Ô¨Åbration in KB to be a map which is a qf-Ô¨Åbration when
regarded as a map in K /B, and similarly for qf-coÔ¨Åbrations.
Theorem 6.2.6. The category KB of ex-spaces over B is a well-grounded model
category with respect to the q-equivalences, qf-Ô¨Åbrations, and qf-coÔ¨Åbrations. The
sets If
B and Jf
B of generating qf-coÔ¨Åbrations and generating acyclic qf-coÔ¨Åbrations
are obtained by adjoining disjoint sections to the corresponding sets of maps in
K /B. All qf-coÔ¨Åbrations are ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations and all qf-Ô¨Åbrations are quasiÔ¨Åbra-
tions.
Since the qf-model structures are well-grounded, they are in particular proper
and topological. Furthermore, the qf-coÔ¨Åbrant spaces over B are well-grounded
and the qf-Ô¨Åbrant spaces over B are quasiÔ¨Åbrant, but of course not conversely.
Since qf-coÔ¨Åbrations are q-coÔ¨Åbrations, we have an obvious comparison.
Theorem 6.2.7. The identity functor is a left Quillen equivalence from K /B
with the qf-model structure to K /B with the q-model structure, and similarly for
the identity functor on KB.
The following result, which implements the philosophy of ¬ß4.1, is false for the
q-model structure. It implies that an acyclic qf-coÔ¨Åbration is an f-equivalence and
not just an h-equivalence, although it still need not be an fp-equivalence in the
case of KB.
Theorem 6.2.8. The identity functor is a left Quillen adjoint from K /B with
the qf-model structure to K /B with the f-model structure. Therefore the identity
functor is a left Quillen adjoint from KB with the qf-model structure to KB with
the f-model structure.
The one real advantage that the q-model structure has over the qf-model struc-
ture is that naturally occurring q-coÔ¨Åbrant ex-spaces are far more common than
naturally occurring qf-coÔ¨Åbrant ex-spaces. The scarcity of qf-coÔ¨Åbrations will force
us to introduce a number of variants of the qf-model structure in the next chapter,
as the following warning illustrates.
Warning 6.2.9. Let B be a cell complex. Then S0
B = (B, id)+ is q-coÔ¨Åbrant
in GKB, but it is not qf-coÔ¨Åbrant with the qf-model structure speciÔ¨Åed in this
chapter. In fact, (K, p)+ is q-coÔ¨Åbrant but not necessarily qf-coÔ¨Åbrant for any cell
complex K.
We state and prove two technical lemmas in ¬ß6.3, prove that K /B is a com-
pactly generated model category in ¬ß6.4, and prove that the qf-Ô¨Åbrations are quasi-
Ô¨Åbrations and the model structure is right proper in ¬ß6.5.
6.3. Statements and proofs of the thickening lemmas
We need two technical ‚Äúthickening lemmas‚Äù. They encapsulate the idea that
no information about homotopy groups is lost if we restrict from the general disks

and cells used in the q-model structure to the f-disks and f-cells that we use in the
qf-model structure.

Turning to the ‚ñ°-product condition, Theorem 5.5.1(iv), let i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY be a
map in K /B and j : K ‚àí‚ÜíL be a map in K . We must show that if i is in If
B and j

B. If we were working with the q-model structure, this would
be evident from the fact that a product of cell-boundary pairs is homeomorphic to
a cell-boundary pair. In our situation, by the Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair characterization
of f-coÔ¨Åbrations and a standard argument for product pairs (for example, [121, p.
43]), the boundary inclusion i‚ñ°j is an f-coÔ¨Åbration since i is an f-coÔ¨Åbration and j
is an h-coÔ¨Åbration. This gives that i‚ñ°j is in If
B, as required, and it follows that the
‚ñ°-product of a qf-coÔ¨Åbration in KB and a q-coÔ¨Åbration in K is a qf-coÔ¨Åbration.
Elaborating on this observation, we can show that if i is in Jf
B and j is in I or if i
is in If
B and j is in J, then i‚ñ°j is in Jf
B. However, it is worth observing that we do

6.5. THE QUASIFIBRATION AND RIGHT PROPERNESS PROPERTIES
107
not need such precision to conclude that the qf-model structure is topological. It is
simpler and more general to observe that i‚ñ°j is a generating acyclic q-coÔ¨Åbration
if i ‚ààIB and j ‚ààJ or i ‚ààJB and j ‚ààI, by inspection of cells exactly as in
the unparametrized context. Therefore the acyclicity condition required for the
q-model structure to be topological holds. The acyclicity condition required for the
qf-model structure to be topological is a special case.
6.5. The quasiÔ¨Åbration and right properness properties
We have now established the qf-model structures on both K /B and KB. We
will derive the right properness of K /B, and therefore of KB, from the fact that
every qf-Ô¨Åbration is a quasiÔ¨Åbration.

Ô¨Åbration. Therefore, for any choice of e ‚ààE, there results a long exact sequence of
homotopy groups

Corollary 6.5.2. The qf-model structure on K /B is right proper.
Proof. Since qf-Ô¨Åbrations are preserved under pullbacks, this is a Ô¨Åve lemma
comparison of long exact sequences as in Proposition 6.5.1.
‚ñ°

CHAPTER 7
Equivariant qf-type model structures
Introduction
We return to the equivariant context in this chapter, letting G be a Lie group
throughout. Actually, our deÔ¨Ånitions of the q and qf-model structures work for
arbitrary topological groups G, but we must restrict to Lie groups to obtain struc-
tures that are G-topological and behave well with respect to change of groups and
smash products. A discussion of details special to the non-compact Lie case is given
in ¬ß7.1, which describes the role played by the family G of compact subgroups of
a Lie group G, but after that the generalization from compact to non-compact Lie
groups requires no extra work. However, we alert the reader that passage to stable
equivariant homotopy theory raises new problems in the case of non-compact Lie
groups that will not be dealt with in this book; see ¬ß11.6.
The equivariant q-model structure on GKB is just the evident over and under q-
model structure. However, the equivariant generalization of the qf-model structure
is subtle. In fact, the subtlety is already relevant nonequivariantly when we study
base change along the projection of a bundle. The problem is that there are so few
generating qf-coÔ¨Åbrations that many functors that take generating q-coÔ¨Åbrations
to q-coÔ¨Åbrations do not take generating qf-coÔ¨Åbrations to qf-coÔ¨Åbrations. We show
how to get around this in ¬ß7.2. For each such functor that we encounter, we Ô¨Ånd
an enlargement of the obvious sets of (acyclic) generating qf-coÔ¨Åbrations on the
target of the functor so that it is still a model category, but now the functor does
send generating (acyclic) qf-coÔ¨Åbrations to (acyclic) qf-coÔ¨Åbrations.
The point is that there are many diÔ¨Äerent useful choices of Quillen equiva-
lent qf-type model structures, and they can be used in tandem. For all of our
choices, the weak equivalences are the G -equivalences and all coÔ¨Åbrations are both
q-coÔ¨Åbrations and f-coÔ¨Åbrations. Given a Ô¨Ånite number of adjoint pairs with com-
posable left adjoints such that each is a Quillen adjunction with its own choice
of qf-type model structure, we can successively expand generating sets in target
categories of the left adjoints to arrange that the composite be one of Quillen left
adjoints with respect to well chosen qf-type model structures.
In ¬ß7.2, we describe the qf(C )-model structure associated to a ‚Äúgenerating set‚Äù
C of G -complexes. Each such model structure is G-topological. In ¬ß7.3, we show
that external smash products are Quillen adjunctions when C is a ‚Äúclosed‚Äù gener-
ating set, as can always be arranged, and we show that all base change adjunctions
(f!, f ‚àó) are Quillen adjunctions. We show further that there are generating sets for
which (f ‚àó, f‚àó) is a Quillen adjunction when f is a bundle with cellular Ô¨Åbers. In
¬ß7.4, we show similarly that various change of group functors are given by Quillen
adjunctions when the generating sets are well chosen. In ¬ß7.5, we show that HoGKB
has the properties required for application of the Brown representability theorem.
109

110
7. EQUIVARIANT qf-TYPE MODEL STRUCTURES
Those adjunctions between our basic functors that are not given by Quillen adjoint
pairs in any choice of qf-model structure are studied in Chapter 9.
We let [X, Y ]G,B denote the set of maps X ‚àí‚ÜíY in HoGKB. The reader
wishing to focus on the nonequivariant theory should skip ¬ß¬ß7.1, 7.2, and 7.4 on a
Ô¨Årst reading; ¬ß¬ß7.3 and 7.5 work the same way equivariantly and nonequivariantly
and, except for some use of the generalized qf-model structures of ¬ß7.2, are largely
independent of the other sections.
7.1. Families and non-compact Lie groups
There are several sources of problems in the equivariant homotopy theory of
general topological groups G. Two key examples are that we only know that orbit
types G/K are H-CW complexes for H ‚äÇG when G is a Lie group and K is a
compact subgroup, and we only know that a product of orbits G/H √ó G/K is a
G-CW complex when G is a Lie group and either H or K is a compact subgroup.
This motivates us to restrict to Lie groups, for which these conclusions are ensured
by Theorem 3.4.2 and Lemma 3.4.3.
The compactness requirements force us to restrict orbit types when we prove
properties of our model structures, and the family G of all compact subgroups of
our Lie group G plays an important role. We recall the relevant deÔ¨Ånitions, which
apply to any topological group G and are familiar and important in a variety of
contexts. They provide a context that allows us to work with non-compact Lie
groups with no more technical work than is required for compact Lie groups.
A family F in G is a set of subgroups that is closed under passage to subgroups
and conjugates. An F-space is a G-space all of whose isotropy groups are in F.
An F-equivalence is a G-map f such that f H is a weak equivalence for all H ‚ààF.
If X is an F-space, then the only non-empty Ô¨Åxed point sets XH are those for
groups H ‚ààF. In particular, an F-equivalence between F-spaces is the same as
a q-equivalence. For based G-spaces, the deÔ¨Ånition of an F-space must be altered
to require that all isotropy groups except that of the G-Ô¨Åxed base point must be in
F. The notion of an F-equivalence remains unchanged.
A map in GK /B or GKB is an F-equivalence if its map of total G-spaces
is an F-equivalence. If B is an F-space, then so is any G-space X over B and
any Ô¨Åber Xb. The only orbits that can then appear in our parametrized theory are
of the form G/H with H ‚ààF and the only non-empty Ô¨Åxed point sets XH are
those for groups H ‚ààF. In particular, H must be subconjugate to some Gb. An
F-equivalence of G-spaces over an F-space B is the same as a q-equivalence.
It is well-known that equivariant q-type model structures generalize naturally
to families. One takes the weak equivalences to be the F-equivalences, and one
restricts the orbits G/H that appear as factors in the generating (acyclic) coÔ¨Åbra-
tions to be those such that H ‚ààF. The resulting cell complexes are called F-cell
complexes. Restricting tensors from G-spaces to F-spaces, we obtain a restriction
of the notion of a G-topological model category to an F-topological model category
that applies here; see Remark 10.3.5.
Proper G-spaces are particularly well-behaved G -spaces, and G -cell complexes
are proper G-spaces. Restricting base G-spaces to be proper, or more generally to
be G -spaces, has the eÔ¨Äect of restricting all relevant orbit types G/H to ones where
H is compact. However, this is too restrictive for some purposes. For example,
we are interested in developing nonparametrized equivariant homotopy theory for

7.2. THE EQUIVARIANT q AND qf-MODEL STRUCTURES
111
non‚Äìcompact Lie groups G. Here B = ‚àóis a G-space which, in the unbased sense,
is not a G -space.
We therefore do not make the blanket assumption that B is a G -space. We
give the q-model structure in complete generality, in Theorem 7.2.3, but after that
we restrict to G -model structures throughout. That is, our weak equivalences will
be the G -equivalences. This ensures that, after coÔ¨Åbrant approximation, our total
G-spaces are G -spaces. This convention enables us to arrange that all of our model
categories are G-topological. Everything in this chapter applies more generally to
the study of parametrized F-homotopy theory for any family F; see Remark 7.2.14.
The reader may prefer to think in terms of either the case when B = ‚àóor the
case when B is proper. Indeed, in order to resolve the problems intrinsic to the
parametrized context that are described in the Prologue, which we do in Chapter
9, it seems essential that we restrict to proper actions on base spaces. The reason
is that StasheÔ¨Ä‚Äôs Theorem 3.5.2 relating the equivariant homotopy types of Ô¨Åbers
and total spaces plays a fundamental role in the solution. Alternatively, the reader
may prefer to focus just on compact Lie groups, reading q-equivalence instead of
G -equivalence and G-space instead of G -space throughout.
7.2. The equivariant q and qf-model structures
Recall from DeÔ¨Ånition 4.5.10 that the sets I and J of generating coÔ¨Åbrations
and generating acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations of G-spaces are deÔ¨Åned as the sets of all maps
of the form G/H √ó i, where i is in the corresponding set I or J of maps of spaces.
Definition 7.2.1. Starting from the sets I and J of maps of G-spaces, deÔ¨Åne
sets IB and JB of maps of ex-G-spaces over B in exactly the same way that their
nonequivariant counterparts were deÔ¨Åned in terms of the sets I and J of maps of
spaces in DeÔ¨Ånition 6.1.1. Note that if B is a G -space, then only orbits G/H with
H compact appear in the sets IB and JB.
Taking Y = B in the usual composite adjunction
(7.2.2)
GK (G/H √ó T, Y ) ‚àº= HK (T, Y ) ‚àº= K (T, Y H)
for non-equivariant spaces T and G-spaces Y , we can translate back and forth
between equivariant homotopy groups and cells for G-spaces over B on the one hand
and nonequivariant homotopy groups and cells for spaces over BH on the other.
Maps in each of the equivariant sets speciÔ¨Åed in DeÔ¨Ånition 7.2.1 correspond by
adjunction to maps in the nonequivariant set with the same name. Systematically
using this translation, it is easy to use Theorem 4.5.6 to generalize the q-model
structures on K /B and KB to corresponding model structures on GK /B and
GKB. We obtain the following theorem.
Theorem 7.2.3 (q-model structure). The categories GK /B and GKB are
compactly generated proper G -topological model categories whose q-equivalences, q-
Ô¨Åbrations, and q-coÔ¨Åbrations are the maps whose underlying maps of total G-spaces
are q-equivalences, q-Ô¨Åbrations, and q-coÔ¨Åbrations. The sets IB and JB are the
generating q-coÔ¨Åbrations and generating acyclic q-coÔ¨Åbrations, and all q-coÔ¨Åbrations
are ¬Øh-coÔ¨Åbrations. If B is a G -space, then the model structure is G-topological.
To show that the q-model structures are G -topological, and G-topological if B
is a G -space, we must inspect the maps i‚ñ°j in GK /B, where i is a generating

112
7. EQUIVARIANT qf-TYPE MODEL STRUCTURES
q-coÔ¨Åbration in GK /B and j is a generating coÔ¨Åbration in GK . They can be
written in the form
i‚ñ°j : G/H √ó G/K √ó ‚àÇ(Dm √ó Dn) ‚àí‚ÜíG/H √ó G/K √ó Dm √ó Dn,
where i‚ñ°j is the product of the identity map of G/H √ó G/K with the inclusion
of the boundary of Dm √ó Dn. By Lemma 3.4.3, G/H √ó G/K is a proper G-space
if H or K is compact. Since we are assuming that G is a Lie group, we can then
triangulate G/H √ó G/K as a G -CW complex and use the triangulation to write
i‚ñ°j as a relative IB-cell complex. The case when either i or j is acyclic works in
the same way. As explained in Warning 6.1.7, there is no problem with projection
maps in this external context. Moreover, if i and j are f-coÔ¨Åbrations, then so is
i‚ñ°j, as we see from the Ô¨Åberwise NDR pair characterization.
One might be tempted to generalize the qf-model structure to the equivariant
context in exactly the same way as we just did for the q-model structure. This
certainly works to give a model structure. However, there is no reason to think
that it is either G or G -topological. The problem is that we need i‚ñ°j above to be a
qf-coÔ¨Åbration when i is a generating qf-coÔ¨Åbration, and triangulations into f-cells
are hard to come by. Therefore the G-CW structure on G/H √ó G/K will rarely
produce a relative If
B-cell complex.
This means that we must be careful when
selecting the generating (acyclic) qf-coÔ¨Åbrations if we want the resulting model
structure to be G-topological.
We will build the solution into our deÔ¨Ånition of
qf-type model structures, but we need a few preliminaries.
We shall make repeated use of the adjunction
(7.2.4)
GK (C √ó T, Y ) ‚àº= K (T, MapG(C, Y ))
for non-equivariant spaces T and G-spaces C and Y . This is a generalization of
(7.2.2). Taking Y = B, we note in particular that it gives a correspondence between
maps f : T ‚àí‚ÜíT ‚Ä≤ over MapG(C, B) and G-maps id √ó f : C √ó T ‚àí‚ÜíC √ó T ‚Ä≤ over B.
Lemma 7.2.5. For a G -cell complex C, the functor MapG(C, ‚àí): GK ‚àí‚ÜíK
preserves q-equivalences.
Proof. The functor Map(C, ‚àí) is a Quillen right adjoint since the q-model
structure on GK is G -topological.
The G-Ô¨Åxed point functor is also a Quillen
right adjoint, for example by Proposition 7.4.3 below. The composite MapG(C, ‚àí)
therefore preserves q-equivalences between q-Ô¨Åbrant G-spaces. However, every G-
space is q-Ô¨Åbrant.
‚ñ°
Observe that Lemma 3.4.3 gives that the collection of G -cell complexes is closed
under products with arbitrary orbits G/H of G.
Definition 7.2.6. Let OG denote the set of all orbits G/H of G. Any set C
of G -cell complexes in GK that contains all orbits G/K with K ‚ààG and is closed
under products with arbitrary orbits in OG is called a generating set. It is a closed
generating set if it is closed under Ô¨Ånite products. The closure of a generating set
C is the generating set consisting of the Ô¨Ånite products of the G -cell complexes in
C . We deÔ¨Åne sets of generating qf(C )-coÔ¨Åbrations and acyclic qf(C )-coÔ¨Åbrations
in GK /B associated to any generating set C as follows.
(i) Let If
B(C ) consist of the maps
(id √ó i)(d): C √ó Sn‚àí1 ‚àí‚ÜíC √ó Dn

7.2. THE EQUIVARIANT q AND qf-MODEL STRUCTURES
113
such that C ‚ààC , d: C √ó Dn ‚àí‚ÜíB is a G-map, i is the boundary inclusion,
and the corresponding map Àúƒ± over MapG(C, B) is a generating qf-coÔ¨Åbration
in K /MapG(C, B); that is, Àúƒ± must be an f-coÔ¨Åbration.
(ii) Similarly let Jf
B(C ) consist of the maps
(id √ó i)(d): C √ó Sn
+ ‚àí‚ÜíC √ó Dn+1
such that C ‚ààC , d: C √ó Dn+1 ‚àí‚ÜíB is a G-map, i is the inclusion, and the
corresponding map Àúƒ± over MapG(C, B) is a generating acyclic qf-coÔ¨Åbration
in K /MapG(C, B).
Adjoining disjoint sections to these maps, we obtain the corresponding sets If
B(C )
and Jf
B(C ) in GKB.
Fix a generating set C .
We deÔ¨Åne a qf-type model structure based on C ,
called the qf(C )-model structure. Its weak equivalences are the G -equivalences,
which are the same as the q-equivalences when B is a G -space.
We deÔ¨Åne the
qf(C )-Ô¨Åbrations.
Definition 7.2.7. A map f in GK /B is a qf(C )-Ô¨Åbration if MapG(C, f) is
a qf-Ô¨Åbration in K /MapG(C, B) for all C ‚ààC .
A map in GKB is a qf(C )-
Ô¨Åbration if the underlying map in GK /B is one. In either category, a map f is a
G -quasiÔ¨Åbration if f H is a quasiÔ¨Åbration for H ‚ààG .
Theorem 7.2.8 (qf-model structure). For any generating set C , the categories
GK /B and GKB are well-grounded (hence G-topological) model categories. The
weak equivalences and Ô¨Åbrations are the G -equivalences and the qf(C )-Ô¨Åbrations.
The sets If
B(C ) and Jf
B(C ) are the generating qf(C )-coÔ¨Åbrations and the generating
acyclic qf(C )-coÔ¨Åbrations. All qf(C )-coÔ¨Åbrations are both q-coÔ¨Åbrations and ¬Øf-
coÔ¨Åbrations, and all qf(C )-Ô¨Åbrations are G -quasiÔ¨Åbrations.
Proof. Recall from Proposition 5.4.9 that the q-equivalences in GK /B and
GKB are well-grounded with respect to the ground structure given in DeÔ¨Åni-
tion 5.3.6 and Proposition 5.3.7. It follows that the G -equivalences are also well-
grounded. It suÔ¨Éces to verify conditions (i)‚Äì(iv) of Theorem 5.5.1. The acyclicity
condition (i) is inherited from the q-model structure.
Consider the compatibility condition (ii). By the adjunction (7.2.4), a map
f has the RLP with respect to If
B(C ) if and only if MapG(C, f) has the RLP
with respect to If
MapG(C,B) for all C ‚ààC .
By the compatibility condition for
the nonequivariant qf-model structure, that holds if and only if MapG(C, f) is a
q-equivalence and has the LLP with respect to Jf
MapG(C,B) for all C ‚ààC .
By
Lemma 7.2.5, MapG(C, f) is a q-equivalence if f is one. Conversely, if MapG(C, f)
is a q-equivalence for all C ‚ààC , then the case C = G/K shows that f K is a q-
equivalence for every compact K and thus f is a G -equivalence. By the adjunction
again, we see that f has the RLP with respect to If
B(C ) if and only if f is a
G -equivalence which has the RLP with respect to Jf
B(C ).
The Ô¨Åberwise NDR characterization of ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations given in Lemma 5.2.4
shows that If
B(C ) and Jf
B(C ) consist of ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations, as stipulated in (iii). More
precisely, if (u, h), u: Dn ‚àí‚ÜíI and h: Dn √ó I ‚àí‚ÜíDn, represents (Dn, Sn‚àí1) as a
Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair over MapG(C, B), then the map v = u‚ó¶œÄ: C√óDn ‚àí‚ÜíDn ‚àí‚ÜíI
and the homotopy given by the maps id√óht over B corresponding to the ht represent
(C √ó Dn, C √ó Sn‚àí1) as a Ô¨Åberwise NDR pair over B.

7. EQUIVARIANT qf-TYPE MODEL STRUCTURES
Since MapG(G/K, f) ‚àº= f K is a nonequivariant qf-Ô¨Åbration for any qf(C )-
Ô¨Åbration f, every qf(C )-Ô¨Åbration is a G -quasiÔ¨Åbration by Proposition 6.5.1. That
the model structure is right proper follows as in Corollary 6.5.2.
Finally, we must verify the ‚ñ°-product condition (iv). The relevant maps i‚ñ°j,
i: C √ó Sm‚àí1 ‚àí‚ÜíC √ó Dm
and
j : G/H √ó Sn‚àí1 ‚àí‚ÜíG/H √ó Dn,
are of the form
C √ó G/H √ó k: C √ó G/H √ó ‚àÇ(Dm √ó Dn) ‚àí‚ÜíC √ó G/H √ó Dm √ó Dn,
where k is the boundary inclusion. Now C √ó G/H ‚ààC by the closure property
of the generating set, so we don‚Äôt need to triangulate. The projection of the tar-
get factors through the projection of the target C √ó Dm of i.
To see that the
corresponding map k over MapG(C √ó G/H, B) is an ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration, let (u, h) repre-
sent (Dm, Sm‚àí1) as a Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair over MapG(C, B) and let (v, j) represent
(Dn, Sn‚àí1) as an NDR-pair; we can think of the latter as a Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair
over ‚àó= MapG(G/H, ‚àó). Then the usual product pair representation (for example,
[121, p. 43]) exhibits k as a Ô¨Åberwise NDR over MapG(C, B) √ó MapG(G/H, ‚àó) and
thus, by the factorization of the projection of i‚ñ°j, also over MapG(C √ó G/H, B √ó
‚àó).
‚ñ°
Theorem 7.2.9. If C ‚äÇC ‚Ä≤ is an inclusion of generating sets, then the identity
functor is a left Quillen equivalence from GK /B with the qf(C )-model structure
to GK /B with the qf(C ‚Ä≤)-model structure.
The identity functor is also a left
Quillen equivalence from GK /B with the qf(C )-model structure to GK /B with
the q-model structure. Both statements also hold for the identity functor on GKB.
Proof. The Ô¨Årst statement is obvious. For the second, if idC √ói is a generating
qf(C )-coÔ¨Åbration, then C is a G -cell complex and we can use the triangulation to
write idC √ó i as a relative IB-cell complex.
‚ñ°
Theorem 7.2.10. For any C , the identity functor is a left Quillen adjoint
from GK /B with the qf(C )-model structure to GK /B with the f-model structure.
Therefore, the identity functor is a left Quillen adjoint from GKB with the qf(C )-
model structure to GKB with the f-model structure.
Remark 7.2.11. The smallest generating set C is the set of all (non-empty)
Ô¨Ånite products of orbits G/H of G such that at least one of the factors has H
compact.
Clearly it is a closed generating set.
Henceforward, by the qf-model
structure, we mean the qf(C )-model structure associated to this choice of C . In
the nonequivariant case, this is the qf-model structure of the previous chapter.
Remark 7.2.12. In the nonparametrized setting, the G -model structure associ-
ated to the q-model structure and the qf(C )-model structures on GK = GK /‚àóco-
incide, and similarly for GK‚àó. This holds since the f-coÔ¨Åbrations and h-coÔ¨Åbrations
over a point coincide and since the C ‚ààC for any choice of C are G -cell complexes.
Of course, the qf(C )-model structures have more generating (acyclic) coÔ¨Åbrations.
Remark 7.2.13. It might be useful to combine the various qf(C )-model struc-
tures by taking the union of the qf(C )-coÔ¨Åbrations over some suitable collection
of generating sets C and so obtain a ‚Äúclosure‚Äù of the qf-model structure whose
coÔ¨Åbrations are as close as possible to being the intersection of the q-coÔ¨Åbrations
with the ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations. We do not know whether or not that can be done.

7.3. EXTERNAL SMASH PRODUCT AND BASE CHANGE ADJUNCTIONS
115
Remark 7.2.14. As noted in the introduction, we can generalize the q and
qf(C )-model structures to the context of families F. We generalize the q-model
structure to the F-model structure by taking the F-equivalences and F-Ô¨Åbrations
and by restricting the sets IB and JB to be constructed from orbits G/H with
H ‚ààF. The resulting model structure will then be (F ‚à©G )-topological and F-
topological if the base space B is a G -space.
To generalize the qf(C ) model structure, we take the weak equivalences to be
the F ‚à©G -equivalences and we require the generating set C to consist of F ‚à©G -
cell complexes, to contain the orbits G/K for K ‚ààF ‚à©G , and to be closed under
products with orbits G/K where K ‚ààF. With that modiÔ¨Åcation, everything else
above goes through unchanged.
7.3. External smash product and base change adjunctions
The following results relate the q and qf(C )-model structures to smash prod-
ucts and base change functors and show that various of our adjunctions are given by
Quillen adjoint pairs and therefore induce adjunctions on passage to homotopy cat-
egories. For uniformity, since we are not assuming that our base G-space is proper,
we must understand the q-model structure to mean the associated G -model struc-
ture, although many of the results do apply to the full q-model structure. Those
results that refer to q-equivalences by name work equally well for G -equivalences.
Most of the results in this section and the next apply both to the q-model
structure and to the qf(C )-model structure for any generating set C . We agree to
omit the q or qf(C ) from the notations in those cases. In the remaining cases, we
will have to restrict to well chosen generating sets C . Here the idea is to expand
the collection of generating coÔ¨Åbrations in the target category of a left adjoint F
to make it large enough that F takes generating (acyclic) coÔ¨Åbrations to (acyclic)
coÔ¨Åbrations and is therefore a Quillen left adjoint.
With these conventions, our Ô¨Årst result is clear from the fact that our model
structures are G-topological.
Proposition 7.3.1. For a based G-CW complex K, the functor (‚àí) ‚àßB K
preserves coÔ¨Åbrations and acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations, hence the functor FB(K, ‚àí) preserves
Ô¨Åbrations and acyclic Ô¨Åbrations. Thus ((‚àí) ‚àßB K, FB(K, ‚àí)) is a Quillen adjoint
pair of endofunctors of GKB.
For the rest of our results, recall from Lemma 5.4.7 that a left adjoint that
takes generating acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations to acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations preserves acyclic coÔ¨Å-
brations. The following two results apply to the qf(C )-model structure for any
closed generating set C .
Proposition 7.3.2. If i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY and j : W ‚àí‚ÜíZ are coÔ¨Åbrations over base
G-spaces A and B, then
i‚ñ°j : (Y ‚äºW) ‚à™X‚äºW (X ‚äºZ) ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚äºZ
is a coÔ¨Åbration over A √ó B which is acyclic if either i or j is acyclic.
Proof. It suÔ¨Éces to inspect i‚ñ°j for generating (acyclic) coÔ¨Åbrations as was
done for the case A = ‚àóin the proof of Theorem 7.2.8. For generating coÔ¨Åbrations,
the argument there generalizes without change to this setting. The assumption that
C is closed avoids the need for triangulations here. For the acyclicity, it suÔ¨Éces
to work in the q-model structure, for which the conclusion is both more general

116
7. EQUIVARIANT qf-TYPE MODEL STRUCTURES
and easier to prove. There it is easily checked using triangulations of products of
G -cell complexes, that if i is a generating coÔ¨Åbration and j is a generating acyclic
coÔ¨Åbration, then i‚ñ°j is an acyclic coÔ¨Åbration.
‚ñ°
Of course, by Warning 6.1.7, the analogue for internal smash products fails.
Taking W = ‚àóB and changing notations, we obtain the following special case.
Corollary 7.3.3. Let Y be a coÔ¨Åbrant ex-space over B. Then the functor
(‚àí) ‚äºY from ex-spaces over A to ex-spaces over A √ó B preserves coÔ¨Åbrations and
acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations, hence the functor ¬ØF(Y, ‚àí) from ex-spaces over A √ó B to ex-
spaces over A preserves Ô¨Åbrations and acyclic Ô¨Åbrations. Thus ((‚àí) ‚äºY, ¬ØF(Y, ‚àí))
is a Quillen adjoint pair of functors between GKA and GKA√óB.
The next two results apply to the qf(C )-model structures for any C , provided
that we use the same generating set C for both GKA and GKB.
Proposition 7.3.4. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a G-map. Then the functor f! preserves
coÔ¨Åbrations and acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations, hence (f!, f ‚àó) is a Quillen adjoint pair. The
functor f! also preserves q-equivalences between well-sectioned ex-spaces. If f is a
q-Ô¨Åbration, then the functor f ‚àópreserves all q-equivalences.
Proof. If (D, p) is a space over A, then f!((D, p) ‚®øA) = (D, f ‚ó¶p) ‚®øB.
Therefore f! takes generating (acyclic) q-coÔ¨Åbrations over A to such maps over B.
If (u, h) represents (Dn, Sn‚àí1) as a Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair over MapG(C, A), then,
after composing the projection maps with MapG(C, A) ‚àí‚ÜíMapG(C, B), it also
represents (Dn, Sn‚àí1) as a Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair over MapG(C, B). It follows that
f! also preserves the generating (acyclic) qf-coÔ¨Åbrations.
Recall that the well-
sectioned ex-spaces are those that are ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrant and that f-coÔ¨Åbrations are h-
coÔ¨Åbrations. Since f!X is deÔ¨Åned by a pushout in GK , the gluing lemma in GK
implies that f! preserves q-equivalences between well-sectioned ex-spaces.
If f is a q-Ô¨Åbration and k: Y ‚àí‚ÜíZ is a q-equivalence of ex-spaces over B,
consider the diagram

Proposition 7.3.5. If f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB is a q-equivalence, then (f!, f ‚àó) is a Quillen
equivalence.
Proof. The conclusion holds if and only if the induced adjunction on homo-

deÔ¨Åning condition for a Quillen adjunction in either model structure. The condition
for the other model structure follows formally. We choose the q-model structure.
Let X be a q-coÔ¨Åbrant ex-space over A and Y be a q-Ô¨Åbrant ex-space over B, so

In view of Counterexample 0.0.1, we can at best expect only a partial and
restricted analogue of Proposition 7.3.4 for (f ‚àó, f‚àó). We Ô¨Årst give a result for the
q-model structure and then show how to obtain the analogue for the qf(C )-model
structures using well chosen generating sets C .
Proposition 7.3.6. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a G-bundle such that B is a G -space
and each Ô¨Åber Ab is a Gb-cell complex. Then (f ‚àó, f‚àó) is a Quillen adjoint pair with
respect to the q-model structures. Moreover, if the total space of an ex-G-space Y
over B is a G -cell complex, then so is the total space of f ‚àóY .
Proof. Since f is a q-Ô¨Åbration, f ‚àópreserves q-equivalences. It therefore suf-
Ô¨Åces to show that f ‚àótakes generating coÔ¨Åbrations in IB to relative IA-cell com-
plexes. Observe Ô¨Årst that if œÜ: G/H ‚àí‚ÜíB is a G-map with œÜ(eH) = b, then
H ‚äÇGb and the pullback G-bundle œÜ‚àóf : f ‚àó(G/H, œÜ) ‚àí‚ÜíG/H of f along œÜ is
G-homeomorphic to G √óH Ab ‚àí‚ÜíG/H. We can triangulate orbits in a Gb-cell

structure of an H-cell complex. Then G√óH Ab has an induced structure of a G -cell
complex and thus so does f ‚àó(G/H, œÜ).
For a space d: E ‚àí‚ÜíB over B with associated ex-space E ‚®øB over B, we have
f ‚àó(E ‚®øB) = f ‚àóE ‚®øA. Let E = G/H √ó Dn and let i: G/H ‚àí‚ÜíG/H √ó Dn be

The previous result fails for the qf-model structure. In fact, it already fails
nonequivariantly for the unique map r: A ‚àí‚Üí‚àó, where A is a cell complex. The

proof breaks down when we try to use a cell decomposition of A (the Ô¨Åber over ‚àó) to

the equivariant proof above breaks down when we try to use the G-cell structure
of f ‚àó(G/H, œÜ) to obtain a relative If

Note, however, that there
is no problem when the Ô¨Åbers are homogeneous spaces G/H; the nonequivariant
analogue is just the trivial case when f is a homeomorphism, but principal bundles
and projections G/H √ó B ‚àí‚ÜíB give interesting equivariant examples. For the
general equivariant case, we choose a closed generating set C (f) that depends on
the G-bundle f and a given closed generating set C . Using the qf(C (f))-model
structures on GKA and GKB, we then recover the Quillen adjunction.
Construction 7.3.7. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a G-bundle such that B is a G -space
and each Ô¨Åber Ab is a Gb-cell complex and let C be a closed generating set. We
construct the set C (f) inductively.
Let C (f)0 = C and suppose that we have
constructed a set C (f)n of G -cell complexes in GK that is closed under both Ô¨Ånite
products and products with arbitrary orbits G/H of G. Let
An = {f ‚àó(C, œÜ) | C ‚ààC (f)n and œÜ ‚ààGK (C, B)}.
Then let C (f)n+1 consist of all Ô¨Ånite products of spaces in C (f)n ‚à™An. Note that
C (f)n+1 contains C (f)n and that the f ‚àó(C, œÜ) are G -cell complexes by the last
statement of Proposition 7.3.6. Finally, let C (f) = S C (f)n. Clearly C (f) ‚äÉC
is a closed generating set that contains f ‚àó(C, œÜ) for all C ‚ààC (f) and all G-maps
œÜ: C ‚àí‚ÜíB.
Proposition 7.3.8. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a G-bundle such that B is a G -space
and all Ô¨Åbers Ab are Gb-cell complexes. Then (f ‚àó, f‚àó) is a Quillen adjoint pair with
respect to the qf(C (f))-model structures on GKA and the qf(C )-model structure
on GKB.
Proof. Reexamining the proof of Proposition 7.3.6, but starting with a map
d: E = C √ó Dn ‚àí‚ÜíB where C ‚ààC (f), we see that
f ‚àóE ‚àº= f ‚àó(C, œÜ) √ó Dn
where œÜ = d ‚ó¶i.
Since f ‚àó(C, œÜ) is a G -cell complex in C (f), it remains only
to show that f ‚àó(C, œÜ) √ó Sn‚àí1 ‚àí‚Üíf ‚àó(C, œÜ) √ó Dn is an f-coÔ¨Åbration. Let (u, h)
represent (Dn, Sn‚àí1) as a Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair over MapG(C, B).

to the corresponding maps ht : C √ó Dn ‚àí‚ÜíC √ó Dn over B, we obtain maps
f ‚àóht : f ‚àóE ‚àí‚Üíf ‚àóE over A. Under the displayed isomorphism, these maps give

a Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair over MapG(f ‚àó(C, œÜ), A).

7.4. Change of group adjunctions
We consider change of groups in the q and the qf-model structures, starting
with the former. The context of the following results is given in ¬ß2.3 and ¬ß2.4.

7.4. CHANGE OF GROUP ADJUNCTIONS
119
Proposition 7.4.1. Let Œ∏: G ‚àí‚ÜíG‚Ä≤ be a homomorphism of Lie groups. The
restriction of action functor
Œ∏‚àó: G‚Ä≤KB ‚àí‚ÜíGKŒ∏‚àóB
preserves q-equivalences and q-Ô¨Åbrations. If B is a G ‚Ä≤-space, then it also preserves
q-coÔ¨Åbrations.
Proof. Since (Œ∏‚àóA)H = AŒ∏(H) for any subgroup H of G and a map f :
X ‚àí‚ÜíY of G-spaces is a q-equivalence or q-Ô¨Åbration if and only if each f H is
a q-equivalence or q-Ô¨Åbration, it is clear that Œ∏‚àópreserves q-equivalences and q-
Ô¨Åbrations.
To study q-coÔ¨Åbrations, recall that Œ∏ factors as the composite of a
quotient homomorphism, an isomorphism, and an inclusion. If Œ∏ is an inclusion
and H‚Ä≤ is a compact subgroup of G‚Ä≤, then we can triangulate G‚Ä≤/H‚Ä≤ as a G-CW
complex by Theorem 3.4.2. If Œ∏ is a quotient homomorphism with kernel N and H‚Ä≤
is a subgroup of G‚Ä≤, then H‚Ä≤ = H/N for a subgroup H of G and Œ∏‚àó(G‚Ä≤/H‚Ä≤) = G/H
so that no triangulations are required. Thus in both of these cases, Œ∏‚àótakes gener-
ating q-coÔ¨Åbrations to q-coÔ¨Åbrations. Since Œ∏‚àóis also a left adjoint in both cases,
it preserves q-coÔ¨Åbrations in general.
‚ñ°
Remark 7.4.2. We did not require Œ∏‚àóB to be a G -space in Proposition 7.4.1.
However, if the kernel of Œ∏ is compact and B is a G ‚Ä≤-space, then Œ∏‚àóB is a G -space.
Indeed, Œ∏ is then a proper map and Gb = Œ∏‚àí1(G‚Ä≤
b) is compact since G‚Ä≤
b is compact.
The restriction to compact kernels is the price we must pay in order to stay in
the context of compact isotropy groups. We might instead consider G‚Ä≤-spaces B
such that the isotropy groups of both B as a G‚Ä≤-space and Œ∏‚àóB as a G-space are
compact, but the assumption on Œ∏‚àóB would be unnatural. Note however that one
of the main reasons for restricting to compact isotropy groups is to obtain G-CW
structures. If X is a G‚Ä≤-CW complex where G‚Ä≤ = G/N is a quotient group of G,
then Œ∏‚àóX is a G-CW complex with the same cells since the relevant orbits G‚Ä≤/H‚Ä≤
can be identiÔ¨Åed with G/H, where H‚Ä≤ = H/N.
For the qf-model structures, and to study adjunctions, it is convenient to con-
sider quotient homomorphisms and inclusions separately. For the former, we con-
sider the adjunctions of Proposition 2.4.1.
Proposition 7.4.3. Let œµ: G ‚àí‚ÜíJ be a quotient homomorphism of G by a
normal subgroup N. For a G-space B, consider the functors
(‚àí)/N : GKB ‚àí‚ÜíJKB/N
and (‚àí)N : GKB ‚àí‚ÜíJKBN .
Let j : BN ‚àí‚ÜíB be the inclusion and p: B ‚àí‚ÜíB/N be the quotient map.
(i) ((‚àí)/N, p‚àóœµ‚àó) and (j!œµ‚àó, (‚àí)N) are Quillen adjoint pairs with respect to the
q-model structures on both GKB and JKB/N.
Let CG and CJ be generating sets of G-cell complexes and J-cell complexes. Con-
sider GKB with the qf(CG)-model structure and JKB/N and JKBN with the
qf(CJ)-model structure.
(ii) ((‚àí)/N, p‚àóœµ‚àó) is a Quillen adjunction if C/N ‚ààCJ for C ‚ààCG.
(iii) (j!œµ‚àó, (‚àí)N) is a Quillen adjunction if Œµ‚àóC ‚ààCG for C ‚ààCJ.
Proof. Since (j!, j‚àó) and (p!, p‚àó) are Quillen adjoint pairs in both the q and
the qf contexts, it suÔ¨Éces to consider the case when N acts trivially on B, so
that j and p are identity maps. Then Œµ‚àóis right adjoint to (‚àí)/N and left adjoint

7. EQUIVARIANT qf-TYPE MODEL STRUCTURES
to (‚àí)N. The properties of Œµ‚àóin the previous result give the conclusion for the
q-model structures. The functors Œµ‚àóand (‚àí)N preserve q-equivalences. Since
MapG(C, Œµ‚àóf ‚Ä≤) ‚àº= MapG(C/N, f ‚Ä≤) and MapJ(C‚Ä≤, f N) ‚àº= MapG(œµ‚àóC‚Ä≤, f)
for a J-map f ‚Ä≤ and a G-map f, the conditions on generating sets in (i) and (ii)
ensure that Œµ‚àóand (‚àí)N preserve the relevant qf-Ô¨Åbrations.
‚ñ°
Remark 7.4.4. In (i), we can take CJ to consist of all Ô¨Ånite products of quo-
tients C/N with C ‚ààCG and orbits J/H to arrange that CJ be closed and contain
these C/N. In (ii), we can take CG to consist of all products of pullbacks Œµ‚àóC for
C ‚ààCJ with Ô¨Ånite products of orbits G/H. This set will be closed if CJ is closed
since Œµ‚àópreserves products.
Using Proposition 7.4.3 in conjunction with the additional change of group
relations of Propositions 2.4.3 and 2.4.4, we obtain the following compendium of
equivalences in homotopy categories.
Proposition 7.4.5. Let A and B be G-spaces. Let j : BN ‚àí‚ÜíB be the in-
clusion and p: B ‚àí‚ÜíB/N be the quotient map, and let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a G-map.
Then, for ex-G-spaces X over A and Y over B,
(p!Y )/N ‚âÉY/N,
(f!X)/N ‚âÉ(f/N)!(X/N),
(j‚àóY )N ‚âÉY N,
(f ‚àóY )N ‚âÉ(f N)‚àó(Y N),
(p‚àóY )N ‚âÉY/N,
(f!X)N ‚âÉ(f N)!(XN)
(f ‚àóY )/N ‚âÉ(f/N)‚àó(Y/N).
Here B is assumed to be N-free for the last equivalence in the Ô¨Årst column, and both
A and B are assumed to be N-free for the last equivalence in the second column.
Proof. The equivalences displayed in the Ô¨Årst line come from isomorphisms
between Quillen left adjoints and are therefore clear. Similarly the equivalences in
the second line come from isomorphisms between Quillen right adjoints. The Ô¨Årst
equivalence in the third line (in which we have changed notations from Proposi-
tion 2.4.4) comes from an isomorphism between a Quillen right adjoint on the left
hand side, by Proposition 7.3.6, and a Quillen left adjoint on the right hand side
and therefore also descends directly to an equivalence on homotopy categories. For
the second equivalence on the third line, note that (‚àí)N preserves all q-equivalences
and also preserves well-grounded ex-spaces and that (f N)! preserves q-equivalences
between well-grounded ex-spaces. Letting Q and R denote coÔ¨Åbrant and Ô¨Åbrant
replacement functors, as usual, it follows that the maps
(R(f!X))N ‚Üê‚àí(f!X)N ‚àº= (f N)!(XN) ‚Üê‚àí(f N)!(Q(XN))
are q-equivalences on ex-spaces X that are qf-Ô¨Åbrant and qf-coÔ¨Åbrant. As noted in
the proof of Proposition 2.4.3, the point set level isomorphism (f!X)N ‚àº= (f N)!(XN)
is only valid for an ex-space X whose section is a closed inclusion. However, if X
is qf-coÔ¨Åbrant, then it is compactly generated and this holds by Lemma 1.6.2(i).
Thus the equivalence holds in general in the homotopy category. For the last equiv-
alence, take A and B to be N-free and let q: A ‚àí‚ÜíA/N be the quotient map. Then
(‚àí)/N ‚àº= (q‚àó(‚àí))N on ex-G-spaces over A and (‚àí)/N ‚àº= (p‚àó(‚àí))N on ex-G-spaces
over B. Since p and q are J-bundles satisfying the hypothesis of Proposition 7.3.8

121
(compare ¬ß3.2), these isomorphisms exhibit both orbit functors (‚àí)/N as compos-
ites of Quillen right adjoints. Therefore the point-set level isomorphism
(f ‚àóY )/N ‚àº= (f/N)‚àó(Y/N)
(which only required B to be N-free) is a comparison between Quillen right adjoints
and so descends to the claimed equivalence of derived functors.

The result Proposition 2.4.4 describing passage to orbits as a right adjoint also
descends to homotopy categories.
Proposition 7.4.6. Let E be an N-free G-space, let B = E/N, and let
p: E ‚àí‚ÜíB be the quotient map.
For X ‚ààGKE, X/N ‚àº= (p‚àóX)N, and this
isomorphism descends to an isomorphism in HoJKB. Therefore the left adjoint
(‚àí)/N of the functor p‚àóŒµ‚àóis also its right adjoint on homotopy categories.
Proof. The point set level isomorphism is given in Proposition 2.4.4. Since
it gives an isomorphism between a Quillen left adjoint on the left hand side and a
composite of Quillen right adjoints on the right hand side, it descends directly to
homotopy categories.
‚ñ°
The context for the next result is given in DeÔ¨Ånition 2.3.7 and Proposition 2.3.9.
Proposition 7.4.7. Let Œπ: H ‚àí‚ÜíG be the inclusion of a subgroup and let A
be an H-space. The adjoint equivalence (Œπ!, ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àó) relating HKA and GKŒπ!A is a
Quillen equivalence in the q-model structures and also in the qf(CH) and qf(CG)-
model structures for any generating sets CH and CG of H-cell complexes and G-cell
complexes such that Œπ!C = G√óH C ‚ààCG for C ‚ààCH. If A is proper and completely
regular, then the functor Œπ! is also a Quillen right adjoint with respect to the q and
qf-model structures.
Proof. Recall that ŒΩ : A ‚àí‚ÜíŒπ‚àóŒπ!A = G √óH A is the natural inclusion of H-
spaces and that (ŒΩ!, ŒΩ‚àó) is a Quillen adjunction in both the q and qf contexts. The
functor Œπ‚àópreserves q-equivalences and q-Ô¨Åbrations. It takes qf(CG)-Ô¨Åbrations to
qf(CH)-Ô¨Åbrations when Œπ!C ‚ààCG for C ‚ààCH since
MapH(C, Œπ‚àóf) ‚àº= MapG(Œπ!C, f).
To show that (Œπ!, ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àó) is a Quillen equivalence, we may as well check the
deÔ¨Åning condition in the q-model structure. Let X be a q-coÔ¨Åbrant ex-H-space over
A and Y be a q-Ô¨Åbrant ex-G-space over Œπ!A. Consider a G-map f : Œπ!X ‚àí‚ÜíY . We
must show that f is a q-equivalence if and only if its adjoint H-map Àúf : X ‚àí‚ÜíŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àóY
is a q-equivalence. Since Œπ! preserves acyclic q-coÔ¨Åbrations, we can extend f to
f ‚Ä≤ : Œπ!RX ‚àí‚ÜíY , where RX is a q-Ô¨Åbrant approximation. Since f ‚Ä≤ is a q-equivalence
if and only if f is one, and similarly for their adjoints, we may assume without loss
of generality that X is q-Ô¨Åbrant. Recall from Proposition 2.3.9 that Œπ! and ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àó
are inverse equivalences of categories and observe that ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àóY can be viewed as the
restriction, Y |A, of Y along the inclusion of H-spaces ŒΩ : A ‚àí‚ÜíG√óH A. From that
point of view, Àúf : X ‚àí‚ÜíŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àóY is just the map X ‚àí‚ÜíY |A of ex-H-spaces over A
obtained by restriction of Œπ‚àóf along ŒΩ.
Now f is a q-equivalence if and only if f restricts to a q-equivalence f[g,a] on
each Ô¨Åber, meaning that this restriction is a weak equivalence after passage to
Ô¨Åxed points under all subgroups of the isotropy group of [g, a]. For a ‚ààA, the
isotropy subgroup Ha ‚äÇH of a coincides with the isotropy subgroup G[e,a] ‚äÇG of

122
7. EQUIVARIANT qf-TYPE MODEL STRUCTURES
[e, a] ‚ààG √óH A. For g ‚ààG, the isotropy subgroup of [g, a] is gHag‚àí1. Since the
action by g ‚ààG induces a homeomorphism between the Ô¨Åbers over [e, a] and over
[g, a], we see that f is a q-equivalence if and only if each of the restrictions f[e,a] is
a q-equivalence. But that holds if and only if Àúf is a q-equivalence.
For the last statement, recall the description of Œπ! in Remark 2.4.5 as the com-
posite (p‚àóœÄ‚àóŒµ‚àó(‚àí))H, where Œµ: G√óH ‚àí‚ÜíH and œÄ: G√óA ‚àí‚ÜíA are the projections
and p: G √ó A ‚àí‚ÜíG √óH A is the quotient map. Since G √ó A is completely regu-
lar, p is a bundle with Ô¨Åber G/Ha over [g, a], and Ha is compact since A is proper.
Therefore, by Propositions 7.3.6 and 7.3.8, p‚àóis a Quillen right adjoint with respect
to the q and qf-model structures. In view of Proposition 7.4.3, this displays Œπ! as a
composite of Quillen right adjoints.

Remark 7.4.8. We can take CG to consist of all Ô¨Ånite products of the Œπ!C with

We shall prove that (Œπ!, ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àó) descends to a closed symmetric monoidal equiv-

7.5. Fiber adjunctions and Brown representability
For a point b in B, we combine the special case Àúb: G/Gb ‚àí‚ÜíB of Proposi-
tion 7.3.4 with the special case Œπ: Gb ‚àí‚ÜíG and A = ‚àó, hence ŒΩ : ‚àó‚àí‚ÜíG/Gb, of
Proposition 7.4.7 to obtain the following result concerning passage to Ô¨Åbers. Re-
call from Example 2.3.12 that the Ô¨Åber functor (‚àí)b : GKB ‚àí‚ÜíGbK‚àóis given by
ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àóÀúb‚àó= b‚àóŒπ‚àó. By conjugation, its left adjoint (‚àí)b therefore agrees with Àúb!Œπ!.
Proposition 7.5.1. For b ‚ààB, the pair of functors ((‚àí)b, (‚àí)b) relating GbK‚àó
and GKB is a Quillen adjoint pair.
We use certain objects Xb to verify the formal hypotheses of Brown‚Äôs repre-
sentability theorem [26] for the category HoGKB, or rather for a suitable subcate-
gory. We need a few preliminaries and some discussion of the nature and limitations
of the Brown representability theorem.
Definition 7.5.2. DeÔ¨Åne weak colimits in any category H by requiring the
existence but not the uniqueness property of colimits. When H has (speciÔ¨Åed)
weak sequential colimits, denoted hocolim Yn or Tel Yn, we say that an object X of
H is compact if
colim H (X, Yn) ‚àº= H (X, hocolim Yn)
for any sequence of maps Yn ‚àí‚ÜíYn+1 in H .
Of course, homotopy colimits often provide weak colimits, but the two notions
are conceptually distinct. If H has coproducts and weak pushouts, then it has weak
coequalizers and weak sequential colimits, as in ¬ß5.6. DeÔ¨Ånitions 5.6.8, 5.6.10, and
5.6.12 together with Lemmas 5.6.9, 5.6.11, and 5.6.13 give the following result.

7.5. FIBER ADJUNCTIONS AND BROWN REPRESENTABILITY
123
Lemma 7.5.3. Applied to diagrams of coÔ¨Åbrant objects, the classical homotopy
pushouts, homotopy coequalizers, and telescopes in a well-grounded model category
give weak pushouts, weak coequalizers, and weak sequential colimits in its homotopy
category.
Warning 7.5.4. When verifying weak colimit properties by use of homotopy
classes of maps, as in ¬ß5.6, one is studying maps out of homotopy colimits, and it
suÔ¨Éces to restrict attention to coÔ¨Åbrant objects. However, when trying to verify
compactness similarly, one must study maps into homotopy colimits, and one must
therefore apply Ô¨Åbrant approximation to homotopy colimits in order to pass to
homotopy classes of maps. This destroys the point-set level control that classical
homotopy colimits provide. Said another way, topological intuition relates to the
hom sets œÄ(X, ‚àí) of the classical homotopy category and not the hom sets [X, ‚àí]
of the relevant homotopy category. For this reason, compactness is a quite subtle
notion in the homotopy categories of topological model categories in which not all
objects are Ô¨Åbrant.
We also need generating sets of objects and, in unstable homotopy theory, it
is useful to distinguish these from detecting sets of objects. Variant forms of the
following deÔ¨Ånition appear in [76,134] and elsewhere. In topological or triangulated
categories, it is natural to insist that these classes be closed under suspension, and
we shall do so implicitly.
Definition 7.5.5. A set D of objects in a pointed category H is a detecting set
if H (D, X) = ‚àófor all objects D ‚ààD implies that X ‚àº= ‚àó. A set D is a generating
set if a map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY such that f‚àó: H (D, X) ‚àí‚ÜíH (D, Y ) is a bijection for
all D ‚ààD is an isomorphism.
Remark 7.5.6. Clearly any generating set is a detecting set. The converse
holds in triangulated categories, as we shall see in Lemma 13.1.6. The term ‚Äúde-
tecting set‚Äù is new, but we have followed the literature in deÔ¨Åning generating sets,
although they might more reasonably be called detecting sets. The reason for the
name ‚Äúgenerating set‚Äù is given by Theorem 13.1.14 below.
The point of the distinction is that Brown‚Äôs theorem requires the use of a gen-
erating set and not just a detecting set of objects, and for that reason it requires
a connectedness hypothesis in unstable situations. The following abstract repre-
sentability theorem was proven by Brown [26, 2.9], although he stated it diÔ¨Äerently.
Theorem 7.5.7 (Brown). Let H
be a category with coproducts and weak
pushouts and therefore weak sequential colimits. Assume that H has a generat-
ing set of compact objects. Let k: H ‚àí‚ÜíSets be a contravariant functor that
takes coproducts to products and weak pushouts to weak pullbacks. Then there is an
object Y ‚ààH and a natural isomorphism k(X) ‚àº= H (X, Y ) for X ‚ààH .
The conditions on k are called the wedge and Mayer-Vietoris axioms. Of course,
the representing object Y is unique up to isomorphism. The hypotheses are satisÔ¨Åed
in appropriate subcategories of unstable homotopy categories.
Definition 7.5.8. A G-space K is said to be G-connected if each of its Ô¨Åxed
point sets KH is non-empty and path connected. Let HoGK c
‚àóbe the full subcat-
egory of G-connected G-spaces in HoGK‚àó. Say that an ex-G-space X over B is
G-connected if, after Ô¨Åbrant approximation, each of its Ô¨Åbers is Gb-connected. Let
HoGK c
B be the full subcategory of G-connected ex-G-spaces in HoGKB.

124
7. EQUIVARIANT qf-TYPE MODEL STRUCTURES
Model categorically, one has the following general result of Hovey [75, 7.3.1].
We need some language to state it.
Notation 7.5.9. By a standard abuse of language, deÔ¨Åne the coÔ¨Åber Z of a
coÔ¨Åbration f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY in a pointed model category C to be the quotient Y/X,
that is, the pushout of f along the trivial map X ‚àí‚Üí‚àó. Observe that if C is
coÔ¨Åbrantly generated, then the cell complexes in C consisting of a single cell, the
1-cell complexes, are precisely the coÔ¨Åbers of the generating coÔ¨Åbrations.
Theorem 7.5.10. Let C be a pointed coÔ¨Åbrantly generated model category.
Then the set of all iterated suspensions Œ£nZ, n ‚â•0, of 1-cell complexes Z in
C is a set of detecting objects for HoC .
This specializes to give the Ô¨Årst statement in the following familiar example.
Lemma 7.5.11. In HoGK‚àó, the set of spheres Sn
H = G/H+ ‚àßSn, n ‚â•0, is a
detecting set. On the subcategory HoGK c
‚àóof G-connected G-spaces, the set of such
spheres with n > 0 is a generating set.
We emphasize that, already nonequivariantly, we do not know of a convenient
generating set in HoK‚àó. Naive variants of the sets of spheres given in Lemma 7.5.11
are incorrect, as consideration of based versus unbased homotopy classes of maps
makes clear. The notion of a weak equivalence of spaces, as a condition on homo-
topy groups for all choices of basepoint and thus all components, is more subtle
than appears at Ô¨Årst sight. Lemma 7.5.11 leads to the appropriate parametrized
analogue, but here we can restrict to smaller detecting and generating sets than
Theorem 7.5.10 would suggest.
Definition 7.5.12. For n ‚â•0, b ‚ààB, and H ‚äÇGb, let Sn,b

for any sequence of maps fq : Yq ‚àí‚ÜíYq+1 in HoGSB. Since we are working in the
homotopy category, we may assume that the Yq are qf-Ô¨Åbrant and qf-coÔ¨Åbrant.
We choose representative maps fq for the given homotopy classes and, since we are
studying maps into homotopy colimits, we take our representative for the homotopy
colimit to be a Ô¨Åbrant approximation RTel Yq of the classical telescope of these fq.
Now our desired isomorphism becomes
colim œÄH

In HoHK‚àó, where every object is q-Ô¨Åbrant, homotopy groups of telescopes are given
as colimits, so that
colim œÄH
n ((Yq)b) ‚àº= œÄH
n (Tel(Yq)b).
By direct inspection of the telescope construction, we have
Tel(Yq)b ‚àº= (Tel Yq)b.
The desired isomorphism is immediate from the following result.
‚ñ°
Lemma 7.5.15. For a sequence of maps fn : Yn ‚àí‚ÜíYn+1 between qf-Ô¨Åbrant
and qf-coÔ¨Åbrant objects of GKB and a point b ‚ààB, a qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation
Tel Yq ‚àí‚ÜíRTel Yq induces a weak Gb-equivalence (Tel Yq)b ‚àí‚Üí(RTel Yq)b for each
b ‚ààB.
Proof. Inductively, starting with Z1 = Y1 and œÄ1 = id, we construct acyclic
qf-Ô¨Åbrations œÄq : Zq ‚àí‚ÜíYq together with qf-coÔ¨Åbrations gq : Zq ‚àí‚ÜíZq+1 such that
œÄq+1 ‚ó¶gq = fq ‚ó¶œÄq by applying the appropriate factorization axiom to fq ‚ó¶œÄq. Then
the Zq are also qf-Ô¨Åbrant and qf-coÔ¨Åbrant. Therefore the œÄq are fp-equivalences,
so induce homotopy equivalences of Ô¨Åbers. Comparing constructions as in the proof
of Lemma 5.6.14, we see that the telescope of the maps fq is weakly equivalent to
the telescope and therefore to the colimit of the sequence of maps gq. Because the
latter colimit is quasiÔ¨Åbrant, by Lemma 3.6.3, the homotopy groups of its Ô¨Åbers are
isomorphic to the homotopy groups of the Ô¨Åbers of its qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation.
The conclusion follows.
‚ñ°
Warning 7.5.16. We do not know whether or not a general 1-cell complex is
compact. At Ô¨Årst sight, that might seem obvious from the compactness of discs,
but, as pointed out in Warning 7.5.4, the need for qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation of
targets before passage to homotopy classes of maps obstructs such an argument.
Theorem 7.5.17 (Brown). A contravariant set-valued functor on the category
HoGK c
B is representable if and only if it satisÔ¨Åes the wedge and Mayer-Vietoris
axioms.


CHAPTER 8
Ex-Ô¨Åbrations and ex-quasiÔ¨Åbrations
To complete the space level foundations of parametrized homotopy theory, we
are faced with two problems that were discussed in the Prologue. In our preferred
qf-model structure, the base change adjunction (f!, f ‚àó) is a Quillen pair for any
map f and is a Quillen equivalence if f is an equivalence. As shown by Coun-
terexample 0.0.1, this implies that the base change adjunction (f ‚àó, f‚àó) cannot be
a Quillen adjoint pair, and some such defect must hold for any model structure.
Therefore, we cannot turn to model theory to construct the functor f‚àóon the level
of homotopy categories. The same counterexample illustrates that passage to de-
rived functors is not functorial in general, so that a relation between composites of
functors that holds on the point-set level need not imply a corresponding relation
on homotopy categories.
In any attempt to solve those two problems, one runs into a third one that
concerns a basic foundational problem in ex-space theory. Model theoretical con-
siderations lead to the use of Serre Ô¨Åbrations as projections, or to the even weaker
class of qf-Ô¨Åbrations. However, only Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations are considered in most of
the literature. There is good reason for that. Fiberwise smash products, suspen-
sions, coÔ¨Åbers, function spaces, and other fundamental constructions in ex-space
theory do not preserve Serre Ô¨Åbrations.
The solutions to all three problems are obtained by the use of ex-Ô¨Åbrations. Re-
call that these are the well-sectioned h-Ô¨Åbrant ex-spaces. We study their properties
in ¬ß8.1. They seem to give the deÔ¨Ånitively right kind of ‚ÄúÔ¨Åbrant ex-space‚Äù from the
point of view of classical homotopy theory, and they behave much better under the
cited constructions than do Serre Ô¨Åbrations, as we show in ¬ß8.2. Many variants of
this notion appear in the literature. Precisely this variant, with this name, appears
in Monica Clapp‚Äôs paper [31], and we are indepted to her work for an understanding
of the centrality of the notion. Perversely, as we noted in Remark 5.2.7, it is unclear
how it Ô¨Åts into the model categorical framework.
We construct an elementary ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation functor in ¬ß8.3. It plays
a key role in bridging the gap between the model theoretic and classical worlds.
In a diÔ¨Äerent context, the classiÔ¨Åcation of sectioned Ô¨Åbrations, the Ô¨Årst author
introduced this construction in [111, ¬ß5]. We record some of its properties in ¬ß8.4.
We deÔ¨Åne quasiÔ¨Åbrant ex-spaces and ex-quasiÔ¨Åbrations and show that they
inherit some of the good properties of ex-Ô¨Åbrations in ¬ß8.5. They will play a key
role in the stable theory.
Everything in this chapter works just as well equivariantly as nonequivariantly
for any topological group G of equivariance.
127

128
8. EX-FIBRATIONS AND EX-QUASIFIBRATIONS
8.1. Ex-Ô¨Åbrations
Under various names, the following notions were in common use in the 1970‚Äôs.
We shall see shortly that these deÔ¨Ånitions agree with those given in DeÔ¨Ånition 5.2.5.
Definition 8.1.1. Let (X, p, s) be an ex-space over B.
(i) (X, p, s) is well-sectioned if s is a closed inclusion and there is a retraction
œÅ: X √ó I ‚àí‚ÜíX ‚à™B (B √ó I) = Ms
over B.
(ii) (X, p, s) is well-Ô¨Åbered if there is a coretraction, or path-lifting function,
Œπ: Np = X √óB BI ‚àí‚ÜíXI
under BI, where BI maps to Np via Œ± ‚àí‚Üí(sŒ±(0), Œ±).
(iii) (X, p, s) is an ex-Ô¨Åbration if it is both well-sectioned and well-Ô¨Åbered.
The requirement in (i) that the retraction œÅ be a map over B ensures that it
restricts on Ô¨Åbers to a retraction that exhibits the nondegeneracy of the basepoint
s(b) in Xb for each b ‚ààB. In view of Theorem 5.2.8(i), we have the following
characterization of well-sectioned ex-spaces, in agreement with DeÔ¨Ånition 5.2.5.
Lemma 8.1.2. An ex-space X is well-sectioned if and only if X is ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrant.
We use the term ‚Äúwell-sectioned‚Äù since it goes well with ‚Äúwell-based‚Äù. The
category of well-sectioned ex-spaces is the appropriate parametrized generalization
of the category of well-based spaces, and restricting to well-sectioned ex-spaces is
analogous to restricting to well-based spaces.
Note that the section of X provides a canonical way of lifting a path in B that
starts at b to a path in X that starts at s(b). The requirement in DeÔ¨Ånition 8.1.1(ii)
that the path-lifting function Œπ be a map under BI says that Œπ(sŒ±(0), Œ±)(t) = s(Œ±(t))
for all Œ± ‚ààBI and t ‚ààI.
That is, Œπ is required to restrict to the canonical
lifts provided by the section, so that paths in X that start in s(B) remain in
s(B). In contrast with Lemma 8.1.2, the well-Ô¨Åbered condition does not by itself
Ô¨Åt naturally into the model theoretic context of Chapter 5. However, we have the
following characterization of ex-Ô¨Åbrations, which again is in agreement with the
original deÔ¨Ånition we gave in DeÔ¨Ånition 5.2.5.
Lemma 8.1.3. If X is well-Ô¨Åbered, then X is h-Ô¨Åbrant. If X is well-sectioned,
then X is an ex-Ô¨Åbration if and only if X is h-Ô¨Åbrant.
Proof. The Ô¨Årst statement is clear since the coretraction Œπ is a path-lifting
function.
This gives the forward implication of the second statement, and the
converse is a special case of the following result of Eggar [57, 3.2].
‚ñ°
Lemma 8.1.4. Let i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY be an ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration of ex-spaces over B, where
Y is h-Ô¨Åbrant. Then any map Œπ: X √óB BI ‚àí‚ÜíY I such that the composite
X √óB BI
