‚ñ°
Remark 8.1.5. We comment on the terminology and history.
(1) We are following [42,83] and others in saying that an ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrant ex-space
is well-sectioned; the term ‚ÄúÔ¨Åberwise well-pointed‚Äù is also used. For a based space,
the terms ‚Äúnondegenerately based‚Äù and ‚Äúwell-based‚Äù or ‚Äúwell-pointed‚Äù are used
interchangeably to mean that the inclusion of the basepoint is an h-coÔ¨Åbration. In
contrast, for an ex-space, the term ‚ÄúÔ¨Åberwise nondegenerately pointed‚Äù is used in
[42,83] to indicate a somewhat weaker condition than well-sectioned.
(2) The term ‚Äúwell-Ô¨Åbered‚Äù is new but goes naturally with well-sectioned. The
concept itself is old.
We believe that it is due to Eggar [57, 3.3], who calls a
coretraction under BI a special lifting function.
(3) Becker and Gottlieb [9] may have been the Ô¨Årst to use the term ‚Äúex-
Ô¨Åbration‚Äù, but for a slightly diÔ¨Äerent notion with sensible CW restrictions.
As
noted in the introduction, precisely our notion is used by Clapp [31]. Earlier, in
[111, ¬ß5] and [113], the Ô¨Årst author called ex-Ô¨Åbrations ‚ÄúT -Ô¨Åbrations‚Äù, and he
studied their classiÔ¨Åcation and their Ô¨Åberwise localizations and completions. The
equivariant generalization appears in Waner [170]. A more recent treatment of the
classiÔ¨Åcation of ex-Ô¨Åbrations has been given by Booth [20].
8.2. Preservation properties of ex-Ô¨Åbrations
We have a series of results that show that ex-Ô¨Åbrations behave well with respect
to standard constructions. In some of them, one must use the equivariant version of
Lemma 5.2.4 to verify that the given construction preserves well-sectioned objects.
In all of them, if we only assume that the input ex-spaces are well-sectioned, then
we can conclude that the output ex-spaces are well-sectioned. It is the fact that
the given constructions preserve well-Ô¨Åbered objects that is crucial. Few if any of
these results hold with Serre rather than Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations as projections.
Proposition 8.2.1. Ex-Ô¨Åbrations satisfy the following properties.
(i) A wedge over B of ex-Ô¨Åbrations is an ex-Ô¨Åbration.
(ii) If X, Y and Z are ex-Ô¨Åbrations and i is an ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration in the following
pushout diagram of ex-spaces over B, then Y ‚à™X Z is an ex-Ô¨Åbration.
X
i
/

Y

Z
/ Y ‚à™X Z
(iii) The colimit of a sequence of ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrations Xi ‚àí‚ÜíXi+1 between ex-Ô¨Åbrations
is an ex-Ô¨Åbration.

130
8. EX-FIBRATIONS AND EX-QUASIFIBRATIONS
If the input ex-spaces are only assumed to be well-sectioned, then the output ex-
spaces are well-sectioned.
Proof. The last statement is clear. Using it, we see that the colimits in (i),
(ii), and (iii) are well-sectioned, hence it suÔ¨Éces to prove that they are h-Ô¨Åbrant.
This is done by constructing path lifting functions for the colimits from path lifting
functions for their inputs. In (i), we start with path lifting functions under BI
for the wedge summands and see that they glue together to deÔ¨Åne a path lifting
function under BI for the wedge. Part (ii) is due to Clapp [31, 1.3], and we omit
full details. She starts with a path lifting function for X and uses Lemma 8.1.4 to
extend it to a path lifting function for Y . She also starts with a path lifting function
for Z. She then uses a representation (h, u) of (Y, X) as a Ô¨Åberwise NDR pair to
build a path lifting function for the pushout from the given path lifting function
for Z and a suitably deformed version of the path lifting function for Y . In (iii),
Lemma 8.1.4 shows that we can extend a path lifting function for Xi to a path
lifting function for Xi+1. Inductively, this allows the construction of compatible
path lifting functions for the Xi that glue together to give a path lifting function
for their colimit.
‚ñ°
Although of little use to us, since the f-homotopy category is not the right one
for our purposes, many of our adjunctions give Quillen adjoint pairs with respect to
the f-model structure. For example, the following result, which should be compared
with Proposition 7.3.4, implies that (f!, f ‚àó) is a Quillen adjoint pair in the f-model
structures and that it is a Quillen equivalence if f is an h-equivalence.
Proposition 8.2.2. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a map, let X be a well-sectioned ex-
space over A, and let Y be a well-sectioned ex-space over B. Then f!X and f ‚àóY are
well-sectioned. If Y is an ex-Ô¨Åbration, then so is f ‚àóY , and the functor f ‚àópreserves
f-equivalences. If f is an h-equivalence, then (f!, f ‚àó) induces an equivalence of
f-homotopy categories.
Proof. It is easy to check that representations of (X, A) and (Y, B) as Ô¨Åber-
wise NDR-pairs induce representations of (f!X, B) and (f ‚àóY, A) as Ô¨Åberwise NDR-
pairs.
As a pullback, the functor f ‚àópreserves both f-Ô¨Åbrant and h-Ô¨Åbrant ex-
spaces, and f ‚àópreserve f-equivalences since it preserves f-homotopies. For the
last statement, if f is a homotopy equivalence with homotopy inverse g, then stan-
dard arguments with the CHP imply that f ‚àóinduces an equivalence of f-homotopy
categories with inverse g‚àó; see, for example, [111, 2.5]. It follows that g‚àóis equiva-
lent to f! and that (f!, f ‚àó) is a Quillen equivalence.
‚ñ°
The following result appears in [57] and [111, 3.6]. It also leads to a Quillen
adjoint pair with respect to the f-model structure; compare Corollary 7.3.3.
Proposition 8.2.3. Let X and Y be well-sectioned ex-spaces over A and B.
Then X ‚äºY is a well-sectioned ex-space over A √ó B. If X and Y are ex-Ô¨Åbrations,
then X ‚äºY is an ex-Ô¨Åbration.
Proof. Representations of (X, A) and (Y, B) as Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pairs deter-
mine a representation of (X ‚äºY, A √ó B) as a Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair, by standard
formulas [121, p. 43]. Similarly, path lifting functions for X and Y can be used to
write down a path lifting function for X ‚äºY .
‚ñ°
Corollary 8.2.4. If X and Y are ex-Ô¨Åbrations over B, then so is X ‚àßB Y .

8.3. THE EX-FIBRANT APPROXIMATION FUNCTOR
131
Corollary 8.2.5. If X is an ex-Ô¨Åbration over B and K is a well-based space,
then X ‚àßB K is an ex-Ô¨Åbration over B.
Proposition 8.2.6. Let X and Y be well-sectioned and let f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY be
an ex-map that is an h-equivalence. Then f ‚àßB id: X ‚àßB Z ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚àßB Z is an
h-equivalence for any ex-Ô¨Åbration Z. In particular, f ‚àßB id: X ‚àßB K ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚àßB K
is an h-equivalence for any well-based space K.
Proof. As observed by Clapp [31, 2.7], this follows from the gluing lemma by
comparing the deÔ¨Åning pushouts.
‚ñ°
As in ordinary topology, function objects work less well, but we do have the
following analogue of Corollary 8.2.5.
Proposition 8.2.7. If X is an ex-Ô¨Åbration over B and K is a compact well-
based space, then FB(K, X) is an ex-Ô¨Åbration over B.
Proof. Let (h, u) represent (X, B) as a Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair. Then (j, v) rep-
resents (FB(K, X), B) as a Ô¨Åberwise NDR-pair, where
v(f) = supk‚ààKu(f(k))
and
jt(f)(k) = ht(f(k))
for f ‚ààFB(K, X).
Note for this that FB(K, B) = B and that, by Proposi-
tion 1.3.16, FB(K, X) is h-Ô¨Åbrant.
‚ñ°
8.3. The ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation functor
We describe an elementary ex-Ô¨Åbrant replacement functor P. It is just the
composite of a whiskering functor W with a version of the mapping path Ô¨Åbration
functor N. The functor P replaces ex-spaces by naturally h-equivalent ex-Ô¨Åbrations.
From the point of view of model theory, P can be thought of as a kind of q-Ô¨Åbrant
replacement functor that gives Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations rather than just Serre Ô¨Åbrations
as projections.
The nonequivariant version of P appears in [111, 5.3, 5.6], and
the equivariant version appears in [170, ¬ß3]. With motivation from the theory of
transports in Ô¨Åbrations, those sources work with Moore paths of varying length.
Surprisingly, that choice turns out to be essential for the construction to work.
We therefore begin by recalling that the space of Moore paths in B is given by
ŒõB = {(Œª, l) ‚ààB[0,‚àû] √ó [0, ‚àû) | Œª(r) = Œª(l) for r ‚â•l}
with the subspace topology. We write Œª for (Œª, l) and lŒª for l, which is the length
of Œª. Let e: ŒõB ‚àí‚ÜíB be the endpoint projection e(Œª) = Œª(lŒª). The composite of
Moore paths ¬µ and Œª such that Œª(lŒª) = ¬µ(0) is deÔ¨Åned by l¬µŒª = l¬µ + lŒª and
(¬µŒª)(r) =
(
Œª(r)
if r ‚â§lŒª,
¬µ(r ‚àílŒª)
if r ‚â•lŒª.
Embed B and BI in ŒõB as the paths of length 0 and 1. For a Moore path Œª in
B and real numbers u and v such that 0 ‚â§u ‚â§v, let Œª|v
u denote the Moore path
r 7‚ÜíŒª(u + r) of length v ‚àíu.
Definition 8.3.1. Consider an ex-space X = (X, p, s) over B.
(i) DeÔ¨Åne the whiskering functor W by letting
WX = (X ‚à™B (B √ó I), q, t),

mapping cylinder construction of the section of X, thought of as a map in GK /B.
The section t of WX is just the f-coÔ¨Åbration in the standard factorization œÅ ‚ó¶t
of s through its mapping cylinder. In particular, WX is well-sectioned. Similarly,

Warning 8.4.4. We oÔ¨Äer another example of the technical dangers lurking in
this subject. The maps ¬µ in the previous proposition are not h-equivalences in
general, the problem in (ii), say, being that f ‚àódoes not preserve h-equivalences
in general. If ¬µ: Pf ‚àóY ‚àí‚Üíf ‚àóPY were always an h-equivalence, then one could
prove by the methods in ¬ß9.3 below that the relations (2.2.12) descend to homotopy
categories for all pullbacks of the form displayed in Proposition 2.2.11. In view of
Counterexample 0.0.1, that conclusion is false. This is a pitfall we fell into, and it
invalidated much work in an earlier draft.
8.5. QuasiÔ¨Åbrant ex-spaces and ex-quasiÔ¨Åbrations
By analogy with the fact that an ex-Ô¨Åbration is a well-sectioned h-Ô¨Åbrant ex-
space, we adopt the following terminology.
Definition 8.5.1. An ex-space X is quasiÔ¨Åbrant if its projection p is a quasi-
Ô¨Åbration. An ex-quasiÔ¨Åbration is a well-sectioned quasiÔ¨Åbrant ex-space.
If X is quasiÔ¨Åbrant, there is a long exact sequence of homotopy groups
¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH

pairs (X, Xb), Ô¨Åve lemma comparisons give the following observations.

136
8. EX-FIBRATIONS AND EX-QUASIFIBRATIONS
Lemma 8.5.2. Let f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY be a q-equivalence of ex-spaces over B. Then
each map of Ô¨Åbers f : Xb ‚àí‚ÜíYb is a q-equivalence if and only if each map of
pairs f : (X, Xb) ‚àí‚Üí(Y, Yb) is a q-equivalence. If X and Y are quasiÔ¨Åbrant, then
these maps of pairs are q-equivalences. Conversely, if these maps of pairs are q-
equivalences and either X or Y is quasiÔ¨Åbrant, then so is the other.
Working in GUB, we obtain the following result. The same pattern of proof
gives many other results of the same nature that we leave to the reader.
Proposition 8.5.3. The following statements hold.
(i) A wedge over B of ex-quasiÔ¨Åbrations is an ex-quasiÔ¨Åbration.
(ii) If f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a map such that X is an ex-quasiÔ¨Åbration and Y is quasiÔ¨Å-
brant, then the coÔ¨Åber CBf is quasiÔ¨Åbrant.
(iii) If X is an ex-quasiÔ¨Åbration and K is a well-based space, then X ‚àßB K is an
ex-quasiÔ¨Åbration.
Proof. This follows from Lemma 8.5.2, the natural zig-zag

result plays a vital role in our work, we give more complete details of (ii) and (iii);
(i) works the same way.

CHAPTER 9
The equivalence between Ho GKB and hGWB
Introduction
We developed the point-set level properties of the category GKB of ex-G-spaces
over B in Chapters 1 and 2, and we developed those homotopical properties that
are accessible to model theoretic techniques in Chapters 4 ‚Äì 7. In this chapter,
we use ex-Ô¨Åbrations to prove that certain structure on the point-set level that
seems inaccessible from the point of view of model category theory nevertheless
descends to homotopy categories. In particular, we prove that Ho GKB is closed
symmetric monoidal and that the right derived functor f ‚àóof the Quillen adjunction
(f!, f ‚àó) in the qf-model structure is closed symmetric monoidal. We use Brown
representability to show that f ‚àóhas a partially deÔ¨Åned right adjoint. Here on the
ex-space level, the classical limitation of Brown representability to connected spaces
forces us to restrict the construction of f‚àóto G-connected ex-Ô¨Åbrations, which have
Gb-connected Ô¨Åbers.
In ¬ß9.1 we use the ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation functor and the good properties of
the qf-model structure to prove that our model theoretic homotopy category of ex-
G-spaces over B is equivalent to the classical homotopy category of ex-G-Ô¨Åbrations
over B. In ¬ß9.2, we discuss how to compare derived functors as constructed on either
side of that equivalence in certain general cases. Replacing the model-theoretic
method of constructing derived functors by a more classical method given in terms
of ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation, we construct the functors f‚àóand FB on homotopy
categories in ¬ß9.3.
By a combination of methods, we prove that Ho GKB is a
symmetric monoidal category and that the base change functor f ‚àódescends to a
closed symmetric monoidal functor on homotopy categories in ¬ß9.4. We also obtain
such descent results for change of group adjunctions and for passage to Ô¨Åbers in that
section. These results are central to the theory, and there seem to be no shortcuts
to their proofs.
Everything is understood to be equivariant in this chapter, and we abbreviate
ex-G-Ô¨Åbration and ex-G-space to ex-Ô¨Åbration and ex-space throughout. We shall
retreat just a bit from all‚Äìembracing generality. We assume that G is a Lie group
and that all given base G-spaces B are proper and are of the homotopy types of
G-CW complexes. The reader may prefer to assume that G is compact, but there
is no gain in simplicity. In view of the properties of the base change adjunction
(f!, f ‚àó) given in Proposition 7.3.4, there would be no real loss of generality if we
restricted further to base spaces that are actual G-CW complexes, but that would
be inconveniently restrictive.
137

138
9. THE EQUIVALENCE BETWEEN Ho GKB AND hGWB
9.1. The equivalence of Ho GKB and hGWB
Recall that X ‚àßB I+ is a cylinder object in the sense of the qf-model structure.
When we restrict to qf-Ô¨Åbrant and qf-coÔ¨Åbrant objects, homotopies in the qf-
model sense are the same as fp-homotopies, by Lemma 5.6.3. The morphism set
[X, Y ]G,B in Ho GKB is naturally isomorphic to [RQX, RQY ]G,B, and this is the
set of fp-homotopy classes of maps RQX ‚àí‚ÜíRQY . Here R and Q denote the
functorial qf-Ô¨Åbrant and qf-coÔ¨Åbrant approximation functors obtained from the
small object argument. The total space of RQX has the homotopy type of a G-
CW complex since B does. This leads us to introduce the following categories.
Definition 9.1.1. DeÔ¨Åne GVB to be the full subcategory of GKB whose ob-
jects are well-grounded and qf-Ô¨Åbrant with total spaces of the homotopy types of
G-CW complexes. DeÔ¨Åne GWB to be the full subcategory of GVB whose objects
are the ex-Ô¨Åbrations over B. Let hGWB denote the category obtained from GWB
by passage to fp-homotopy classes of maps.
Note that the deÔ¨Ånition of GWB makes no reference to model category theory.
Recall that well-grounded means well-sectioned and compactly generated. When
B = ‚àó, GW‚àóis just the category of well-based compactly generated G-spaces of the
homotopy types of G-CW complexes, and it is standard that its classical homotopy
category is equivalent to the homotopy category of based G-spaces with respect to
the q-model structure. We shall prove a parametrized generalization.
We think of GVB as a convenient half way house between GKB and GWB. It
turns out to be close enough to the category of qf-coÔ¨Åbrant and qf-Ô¨Åbrant objects in
GKB to serve as such for our purposes, while already having some of the properties
of GWB. The following crucial theorem fails for the q-model structure. It is essential
for this result that we only require the objects of VB to be well-sectioned, rather
than requiring them to be qf-coÔ¨Åbrant. This will force an assymmetry when we
deal with left and right derived functors in Proposition 9.2.2 below.
Theorem 9.1.2. The qf-coÔ¨Åbrant and qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation functor RQ
and the ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation functor P, together with the forgetful functors I
and J, induce the following equivalences of homotopy categories.
Ho GKB
RQ / Ho GVB
P
/
I
o
hGWB
J
o
Proof. For X in GKB, we have a natural zig-zag of q-equivalences in GKB
X
QX
o
/ RQX.
Therefore X and IRQX are naturally q-equivalent in GKB. If X is in GVB, then
it is qf-Ô¨Åbrant and therefore so is QX. Then the above zig-zag is in GVB and thus
X and RQIX are naturally q-equivalent in GVB.
Since q-equivalences in GVB are h-equivalences, and P takes h-equivalences to
fp-equivalences, it is clear that P induces a functor on homotopy categories. Con-
versely, since fp-equivalences are in particular q-equivalences, the forgetful functor
J induces a functor in the other direction. For X in GVB we have the natural
zig-zag of h-equivalences
X
WX
W Œπ /
œÅ
o
PX

9.2. DERIVED FUNCTORS ON HOMOTOPY CATEGORIES
139
of DeÔ¨Ånition 8.3.4. However WX may not be in GVB since it may not be qf-Ô¨Åbrant.
Applying qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation, we get a natural zig-zag of q-equivalences in
GVB connecting X and PX. It follows that X and JPX are naturally q-equivalent
in GVB. Starting with X in GWB, the above display is a zig-zag of fp-equivalences
in GWB, by Proposition 8.3.2.
It follows that X and JPX are naturally fp-
equivalent in GWB.
‚ñ°
9.2. Derived functors on homotopy categories
Model category theory tells us how Quillen functors V : GKA ‚àí‚ÜíGKB induce
derived functors on the homotopy categories on the left hand side of the equivalence
displayed in Theorem 9.1.2. We now seek an equivalent way of passing to derived
functors on the right hand side. We begin with an informal discussion. We focus
on functors of one variable, but functors of several variables work the same way.
Following the custom in algebraic topology, we have been abusing notation
by using the same notation for point-set level functors and for derived homotopy
category level functors. We will continue to do so. However, the more accurate no-
tations of algebraic geometry, LV and RV for left and right derived functors, might
clarify the discussion. As we have already seen in Counterexample 0.0.1, passage to
derived functors is not functorial in general, so that a relation between composites
of functors that holds on the point-set level need not imply a corresponding relation
on passage to homotopy categories.
Recall that, model theoretically, if V is a Quillen right adjoint, then the right
derived functor of V is obtained by Ô¨Årst applying Ô¨Åbrant approximation R and
then applying V on homotopy categories, which makes sense since V preserves
weak equivalences between Ô¨Åbrant objects. The left derived functor of a Quillen
left adjoint V is deÔ¨Åned dually, via V Q. Problems arise when one tries to compose
left and right derived functors, which is what we must do to prove some of our
compatibility relations.
The equivalence of categories proven in Theorem 9.1.2 gives us a way of putting
the relevant left and right adjoints on the same footing, giving a ‚Äústraight‚Äù passage
to derived functors that is neither ‚Äúleft‚Äù nor ‚Äúright‚Äù. We do not attempt a formal
categorical analysis. We need mild good behavior for this to work.
Definition 9.2.1. A functor V : GKA ‚àí‚ÜíGKB is good if it is continu-
ous, takes well-grounded ex-spaces to well-grounded ex-spaces, and takes ex-spaces
whose total spaces are of the homotopy types of G-CW complexes to ex-spaces with
that property. Since V is continuous, it preserves fp-homotopies.
Proposition 9.2.2. Let V : GKA ‚àí‚ÜíGKB be a good functor that is a left or a
right Quillen adjoint. If V is a Quillen left adjoint, assume further that it preserves
q-equivalences between well-grounded ex-spaces.
Then, under the equivalence of
categories in Theorem 9.1.2, the derived functor Ho GKA ‚àí‚ÜíHo GKB induced
by V Q or V R is equivalent to the functor PV J : hGWA ‚àí‚ÜíhGWB obtained by
passage to homotopy classes of maps.
Proof. If V is a Quillen right adjoint, then it preserves q-equivalences between
qf-Ô¨Åbrant objects.
If V is a Quillen left adjoint, then we are assuming that it
preserves q-equivalences between well-grounded objects.
Since GVA consists of
well-sectioned qf-Ô¨Åbrant objects, it follows in both cases that V : GVA ‚àí‚ÜíGVB
passes straight to homotopy categories to give V : HoGVA ‚àí‚ÜíHoGVB. Since V

preserves G-CW homotopy types on total spaces, V takes q-equivalences to h-
equivalences. Therefore PV takes q-equivalences to fp-equivalences and induces
a functor Ho GVA ‚àí‚ÜíhGWB. To show that PV J and either V Q or V R agree
under the equivalence of categories, it suÔ¨Éces to verify that the following diagram
commutes.

Remark 9.2.3. When V preserves ex-Ô¨Åbrations, PV is naturally fp-equivalent
to V on ex-Ô¨Åbrations, by Proposition 8.3.2. The derived functor of V can then be
obtained directly by applying V and passing to equivalence classes of maps under
fp-homotopy.
9.3. The functors f‚àóand FB on homotopy categories
We use the equivalence between Ho GKB and hGWB to prove that, for any
map f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB between spaces of the homotopy types of G-CW complexes, the
adjunction (f ‚àó, f‚àó) descends to homotopy categories. We begin by verifying that
f ‚àósatisÔ¨Åes the hypotheses of Proposition 9.2.2.
Proposition 9.3.1. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a map of base spaces. Then the base
change functor f ‚àórestricts to a functor f ‚àó: GWB ‚àí‚ÜíGWA.
Proof. Consider Y in GWB. Since the total space of Y is of the homotopy type
of a G-CW complex, the Ô¨Åbers Yb are of the homotopy types of Gb-CW complexes
by Theorem 3.5.2. The Ô¨Åber (f ‚àóY )a is a copy of Yf(a), and Ga acts through the
evident inclusion Ga ‚äÇGf(a).
Therefore (f ‚àóY )a is of the homotopy type of a
Ga-CW complex. The total space of f ‚àóY is therefore of the homotopy type of
a G-CW complex, again by Theorem 3.5.2. Moreover, f ‚àóY is an ex-Ô¨Åbration by
Proposition 8.2.2. Thus f ‚àórestricts to a functor f ‚àó: GWB ‚àí‚ÜíGWA.
‚ñ°
Recalling the discussion of ¬ß7.5, we write GW c
B for the full subcategory of GWB
whose objects are the G-connected ex-Ô¨Åbrations.

141
Theorem 9.3.2. For any map f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB of base spaces, the right derived
functor f ‚àó: Ho GK c
B ‚àí‚ÜíHo GK c
A has a right adjoint f‚àó, so that
[f ‚àóY, X]G,A ‚àº= [Y, f‚àóX]G,B
for X in GK c
A and Y in GK c
B.
Proof. Clearly f ‚àóY is G-connected if Y is G-connected. In view of the equiv-
alence of categories in Theorem 9.1.2 and the fact that f ‚àódescends directly to a
functor f ‚àó: hGW c
B ‚àí‚ÜíhGW c
B on homotopy categories, by Propositions 9.2.2 and
9.3.1, it suÔ¨Éces to construct a right adjoint f‚àó: hGW c
A ‚àí‚ÜíhGW c
B. We do that us-
ing the Brown representability theorem. By Theorem 7.5.17, Ho GK c
B satisÔ¨Åes the
formal hypotheses for Brown representability, and therefore so does hGW c
B. In fact
GW c
B has the required wedges over B, double mapping cylinders and telescopes since
these constructions preserve ex-Ô¨Åbrations by Proposition 8.2.1 and Corollary 8.2.5
and since they clearly preserve G-CW homotopy types on the total space level and
stay within GUB. The objects in the detecting set DB of DeÔ¨Ånition 7.5.12 are
not in GWB, but we can apply the ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation functor P to them to
obtain a detecting set of objects in hGWB. They still satisfy the requisite compact-
ness by Lemma 7.5.14 and our equivalence of categories. Therefore a contravariant
set-valued functor on hGW c
B is representable if and only if it satisÔ¨Åes the wedge and
Mayer-Vietoris axoms.
For a Ô¨Åxed ex-Ô¨Åbrant space X over A, consider the functor œÄ(f ‚àóY, X)G,A on
objects Y of GW c
B, where œÄ denotes fp-homotopy classes of maps. Since the functor
œÄ(W, X)G,A on objects W of GW c
A is represented and is computed using homotopy
classes of maps, it clearly satisÔ¨Åes the wedge and Mayer-Vietoris axioms. More-
over, the functor f ‚àópreserves wedges, double mapping cylinders, and telescopes.
Indeed, f ‚àó: GK c
B ‚àí‚ÜíGK c
A is a continuous left adjoint and therefore preserves col-
imits and tensors, and this implies that f ‚àó: GW c
B ‚àí‚ÜíGW c
A preserves the relevant
homotopy colimits. Moreover, f ‚àópreserves fp-homotopies and so induces a functor
on homotopy categories that still preserves these homotopy colimits. Therefore the
functor œÄ(f ‚àóY, X)G,A of Y also satisÔ¨Åes the wedge and Mayer-Vietoris axioms. We
conclude that there is an object f‚àóX ‚ààGW c
B that represents this functor. It follows
formally that f‚àóis a functor of X and that the required adjunction holds.
‚ñ°
Remark 9.3.3. When thinking in terms of HoGKB rather than hGWB, it is
vital to remember that f ‚àóhere refers to the right derived functor on homotopy
categories. While f ‚àópreserves some coÔ¨Åbrant objects, it still cannot be computed
in terms of such point-set level objects. For example, working nonequivariantly,
if f is an inclusion, then, on the point-set level, f ‚àóSn,b ‚àº= Sn,a if f(a) = b while
f ‚àóSn,b ‚àº= ‚àóA if b /‚ààIm(f). Our adjunction gives
[f ‚àóSn,b, X]A = [Sn,b, f‚àóX]B = œÄn((f‚àóX)b).
Clearly, this cannot have the erroneously predicted value œÄn(Xa) if f(a) = b and 0
otherwise. In particular, if A and B are connected and A is not all of B, this would
imply that œÄn(Xa) = 0 for all a and any X, which is nonsense.
We agree to write ‚âÉfor natural equivalences on homotopy categories.
Remark 9.3.4. For composable maps f and g, g‚àó‚ó¶f‚àó‚âÉ(g ‚ó¶f)‚àóon homotopy
categories since f ‚àó‚ó¶g‚àó‚âÉ(g ‚ó¶f)‚àóon homotopy categories. The latter equivalence

142
9. THE EQUIVALENCE BETWEEN Ho GKB AND hGWB
is clear since f ‚àóand g‚àóare derived from Quillen right adjoints. More sophisticated
commutation laws are proven in the next section.
Applying Theorem 9.3.2 to diagonal maps and composing with the homotopy
category level adjunction between the external smash product and function ex-space
functors, we obtain the following basic result; compare Lemma 2.5.6. Implicitly,
in everything that follows in this section and the next, we restrict to G-connected
ex-spaces whenever we apply base change functors f‚àó, such as ‚àÜ‚àó. Conclusions
that do not involve these functors apply in general.
Theorem 9.3.5. DeÔ¨Åne ‚àßB and FB on Ho GKB as the composite (derived)
functors
X ‚àßB Y = ‚àÜ‚àó(X ‚äºY )
and
FB(X, Y ) = ¬ØF(X, ‚àÜ‚àóY ).
Then
[X ‚àßB Y, Z]G,B ‚àº= [X, FB(Y, Z)]G,B
for X, Y , and Z in Ho GK c
B.
Proof. The displayed adjunction is the composite of adjunctions for the (de-
rived) external smash and function ex-space functors and for the (derived) adjoint
pair (‚àÜ‚àó, ‚àÜ‚àó).
‚ñ°
Remark 9.3.6. The referee (of the preliminary version) pointed out that the
ex-space analogue of [22, 7.2] shows that we can work directly with the point-
set topology to show that the (‚àßB, FB) adjunction on the original category GKB
is continuous and so descends to (classical) fp-homotopy categories to give the
adjunction
hGKB(X ‚àßB Y, Z) ‚àº= hGKB(X, FB(Y, Z)).
Similar point-set topological arguments work to show that, for a map f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB,
we have an adjunction
hGKA(f ‚àóX, Y ) ‚àº= hGKB(X, f‚àóY ).
These adjunctions do not imply our Theorems 9.3.2 and 9.3.5. By deÔ¨Ånition, our
category hGWB is a full subcategory of hGKB, but it is not an equivalent full
subcategory.
The objects of GWB are very restricted, and general function ex-
spaces FB(Y, Z) are not fp-homotopy equivalent to such objects. The force of our
theorems is that, after restricting to our subcategories hGW c
B, we still have right
adjoints in these categories. It is this fact that we need to obtain right adjoints in
our preferred homotopy categories Ho GK c
B.
9.4. Compatibility relations for smash products and base change
We Ô¨Årst prove that Ho GKB satisÔ¨Åes the associativity, commutativity and unity
conditions required of a symmetric monoidal category. We then show that all of
the isomorphisms of functors in Proposition 2.2.2 and some of the isomorphisms
of functors in Proposition 2.2.11 still hold after passage to homotopy categories.
Finally, we relate change of groups and passage to Ô¨Åbers to the symmetric monoidal
structure on homotopy categories. In some of our arguments, it is natural to work
in Ho GKB. In others, it is natural to work in the equivalent category hGWB.

9.4. COMPATIBILITY RELATIONS FOR SMASH PRODUCTS AND BASE CHANGE
143

Proof. For (9.4.2), we work with ex-Ô¨Åbrations, starting in hGWB√óB‚Ä≤.

Lemma 8.4.3(ii), we see that ¬µ: Pf ‚àó‚àí‚Üíf ‚àóP is a natural h-equivalence here. This
would be false for arbitrary maps f, as observed in Warning 8.4.4. Since ¬µ is an

topy equivalence. By Proposition 7.3.4, (i!, i‚àó) and (j!, j‚àó) are adjoint equivalences
of homotopy categories. Therefore

‚ñ°
Remark 9.4.8. As illustrated in this proof, it is a useful general procedure
to factor a map f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB as the composite of a homotopy equivalence and
a Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration. If f is an equivalence, then f! on derived categories is an
equivalence with inverse f ‚àó, hence f! is equivalent to g‚àófor a homotopy inverse g of
f. Therefore good properties of (‚àí)‚àótranslate to good properties of (‚àí)!. When f
is a Ô¨Åbration, we have derived commutation relations coming from Theorem 9.4.6
that can help in the study of f!. Note, however, that this factorization procedure
cannot be used to get around the Ô¨Åbration hypothesis in Theorem 9.4.6. It was our
attempt to achieve this that led to the discovery of Counterexample 0.0.1.
Finally, we turn to a promised compatibility relationship between products and
change of groups. We observed in Proposition 7.4.7 that the point-set level closed
symmetric monoidal equivalence of Proposition 2.3.9 is given by a Quillen equiva-
lence. The following addendem shows that the resulting equivalence on homotopy
categories is again closed symmetric monoidal.
Proposition 9.4.9. Let Œπ: H ‚àí‚ÜíG be the inclusion of a subgroup and A
be an H-space. The Quillen equivalence (Œπ!, ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àó) descends to a closed symmetric
monoidal equivalence between HoHKA and HoGKŒπ!A.
Proof. Let ‚àÜ: A ‚àí‚ÜíA √ó A be the diagonal map. The isomorphisms
Œπ‚àó‚àÜ‚àó(X ‚äºY ) ‚àº= ‚àÜ‚àóŒπ‚àó(X ‚äºY ) ‚àº= ‚àÜ‚àó(Œπ‚àóX ‚äºŒπ‚àóY )
descend to equivalences on homotopy categories, the Ô¨Årst since it is between Quillen
right adjoints, the second since Œπ‚àópreserves all q-equivalences.
It follows that
ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àóis a symmetric monoidal functor on homotopy categories.
Since it is also
an equivalence, it follows formally that it is closed symmetric monoidal.
‚ñ°
Combined with Theorem 9.4.5 applied to the inclusion Àúb: G/Gb ‚àí‚ÜíB, this
last observation gives us the following conclusion.
Theorem 9.4.10. The derived Ô¨Åber functor (‚àí)b : Ho GKB ‚àí‚ÜíHo GbKb is
closed symmetric monoidal, and it has a left adjoint (‚àí)b and a right adjoint b(‚àí).
We emphasize that this innocent looking result packages highly non-trivial and
important information.
It gives in particular that, for ex-spaces X and Y , the

146
9. THE EQUIVALENCE BETWEEN Ho GKB AND hGWB
(derived) Ô¨Åber FB(X, Y )b of the (derived) function space FB(X, Y ) is equivalent in
Ho GbKb to the (derived) function space F(Xb, Yb) of the (derived) Ô¨Åbers Xb and
Yb. On the point set level, that is what motivated the deÔ¨Ånition of the internal
function ex-space.
That it still holds on the level of homotopy categories is a
reassuring consistency result.
The annoying implicit restriction to G-connected
ex-spaces will disappear when we pass to a stable situation in Part III.

Part III
Parametrized equivariant stable
homotopy theory


Introduction
We develop rigorous foundations for parametrized equivariant stable homotopy
theory.
The idea is to start with a Ô¨Åxed base G-space B and to build a good
category, here denoted GSB, of G-spectra over B. We assume once and for all
that our base spaces B must be compactly generated and must have the homotopy
types of G-CW complexes. By ‚Äúgood‚Äù we mean that GSB is a closed symmet-
ric monoidal topological model category whose associated homotopy category has
properties analogous to those of the ordinary equivariant stable homotopy category.
Informally, the homotopy theory of GSB is speciÔ¨Åed by the homotopy theory that
is seen on the Ô¨Åbers of G-spectra over B. This builds a natural home in which one
can do stable homotopy theory while still keeping track of such unstable data as
the fundamental groupoid of the base space.
There are many foundational problems that make the development of the
parametrized theory a less than obvious generalization of the nonparametrized the-
ory. Problems on the space level were dealt with in Parts I and II, and we deal
with the analogous spectrum level problems here. We give some categorical pre-
liminaries on enriched equivariant categories in Chapter 10. We deÔ¨Åne and develop
the basic properties of our preferred category of parametrized G-spectra in Chapter
11, working on the point-set level. We study its model structures in Chapter 12,
and we study adjunctions and compatibility relations in Chapter 13. All of the
problems that we faced on the space level are still there, but their solutions are
more diÔ¨Écult. In Chapter 14, we go on to study further such compatibilities that
more fundamentally involve equivariance.
The theory of highly structured spectra is highly cumulative. We build on the
theory of equivariant orthogonal spectra of Mandell and May [105]. In turn, that
theory builds on the theory of nonequivariant orthogonal spectra. A self-contained
treatment of nonequivariant diagram spectra, including orthogonal spectra, is given
by Mandell, May, Schwede, Shipley in [106]. The treatments of [105] and [106], like
this one, are topological as opposed to simplicial. That seems to be essential when
dealing with inÔ¨Ånite groups of equivariance. It also allows use of orthogonal spectra
rather than symmetric spectra. These are much more natural equivariantly and,
even nonequivariantly, they have the major convenience that their weak equiva-
lences are exactly the maps that induce isomorphisms of homotopy groups.
The theory of equivariant parametrized spectra can be thought of as the pushout
over the theory of spectra of the theories of equivariant spectra and of nonequiv-
ariant parametrized spectra. In fact, given [105], the equivariance adds few serious
diÔ¨Éculties to the passage from spectra to parametrized spectra, although it does
add many interesting new features. The reader primarily interested in classical ho-
motopy theory should ignore all details of equivariance in reading Chapters 11‚Äì13.
149

150
INTRODUCTION
However, there is no nonequivariant precursor of the present treatment of
parametrized spectra in the literature. There are preliminary forms of such a theory
[9,10,31,32,42], but these either do not go beyond suspension spectra or are based
on obsolescent technology. None go far enough for our purposes, although the early
Ô¨Årst approximation of Monica Clapp [31], written up in more detail with Dieter
Puppe [32], deserves much credit. Clapp‚Äôs emphasis on ex-Ô¨Åbrations, together with
some key technical results about them, have been very helpful.
There are several possible alternative approaches.
Rather than building on
the theory of orthogonal G-spectra of [105, 106], one can build on the theory of
G-spectra, S-modules, and SG-modules of [98], [61], and [105], respectively. Po Hu
[78] began work on such a treatment, using parametrized G-spectra. However, she
followed the Ô¨Årst author‚Äôs unpublished notes [122] by taking the q-model structure
on ex-G-spaces as her starting point, and the stable model structure cannot be
made rigorous from there. It seems to us that resolving the foundational issues
concerning smash products, function spectra, base change functors, compatibility
relations, and so forth considered here would be more diÔ¨Écult in that framework
than in the one we have chosen. In ¬ß24.4, we at least give a rigorous deÔ¨Ånition of
the parametrized stable homotopy category from that point of view.
Alternatively, for Ô¨Ånite groups G, one can build on the theory of symmetric
spectra of Hovey, Smith, and Shipley [77] and its equivariant generalization due to
Mandell [104]. Such an approach would avoid the point-set topological technicalities
of the present approach and would presumably lead to rather diÔ¨Äerent looking
problems with Ô¨Åbrations and coÔ¨Åbrations. The problems with the stable homotopy
category level adjunctions that involve base change functors, smash products, and
function spectra are intrinsic and would remain. Our solutions to these problems
do not seem to carry over to the simplicial context in an obvious way, and an
alternative simplicial treatment could prove to be quite illuminating.
In view of the understanding of unstable equivariant homotopy theory for
proper actions of non-compact Lie groups that was obtained in Part II, it might
seem that there should be no real diÔ¨Éculty in obtaining a good stable theory along
the same lines as the theory for compact Lie groups. However, equivariant stable
homotopy theory for non-compact Lie groups is in rudimentary form. We leave its
study to future work, explaining in ¬ß11.6 where some of the problems lie. Except in
that section, G is asssumed to be a compact Lie group from Chapter 11 onwards.
A few other notes on terminology may be helpful. We shall not use the term
‚Äúex-spectrum over B‚Äù since, stably, there is no meaningful unsectioned theory.
Instead, we shall use the term ‚Äúspectrum over B‚Äù. This is especially convenient
when considering base change.
We write out ‚Äúorthogonal G-spectrum over B‚Äù
until ¬ß11.4.
However, since we consider no other kinds of G-spectra and work
equivariantly throughout, we later abbreviate this to ‚Äúspectrum over B‚Äù when
there is no danger of confusion. That is, we work equivariantly throughout, but we
only draw attention to this fact when it plays a signiÔ¨Åcant mathematical role.
In Part II, the main objects of study were ex-spaces over B, and we used letters
such as X and Y for them, using K and L for spaces. In this part, the main objects
of study are spectra over B, and we change conventions by now using letters such
as X and Y for them, using letters such as K and L for ex-spaces, and using letters
such as T for based spaces.

CHAPTER 10
Enriched categories and G-categories
Introduction
To give context for the structure enjoyed by the categories of parametrized
orthogonal G-spectra that we shall deÔ¨Åne, we Ô¨Årst describe the kind of equivariant
parametrized enrichments that we shall encounter. In fact, our categories have sev-
eral layers of enrichment, and it is helpful to have a consistent language, somewhat
non-standard from a categorical point of view, to keep track of them. In ¬ß¬ß10.1 and
10.2, we give some preliminaries on enriched categories, working nonequivariantly
in ¬ß10.1 and adding considerations of equivariance in ¬ß10.2. We discuss the role of
the several enrichments in sight in our G-topological model G-categories in ¬ß10.3.
In this chapter, G can be any topological group.
10.1. Parametrized enriched categories
As discussed in ¬ß1.2, all of our categories C are topological, meaning that
they are enriched over the category K‚àóof based spaces (= k-spaces). In contrast
with general enriched category theory and our further enrichments, the topological
enrichment is given just by a topology on the underlying set of morphisms, and we
denote the space of morphisms X ‚àí‚ÜíY by C (X, Y ). We say that a topological
category C is topologically bicomplete if it is bicomplete and bitensored over K‚àó.
In fact, we shall have enrichments and bitensorings over the category KB of ex-
spaces over B that imply the topological enrichment and bitensoring by restriction
to ex-spaces B √ó T for T ‚ààK‚àó.
Recall from ¬ß1.3 that KB is topologically bicomplete, with tensors and coten-
sors denoted by K ‚àßB T and FB(T, K) for T ‚ààK‚àóand K ‚ààKB. It is also closed
symmetric monoidal under its Ô¨Åberwise smash product and function space func-
tors, which are also denoted by ‚àßB and FB; its unit object is S0
B = B √ó S0. It is
therefore enriched and bitensored over itself. The two enrichments are related by
natural based homeomorphisms
(10.1.1)
KB(K, L) ‚àº= KB(S0
B, FB(K, L)).
This is the case T = S0 of the more general based homeomorphism
(10.1.2)
K‚àó(T, KB(K, L)) ‚àº= KB(S0
B ‚àßB T, FB(K, L))
for T ‚ààK‚àóand K, L ‚ààKB. The Yoneda lemma, (10.1.1), and the bitensoring
adjunctions imply that the two bitensorings are related by the equivalent natural
isomorphisms of ex-spaces
(10.1.3)
K ‚àßB T ‚àº= K ‚àßB (S0
B ‚àßB T)
and
FB(T, K) ‚àº= FB(S0
B ‚àßB T, K).
These in turn imply the equivalent generalizations
(10.1.4) K ‚àßB (L‚àßB T) ‚àº= (K ‚àßB L)‚àßB T and FB(T, FB(K, L)) ‚àº= FB(K ‚àßB T, L).
151

152
10. ENRICHED CATEGORIES AND G-CATEGORIES
Formally, rather than deÔ¨Åning the enrichments and bitensorings over K‚àóindepen-
dently, we can take (10.1.2) and (10.1.3) as deÔ¨Ånitions of these structures in terms
of the enrichment and bitensoring over KB.
Then (10.1.4) and the bitensoring
adjunction homeomorphisms
(10.1.5)
KB(K ‚àßB T, L) ‚àº= K‚àó(T, KB(K, L)) ‚àº= KB(K, FB(T, L))
follow directly.
Remark 10.1.6. We make frequent use of the functor r‚àó(‚àí) = S0
B ‚àßB (‚àí)
from based spaces to ex-spaces over B, and we henceforward abbreviate notation
by setting
TB = B √ó T = S0
B ‚àßB T
for a based space T, and similarly for maps. Observe that K ‚àßB T and K ‚àßB TB
are two names for the same ex-space over B. When working on a formal conceptual
level, it is often best to think in terms of tensors over K‚àóand use the Ô¨Årst name.
However, on a pragmatic level, to avoid confusion, it is perhaps best to view based
spaces as embedded in ex-spaces via r‚àóand to use the second notation, working
only with tensors over KB.
We generalize and formalize several aspects of the discussion above.
Definition 10.1.7. A topological category C is topological over B if it is en-
riched and bitensored over KB. It is topologically bicomplete over B if it is also
bicomplete. We write PB(X, Y ) for the hom ex-space over B, and we write X ‚àßB K
and FB(K, X) for the tensor and cotensor in C , where X, Y ‚ààC and K ‚ààKB.
Explicitly, we require bitensoring adjunction homeomorphisms of based spaces
(10.1.8)
C (X ‚àßB K, Y ) ‚àº= KB(K, PB(X, Y )) ‚àº= C (X, FB(K, Y )).
By Yoneda lemma arguments, these imply unit and transitivity isomorphisms in
C , namely
(10.1.9)
X ‚àº= X ‚àßB S0
B
and
X ‚àßB (K ‚àßB L) ‚àº= (X ‚àßB K) ‚àßB L,
and also bitensoring adjunction isomorphisms of ex-spaces
(10.1.10)
PB(X ‚àßB K, Y ) ‚àº= FB(K, PB(X, Y )) ‚àº= PB(X, FB(K, Y )).
Conversely, there is a natural homeomorphism
(10.1.11)
C (X, Y ) ‚àº= KB(S0
B, PB(X, Y )),
and the isomorphisms (10.1.8) follow from (10.1.10) by applying KB(S0
B, ‚àí).
If we do not require C to be topological to begin with, we can take (10.1.11)
as the deÔ¨Ånition of the space C (X, Y ) and so recover the topological enrichment.
With the notation of Remark 10.1.6, we obtain tensors and cotensors with based
spaces T by setting
(10.1.12)
X ‚àßB T = X ‚àßB TB
and
FB(T, X) = FB(TB, X).
The adjunction homeomorphisms
(10.1.13)
C (X ‚àßB T, Y ) ‚àº= K‚àó(T, C (X, Y )) ‚àº= C (X, FB(T, Y ))
are obtained by replacing K by TB in (10.1.8) and using (10.1.2) and (10.1.11).
In the cases of interest, C is closed symmetric monoidal, and then the hom
ex-spaces PB(X, Y ) can be understood in terms of the internal hom in C by the
following deÔ¨Ånition and result.

10.2. EQUIVARIANT PARAMETRIZED ENRICHED CATEGORIES
153
Definition 10.1.14. Let C be a topological category over B with a closed
symmetric monoidal structure given by a product ‚àßB and function object functor
FB, with unit object SB. We say that C is a topological closed symmetric monoidal
category over B if the tensors and products are related by a natural isomorphism
X ‚àßB K ‚àº= X ‚àßB (SB ‚àßB K)
in C for K ‚ààKB and X ‚ààC .
Proposition 10.1.15. Let C be a topological closed symmetric monoidal cate-
gory over B. Then, for K ‚ààKB and X, Y , Z ‚ààC , there are natural isomorphisms
FB(K, Y ) ‚àº= FB(SB ‚àßB K, Y ),
PB(X, Y ) ‚àº= PB(SB, FB(X, Y )),
PB(X ‚àßB Y, Z) ‚àº= PB(X, FB(Y, Z))
in C and a natural homeomorphism of based spaces
KB(K, PB(X, Y )) ‚àº= C (SB ‚àßB K, FB(X, Y )).
10.2. Equivariant parametrized enriched categories
Turning to the equivariant generalization, we give details of the context of
topological G-categories, continuous G-functors, and natural G-maps that we Ô¨Årst
alluded to in ¬ß1.4. The discussion elaborates on that given in [105, II¬ß1]. Generi-
cally, we use notations of the form CG and GC to denote a category CG enriched
over the category GK‚àóof based G-spaces and its associated ‚ÄúG-Ô¨Åxed category‚Äù
GC with the same objects and the G-maps between them; GC is enriched over
K‚àó. We shall write (CG, GC ) for such a pair, and we shall refer to the pair as a
‚ÄúG-category‚Äù.
In the terminology of enriched category theory, GC is the underlying topological
category of CG. The hom objects of CG are G-spaces CG(X, Y ); G-functors and
natural G-maps just mean functors and natural transformations enriched over GK‚àó.
Consistently with enriched category theory, the space GC (X, Y ) = CG(X, Y )G can
be identiÔ¨Åed with the space of G-maps S0 ‚àí‚ÜíCG(X, Y ). We call the points of
CG(X, Y ) ‚Äúarrows‚Äù to distinguish them from the points of GC (X, Y ), which we
call ‚ÄúG-maps‚Äù, or often just ‚Äúmaps‚Äù, with the equivariance understood.
We cannot expect CG to have limits and colimits, but GC is usually bicomplete.
In many of our examples, both CG and GC are closed symmetric monoidal under
functors ‚àßB and FB. For example, we have the closed symmetric monoidal G-
category (KG,B, GKB) of ex-G-spaces over a G-space B described in ¬ß1.4.
Definition 10.2.1. A G-category (CG, GC ) is G-topological over B if CG is
enriched over GKB and bitensored over KG,B. It follows that GC is enriched over
KB and bitensored over GKB. We say that (CG, GC ) is G-topologically bicomplete
over B if, in addition, GC is bicomplete. We write PB(X, Y ) for the hom ex-G-
space over B, and we write X ‚àßB K and FB(K, X) for the tensor and cotensor in
CG, where X, Y ‚ààCG and K ‚ààKG,B. Explicitly, we require bitensoring adjunction
homeomorphisms of based G-spaces
(10.2.2)
CG(X ‚àßB K, Y ) ‚àº= KG,B(K, PB(X, Y )) ‚àº= CG(X, FB(K, Y )).
There result coherent unit and transitivity isomorphisms in GC
(10.2.3)
X ‚àº= X ‚àßB S0
B
and
X ‚àßB (K ‚àßB L) ‚àº= (X ‚àßB K) ‚àßB L

154
10. ENRICHED CATEGORIES AND G-CATEGORIES
and also bitensoring adjunction isomorphisms of ex-G-spaces
(10.2.4)
PB(X ‚àßB K, Y ) ‚àº= FB(K, PB(X, Y )) ‚àº= PB(X, FB(K, Y )).
Conversely, there is a natural homeomorphism of based G-spaces
(10.2.5)
CG(X, Y ) ‚àº= KG,B(S0
B, PB(X, Y )),
and the isomorphisms (10.2.2) follow from (10.2.4) by applying KG,B(S0
B, ‚àí). Pas-
sage to G-Ô¨Åxed points from (10.2.2) gives the bitensoring adjunction homeomor-
phisms of based spaces
(10.2.6)
GC (X ‚àßB K, Y ) ‚àº= GKB(K, PB(X, Y )) ‚àº= GC (X, FB(K, Y )).
We warn the reader that we shall not always adhere strictly to the notational
pattern of DeÔ¨Ånition 10.2.1 for our several layers of enrichment. In particular, in
the domain categories for our equivariant diagram spaces and diagram spectra, only
CG is of interest, not GC , and our notations will reÔ¨Çect that. On the other hand,
when studying model categories, it is always the bicomplete category GC that is
of fundamental interest.
If (CG, GC ) is G-topological over B, then it is automatically G-topological
(over ‚àó). This enrichment is recovered by taking (10.1.11), read equivariantly, as
the deÔ¨Ånition of the based G-space CG(X, Y ). Just as in the nonequivariant case,
for based G-spaces T and objects X of CG, the tensors and cotensors in CG and
GC are given on objects by
(10.2.7)
X ‚àßB T = X ‚àßB TB
and
FB(T, X) = FB(TB, X),
using the notation of Remark 10.1.6 equivariantly. The required G-homeomorphisms
(10.2.8)
CG(X ‚àßB T, Y ) ‚àº= KG,‚àó(T, CG(X, Y )) ‚àº= CG(X, FB(T, Y ))
follow directly.
We have equivariant analogues of DeÔ¨Ånition 10.1.14 and Proposition 10.1.15.
Definition 10.2.9. Let (CG, GC ) be a G-topological G-category over B with
a closed symmetric monoidal structure given by a product G-functor ‚àßB and a
function object G-functor FB, with unit object SB.
We say that (CG, GC ) is
a G-topological closed symmetric monoidal G-category over B if the tensors and
products are related by a natural isomorphism
X ‚àßB K ‚àº= X ‚àßB (SB ‚àßB K)
in GC for K ‚ààGKB and X ‚ààGC .
Proposition 10.2.10. Let (CG, GC ) be a G-topological closed symmetric mon-
oidal G-category over B. Then, for K ‚ààKB and X, Y , Z ‚ààC , there are natural
isomorphisms
FB(K, Y ) ‚àº= FB(SB ‚àßB K, Y ),
PB(X, Y ) ‚àº= PB(SB, FB(X, Y )),
PB(X ‚àßB Y, Z) ‚àº= PB(X, FB(Y, Z))
in GC and there is a natural homeomorphism of based G-spaces
KG,B(K, PB(X, Y )) ‚àº= CG(SB ‚àßB K, FB(X, Y )).

10.3. G-TOPOLOGICAL MODEL G-CATEGORIES
155
10.3. G-topological model G-categories
We explain what it means for a G-topological G-category (CG, GC ) over B to
have a G-topological model structure. This structure implies in particular that the
homotopy category HoGC is bitensored over the homotopy category HoGK . We
need some notation. Throughout this section, we consider maps
i: W ‚àí‚ÜíX, j : V ‚àí‚ÜíZ, and p: E ‚àí‚ÜíY
in GC and a map k: K ‚àí‚ÜíL in either GKB or GK‚àó; in the latter case we apply
the functor (‚àí)B = B √ó (‚àí) to k and so regard it as a map in GKB, as suggested
in Remark 10.1.6. We shall deÔ¨Åne the notion of a G-topological model category in
terms of the induced map
(10.3.1)
C ‚ñ°
G (i, p): CG(X, E) ‚àí‚ÜíCG(W, E) √óCG(W,Y ) CG(X, Y )
of based G-spaces. Passing to G-Ô¨Åxed points, this gives rise to a map
(10.3.2)
GC ‚ñ°(i, p): GC (X, E) ‚àí‚ÜíGC (W, E) √óGC (W,Y ) GC (X, Y )
of based spaces, and we have the following motivating observation.
Lemma 10.3.3. The pair (i, p) has the lifting property if and only if the function
GC ‚ñ°(i, p) is surjective.
Definition 10.3.4. Let (CG, GC ) be a G-topological G-category over B such
that GC is a model category. We say that the model structure is G-topological if
C ‚ñ°
G (i, p) is a Ô¨Åbration in GK‚àówhen i is a coÔ¨Åbration and p is a Ô¨Åbration and is
acyclic when, further, either i or p is acyclic.
Remark 10.3.5. The deÔ¨Ånition must refer consistently to either h-type or q-
type model structures; the resulting notions are quite diÔ¨Äerent. We usually have in
mind a q-type model structure, in which case the weak equivalences and Ô¨Åbrations
are often characterized by conditions on the H-Ô¨Åxed point maps f H of a map f. If
F is a family of subgroups of G, such as the family G of compact subgroups, then
we can restrict attention to those H that are in F. The resulting F-equivalences
and F-Ô¨Åbrations usually specify another model structure on GC . In particular, we
have the F-model structure on GK‚àó. For the qf-type model structures of ¬ß7.2, we
must start with a generating set C that contains the orbits G/H with H ‚ààF ‚à©G
and consists of F ‚à©G -cell complexes. We say that an F-model structure on GC is
F-topological if the condition of the previous deÔ¨Ånition holds when we use the F-
notions of Ô¨Åbration, coÔ¨Åbration and weak equivalence throughout. The observations
of this section generalize to F-topological model categories for any family F.
In addition to the map of G-spaces displayed in (10.3.1), we have a map
(10.3.6)
P ‚ñ°
B (i, p): PB(X, E) ‚àí‚ÜíPB(W, E) √óPB(W,Y ) PB(X, Y )
of ex-G-spaces over B.
Warning 10.3.7. We can deÔ¨Åne what it means for (CG, GC ) to be a G-
topological model G-category over B, using the map P ‚ñ°
B (i, p) of ex-G-spaces rather
than the map C ‚ñ°
G (i, p) of G-spaces. However,we know of no q-type examples (even
nonequivariant ones) where this condition is satisÔ¨Åed. For example, (KG,B, GKB)
is G-topological, by Theorems 7.2.3 and 7.2.8, but, as Warning 6.1.7 makes clear
by adjunction, we cannot expect it to be G-topological over B.

156
10. ENRICHED CATEGORIES AND G-CATEGORIES
Just as in the classical theory of simplicial or topological model categories, there
are various equivalent reformulations of what it means for GC to be G-topological.
To explain them, observe that the tensors and cotensors with ex-G-spaces over B
give rise to induced maps
(10.3.8)
i‚ñ°Bk: (X ‚àßB K) ‚à™W ‚àßBK (W ‚àßB L) ‚àí‚ÜíX ‚àßB L
and
(10.3.9)
F ‚ñ°
B (k, p): FB(L, E) ‚àí‚ÜíFB(K, E) √óFB(K,Y ) FB(L, Y )
of ex-G-spaces over B. If (CG, GC ) is closed symmetric monoidal, then we also
have the induced maps
(10.3.10)
i‚ñ°Bj : (X ‚àßB V ) ‚à™W ‚àßBV (W ‚àßB Z) ‚àí‚ÜíX ‚àßB Z
and
(10.3.11)
F ‚ñ°
B (j, p): FB(Z, E) ‚àí‚ÜíFB(V, E) √óFB(V,Y ) FB(Z, Y )
in GC . We have various adjunction isomorphisms relating these various ‚ñ°-product
maps and ‚ñ°-function object maps.
Proposition 10.3.12. If k is a map of ex-G-spaces over B, then there are
adjunction isomorphisms
(10.3.13)
P ‚ñ°
B (i‚ñ°Bk, p) ‚àº= F ‚ñ°
B (k, P ‚ñ°
B (i, p)) ‚àº= P ‚ñ°
B (i, F ‚ñ°
B (k, p))
of maps of ex-G-spaces over B and
(10.3.14)

G,B(k, P ‚ñ°
B (i, p)) ‚àº= C ‚ñ°
G (i, F ‚ñ°
B (k, p))
of maps of based G-spaces. If k is a map of based G-spaces, then the last pair of
isomorphisms can be rewritten as
(10.3.15)
C ‚ñ°
G (i‚ñ°Bk, p) ‚àº= K ‚ñ°
G,‚àó(k, C ‚ñ°

G (i, F ‚ñ°
B (k, p)).
When (CG, GC ) is closed symmetric monoidal there are adjunction isomorphisms
(10.3.16)
P ‚ñ°
B (i‚ñ°Bk, p) ‚àº= P ‚ñ°
B (i, F ‚ñ°
B (k, p))
of maps of ex-G-spaces over B and
(10.3.17)
C ‚ñ°
G (i‚ñ°Bk, p) ‚àº= C ‚ñ°
G (i, F ‚ñ°
B (k, p))
of maps of based G-spaces.
Together with Lemma 10.3.3, this implies the promised alternative equivalent
conditions that describe when a model category is G-topological.
Proposition 10.3.18. Let (CG, GC ) be a G-topological G-category over B such
that GC has a model structure. Then the following conditions are equivalent.
(i) The map i‚ñ°Bk of (10.3.8) is a coÔ¨Åbration in GC if i is a coÔ¨Åbration in GC
and k is a coÔ¨Åbration in GK‚àó. It is acyclic if either i or k is acyclic.
(ii) The map F ‚ñ°
B (k, p) of (10.3.9) is a Ô¨Åbration in GC if p is a Ô¨Åbration in GC
and k is a coÔ¨Åbration in GK‚àó. It is acyclic if either p or k is acyclic.
(iii) The map C ‚ñ°
G (i, p) of (10.3.1) is a Ô¨Åbration in GK‚àóif i is a coÔ¨Åbration in GC
and p is a Ô¨Åbration in GC . It is acyclic if either i or p is acyclic.

10.3. G-TOPOLOGICAL MODEL G-CATEGORIES
157
Proof. The third condition is our deÔ¨Ånition of the model structure being
G-topological.
We prove that the Ô¨Årst condition is equivalent to the third.
A
similar argument shows that the second condition is also equivalent to the third.
The map C ‚ñ°
G (i, p) is a Ô¨Åbration if and only if (k, C ‚ñ°
G (i, p)) has the lifting property
with respect to all acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations k in GK‚àó. By Lemma 10.3.3 and the Ô¨Årst
adjunction isomorphism in (10.3.15), that holds if and only if (i‚ñ°Bk, p) has the
lifting property, that is, if and only if i‚ñ°Bk is an acyclic coÔ¨Åbration. If either i or
p is acyclic, then we take k to be a coÔ¨Åbration in GK‚àóand argue similarly.
‚ñ°


CHAPTER 11
The category of orthogonal G-spectra over B
Introduction
Intuitively, an orthogonal spectrum X over B consists of ex-spaces X(V ) over B
and ex-maps œÉ: X(V )‚àßBSW ‚àí‚ÜíX(V ‚äïW) for suitable inner product spaces V and
W. The orthogonal group O(V ) must act on X(V ), and œÉ must be (O(V )√óO(W))-
equivariant. The orthogonal group actions enable the deÔ¨Ånition of a good external
smash product. Moreover, they will later allow us to deÔ¨Åne stable weak equivalences
in terms of homotopy groups, as would not be possible if we only had actions by
symmetric groups.
Similarly, use of general inner product spaces allows us to build in actions
by a compact Lie group G without diÔ¨Éculty.
For non-compact Lie groups, we
should ignore inner products and use linear isomorphisms, replacing the compact
orthogonal group O(V ) by the general linear group GL(V ). However, as we explain
in ¬ß11.6, there are more serious problems in generalizing to non-compact Lie groups;
except in that section, we require G to be a compact Lie group.
Working equivariantly, we Ô¨Årst ignore the structure maps œÉ and describe the
diagram category of ex-G-spaces in ¬ß11.1. We build in the structure maps in ¬ß11.2,
where we deÔ¨Åne the category of orthogonal G-spectra over B. In ¬ß11.3, we show
that this category too can be described as a diagram category of ex-G-spaces, of
course over a diÔ¨Äerent domain category.
The formal properties of the category
of ex-G-spaces over B carry over to the category of orthogonal G-spectra over B,
but there are some new twists. For example, our category of G-spectra over B is
enriched not just over based G-spaces, but more generally over ex-G-spaces over
B. We discussed the relevant formalities in the previous chapter. This enhanced
enrichment is essential to the deÔ¨Ånition of function G-spectra over B.
We show in ¬ß11.4 that the base change functors and their properties also carry
over to these categories of parametrized G-spectra, and we discuss change of group
functors and restriction to Ô¨Åbers in ¬ß11.5.
11.1. The category of IG-spaces over B
We recall the G-category (IG, GI ) from [105, II.2.1]. The objects and arrows
of IG are Ô¨Ånite dimensional G-inner product spaces and linear isometric isomor-
phisms. The maps of GI are G-linear isometries. More precisely, as dictated by
the general theory of [105,106], we take IG(V, W) as based with basepoint disjoint
from the space of linear isometric isomorphisms V ‚àí‚ÜíW. The objects V run over
a collection V of G-representations that is closed under direct sums and contains
the trivial representation R. We generally focus on the collection V (U) of all rep-
resentations that embed up to isomorphism in a given ‚ÄúG-universe‚Äù U, where a
159

160
11. THE CATEGORY OF ORTHOGONAL G-SPECTRA OVER B
G-universe is a sum of countably many copies of representations in a set of repre-
sentations that includes the trivial representation. We usually think in terms of a
‚Äúcomplete G-universe‚Äù, one that contains all representations of G, but the choice
is irrelevant until otherwise stated.
Based G-spaces are ex-G-spaces over ‚àó, and IG-spaces are deÔ¨Åned in [105,
II.2.3] as G-functors IG ‚àí‚ÜíTG, where TG is the G-category of compactly gen-
erated based G-spaces. One can just as well drop the weak HausdorÔ¨Äcondition,
which plays no necessary mathematical role in [105, 106], and allow general k-
spaces. With the notations of Part II, we can thus change the target G-category
to KG,‚àó. Then we generalize the deÔ¨Ånition to the parametrized context simply
by changing the target G-category to the category KG,B of ex-G-spaces over a G-
space B. Thus we deÔ¨Åne an IG-space X over (and under) B to be a G-functor
X : IG ‚àí‚ÜíKG,B. Using nonequivariant arrows and equivariant maps, we obtain
the G-category (IGKB, GI KB) of IG-spaces.
To unravel deÔ¨Ånitions, for each representation V ‚ààV we are given an ex-G-
space X(V ) over B, for each arrow (linear isometric isomorphism) f : V ‚àí‚ÜíW we
are given an arrow (non-equivariant map)
X(f): X(V ) ‚àí‚ÜíX(W)
of ex-G-spaces over B, and the continuous function
X : IG(V, W) ‚àí‚ÜíKG,B(X(V ), X(W))
is a based G-map. An arrow Œ±: X ‚àí‚ÜíY is just a natural transformation, and
a G-map is a G-natural transformation, for which each Œ±V : X(V ) ‚àí‚ÜíY (V ) is a
G-map. For both arrows and G-maps, the naturality diagrams
X(V )
Œ±V
/
X(f)

Y (V )
Y (f)

X(W)
Œ±W / Y (W)
must commute for all arrows f : V
‚àí‚ÜíW.
The group G acts on the space
IGKB(X, Y ) of arrows by levelwise conjugation. The G-Ô¨Åxed category is denoted
by GI KB. It has objects the IG-spaces X and maps the G-maps.
To study the parametrized enrichment of the G-category of orthogonal G-
spectra over B, it is convenient to extend the domain category IG, which is enriched
over KG,‚àó, to a new domain category IG,B that is enriched over KG,B. Departing
from the notational pattern of DeÔ¨Ånition 10.2.1 and using Remark 10.1.6, we deÔ¨Åne
the hom ex-G-spaces over B of IG,B by
(11.1.1)
IG,B(V, W) = IG(V, W)B ‚â°B √ó IG(V, W).
If X : IG ‚àí‚ÜíKG,B is an IG-space, then the given based G-maps
X : IG(V, W) ‚àí‚ÜíKG,B(X(V ), X(W))
correspond by adjunction (see (10.2.7) and (10.2.8)) to ex-G-maps
X(V ) ‚àßB IG,B(V, W) ‚àí‚ÜíX(W).
In turn, these correspond by the internal hom adjunction to ex-G-maps
X : IG,B(V, W) ‚àí‚ÜíFB(X(V ), X(W)).

These give an equivalent version of the original G-functor X, but now in terms of
categories enriched over the category GKB.
Lemma 11.1.2. The G-category (IGKB, GI KB) of IG-spaces is equivalent
to the G-category of IG,B-spaces, where an IG,B-space is a G-functor
X : IG,B ‚àí‚ÜíKG,B

With these constructions, we see that (IGKB, GI KB) is G-topological over B;
compare DeÔ¨Ånition 10.2.1 and the discussion following it. The last statement follows
since GI KB is complete and cocomplete, with limits and colimits constructed
levelwise from the limits and colimits in GKB.
‚ñ°
We have several kinds of smash products and function objects in this context.
For IG-spaces X and Y over B, deÔ¨Åne the ‚Äúexternal‚Äù smash product X ‚äºB Y by
X ‚äºB Y = ‚àßB ‚ó¶(X √ó Y ): IG √ó IG ‚àí‚ÜíKG,B.
Thus (X ‚äºB Y )(V, W) = X(V ) ‚àßB Y (W). Here we have used the word ‚Äúexternal‚Äù
to refer to the use of pairs of representations, as is usual in the theory of diagram
spectra. It is standard category theory [43,106] to use left Kan extension to inter-
nalize this external smash product over B; relevant general deÔ¨Ånitions are recalled
in ¬ß23.1. This gives the internal smash product X ‚àßB Y of IG-spaces over B, which
is again an IG-space over B. For an IG-space Y over B and an (IG √ó IG)-space
Z over B, deÔ¨Åne the external function IG-space over B, denoted ¬ØFB(Y, Z), by
¬ØFB(Y, Z)(V ) = PB(Y, Z‚ü®V ‚ü©),
where Z‚ü®V ‚ü©(W) = Z(V, W). It is mainly to allow this deÔ¨Ånition that weneed the
morphism ex-G-spaces PB(‚àí, ‚àí). It is also formal to obtain an internal function
IG-space functor FB on IG-spaces over B by use of right Kan extension [43,106].
Using these internal smash product and function IG-space functors, we obtain the
following result. Recall DeÔ¨Ånition 10.2.9 and Proposition 10.2.10.
Theorem 11.1.6. (IGKB, GI KB) is a G-topological closed symmetric mon-
oidal G-category over B.
Remark 11.1.7. In the theory of ex-spaces, we also have the ‚Äúexternal smash
product‚Äù of ex-spaces over diÔ¨Äerent base spaces deÔ¨Åned in ¬ß2.5.
Using the two
diÔ¨Äerent notions of ‚Äúexternal‚Äù together, we obtain the deÔ¨Ånition of the ‚Äúexternal
external smash product‚Äù of an IG-space X over A and an IG-space Y over B; it
is an (IG √ó IG)-space over A √ó B. We write X ‚äºY for the left Kan extension
internalization of this smash product. Thus X ‚äºY is an IG-space over A √ó B.
Similarly, using the external function ex-space construction ¬ØF of ¬ß2.5, for an IG-
space Y over B and an IG-space Z over A√óB, we obtain the ‚Äúinternalized external

163
function IG-space‚Äù ¬ØF(Y, Z) over A.
Notationally, use of ‚äºand ¬ØF without an
ensuing subscript always denotes these internalized external operations with respect
to varying base spaces. We shall return to these functors in Proposition 11.4.10.
Similarly, but more simply, we have the ‚Äúexternal tensor‚Äù K ‚äºY of an ex-G-
space K over A and an IG-space Y over B, which again is an IG-space over A√óB.
When A = ‚àó, this just constructs the tensor of a based G-space with an IG-space
over B. When B = ‚àó, this constructs an IG-space over A from an ex-G-space
over A and a nonparametrized IG-space. Since these external tensors can be view
as special cases of external smash products, via variants of DeÔ¨Ånition 10.2.9 and
(11.2.6) below, we shall not treat them formally and shall not repeat the deÔ¨Ånitions
on the G-spectrum level. However, we shall Ô¨Ånd several uses for them.

be more explicit than that.

The categories PG,B and GPB enjoy the same properties that were speci-

11.3. Orthogonal G-spectra as diagram ex-G-spaces
Arguing as in [106, ¬ß2] and [105, II¬ß4], we construct a new domain category
JG,B which has the same object set V as IG and, like IG,B, is enriched over GKB.
It builds in spheres in such a way that the category of IG-spectra over B is equiva-
lent to the category of JG,B-spaces over B. Here, just as for IG,B in Lemma 11.1.2,
we understand a JG,B-space to be an enriched G-functor X : JG,B ‚àí‚ÜíKG,B.
Thus it is speciÔ¨Åed by ex-G-spaces X(V ) and ex-G-maps
X : JG,B(V, W) ‚àí‚ÜíFB(X(V ), X(W)).
To construct JG,B, recall from [105, II¬ß4] that we have a topological G-category
JG with object set V such that the category of IG-spectra is equivalent to the
category of JG-spaces. We deÔ¨Åne
(11.3.1)
JG,B(V, W) = JG(V, W)B,
just as we deÔ¨Åned IG,B in (11.1.1), and the desired equivalence of categories follows.
Several constructions of JG are given in [105, 106], and we shall shortly give an
alternative direct description of JG,B that is based on one of them. The intuition
is that an extension of an IG,B-space to a JG,B-space builds in an action by SB.
The alternative description of GSB as the category of enriched G-functors
JG,B ‚àí‚ÜíKG,B and enriched G-natural transformations leads to a more concep-
tual proof of Theorem 11.2.5: it is a specialization of general results about diagram
categories of enriched functors.
In analogy with (11.1.4) we could have deÔ¨Åned
PB(X, Y ) to be the end
(11.3.2)
PB(X, Y ) =
Z
JG,B
FB(X(V ), Y (V ))
and derived the isomorphism (11.2.8) just as we derived (11.1.5) in the previous
section.
By the Yoneda lemma, the two deÔ¨Ånitions of PB(X, Y ) agree.
With
this description of PB, some of the adjunctions in Theorem 11.2.5 become more
transparent.
This leads us to the promised alternative description of JG,B. It is given in
terms of IG,B rather than JG and follows the formal deÔ¨Ånition of [106, 2.1]. We
have the represented functors V ‚àó: IG ‚àí‚ÜíKG,B speciÔ¨Åed by V ‚àó(W) = IG,B(V, W).
If X is an IG-space, such as V ‚àó, then the smash product X ‚àßB SB in the category
of IG-spaces should be thought of as the ‚Äúfree‚Äù orthogonal G-spectrum over B
generated by X. Let
(11.3.3)
JG,B(V, W) = PB(W ‚àó‚àßB SB, V ‚àó‚àßB SB),
with the evident composition. Then we can mimic the arguments of [106, ¬ß¬ß2, 23] to
check that the category of JG,B-spaces is equivalent to the category of IG-spectra
over B. An enriched Yoneda lemma argument [87, 2.4] shows that this description
of JG,B coincides up to isomorphism with our original one.

11.4. THE BASE CHANGE FUNCTORS f ‚àó, f!, AND f‚àó
167
Although we will not have occasion to quote it formally, we record the following
consequence of the identiÔ¨Åcation of IG-spectra over B with JG,B-spaces.
Lemma 11.3.4. For any enriched G-functor T : KG,B ‚àí‚ÜíKG,B and orthogonal
G-spectrum X over B, the composite functor T ‚ó¶X is an orthogonal G-spectrum over
B. Similarly, an enriched natural transformation Œæ : T ‚àí‚ÜíT ‚Ä≤ induces a natural G-
map Œæ : T ‚ó¶X ‚àí‚ÜíT ‚Ä≤ ‚ó¶X.
Proof. The enriched functor T is given by maps
T : FB(K, L) ‚àí‚ÜíFB(T(K), T(L)).
Composing levelwise with X gives maps
JG,B(V, W) ‚àí‚ÜíFB(T(X(V )), T(X(W)))
that specify T ‚ó¶X. It is a direct categorical implication of the fact that T is an
enriched functor that there are natural maps of ex-G-spaces
T(K) ‚àßB L ‚àí‚ÜíT(K ‚àßB L)
and
TFB(K, L) ‚àí‚ÜíFB(K, T(L))
for ex-G-spaces K and L. This explains more concretely why the structure maps
of X induce structure maps for T ‚ó¶X. Similarly, since Œæ is enriched, it is given by
maps from the unit ex-G-space S0
B to FB(T(K), T ‚Ä≤(K)) such that the appropriate
diagrams commute. We specialize to K = X(V ) to obtain Œæ : T ‚ó¶X ‚àí‚ÜíT ‚Ä≤ ‚ó¶X.
‚ñ°

11.4. The base change functors f ‚àó, f!, and f‚àó
From now on, we drop the adjective ‚Äúorthogonal‚Äù (or preÔ¨Åx IG), and we gen-
erally take the equivariance for granted, referring to orthogonal G-spectra over B
just as spectra over B. We return G to the notations when considering change of
groups, or for emphasis, but otherwise G-actions are tacitly assumed throughout.
We Ô¨Årst show that the results on base change functors proven for ex-spaces
in ¬ß2.2 extend to parametrized spectra.
We then show that the results in ¬ß2.5
relating external and internal smash product and function ex-spaces also extend to
parametrized spectra. Let A and B be base G-spaces.

168
11. THE CATEGORY OF ORTHOGONAL G-SPECTRA OVER B
Theorem 11.4.1. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a G-map. Let X be in SG,A and let Y
and Z be in SG,B. There are G-functors
f! : SG,A ‚àí‚ÜíSG,B,
f ‚àó: SG,B ‚àí‚ÜíSG,A,
f‚àó: SG,A ‚àí‚ÜíSG,B
and G-adjunctions
SG,B(f!X, Y ) ‚àº= SG,A(X, f ‚àóY )
and
SG,A(f ‚àóY, X) ‚àº= SG,B(Y, f‚àóX).
On passage to G-Ô¨Åxed points levelwise, there result functors
f! : GSA ‚àí‚ÜíGSB,
f ‚àó: GSB ‚àí‚ÜíGSA,
f‚àó: GSA ‚àí‚ÜíGSB
and adjunctions
GSB(f!X, Y ) ‚àº= GSA(X, f ‚àóY )
and
GSA(f ‚àóY, X) ‚àº= GSB(Y, f‚àóX).
The functor f ‚àóis closed symmetric monoidal. Therefore, by deÔ¨Ånition and impli-
cation, f ‚àóSB ‚àº= SA and there are natural isomorphisms
f ‚àó(Y ‚àßB Z) ‚àº= f ‚àóY ‚àßA f ‚àóZ,
(11.4.2)
FB(Y, f‚àóX) ‚àº= f‚àóFA(f ‚àóY, X),
(11.4.3)
f ‚àóFB(Y, Z) ‚àº= FA(f ‚àóY, f ‚àóZ),
(11.4.4)
f!(f ‚àóY ‚àßA X) ‚àº= Y ‚àßB f!X,
(11.4.5)
FB(f!X, Y ) ‚àº= f‚àóFA(X, f ‚àóY ).
(11.4.6)
Proof. We deÔ¨Åne the functors f ‚àó, f!, and f‚àólevelwise. This certainly gives
well-deÔ¨Åned functors on IG-spaces that satisfy the appropriate adjunctions there.
We shall show shortly that these functors preserve IG-spectra. For a based G-
space T, f ‚àó(TB) ‚àº= TA, and this implies f ‚àóSB ‚àº= SA. If we replace IG-spectra
by IG-spaces and replace the internal smash product and function object functors
(‚àßand F) by their external precursors (‚äºand ¬ØF), then everything is immediate
by levelwise application of the corresponding results for ex-spaces. Still working
with IG-spaces, we Ô¨Årst show how to internalize the isomorphisms (11.4.2) and
(11.4.5) by use of the universal property of left Kan extension. Indeed, noting that
(f‚àóX) ‚ó¶‚äï‚àº= f‚àó(X ‚ó¶‚äï), and similarly for f ‚àóand f!, we have
IGKA(f ‚àó(Y ‚àßB Z), X) ‚àº= IGKB(Y ‚àßB Z, f‚àóX)
‚àº= (IG √ó IG)KB(Y ‚äºB Z, f‚àóX ‚ó¶‚äï)
‚àº= (IG √ó IG)KA(f ‚àó(Y ‚äºB Z), X ‚ó¶‚äï)
‚àº= (IG √ó IG)KA(f ‚àóY ‚äºA f ‚àóZ, X ‚ó¶‚äï)
‚àº= IGKA(f ‚àóY ‚àßA f ‚àóZ, X)
and
IGKB(f!X ‚àßB Y, Z) ‚àº= (IG √ó IG)KB(f!X ‚äºB Y, Z ‚ó¶‚äï)
‚àº= (IG √ó IG)KB(f!(X ‚äºA f ‚àóY ), Z ‚ó¶‚äï)
‚àº= (IG √ó IG)KA(X ‚äºA f ‚àóY, f ‚àóZ ‚ó¶‚äï)
‚àº= IGKA(X ‚àßA f ‚àóY, f ‚àóZ)
‚àº= IGKA(f!(X ‚àßA f ‚àóY ), Z).

As explained in [62, ¬ß¬ß2‚Äì3], the remaining isomorphisms on the IG-space level
follow formally.
We must show that our functors on IG-spaces preserve IG-spectra. The given

œÄ: f‚àóX ‚äºB Y ‚àí‚Üíf‚àó(X ‚äºA f ‚àóY ).

f‚àóX ‚äºB SB ‚àí‚Üíf‚àó(X ‚äºA SA) ‚àí‚Üíf‚àóX ‚ó¶‚äï.
Now the spectrum level adjunctions follow directly from their IG-space analogues.
The spectrum level isomorphisms (11.4.2) and (11.4.5) follow from their IG-space
analogues by comparisons of coequalizer diagrams, and the remaining isomorphisms
again follow formally.

11.5. Change of groups and restriction to Ô¨Åbers
We give the analogues for parametrized spectra of the results concerning change
of groups and restriction to Ô¨Åbers that were given for parametrized ex-spaces in
¬ß2.3. We shall say more about change of groups in Chapter 14. Fix an inclusion
Œπ: H ‚àí‚ÜíG of a (closed) subgroup H of G and let A be an H-space and B be a
G-space. We index H-spectra over A on the collection Œπ‚àóV of H-representations
Œπ‚àóV with V ‚ààV . As we discuss in ¬ß¬ß14.2 and 14.3, when V is the collection of all
representations of G, we can change indexing to the collection of all representations
of H since our assumption that G is compact ensures that every representation
of H is a direct summand of a representation Œπ‚àóV . We have an evident forgetful
functor
(11.5.1)
Œπ‚àó: GSB ‚àí‚ÜíHSŒπ‚àóB.
On the space level, we write Œπ! ambiguously for both the based and unbased induc-
tion functors G+ ‚àßH (‚àí) and G √óH (‚àí), and similarly for coinduction Œπ‚àó. Context
should make clear which is intended. Applying the unbased versions to retracts, we
deÔ¨Åned induction and coinduction functors Œπ! and Œπ‚àóon ex-spaces in DeÔ¨Ånition 2.3.7.
These functors extend to the spectrum level. Since we are now considering change
of groups, we write SG,B instead of SB for the G-sphere spectrum over B.
Proposition 11.5.2. Levelwise application of Œπ! and Œπ‚àógives functors
Œπ! : HSA ‚àí‚ÜíGSŒπ!A
and
Œπ‚àó: HSA ‚àí‚ÜíGSŒπ‚àóA.

we could more easily prove this directly.

Œπ‚àó‚àº= r‚àó,

and

where r: G/H ‚àí‚Üí‚àó.
Looking at the Ô¨Åber Xb(V ) = X(V )b over b of a G-spectrum X over B, we
see a Gb-spectrum Xb of the sort that has been studied in [105], where Gb is the

we can think of this Ô¨Åber as a G-spectrum over G/Gb. The following spectrum level

passage to Ô¨Åbers, base change, and change of groups.
