11.6. Some problems concerning non-compact Lie groups
In equivariant stable homotopy theory, the key idea is that the one-point com-
pactiÔ¨Åcation of a representation V of dimension n is a G-sphere and that smashing
with that sphere should be a self-equivalence of the equivariant stable homotopy
category.
That is, the idea is to invert G-spheres in just the way that we in-
vert spheres when constructing the nonequivariant stable homotopy category. For
compact Lie groups of equivariance, the philosophy and its implementation and
applications are well understood. When we invert representation spheres, we invert
other homotopy spheres as well, and the relevant Picard group is analyzed in [63].
For non-compact Lie groups, the philosophy is less clear and its technical im-
plementation is problematic.
The focus on Ô¨Ånite dimensional representations is
intrinsic to the philosophy just expressed, but fails to come to grips with basic
features of the representation theory of non-compact Lie groups. A theory based
on Ô¨Ånite dimensional representations may still have its uses, but there are real dif-
Ô¨Åculties in obtaining even that much. In particular, a focus on spheres associated
to linear representations, rather than on less highly structured homotopy spheres,
may be misplaced.
A non-compact semi-simple Lie group will generally have no non-trivial Ô¨Ånite
dimensional unitary or orthogonal representations, hence our theory of ‚Äúorthogo-
nal‚Äù G-spectra is clearly too restrictive. This, at least, is easily remedied. The use
of linear isometries in the deÔ¨Ånition of orthogonal spectra is a choice dictated more

11.6. SOME PROBLEMS CONCERNING NON-COMPACT LIE GROUPS
173
by the history than by the mathematics. In the alternative approach to equivariant
stable homotopy theory based on Lewis-May spectra and EKMM [61,98,105], use
of orthogonal complements is certainly convenient and perhaps essential. However,
the diagram orthogonal spectra of [105,106] could just as well have been developed
in terms of diagram ‚Äúgeneral linear spectra‚Äù. In the few places where complements
are used, they can by avoided. For consistency with the previous literature, we have
chosen to give our exposition in the compact case using the word ‚Äúorthogonal‚Äù and
the language from the cited references, but for general Lie groups of equivariance,
we should eliminate all considerations of isometries.
More precisely, for the complete case, we redeÔ¨Åne I by taking V to be the
collection of all Ô¨Ånite dimensional representations V of G. More generally, we can
index on any subcollection that contains the trivial representation and is closed
under Ô¨Ånite direct sums. Since we are only interested in a skeleton of I , we may
as well restrict to orthogonal representations in V when G is compact. We re-
place linear isometries by linear isomorphims when deÔ¨Åning the G-spaces I (V, W).
Thus we replace orthogonal groups by general linear groups. Otherwise, the formal
deÔ¨Ånitional framework developed in this chapter (or, in the nonparametrized case,
[105, II]) goes through verbatim for general topological groups G.
However, we emphasize the formality. When considering change of groups, for
example, the signiÔ¨Åcance changes drastically. As noted at the start of the previous
section, for an inclusion Œπ: H ‚àí‚ÜíG of a (closed) subgroup H of G, we index
H-spectra on the collection Œπ‚àóV of H-representations Œπ‚àóV with V ‚ààV . We also
pointed out the relevance of the compact case of the following result.
Proposition 11.6.1. If G is either a compact Lie group or a matrix group and
W is a representation of a subgroup H, then there is a representation V of G and
an embedding of W as a subrepresentation of Œπ‚àóV .
This is clear in the compact case and is given by [136, 3.1] for matrix groups.
However, the following striking counterexample, which we learned from Victor
Ginzburg, shows just how badly this basic result fails in general.
Counterexample 11.6.2 (Ginzburg). Let H be the Heisenberg group of 3√ó3
matrices
Ô£´
Ô£≠
1
a
c
0
1
b
0
0
1
Ô£∂
Ô£∏
where a, b, and c are real numbers. Embed R in H as the subgroup of matrices
with a = b = 0. Embed Z in R as usual. Then R is a central subgroup of H.
DeÔ¨Åne G = H/Z. Then T = R/Z is a circle subgroup of G. Moreover, T is the
center of G and coincides with the commutator subgroup [G, G]. Let V be any
Ô¨Ånite dimensional (complex linear) representation of G. Since T is compact, the
action of T on V is semisimple, and since T is central, any weight space of T is a
G-submodule. Therefore V is a direct sum of G-submodules Vi such that T acts on
each Vi by scalar matrices. Since T = [G, G], this scalar action of T on Vi is trivial:
the determinant of g is 1 for any g ‚àà[G, G]. Therefore no nontrivial 1-dimensional
character of T can embed in V . Reinterpreting in terms of real representations, as
we may, we conclude that, for Œπ: T ‚àí‚ÜíG, Œπ‚àóV is the trivial T-universe.
For a compact Lie group G and an inclusion Œπ: H ‚äÇG, Œπ‚àóX is a dualizable H-
spectrum if X is a dualizable G-spectrum, and an H-spectrum indexed on the trivial

174
11. THE CATEGORY OF ORTHOGONAL G-SPECTRA OVER B
H-universe is dualizable if and only if it is a retract of a Ô¨Ånite H-CW spectrum built
up from trivial orbits. We conclude that duality theory (in the nonparametrized
context) cannot work as one would wish in the context of the previous example.
Looking ahead, some of the theory of the following three chapters also works
formally in the context of non-compact Lie groups. However, there is an obvious
mismatch between our emphasis on the one-point compactiÔ¨Åcations of representa-
tions, which have at least two Ô¨Åxed points even if the isotropy groups away from
zero are compact, and the desire to focus on proper actions. Even ignoring 0 and
‚àû, it is not clear that anything like Illman‚Äôs Theorem 3.4.2 applies to give homo-
topical control on spheres of representations, however they might be interpreted, or
on orbits. A serious attempt to come to grips with these and other issues is beyond
the scope of this book.

CHAPTER 12
Model structures for parametrized G-spectra
Introduction
We deÔ¨Åne and study two model structures on the category GSB of (orthogonal)
G-spectra over B. We emphasize that, except for the theory of smash products,
everything in this chapter applies equally well to the category GPB of G-prespectra
over B. That fact will become important in the next chapter.
We start in ¬ß12.1 by deÔ¨Åning a ‚Äúlevel model structure‚Äù on GSB, based on the
qf-model structure on GKB. In ¬ß12.2, we record analogues for this model structure
of the results on external smash product and base change functors that were given
for GKB in ¬ß7.2. The level model structure serves as a stepping stone to the stable
model structure, which we deÔ¨Åne in ¬ß12.3. It has the same coÔ¨Åbrations as the level
model structure, and we therefore call these ‚Äús-coÔ¨Åbrations‚Äù. An essential point
in our approach is a Ô¨Åberwise deÔ¨Ånition of the homotopy groups of a parametrized
G-spectrum that throws much of our work onto the theory of nonparametrized
orthogonal G-spectra developed by Mandell and the Ô¨Årst author in [105]. We deÔ¨Åne
homotopy groups using the level qf-Ô¨Åbrant replacement functor provided by the
level model structure, and we deÔ¨Åne stable equivalences to be the œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms.
It is essential to think in terms of Ô¨Åbers and not total spaces since the total spaces
of a parametrized spectrum do not assemble into a spectrum. We show in ¬ß12.4
that the œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms give a well-grounded subcategory of weak equivalences,
and we complete the proofs of the model axioms in ¬ß12.5. We return to the context
of ¬ß12.2 in ¬ß12.6, where we prove that various Quillen adjoint pairs in the level
model structures are also Quillen adjoint pairs in the stable model structures.
The basic conclusion is that GSB is a well-grounded model category in the
sense of ¬ß5.5 under the stable model structure. Although not very noticeable on
the surface, essential use is made of the qf-model structure on GKB throughout this
chapter. As we observe in Remark 12.1.8, the q-model structure on GKB does give
rise to a level model structure on GSB. However this model structure is not well-
grounded and does not provide the necessary tools to work out the technical details
of ¬ß12.4. The results there are crucial to prove that the relative cell complexes over
B deÔ¨Åned in terms of the appropriate generating acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbrations are acyclic.1
It was our fruitless attempt to obtain a stable model structure starting from the
level q-model structure that led us to the construction of the qf-model structure
on GKB and to the notion of a well-grounded model category.
When there are no issues of equivariance, we generally abbreviate G-spectrum
over B, ex-G-space, and G-space to spectrum over B, ex-space, and space; G is a
compact Lie group throughout.
1In [78, 3.4], such acyclicity of relative cell complexes is assumed without proof.
175

176
12. MODEL STRUCTURES FOR PARAMETRIZED G-SPECTRA
12.1. The level model structure on GSB
After changing the base space from ‚àóto B, the level model structure works in
much the same way as in the nonparametrized case of [105].
Definition 12.1.1. Let f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY be a map of spectra over B. With one
exception, for any type of ex-space and any type of map of ex-spaces, we say that
X or f is a level type of spectrum over B or a level type of map of spectra over B if
each X(V ) or f(V ): X(V ) ‚àí‚ÜíY (V ) is that type of ex-space or that type of map.
Thus, for example, we have level h, level f and level fp-Ô¨Åbrations, coÔ¨Åbrations
and equivalences from ¬ß5.1 together with the corresponding Ô¨Åbrant and coÔ¨Åbrant
objects. We have level q-equivalences and level q and qf-Ô¨Åbrations from ¬ß7.1 and
we have level ex-Ô¨Åbrations and level ex-quasiÔ¨Åbrations from ¬ß8.1 and ¬ß8.5. The
exceptions concern coÔ¨Åbrations and coÔ¨Åbrant objects. We shall never be interested
in ‚Äúlevel q-coÔ¨Åbrations‚Äù or ‚Äúlevel qf-coÔ¨Åbrations‚Äù, nor in ‚Äúlevel q-coÔ¨Åbrant‚Äù or ‚Äúlevel
qf-coÔ¨Åbrant‚Äù objects, since these do not correspond to coÔ¨Åbrations and coÔ¨Åbrant
objects in the model structures that we consider. Instead we have the following
deÔ¨Ånitions.
(i) f is an s-coÔ¨Åbration if it satisÔ¨Åes the LLP with respect to the level acyclic
qf-Ô¨Åbrations.
(ii) f is a level acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbration if it is both a level q-equivalence and an
s-coÔ¨Åbration.
To reiterate, in the phrase ‚Äúlevel acyclic qf-Ô¨Åbration‚Äù, the adjective ‚Äúlevel‚Äù applies
to ‚Äúacyclic qf-Ô¨Åbration‚Äù, but in the phrase ‚Äúlevel acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbration‚Äù it applies
only to ‚Äúacyclic‚Äù; the coÔ¨Åbrations are not deÔ¨Åned levelwise.
Definition 12.1.2. A spectrum X over B is well-sectioned if it is level well-
sectioned, so that each ex-space X(V ) is ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbrant. It is well-grounded if it is
level well-grounded, so that each X(V ) is well-sectioned and compactly generated.
The discussion of ¬ß4.3 applies to the category GSB of G-spectra over B with
homotopies deÔ¨Åned in terms of the cylinders X ‚àßB I+. In particular, we have the
notion of a Hurewicz coÔ¨Åbration in GSB, abbreviated cyl-coÔ¨Åbration, deÔ¨Åned in
terms of these cylinders, and we also have the notion of strong Hurewicz coÔ¨Åbration,
abbreviated cyl-coÔ¨Åbration.
Lemma 12.1.3. A cyl-coÔ¨Åbration of spectra over B is a level fp-coÔ¨Åbration and
a cyl-Ô¨Åbration of spectra over B is a level fp-Ô¨Åbration. A cyl-coÔ¨Åbration between
well-sectioned spectra over B is a level f-coÔ¨Åbration and therefore both a level h-
coÔ¨Åbration and a level fp-coÔ¨Åbration.
Proof. By the mapping cylinder retraction characterization of Hurewicz coÔ¨Å-
brations, a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration of spectra over B is a level fp-coÔ¨Åbration. The statement
about Ô¨Åbrations follows similarly from the path lifting function characterization of
Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations. An fp-coÔ¨Åbration between well-sectioned ex-spaces is an f-
coÔ¨Åbration by Proposition 5.2.3, and all f-coÔ¨Åbrations are h-coÔ¨Åbrations.
‚ñ°
Recall the notions of a ground structure and of a well-grounded subcategory of
weak equivalences from DeÔ¨Ånitions 5.3.2, 5.3.3, and 5.4.1.
Proposition 12.1.4. The well-grounded spectra over B give GSB a ground
structure whose ground coÔ¨Åbrations, or g-coÔ¨Åbrations, are the level h-coÔ¨Åbrations.

12.1. THE LEVEL MODEL STRUCTURE ON GSB
177
The level q-equivalences specify a well-grounded subcategory of weak equivalences
with respect to this ground structure. In the gluing and colimit lemmas, one need
only assume that the relevant maps are level h-coÔ¨Åbrations, not necessarily also
cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations.
Proof. That we have a ground structure follows levelwise from the ground
structure on ex-spaces in Proposition 5.3.7. That the level q-equivalences are well-
grounded follows levelwise from Proposition 5.4.9.
‚ñ°
We construct the level model structure on GSB from the qf-model structure
on GKB speciÔ¨Åed in Remark 7.2.11, but all results apply verbatim starting from
the qf(C )-model structure for any closed generating set C (as deÔ¨Åned in DeÔ¨Åni-
tion 7.2.6). We shall need the extra generality for the reasons discussed in Chapter
7. Recall that If
B and Jf
B denote the sets of generating qf-coÔ¨Åbrations and gener-
ating acyclic qf-coÔ¨Åbrations in GKB. We use the shift desuspension functors FV
of DeÔ¨Ånition 11.3.5 to obtain corresponding sets on the spectrum level. We need
the following observations.
Lemma 12.1.5. The functor FV enjoys the following properties.
(i) If K is a well-grounded ex-space over B, then FV K is well-grounded. If K is
an ex-Ô¨Åbration, then FV K is a level ex-Ô¨Åbration.
(ii) If i: K ‚àí‚ÜíL is an h-equivalence between well-grounded ex-spaces over B,
then FV i is a level h-equivalence.
(iii) If i: K ‚àí‚ÜíL is an fp-coÔ¨Åbration, then FV i is a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration and therefore
a level fp-coÔ¨Åbration. If, further, K and L are well-sectioned, then FV i is a
level f-coÔ¨Åbration and therefore a level h-coÔ¨Åbration.
(iv) If i: K ‚àí‚ÜíL is an fp-coÔ¨Åbration, then FV i is a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration.
(v) If i: K ‚àí‚ÜíL is an f-coÔ¨Åbration between well-grounded ex-spaces over B,
then FV i is a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration which is a level f-coÔ¨Åbration and therefore both
a level fp-coÔ¨Åbration and a level h-coÔ¨Åbration.
Proof. By DeÔ¨Ånition 11.3.5, (FV K)(W) = JG(V, W)B ‚àßB K, and the G-
space JG(V, W) is well-based.
Now (i) holds by Corollary 8.2.5 and (ii) holds
by Proposition 8.2.6.
Since FV is left adjoint to the evaluation functor EvV
and since cyl-Ô¨Åbrations are level fp-Ô¨Åbrations, (iv) and the Ô¨Årst statement of (iii)
follow from the deÔ¨Ånitions by adjunction. The second statement of (iii) follows
from Proposition 5.2.3. The Ô¨Årst half of (v) follows from (iv) since f-coÔ¨Åbrations
are fp-coÔ¨Åbrations, and the second half follows from (iii) since FV i is a level f-
coÔ¨Åbration between well-grounded spectra and therefore a level f-coÔ¨Åbration by
Theorem 5.2.8(ii).

Definition 12.1.6. DeÔ¨Åne FIf

Recall the notion of a well-grounded model structure from DeÔ¨Ånition 5.5.4.
Among other properties, such model structures are compactly generated, proper,
and G-topological.
Theorem 12.1.7. The category GSB is a well-grounded model category with
respect to the level q-equivalences, the level qf-Ô¨Åbrations and the s-coÔ¨Åbrations. The

sets FIf
B and FJf
B give the generating s-coÔ¨Åbrations and the generating level acyclic
s-coÔ¨Åbrations. All s-coÔ¨Åbrations are both Cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations and level f-coÔ¨Åbrations,
hence level fp and level h-coÔ¨Åbrations, and all s-coÔ¨Åbrant spectra over B are well-
grounded.
Proof. By Lemma 12.1.5, the maps in FIf
B and FJf
B are cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations be-
tween well-grounded objects and f-coÔ¨Åbrations, hence the s-coÔ¨Åbrations are bicoÔ¨Å-
brations by Lemma 5.3.5. Moreover, the maps in FJf
B are level acyclic. Therefore,
to prove the model axioms, we need only verify the compatibility condition (ii) in
Theorem 5.5.1. Adjunction arguments show that a map is a level qf-Ô¨Åbration if and
only if it has the RLP with respect to FJf
B and that it is a level acyclic q-Ô¨Åbration
if and only if it has the RLP with respect to FIf
B. This implies that the classes
of s-coÔ¨Åbrations and of FIf

cide. Therefore, if a map has the RLP with respect to FIf
B, then it is a level acyclic
qf-Ô¨Åbration. The required compatibility condition now follows from its analogue
for GKB. Condition (iv) in Theorem 5.5.1 holds by its ex-space level analogue and
the fact that (FV K) ‚àßB T ‚àº= FV (K ‚àßB T) for an ex-space K over B and a based
space T. Right properness follows directly from the space level analogue.
‚ñ°
Remark 12.1.8. Just as in DeÔ¨Ånition 12.1.6, we can also deÔ¨Åne sets FIB and
FJB based on the generating sets IB and JB for the q-model structure on GKB. We
can then use Theorem 4.5.6 to prove the analogue of Theorem 12.1.7 stating that
GSB is a compactly generated model category under the level q-model structure.
Since the compatibility condition holds by the same proof as for the level qf-model
structure, we need only verify the acyclicity condition to show this.
For a generating acyclic q-coÔ¨Åbration j ‚ààJB, we have FV j = V ‚àó‚àßB j, where
V ‚àó(W) = JG,B(V, W). This map is a level h-equivalence by Lemma 12.1.5(ii).
Although j is an h-coÔ¨Åbration, it is not immediate that FV j is a level h-coÔ¨Åbration.
(This holds for j ‚ààJf
B by Lemma 12.1.5(iii), since j is then an fp-coÔ¨Åbration).
Indeed, for general ex-spaces K and h-coÔ¨Åbrations f, K ‚àßB f need not be an h-
coÔ¨Åbration. However, since JG,B(V, W) = JG(V, W)B, we see directly that FV j
is indeed a level h-coÔ¨Åbration. By inspection of the deÔ¨Ånition of wedges over B in
terms of pushouts, the gluing lemma in K then applies to show that wedges over B
of maps in FJB are level acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbrations. Since pushouts and colimits in SB
are constructed levelwise on total spaces, it follows that relative FJB complexes
are acyclic h-coÔ¨Åbrations since the q-model structure on K is well-grounded.
Remark 12.1.9. As in the nonparametrized case [105], ‚Äúpositive‚Äù model struc-
tures would be needed to obtain a comparison with the as yet undeveloped alter-
native approach to parametrized stable homotopy theory based on [61, 98]. Such
model structures can be deÔ¨Åned as in [105, p. 44], starting from the subsets (FIf
B)+
and (FJf
B)+ that are obtained by restricting to those V such that V G Ã∏= 0. One
then deÔ¨Ånes the positive level versions of all of the types of maps speciÔ¨Åed in Def-
inition 12.1.1 by restricting to those levels V such that V G Ã∏= 0.
The positive
level analogue of Theorem 12.1.7 holds, where the positive s-coÔ¨Åbrations are the
s-coÔ¨Åbrations that are isomorphisms at all levels V such that V G = 0; compare
[105, III.2.10]. However, we shall make no use of the positive model structure in
this paper, and we will make little further reference to it.
The same proof as in [105, I.2.10, II.4.10, III.2.12] gives the following result.

12.2. SOME QUILLEN ADJOINT PAIRS RELATING LEVEL MODEL STRUCTURES
179
Theorem 12.1.10. The forgetful functor U from spectra over B to prespectra
over B has a left adjoint P such that (P, U) is a Quillen equivalence.
12.2. Some Quillen adjoint pairs relating level model structures
This section gives the analogues for the level model structure of some of the
ex-space level results in ¬ß¬ß7.2-7.4. These results are also analogues of results in
[105, III.¬ß2], which in turn have non-equivariant precursors in [106, ¬ß6]. They admit
essentially the same proofs as in Chapter 7 or in the cited references. The level qf-
model structure is understood throughout. More precisely, where a qf(C )-model
structure was used in Chapter 7, we must use the corresponding level qf(C )-model
structure here. Since we want our model structures to be G-topological, we only
use generating sets C that are closed under Ô¨Ånite products.
Our Ô¨Årst observation is immediate from the fact that equivalences and Ô¨Åbra-
tions are deÔ¨Åned levelwise, the next follows directly from its ex-space analogue
Proposition 7.3.1, and the third and fourth are proven in the same way as their
ex-space analogues 7.3.2 and Corollary 7.3.3. All apply to the level qf(C )-model
structures for any choice of C .
Proposition 12.2.1. The pair of adjoint functors (FV , EvV ) between GKB
and GSB is a Quillen adjoint pair.
Proposition 12.2.2. For a based G-CW complex T, ((‚àí) ‚àßB T, FB(T, ‚àí)) is
a Quillen adjoint pair of endofunctors of GSB.
Proposition 12.2.3. If i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY and j : W ‚àí‚ÜíZ are s-coÔ¨Åbrations of
spectra over base spaces A and B, then
i‚ñ°j : (Y ‚äºW) ‚à™X‚äºW (X ‚äºZ) ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚äºZ
is an s-coÔ¨Åbration over A √ó B which is level acyclic if either i or j is acyclic.
As in ¬ß7.2, we cannot expect this result to hold for internal smash products over
B. The case A = ‚àó, which relates spectra to spectra over B, is particularly impor-
tant. As we explain in ¬ß14.1, it leads to a fully satisfactory theory of parametrized
module spectra over nonparametrized ring spectra.
Corollary 12.2.4. If Y is s-coÔ¨Åbrant over B, then the functor (‚àí) ‚äºY from
GSA to GSA√óB is a Quillen left adjoint with Quillen right adjoint ¬ØF(Y, ‚àí).
Again the next result is a direct consequence of its ex-space analogue Proposi-
tion 7.3.4 and applies with any choice of C .
Proposition 12.2.5. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a G-map. Then (f!, f ‚àó) is a Quillen
adjoint pair. The functor f! preserves level q-equivalences between well-sectioned
G-spectra over B. If f is a qf-Ô¨Åbration, then f ‚àópreserves all level q-equivalences.
Proposition 12.2.6. If f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB is a q-equivalence, then (f!, f ‚àó) is a Quillen
equivalence.
Proof. We mimic the proof of Proposition 7.3.5, but with X and Y taken to
be an s-coÔ¨Åbrant G-spectrum over A and a level qf-Ô¨Åbrant G-spectrum over B. It
is clear that f ‚àóY ‚àí‚ÜíY is a level q-equivalence since A ‚àí‚ÜíB is a q-equivalence.
Since X is s-coÔ¨Åbrant, ‚àóA ‚àí‚ÜíX is a level h-coÔ¨Åbration. Note that it is essential for
this statement that we start from the qf and not the q-model structure on ex-spaces.

12. MODEL STRUCTURES FOR PARAMETRIZED G-SPECTRA
Since pushouts along level h-coÔ¨Åbrations preserve level q-equivalences, X ‚àí‚Üíf!X
is a level q-equivalence. The conclusion follows as in Proposition 7.3.5.

Proposition 12.2.7. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a G-bundle whose Ô¨Åbers Ab are Gb-

Therefore (f ‚àó, f‚àó) is a Quillen adjoint pair.
Proof. Here we must use a generating set C (f) as speciÔ¨Åed in Proposi-

the maps f ‚àóFV i ‚àº= FV f ‚àói are s-coÔ¨Åbrations for generating s-coÔ¨Åbrations i. Since
FV is a Quillen left adjoint it takes qf-coÔ¨Åbrations to s-coÔ¨Åbrations, so we are
reduced to the ex-space level, where f ‚àói is shown to be a qf-coÔ¨Åbration in Propo-
sition 7.3.8.

Corollary 12.2.8. If B is a G-cell complex, then (r‚àó, r‚àó) is a Quillen adjoint
pair.
Now consider the change of groups functors of ¬ß11.5. The following result shows
that the equivalence of Proposition 11.5.3 descends to homotopy categories. It is
proven by levelwise application of its ex-space analogue Proposition 7.4.7, together
with change of universe considerations that are deferred until ¬ß14.2 and ¬ß14.3.

of functors (Œπ!, ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àó) relating HSA and GSŒπ!A give a Quillen equivalence. If A is
completely regular, then Œπ! is also a Quillen right adjoint.

(‚àí)b therefore agrees with Àúb!Œπ!.

GbS‚àóand GSB is a Quillen adjoint pair.
12.3. The stable model structure on GSB
The essential point in the construction of the stable model structure is to deÔ¨Åne
the appropriate (stable) homotopy groups. The weak equivalences will then be the
maps of parametrized spectra that induce isomorphisms on all homotopy groups.
We refer to them as the œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms or s-equivalences, using these terms in-
terchangeably. There are several motivating observations for our deÔ¨Ånitions. We
return the group G to the notations for much of this section.
For the Ô¨Årst, let ‚àóB denote the terminal G-spectrum over B, so that each ‚àóB(V )
is the terminal ex-G-space ‚àóB. Then a G-spectrum X over B is level qf-Ô¨Åbrant if
and only if each projection X(V ) ‚àí‚Üí‚àóB(V ) = ‚àóB is a qf-Ô¨Åbration of ex-G-spaces.
It is equivalent that each Ô¨Åxed point map X(V )H ‚àí‚ÜíBH be a non-equivariant
qf-Ô¨Åbration, and, by Proposition 6.5.1, we have resulting long exact sequences of
homotopy groups

12.3. THE STABLE MODEL STRUCTURE ON GSB
181
Second, as we have already discussed in ¬ß11.4, the Ô¨Åbers Xb of a G-spectrum X
are Gb-spectra, and our guiding principle is to use these nonparametrized spectra
to encode the homotopical information about our parametrized spectra. Proposi-
tion 12.2.10 allows us to encode levelwise information in the level homotopy groups
of Ô¨Åbers, and it is plausible that we can similarly encode the full structure of our
parametrized G-spectrum X in the spectrum level homotopy groups of the Ô¨Åber
Gb-spectra Xb. However, we can only expect to do so when X is level qf-Ô¨Åbrant
and we have the long exact sequences (12.3.1).
Recall that the homotopy groups œÄH
q (Y ) of a nonparametrized G-spectrum
Y are deÔ¨Åned in [105, III.3.2] as the colimits of the groups œÄH
q (‚Ñ¶V Y (V )), where
the maps of the colimit system are induced in the evident way by the adjoint
structure maps ÀúœÉ: Y (V ) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶W ‚àíV Y (W) of Y .
The functor ‚Ñ¶V on based G-
spaces preserves q-Ô¨Åbrations and the functor ‚Ñ¶V
B = FB(SV , ‚àí) on G-spectra over B
preserves level qf-Ô¨Åbrations. Formally, these hold since SV is a q-coÔ¨Åbrant G-space
and the relevant model structures are G-topological. This leads to two families of
long exact sequences relating the homotopy groups œÄH
q (‚Ñ¶V Xb(W)) of Ô¨Åbers to the
homotopy groups of the base space B and of the total spaces X(W). First, if X is
a level q-Ô¨Åbrant G-spectrum over B, then, using basepoints determined by a point
b ‚ààBH for any H ‚äÇGb, the q-Ô¨Åbrations ‚Ñ¶V X(W) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶V B of based G-spaces
with Ô¨Åbers ‚Ñ¶V Xb(W) induce long exact sequences
(12.3.2)
¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q+1(‚Ñ¶V B) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q (‚Ñ¶V Xb(W)) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q (‚Ñ¶V X(W)) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q (‚Ñ¶V B) ‚àí‚Üí¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ .
Second, if X is level qf-Ô¨Åbrant, then the qf-Ô¨Åbrations (‚Ñ¶V
BX)(W) ‚àí‚Üí‚àóB of ex-G-
spaces over B with Ô¨Åbers ‚Ñ¶V Xb(W) induce long exact sequences
(12.3.3)
¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q+1(B) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q (‚Ñ¶V Xb(W)) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q ((‚Ñ¶V
BX)(W)) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q (B) ‚àí‚Üí¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ .
The Ô¨Årst allows us to relate the homotopy groups of the Xb to the homotopy groups
of the ordinary loops ‚Ñ¶V X(W) on total spaces. The second allows us to relate the
homotopy groups of the Xb to the homotopy groups of the parametrized loop ex-
spaces (‚Ñ¶V
BX)(W). It is the second that is most relevant to our work.
Definition 12.3.4. The homotopy groups of a level qf-Ô¨Åbrant G-spectrum
over B, or of a level qf-Ô¨Åbrant G-prespectrum X, are all of the homotopy groups
œÄH
q (Xb) of all of the Ô¨Åbers Xb, where H ‚äÇGb. The homotopy groups of a general
G-spectrum, or G-prespectrum, X over B are the homotopy groups œÄH
q ((RX)b) of a
level qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation RX to X. We still denote these homotopy groups by
œÄH
q (Xb). In either category, a map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY is said to be a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism or,
synonymously, an s-equivalence, if, after level qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation, it induces
an isomorphism on all homotopy groups.
There are also homotopy groups speciÔ¨Åed in terms of maps out of sphere spectra
over B, but we choose to ignore them in setting up our model theoretic foundations.
Our choice captures the intuitive idea that spectra over B should be parametrized
spectra: the Ô¨Åber spectra should carry all of the homotopy theoretical information.
With this choice, a good deal of the work needed to set up the stable model structure
reduces to work that has already been done in [105]. The following observation is
a starting point that illustrates the pattern of proof.
Lemma 12.3.5. A level q-equivalence of G-spectra over B is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism.

182
12. MODEL STRUCTURES FOR PARAMETRIZED G-SPECTRA
Proof. A level qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation to the given level q-equivalence is a
level acyclic qf-Ô¨Åbration, and it induces a level q-equivalence on Ô¨Åbers over points
of B by Proposition 12.2.10. This allows us to apply [105, III.3.3], which gives the
same conclusion for nonparametrized G-spectra, one Ô¨Åber at a time.
‚ñ°
To exploit our deÔ¨Ånition of homotopy groups, we need the following accompa-
nying deÔ¨Ånition and proposition.
Definition 12.3.6. An ‚Ñ¶-G-prespectrum over B is a level qf-Ô¨Åbrant prespec-
trum X over B whose adjoint structure maps ÀúœÉ: X(V ) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶W ‚àíV
B
X(W) are q-
equivalences of ex-G-spaces over B, that is, q-equivalences of total G-spaces. An
(orthogonal) ‚Ñ¶-G-spectrum over B is a level qf-Ô¨Åbrant G-spectrum over B whose
adjoint structure maps are q-equivalences; equivalently, its underlying prespectrum
must be an ‚Ñ¶-G-prespectrum over B.
Since we are omitting the adjective ‚Äúorthogonal‚Äù from ‚Äúorthogonal G-spectrum
over B‚Äù, we must use the term ‚Äú‚Ñ¶-G-prespectrum over B‚Äù on the prespectrum level
to avoid confusion; the usual term ‚Äú‚Ñ¶-G-spectrum‚Äù was used in [105]. We state the
following two results for ‚Ñ¶-G-spectra, but they hold equally well for ‚Ñ¶-G-prespectra.
Proposition 12.3.7. A level Ô¨Åbrant G-spectrum X over B is an ‚Ñ¶-G-spectrum
over B if and only if each Ô¨Åber Xb is an ‚Ñ¶-Gb-spectrum.
Proof. By the Ô¨Åve lemma, this is immediate from a comparison of the long
exact sequences in (12.3.1) and (12.3.3).
‚ñ°
This result leads to the following partial converse to Lemma 12.3.5.
Theorem 12.3.8. A œÄ‚àó-isomorphism between ‚Ñ¶-G-spectra over B is a level
q-equivalence.
Proof. The analogue for nonparametrized ‚Ñ¶-G-spectra is [105, III.3.4]. In
view of Proposition 12.3.7, we can apply that result on Ô¨Åbers and then use that
‚Ñ¶-G-spectra over B are required to be level qf-Ô¨Åbrant to deduce the claimed level
q-equivalence on total spaces from (12.3.1).
‚ñ°
Technically, the real force of our deÔ¨Ånition of homotopy groups is that this
result describing the œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms between ‚Ñ¶-G-spectra over B is an immediate
consequence of the work in [105].
Given this relationship between ‚Ñ¶-G-spectra
and homotopy groups, many of the arguments of [105] apply Ô¨Åberwise to allow
the development of the stable model structure. However, as discussed in the next
section, careful use of level Ô¨Åbrant approximation is required. We shall use the
terms ‚Äústable model structure‚Äù and ‚Äús-model structure‚Äù interchangeably. The s-
coÔ¨Åbrations are the same as those of the level qf-model structure and the s-Ô¨Åbrant
G-spectra over B turn out to be the ‚Ñ¶-G-spectra over B.
Now that we have seen how the equivariance appears in the deÔ¨Ånition of homo-
topy groups and the deduction of results about G-spectra over B from results about
Gb-spectra, we revert to our custom of generally deleting G from the notations.
Definition 12.3.9. A map of spectra or prespectra over B is
(i) an acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbration if it is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism and an s-coÔ¨Åbration,
(ii) an s-Ô¨Åbration if it satisÔ¨Åes the RLP with respect to the acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbrations,
(iii) an acyclic s-Ô¨Åbration if it is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism and an s-Ô¨Åbration.

12.4. COFIBER SEQUENCES AND œÄ‚àó-ISOMORPHISMS
183
We shall prove the following basic theorem in the next two sections.
Theorem 12.3.10. The categories GSB and GPB are well-grounded model
categories with respect to the œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms (= s-equivalences), s-Ô¨Åbrations and
s-coÔ¨Åbrations. The s-Ô¨Åbrant objects are the ‚Ñ¶-spectra over B.
Remark 12.3.11. Recall Remark 12.1.9. We can deÔ¨Åne positive ‚Ñ¶-prespectra
and positive analogues of our s-classes of maps, starting with the positive level qf-
model structure. As in [105, III¬ß5], the positive analogue of the previous theorem
also holds, with the same proof. The identity functor is the left adjoint of a Quillen
equivalence from GSB or GPB with its positive stable model structure to GSB
or GPB with its stable model structure.
The proof of the following result is virtually the same as the proof of its non-
parametrized precursor [105, III.4.16 and III.5.7] and will not be repeated.
Theorem 12.3.12. The adjoint pair (P, U) relating the categories GPB and
GSB of prespectra and spectra over B is a Quillen equivalence with respect to either
the stable model structures or the positive stable model structures.
As in [105, III.¬ß6], Theorem 12.3.10 leads to the following deÔ¨Ånition and theo-
rem, whose proof is the same as the proof of [105, III.6.1].
Definition 12.3.13. Let [X, Y ]‚Ñìdenote the morphism sets in the homotopy
category associated to the level qf-model structure on GPB or GSB.
A map
f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a stable equivalence if f ‚àó: [Y, E]‚Ñì‚àí‚Üí[X, E]‚Ñìis an isomorphism for
all ‚Ñ¶-spectra E over B. DeÔ¨Åne the positive analogues similarly. Let [X, Y ] denote
the morphism sets in the stable homotopy category Ho GSB of spectra over B.
Theorem 12.3.14. The following are equivalent for a map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY of
spectra or prespectra over B.
(i) f is a stable equivalence.
(ii) f is a positive stable equivalence.
(iii) f is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism.
Moreover [X, E] = [X, E]‚Ñìif E is an ‚Ñ¶-spectrum.
Lemma 12.6.1 below should make it clear why the last statement is true.
12.4. CoÔ¨Åber sequences and œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms
In the main, the proof of Theorem 12.3.10 is obtained by applying the results in
[105] Ô¨Åberwise. Since total spaces are no longer assumed to be weak HausdorÔ¨Ä, we
have to be a little careful: we are quoting results proven for T and using them for
K‚àó. However, we can just as well interpret [105] in terms of K‚àó. The total spaces
X(V ) of an s-coÔ¨Åbrant spectrum over B are weak HausdorÔ¨Ä, hence s-coÔ¨Åbrant
approximation places us in a situation where total spaces are in U and therefore
Ô¨Åbers are in T .
There is a more substantial technical problem to overcome in adapting the
proofs of [105, 106] to the present setting. In the situations encountered in those
references, all objects were level q-Ô¨Åbrant, and that simpliÔ¨Åed matters considerably.
Here, level qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation entered into our deÔ¨Ånition of homotopy groups,
and for that reason the results of this section are considerably more subtle than their

184
12. MODEL STRUCTURES FOR PARAMETRIZED G-SPECTRA
counterparts in the cited sources. Their proofs depend on the full strength of our
topological model structures in general and the qf-model structure in particular.
We begin by noting that any level ex-quasiÔ¨Åbrant approximation, not neces-
sarily a qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation, can be used to calculate the homotopy groups of
parametrized spectra.
Lemma 12.4.1. A zig-zag of level q-equivalences connecting a spectrum X over
B to a level ex-quasiÔ¨Åbrant spectrum Y over B induces an isomorphism between the
homotopy groups of X and of Y , and the latter can be computed directly in terms
of the Ô¨Åbers of Y .
Proof. This follows from Lemma 12.3.5 by applying a level qf-Ô¨Åbrant approx-
imation functor to the zig-zag.
‚ñ°
Theorem 12.4.2. Let f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY be a map between G-spectra over B. For
any H ‚äÇG and b ‚ààBH, there is a natural long exact sequence
¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q+1(Yb) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q ((FBf)b) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q (Xb) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q (Yb) ‚àí‚Üí¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑
and, if X is well-sectioned, there is also a natural long exact sequence
¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q (Xb) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q (Yb) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q ((CBf)b) ‚àí‚ÜíœÄH
q‚àí1(Xb) ‚àí‚Üí¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑ .
Proof. For the Ô¨Årst long exact sequence, let R be a level qf-Ô¨Åbrant approxi-
mation functor and consider Rf. We claim that the induced map FBf ‚àí‚ÜíFBRf
is a level q-equivalence and that FBRf is level qf-Ô¨Åbrant. This means that FBRf is
a level qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation to FBf, so that the homotopy groups of the Ô¨Åbers
(FBRf)b ‚àº= F((Rf)b) are the homotopy groups of FBf. When restricted to Ô¨Åbers
over b, the parametrized Ô¨Åber sequence RX ‚àí‚ÜíRY ‚àí‚ÜíFBRf of spectra over B
gives the nonparametrized Ô¨Åber sequence (RX)b ‚àí‚Üí(RY )b ‚àí‚ÜíF((Rf)b), and the
long exact sequence follows from [105, III.3.5]. To prove the claim, observe that
since FB(I, Y ) ‚àí‚ÜíY is a Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration, it has a path-lifting function which
levelwise shows that FB(I, Y ) ‚àí‚ÜíY is a level fp-Ô¨Åbration and therefore a level
qf-Ô¨Åbration (since all qf-coÔ¨Åbrations are fp-coÔ¨Åbrations in GKB). The dual gluing
lemma (see DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1(iii)) then gives that the induced map FBf ‚àí‚ÜíFBRf
is a level q-equivalence. Since FB(I, ‚àí) preserves level qf-Ô¨Åbrant objects and since
pullbacks of level qf-Ô¨Åbrant objects along a level qf-Ô¨Åbration are level qf-Ô¨Åbrant,
FBRf is level qf-Ô¨Åbrant.
Since the maps X ‚àí‚ÜíCBX and RX ‚àí‚ÜíCBRX are cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations between
well-sectioned spectra and therefore level h-coÔ¨Åbrations by Lemma 12.1.3, the glu-
ing lemma gives that CBf ‚àí‚ÜíCBRf is a level q-equivalence. Since RX and RY
are level well-sectioned and level qf-Ô¨Åbrant, they are level ex-quasiÔ¨Åbrations. It
follows from Proposition 8.5.3 that CBRf is a level ex-quasiÔ¨Åbration. We cannot
conclude that CBRf is level qf-Ô¨Åbrant, but by Lemma 12.4.1 we can nevertheless
use CBRf to calculate the homotopy groups of CBf. On Ô¨Åbers over b, the coÔ¨Åber
sequence of Rf is just the coÔ¨Åber sequence of (Rf)b, and the long exact sequence
follows from [105, III.3.5].
‚ñ°
Recall Proposition 12.1.4, which speciÔ¨Åes the ground structure in GSB and
shows that the level q-equivalences give a well-grounded subcategory of weak equiv-
alences; the g-coÔ¨Åbrations are just the level h-coÔ¨Åbrations. The following result
shows that the same is true for the œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms.
However, in contrast to
Proposition 12.1.4, it is crucial to assume that the relevant maps in the gluing

12.4. COFIBER SEQUENCES AND œÄ‚àó-ISOMORPHISMS
185
and colimit lemmas are both cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations and g-coÔ¨Åbrations, as prescribed in
DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1.
Theorem 12.4.3. The œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms in GSB give a well-grounded subcat-
egory of weak equivalences. In detail, the following statements hold.
(i) A homotopy equivalence is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism.
(ii) The homotopy groups of a wedge of well-grounded spectra over B are the direct
sums of the homotopy groups of the wedge summands.
(iii) The œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms are preserved under pushouts along maps that are both
cyl and g-coÔ¨Åbrations.
(iv) Let X be the colimit of a sequence in : Xn ‚àí‚ÜíXn+1 of maps that are both
cyl and g-coÔ¨Åbrations and assume that X/BX0 is well-grounded. Then the
homotopy groups of X are the colimits of the homotopy groups of the Xn.
(v) For a map i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY of well-grounded spectra over B and a map j : K ‚àí‚ÜíL
of well-based spaces, i‚ñ°j is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism if either i is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism
or j is a q-equivalence.
Proof. The conclusion that the œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms give a well-grounded subcat-
egory of weak equivalences, as prescribed in DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1, follows directly from
the listed properties, using Lemma 5.4.3 to derive the gluing lemma. Since level q-
equivalences are œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms, s-coÔ¨Åbrant approximation in the level qf-model
structure gives the factorization hypothesis Lemma 5.4.3(ii).
A homotopy equivalence of spectra is a level fp-equivalence and hence a level
q-equivalence, so (i) follows from Lemma 12.3.5. For Ô¨Ånite wedges, (ii) is imme-
diate from the evident split coÔ¨Åber sequences and Theorem 12.4.2. For arbitrary
wedges of well-grounded spectra over B, ‚à®BXi ‚àí‚Üí‚à®BRXi is a level q-equivalence
since the level q-equivalences are well-grounded and ‚à®BRXi is level quasiÔ¨Åbrant by
Proposition 8.5.3. By Lemma 12.4.1 we can use ‚à®BRXi to calculate the homotopy
groups of ‚à®BXi. Over a point b in B, ‚à®BRXi is just ‚à®(RXi)b and the result follows
from the nonparametrized analogue [105, III.3.5].
Now consider (iii). Let i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY be both a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration and a g-coÔ¨Åbration
and let f : X ‚àí‚ÜíZ be a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism. Since i and its s-coÔ¨Åbrant approxima-
tion Qi are both cyl and g-coÔ¨Åbrations and since the level q-equivalences give a
well-grounded subcategory of weak equivalences, the gluing lemma shows that we
may approximate our given pushout diagram by one in which all objects are well-
sectioned. Let j : Z ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚à™X Z be the pushout of i along f. Since i and j are
cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations and j is the pushout of i, their coÔ¨Åbers are homotopy equivalent.
Comparing the long exact sequences of homotopy groups associated to the coÔ¨Åber
sequences of i and j gives that the pushout Y ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚à™X Z of f along i is a œÄ‚àó-
isomorphism.
For (iv), we may use s-coÔ¨Åbrant approximation in the level model structure
to replace our given tower by one in which all objects are well-sectioned.
We
note as in the proof of Lemma 5.6.14 that the natural map TelXn ‚àí‚ÜícolimXn
is a level q-equivalence and therefore a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism. Relating the telescope to
a classical homotopy coequalizer as in the cited proof, we reduce the calculation
of the homotopy groups of the telescope to an algebraic inspection based on (ii).
Alternatively, one can commute double colimits to reduce the veriÔ¨Åcation to its
space level analogue.
For (v), it suÔ¨Éces to show that the tensor X ‚àßB T preserves œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms in
either variable, by Lemma 5.4.5. That follows from Proposition 12.4.4 below.
‚ñ°

186
12. MODEL STRUCTURES FOR PARAMETRIZED G-SPECTRA
Proposition 12.4.4. Let X and Y be well-grounded spectra over B and T and
W be well-based spaces.
(i) If g: T ‚àí‚ÜíW is a q-equivalence, then
id ‚àßB g: X ‚àßB T ‚àí‚ÜíX ‚àßB W
is a level q-equivalence and therefore a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism.
(ii) If f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism, then
f ‚àßB id: X ‚àßB T ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚àßB T
is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism; if T is a Ô¨Ånite based CW complex, then
FB(id, f): FB(T, X) ‚àí‚ÜíFB(T, Y )
is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism.
(iii) For a representation V in V , f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism if and only if
Œ£V
Bf is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism.
Proof. Part (i) holds since the level q-equivalences are well-grounded. There-
fore, for the Ô¨Årst part of (ii), we may assume by q-coÔ¨Åbrant approximation in the
space variable that T is a based CW complex. Using Proposition 8.5.3, it also
implies that ‚àí‚àßB T preserves approximations of well-grounded spectra over B
by level ex-quasiÔ¨Åbrations.
Now the Ô¨Årst part of (ii) follows Ô¨Åberwise from its
nonparametrized analogue [105, III.3.11] and (iii) follows Ô¨Åberwise from its non-
parametrized analogue [105, III.3.6].
Since FB(‚àí, X) takes coÔ¨Åber sequences of
based spaces to Ô¨Åber sequences of spectra over B, the second part of (iii) follows
from the Ô¨Årst exact sequence in Theorem 12.4.2, as in the proof of [105, III.3.9].
‚ñ°
This leads to the following result, which shows that we are in a stable situation.
Proposition 12.4.5. For all well-grounded spectra X over B and all repre-
sentations V in IG, the unit Œ∑: X ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶V
BŒ£V
BX and counit Œµ: Œ£V
B‚Ñ¶V
BX ‚àí‚ÜíX of
the (Œ£V
B, ‚Ñ¶V
B) adjunction are œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms. Therefore, if f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a map
between well-grounded spectra over B, then the natural maps Œ∑: FBf ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶BCBf
and œµ: Œ£BFBf ‚àí‚ÜíCBf are œÄ‚àó-isomorphism.
Proof. For Œ∑, after approximation of X by an ex-quasiÔ¨Åbration, the conclusion
follows Ô¨Åberwise from its nonparametrized analogue [105, III.3.6]. Using the two
out of three property and the triangle equality for the adjunction, it follows that
‚Ñ¶V
BŒµ is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism, hence so is Œµ. For the last statement, the maps Œ∑ and Œµ are
the parametrized analogues of the maps deÔ¨Åned for ordinary loops and suspensions
in [121, p. 61], and they Ô¨Åt into diagrams relating Ô¨Åber and coÔ¨Åber sequences like
those displayed there. Now the last statement follows from the Ô¨Åve lemma and the
exact sequences in Theorem 12.4.2.
‚ñ°
12.5. Proofs of the model axioms
We need some G-spectrum level recollections from [105] and their analogues for
G-spectra over B to describe the generating acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbrations. Let (SG, GS )
denote the G-category of G-spectra. To keep track of enrichments, we again return
G to the notations for the moment.

12.5. PROOFS OF THE MODEL AXIOMS
187
We have a shift desuspension functor FV from based G-spaces to G-spectra
given by FV T = V ‚àó‚àßT, where V ‚àó(W) = JG(V, W) [105, III.4.6]. It is left adjoint
to evaluation at V . For G-spectra X, the adjoint structure G-map
ÀúœÉ: X(V ) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶W X(V ‚äïW)
may be viewed by adjunction as a G-map
ÀúœÉ: SG(FV S0, X) ‚àí‚ÜíSG(FV ‚äïW SW , X).
Passing to G-Ô¨Åxed points and taking X = FV S0, the image of the identity map
gives a map of G-spectra
ŒªV,W : FV ‚äïW SW ‚àí‚ÜíFV S0.
(The notation ŒªV,W was used in [105], but we need room for a subscript). A Yoneda
lemma argument then shows that the map of G-spaces
SG(ŒªV,W , id): SG(FV S0, X) ‚àí‚ÜíSG(FV ‚äïW SW , X)
can be identiÔ¨Åed with ÀúœÉ: X(V ) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶W X(V ‚äïW).
We need the analogue for G-spectra over B. Recall from DeÔ¨Ånition 11.3.5 that,
for an ex-G-space K over B, (FV K)(W) = V ‚àó(W) ‚àßB K, where
V ‚àó(W) = JG,B(V, W) = JG(V, W)B = (FV S0)(W) ‚àßB S0
B.
It follows that we can identify FV K with the evident external tensor FV S0 ‚àßB K of
the G-spectrum FV S0 and the ex-G-space K over B; compare Remark 11.1.7. We
have used the notation ‚àßB for this generalized tensor, but viewing it as a special
case of the external smash product of spectra over ‚àóand over B would suggest the
alternative notation ‚äº.
Definition 12.5.1. For ex-G-spaces K over B, we deÔ¨Åne a natural map

12. MODEL STRUCTURES FOR PARAMETRIZED G-SPECTRA
We could have started oÔ¨Äby deÔ¨Åning ŒªV,W
B
in a conceptual manner analogous
to our deÔ¨Ånition of ŒªV,W , but we want the explicit description of ŒªV,W
B
in terms of
ŒªV,W in order to deduce homotopical properties in the parametrized context from
homotopical properties in the nonparametrized context. For that and other pur-
poses, we need the following observation. We return to our convention of deleting
G from the notations, on the understanding that everything is equivariant.
Lemma 12.5.3. If œÜ: X ‚àí‚ÜíY is an s-equivalence of level well-based nonpara-
metrized spectra and K is a well-grounded ex-space with total space of the homotopy
type of a G-CW complex, then œÜ ‚àßB id: X ‚àßB K ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚àßB K is an s-equivalence.
Proof. We use the ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation functor P of DeÔ¨Ånition 8.3.4. We
have a natural zig-zag of h-equivalences between K and PK. By Proposition 8.2.6,
it induces a zig-zag of level h-equivalences between X ‚àßB K and X ‚àßB PK and, by
Corollary 8.2.5, X ‚àßB PK is a level ex-Ô¨Åbration. Therefore, by Lemma 12.4.1, it
suÔ¨Éces to consider the case when K is an ex-Ô¨Åbration. Since (X ‚àßB K)b = X ‚àßKb
and Kb is of the homotopy type of a Gb-CW complex, by Theorem 3.5.2, each
(œÜ ‚àßB id)b is an s-equivalence by [105, III.3.11].
‚ñ°
The following result is crucial.
Proposition 12.5.4. Let K be a well-grounded ex-space with total space of the
homotopy type of a CW complex. Then
ŒªV,W
B
: FV ‚äïW Œ£W

ŒªV,W ‚äºid: FV ‚äïW SW ‚äºFZK ‚àí‚ÜíFV S0 ‚äºFZK

Proof. Since ŒªV,W
B
= ŒªV,W ‚àßB id, Lemma 12.5.3 and the corresponding non-

For the second

X ‚äºFZK ‚àº= X ‚äº(FZS0 ‚àßB K) ‚àº= (X ‚àßFZS0) ‚àßB K.
Taking X = FV T for a based space T and using Lemma 11.3.6, we see that
FV T ‚äºFZK ‚àº= FV ‚äïZ(T ‚àßB K).
Using equivalences of this form and checking deÔ¨Ånitions, we conclude that the map

Corollary 12.5.8. The terminal map F ‚àí‚Üí‚àóB satisÔ¨Åes the RLP with respect
to FKB if and only if F is an ‚Ñ¶-spectrum over B.

Corollary 12.5.9. If f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism that satisÔ¨Åes the RLP
with respect to FKB, then f is a level acyclic qf-Ô¨Åbration.
Proof. Since f is a level qf-Ô¨Åbration by Proposition 12.5.6, the dual of the
gluing lemma applied to the diagram
‚àóB
/

f

gives that the induced map F ‚àí‚ÜíFBf of pullbacks is a level q-equivalence. Since
f has the RLP with respect to FKB, so does its pullback F ‚àí‚Üí‚àóB.
By the
previous corollary, F is thus an ‚Ñ¶-spectrum over B. In particular, it is level qf-
Ô¨Åbrant. We conclude that F is a level qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation for FBf. Since f
is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism, Theorem 12.4.2 gives that F is acyclic. By Theorem 12.3.8,
this implies that F ‚àí‚Üí‚àóB is a level q-equivalence.
Thus the Ô¨Åbers F(V )b all
have trivial homotopy groups. We conclude (with a bit of extra argument as in
[106, 9.8] to handle œÄ0) that each map of Ô¨Åbers f(V )b induces an isomorphism on
homotopy groups. Therefore, since each f(V ) is a qf-Ô¨Åbration, each f(V ) induces
an isomorphism on homotopy groups.
‚ñ°
The proof of the model axioms for the stable model structure is now immediate.
Proof of Theorem 12.3.10. The œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms give a well-grounded sub-
category of weak equivalences, by Theorem 12.4.3. Conditions (i), (iii), and (iv)
in Theorem 5.5.1 are clear from our speciÔ¨Åcation of the generating acyclic s-
coÔ¨Åbrations and the result for the level qf-model structure.
For condition (ii),
a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism that satisÔ¨Åes the RLP with respect to FKB has the RLP with
respect to FIB by Corollary 12.5.9. Conversely, a map that has the RLP with re-
spect to FIB is a level acyclic qf-Ô¨Åbration and therefore has the RLP with respect to
FKB by Proposition 12.5.6. It is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism since it is level acyclic. Since
all s-Ô¨Åbrations are level qf-Ô¨Åbrations, right properness follows from the slightly
stronger observation in the following result.
‚ñ°
Proposition 12.5.10. The œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms in GSB are preserved under pull-
backs along level qf-Ô¨Åbrations.
Proof. Let g be the pullback of a level qf-Ô¨Åbration f along a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism.
Then g is a level qf-Ô¨Åbration and the Ô¨Åbers of g(V ) are isomorphic to the Ô¨Åbers of
f(V ). Therefore the homotopy Ô¨Åbers FBg are level q-equivalent to the homotopy
Ô¨Åbers FBf. The result follows by comparison of the Ô¨Årst long exact sequence in
Theorem 12.4.2 for f and g.
‚ñ°
12.6. Some Quillen adjoint pairs relating stable model structures
We prove here that all of the adjoint pairs that were shown to be Quillen
adjoints with respect to the level model structure in ¬ß12.2 are still Quillen adjoints
with respect to the stable model structure.
In view of the role played by level
qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation in our deÔ¨Ånition of homotopy groups, it is helpful to
Ô¨Årst understand the relationship between s-Ô¨Åbrant approximation and level qf-
Ô¨Åbrant approximation. Now that the model structures have been established, we

12.6. SOME QUILLEN ADJOINT PAIRS RELATING STABLE MODEL STRUCTURES
191
henceforward use the term s-equivalence rather than the synonymous term œÄ‚àó-
isomorphism.
Lemma 12.6.1. Let ŒΩ : X ‚àí‚ÜíRX and ŒΩ‚Ñì: X ‚àí‚ÜíR‚ÑìX be an s-Ô¨Åbrant ap-
proximation of X and a level qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximation of X. Then there is an
s-equivalence Œæ : R‚ÑìX ‚àí‚ÜíRX under X.
Proof. Since ŒΩ‚Ñìis a level acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbration, it is an acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbration by
Lemma 12.3.5. Since RX is s-Ô¨Åbrant, the RLP gives a map Œæ under X, and it is
an s-equivalence since ŒΩ and ŒΩ‚Ñìare s-equivalences.
‚ñ°
We have the following relationship between the homotopy categories of ex-
spaces over B and of spectra over B.
Proposition 12.6.2. The pair (Œ£‚àû
B , ‚Ñ¶‚àû
B ) is a Quillen adjunction relating GSB
and GKB. More generally, (Œ£‚àû
V , ‚Ñ¶‚àû
V ) = (FV , EvV ) is a Quillen adjunction for any
representation V ‚ààV .
Proof. The maps Œ£‚àû
V i, where i ‚ààIf
B is a generating coÔ¨Åbration for the qf-
model structure on GKB, are among the generating coÔ¨Åbrations of the s-model
structure on GSB, and it follows that Œ£‚àû
V preserves coÔ¨Åbrations. Since Œ£‚àû
V takes
acyclic qf-coÔ¨Åbrations to level acyclic qf-coÔ¨Åbrations, and these are acyclic by
Lemma 12.3.5, Œ£‚àû
V also preserves acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations.
‚ñ°
Now consider an adjoint pair (F, V ) between categories of parametrized spectra
that is a Quillen adjunction with respect to the level model structures. Since the
coÔ¨Åbrations are the same in the level model structure and in the stable model
structure, the left adjoint F certainly preserves coÔ¨Åbrations. Thus, to show that
(F, V ) is also a Quillen adjunction with respect to the stable model structures, we
need only show that F carries acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbrations to s-equivalences. When F
preserves all s-equivalences, this is obvious; otherwise, by Lemma 5.4.7, it suÔ¨Éces
to verify this for the generating acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbrations. The cited result applies in
general to subcategories of well-grounded weak equivalences, and in our context
it applies to both the level q-equivalences and the s-equivalences. Recall that a
Quillen left adjoint in any model structure preserves weak equivalences between
coÔ¨Åbrant objects, by Ken Brown‚Äôs lemma [75, 1.1.12]. The following parenthetical
observation applies to give a stronger conclusion for the Quillen left adjoints that
we shall encounter.
It will play a crucial role in exploiting the equivalence of
homotopy categories that we will establish in the next chapter. Note that the s-
coÔ¨Åbrant spectra are the coÔ¨Åbrant objects in both the level and the stable model
structures, and they are well-grounded.
Proposition 12.6.3. Let F be a Quillen left adjoint between categories of
parametrized spectra with their stable model structures and suppose that F preserves
level q-equivalences between well-grounded spectra. Then F preserves s-equivalences
between well-grounded spectra.
Proof. If g: X ‚àí‚ÜíY is an s-equivalence, where X and Y are well-grounded,
factor g in the level model structure as
X
g‚Ä≤
/ W
g‚Ä≤‚Ä≤
/ Y,
where g‚Ä≤ is an s-coÔ¨Åbration and g‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ is a level acyclic qf-Ô¨Åbration. Then W is well-
grounded and Fg‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ is a level q-equivalence by assumption. Since F is a Quillen left

192
12. MODEL STRUCTURES FOR PARAMETRIZED G-SPECTRA
adjoint in the s-model structures, Fg‚Ä≤ is an s-equivalence. Since level q-equivalences
are s-equivalences it follows that Fg = Fg‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ ‚ó¶Fg‚Ä≤ is an s-equivalence.
‚ñ°
The following sequence of results consists of analogues for the stable model
structures of results proven for the level model structures in ¬ß12.2. Recall that we
actually have well-grounded stable model structures s(C ) for any closed generating
set C .
As in ¬ß12.2, wherever a qf(C )-model structure was used in Chapter 7
for some particularly well chosen C , we must use the corresponding s(C )-model
structure here.
Proposition 12.6.4. Let T be a based G-CW complex. Then (‚àí‚àßBT, FB(T, ‚àí))
is a Quillen adjunction on GSB. When T = SV , it is a Quillen equivalence.
Proof. This is immediate from the fact that the stable model structure is
G-topological, together with Propositions 12.4.4 and 12.4.5.
‚ñ°
Proposition 12.6.5. If i: X ‚àí‚ÜíY and j : W ‚àí‚ÜíZ are s-coÔ¨Åbrations of
spectra over base spaces A and B, then
i‚ñ°j : (Y ‚äºW) ‚à™X‚äºW (X ‚äºZ) ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚äºZ
is an s-coÔ¨Åbration over A √ó B which is s-acyclic if either i or j is s-acyclic.
Proof. The statement about s-coÔ¨Åbrations is part of the analogue, Proposi-
tion 12.2.3, for the level model structure. As usual, it suÔ¨Éces to show that i‚ñ°j
is an s-equivalence if i ‚ààFIf
B and j ‚ààFKf
B, where FKf
B is the set of generating
acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbrations speciÔ¨Åed in DeÔ¨Ånition 12.5.5. Arguing as in Lemma 5.4.5 and
using properness, this will hold if smashing the source and the target of i with j
give s-equivalences. The reduction so far would work just as well for internal smash
products. The required last step reduces via inspection of DeÔ¨Ånition 12.5.5 to an
application of Proposition 12.5.4, with base space taken to be A √ó B. The reason
that this last step works for external smash products but fails for internal smash
products is made clear in Warning 6.1.7.
‚ñ°
Corollary 12.6.6. If Y is an s-coÔ¨Åbrant spectrum over B, then the functor
(‚àí) ‚äºY from GSA to GSA√óB is a Quillen left adjoint with Quillen right adjoint
¬ØF(Y, ‚àí).
Proposition 12.6.7. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a G-map. Then (f!, f ‚àó) is a Quillen
adjoint pair. If f is a q-equivalence, then (f!, f ‚àó) is a Quillen equivalence.

A

‚àº= f ‚àókV,W

equivalence if and only if f ‚àóreÔ¨Çects s-equivalences between s-Ô¨Åbrant objects and

the composite X ‚àí‚Üíf ‚àóf!X ‚àí‚Üíf ‚àóRf!X given by the unit of the adjunction
and s-Ô¨Åbrant approximation is an s-equivalence for all s-coÔ¨Åbrant X. Since the s-

That result also gives that the composite X ‚àí‚Üíf ‚àóf!X ‚àí‚Üíf ‚àóR‚Ñìf!X is a level q-

Observe that Proposition 12.6.3 applies to f!.
Proposition 12.6.8. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a G-bundle whose Ô¨Åbers Ab are Gb-

Ô¨Åces by Lemma 5.4.7 to prove that f ‚àók is an s-equivalence between well-grounded

follows from the fact that if K ‚®øB is a space over B with a disjoint section, then
f ‚àóFV (K‚®øB) = FV f ‚àóK‚®øA is well-grounded. To see that f ‚àók is an s-equivalence, it
is enough, as in the proof of Proposition 12.6.7, to consider k = i‚ñ°kV,W
B
with i ‚ààIf
B.
We have that f ‚àókV,W
B
= kV,W

and factorizations through mapping cylinders, we see as in the cited proof that
f ‚àók ‚àº= f ‚àói‚ñ°kV,W

, which is an acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbration.
‚ñ°
Corollary 12.6.9. If B is a G-cell complex, then (r‚àó, r‚àó) is a Quillen adjoint
pair.
Proposition 12.6.10. Let Œπ: H ‚àí‚ÜíG be the inclusion of a subgroup. The pair
of functors (Œπ!, ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àó) relating HSA and GSŒπ!A gives a Quillen equivalence. If A is
completely regular, then Œπ! is also a Quillen right adjoint.
Proof. By Proposition 14.3.1 below, (Œπ!, ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àó) is a Quillen adjoint pair. The
proof that it is a Quillen equivalence is the same as the proof of the ex-space
level analogue in Proposition 7.4.7.
The last statement is less obvious.
As in
the proof of the corresponding statement in Proposition 7.4.7, it follows from the
spectrum level analogue of Remark 2.4.5, which in turn requires the spectrum level
analogue of Proposition 2.4.4, and the analogue in the stable model structure of
Proposition 7.4.3. The required analogues are proven in ¬ß14.4 below.
‚ñ°
We shall see that (Œπ!, ŒΩ‚àóŒπ‚àó) descends to a closed symmetric monoidal equivalence
of homotopy categories in Proposition 13.7.9 below.
Corollary 12.6.11. The functor Œπ‚àó: HoGSB ‚àí‚ÜíHoHSŒπ‚àóB is the composite
HoGSB
¬µ‚àó/HoGKŒπ!Œπ‚àóB ‚âÉHoHKŒπ‚àóB
Using Example 11.5.5 as in Proposition 12.2.10, the following result is now a
special case of Propositions 12.6.10 and 12.6.7.
Proposition 12.6.12. For b ‚ààB, the pair of functors ((‚àí)b, (‚àí)b) relating
GbS and GSB is a Quillen adjoint pair.


CHAPTER 13
Adjunctions and compatibility relations
Introduction
The utility of the stable homotopy category Ho GSB depends on the fact that
the usual functors and adjunctions descend to it and still satisfy appropriate com-
mutation relations. We consider such matters in this chapter. Many of our basic
adjunctions are Quillen adjunctions in the stable model structure. We recorded
those in ¬ß12.6. The crucial adjunction missing from ¬ß12.6 is (f ‚àó, f‚àó) for a general
map f of base spaces. This cannot be a Quillen adjoint pair by the argument in
Counterexample 0.0.1. We used Brown representability to construct the right ad-
joint f‚àóbetween homotopy categories of ex-spaces in Theorem 9.3.2. Analogously,
in ¬ß13.1 we use Brown representability to construct f‚àóbetween homotopy categories
of parametrized spectra, and we use base change along diagonal maps to internalize
smash products and function spectra. There is an interesting twist here. It is not
easy to verify the Mayer-Vietoris axiom directly. Rather, we use the triangulated
category variant of the Brown representability theorem, whose hypotheses turn out
to be easier to check.
In ¬ß13.7, we complete the proof that our stable homotopy categories are sym-
metric monoidal and prove some basic compatibility relations among smash prod-
ucts and base change functors.
These results involve commutation of Quillen
left and right adjoints, and we would not know how to prove them using only
model theoretic Ô¨Åbrant and coÔ¨Åbrant replacement functors. Rather, their proofs
depend on an equivalence between our model theoretic stable homotopy category
of parametrized G-prespectra and a classical homotopy category of what we call
‚Äúexcellent‚Äù parametrized G-prespectra. We used an analogous, but more elemen-
tary, equivalence of categories in Chapter 9. It is essential to use parametrized
G-prespectra rather than parametrized G-spectra to make the comparison since
the relevant constructions do not all preserve functoriality on linear isometries;
that is, they do not preserve IG-spaces. Results proven using the comparison are
then translated to parametrized G-spectra along the Quillen equivalence between
parametrized G-prespectra and parametrized G-spectra.
These equivalences of categories allow us to use a prespectrum level analogue
T of the ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation functor P to study derived functors. We deÔ¨Åne
excellent parametrized G-prespectra in ¬ß13.2. We lift the ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation
functor P from ex-G-spaces to parametrized G-spectra in ¬ß13.3. There are several
further twists here. First, the functor P on ex-G-spaces does not behave well with
respect to tensors, so extending it to a functor on parametrized G-prespectra is
subtle. Second, with the extension, the zig-zag of h-equivalences connecting P to
the identity functor is no longer given by honest maps of parametrized G-prespectra,
only weak maps. Third, the functor P does not take parametrized G-prespectra to
195

196
13. ADJUNCTIONS AND COMPATIBILITY RELATIONS
excellent ones. To remedy this, we introduce two auxiliary functors K and E in
¬ß13.4. The composite T = KEP does land in excellent parametrized G-prespectra,
and K converts weak maps to honest maps. In ¬ß¬ß13.5 and 13.6 we use T to prove
the promised equivalence of homotopy categories and show how to study derived
funtors in this context.
There are few issues of equivariance in this chapter, and we generally continue
to omit the (compact Lie) group G from the notations. We adopt the convention
of calling isomorphisms in homotopy categories equivalences and we denote them
by ‚âÉrather than ‚àº=.
13.1. Brown representability and the functors f‚àóand FB
We need some preliminaries about the two versions of Brown representability
that are applicable in stable situations. Recall Example 11.5.5.

From here, the following three results work in much the same way as their ex-
space analogues in ¬ß7.5. The category Ho GSB has coproducts and weak pushouts,
hence weak sequential colimits. Again, care must be taken with compactness, as
deÔ¨Åned in DeÔ¨Ånition 7.5.2, since maps into homotopy colimits must be interpreted
in the derived sense.
Lemma 13.1.2. Each X ‚ààDB is compact.
Proof. The sphere H-spectra Sn
H are compact in HS , where all objects are
s-Ô¨Åbrant, so that the analogue in that category is clear. We mimic the ex-space level
proofs of Lemmas 7.5.14 and 7.5.15. Remember that s-equivalences are deÔ¨Åned in
terms of homotopy groups of Ô¨Åbers after level Ô¨Åbrant approximation. As in the
proof of Lemma 7.5.14, for a sequence of maps fq : Yq ‚àí‚ÜíYq+1 between s-Ô¨Åbrant
and s-coÔ¨Åbrant G-spectra over B, we take RTel Yq as our model for the derived
homotopy colimit of the Yq, where R denotes s-Ô¨Åbrant approximation. As a Ô¨Åbrant
approximation, the map Tel Yq ‚àí‚ÜíRTel Yq is an s-equivalence. To show that the
homotopy groups of RTel Yq are given as colimits of the homotopy groups of the Yq,
we must show that the homotopy groups of the source can be computed directly,
without level Ô¨Åbrant approximation.
Arguing as in the proof of Lemma 7.5.15,
we approximate our given sequence of maps fq : Yq ‚àí‚ÜíYq+1 by a sequence of s-
coÔ¨Åbrations gq : Zq ‚àí‚ÜíZq+1 of s-Ô¨Åbrant and s-coÔ¨Åbrant G-spectra over B. Here
the Zq are again s-Ô¨Åbrant and s-coÔ¨Åbrant, and the approximating maps Zq ‚àí‚ÜíYq
are homotopy equivalences and therefore level homotopy equivalences on Ô¨Åbers. We
use Theorem 12.4.3(iv) to compute the homotopy groups of colim Zq as the colimit
of homotopy groups of the Zq, and the conclusion follows.
‚ñ°

13.1. BROWN REPRESENTABILITY AND THE FUNCTORS f‚àóAND FB
197
Proposition 13.1.3. A map Œæ : Y ‚àí‚ÜíZ in GSB is an s-equivalence if and
only if the induced map Œæ‚àó: [X, Y ]G,B ‚àí‚Üí[X, Z]G,B is a bijection for all X ‚ààDB.
Proof. This is a tautology since as X ranges through the Sn,b
H , [X, Y ]G,B
ranges through the homotopy groups œÄH
n (Yb) that deÔ¨Åne the s-equivalences.
‚ñ°
Theorem 13.1.4 (Brown). A contravariant set-valued functor on the category
Ho GSB is representable if and only if it satisÔ¨Åes the wedge and Mayer-Vietoris
axioms.
Since we have the Quillen adjoint pair (f!, f ‚àó), we have the right derived func-
tor f ‚àó: Ho GSB ‚àí‚ÜíHo GSA. As in the proof of the analogous result on the level
of ex-spaces, Theorem 9.3.2, we can obtain the desired right adjoint f‚àóto f ‚àóby use
of Brown‚Äôs theorem provided that we can show that f ‚àópreserves the relevant ho-
motopy colimits. However, since f ‚àó: GSB ‚àí‚ÜíGSA does not preserve s-coÔ¨Åbrant
objects, this is not obvious. We will later give results that would allow us to carry
out the proof in a manner analogous to the proof of Theorem 9.3.2, but it is in-
structive to switch gears and give a more direct proof. It is based on the use of
triangulated categories, which are reviewed brieÔ¨Çy in ¬ß16.6, and it would not have
applied on the ex-space level.
Lemma 13.1.5. The category Ho GSB is triangulated.
Proof. The treatment of triangulated categories in [124] gives a general pat-
tern of proof for showing that homotopy categories associated to appropriate model
categories, generally called stable model categories, are triangulated. It applies here.
The distinguished triangles are those equivalent in Ho GSB to coÔ¨Åber sequences of
well-grounded spectra or, equivalently by Proposition 12.4.5, those equivalent to
the negatives of Ô¨Åber sequences. It is relevant to note that, by the proof of Theo-
rem 12.4.2, every coÔ¨Åber sequence is equivalent in Ho GSB to a coÔ¨Åber sequence
of level ex-quasiÔ¨Åbrations.
‚ñ°
In triangulated categories, there is an alternative version of Brown‚Äôs repre-
sentability theorem due to Neeman [132]. It requires a ‚Äúgenerating set of compact
objects‚Äù. We deÔ¨Åned detecting sets and generating sets in DeÔ¨Ånition 7.5.5, but here
the distinction disappears; see, for example, [134, 6.2.9] or [76, 1.4.5]. Contrary to
the usual practice in the literature, we insist that detecting sets and generating sets
in triangulated categories be closed under the suspension equivalence Œ£.
Lemma 13.1.6. Any detecting set in a triangulated category is a generating set.
Together with Theorem 7.5.10, this has the following consequence.
Theorem 13.1.7. The set of iterated suspensions of cell complexes with a single
cell in any coÔ¨Åbrantly generated stable model category C is a set of generating objects
for HoC .
Of course, our generating set DB is smaller than the one given by this general
result. Turning to compactness, we assume that any given triangulated category
A has all small coproducts.
Definition 13.1.8. An object X in a triangulated category A is said to be
compact if the natural map ‚äï[X, Yi] ‚àº= [X, ‚®øYi] is an isomorphism for any set of
objects Yi; A is said to be compactly generated if it has a generating set D of
compact objects.

198
13. ADJUNCTIONS AND COMPATIBILITY RELATIONS
The following obvious lemma describes a general way to prove compactness.
Lemma 13.1.9. Let T : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a left adjoint between triangulated cate-
gories A and B such that the right adjoint U : B ‚àí‚ÜíA preserves coproducts. If
A is compact in A , then TA is compact in B.
Remark 13.1.10. We are following Neeman [132‚Äì134] in using the term ‚Äúcom-
pact‚Äù; the term ‚Äúsmall‚Äù is used for the same notion in [76]. Neither term is fully
satisfactory. Observe that this is a diÔ¨Äerent notion from the sequential one that
we speciÔ¨Åed in DeÔ¨Ånition 7.5.2.
It is clear from the construction of sequential
homotopy colimits (see DeÔ¨Ånition 16.6.5) that a compact object in the sense of
DeÔ¨Ånition 13.1.8 is compact in the sense of DeÔ¨Ånition 7.5.2. We doubt that the
converse holds in general triangulated categories, but we have not looked for a
counterexample. The notion in DeÔ¨Ånition 13.1.8 is the more fundamental one; the
notion in DeÔ¨Ånition 7.5.2 serves only to specify exactly what is relevant to the
classical Brown representability theorem.
Warnings 7.5.4 and 7.5.16 apply equally well to the present notion of compact-
ness, but the required compactness of objects of DB reduces to the compactness of
spheres, as in the proofs of Lemmas 7.5.14 and 13.1.2.
Lemma 13.1.11. DB is a generating set of compact objects in Ho GSB.
Proof. Take U in Lemma 13.1.9 to be the Ô¨Åber functor (‚àí)b : Ho GSB ‚àí‚Üí
Ho GbS for some b ‚ààB. Arguing as in the proof of Lemma 13.1.2, it preserves
coproducts since the homotopy groups of coproducts are the direct sums of their
homotopy groups. Clearly the objects of DB are of the form TA for some compact
A in some Ho GbS , as in Lemma 13.1.2.
‚ñ°
Theorems 13.1.12, 13.1.14, and 13.1.17 below are proven in [132, 2.1 3.1, 3.2,
4.1]. Related results that compare compactness to dualizability appear in [76, 2.1.3]
and will become relevant in ¬ß16.7; see also [62, ¬ß8].
Theorem 13.1.12. Let A be a compactly generated triangulated category. A
functor k: A op ‚àí‚ÜíA b that converts coproducts to products and takes distinguished
triangles to exact sequences is representable.
Definition 13.1.13. Let B be a full subcategory of a triangulated category
A . Then B is a thick subcategory if the third term of a distinguished triangle with
two terms in B is in B and if a direct summand of an object in B is in B. A thick
subcategory B is localizing if it is also closed under coproducts.
Theorem 13.1.14. Let A be a triangulated category with a generating set D
of compact objects. Then the thick subcategory of A generated by D is the full sub-
category B of compact objects in A , and the localizing subcategory of A generated
by D is A itself.
One can be more precise about how this works, giving a kind of cellular theory
in triangulated categories, as in [76, 2.3.1].
Theorem 13.1.15. Let A be a triangulated category with a generating set D
of compact objects. Then every object X is isomorphic to a homotopy colimit of
a sequence of maps fi : Xi ‚àí‚ÜíXi+1 such that X0 = ‚àóand the coÔ¨Åber of fi is a
coproduct of generating objects.

13.1. BROWN REPRESENTABILITY AND THE FUNCTORS f‚àóAND FB
199
Remark 13.1.16. This result applies to our generating set DB in HoSB. Here
the conclusion seems quite surprising since the cell complexes generated by just
those generating s-coÔ¨Åbrations whose coÔ¨Åber 1-cell complexes are in DB are very
restricted. In fact, one Ô¨Ånds by inspection of pushouts and colimits that such a cell
spectrum X is isomorphic to the wedge over B of the (Xb)b = b!Xb. That is, one
sees only Ô¨Åbers, glued together trivially. This illustrates the fundamental diÔ¨Äerence
between generating sets of coÔ¨Åbrations and cellular objects in a stable model cate-
gory and generating sets of objects and cellular objects (as in Theorem 13.1.15) in
its derived triangulated homotopy category. Concretely, the diÔ¨Äerence is explained
by the need for Ô¨Åbrant approximation in the comparison of [‚àí, ‚àí] and œÄ(‚àí, ‚àí).
Theorem 13.1.12 specializes to give an adjoint functor theorem for exact func-
tors between triangulated categories (as deÔ¨Åned in DeÔ¨Ånition 16.6.6).
Theorem 13.1.17. Let A be a compactly generated triangulated category and
let B be any triangulated category. An exact functor F : A ‚àí‚ÜíB that preserves
coproducts has a right adjoint G.
Theorem 13.1.18. For any G-map f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB, there is a right adjoint f‚àóto
the functor f ‚àó: Ho GSB ‚àí‚ÜíHo GSA, so that
[f ‚àóY, X]G,A ‚àº= [Y, f‚àóX]G,B
for X in GSA and Y in GSB.
Proof. The left adjoint f! commutes with Œ£ and preserves coÔ¨Åber sequences,
and this remains true after passage to derived homotopy categories. Therefore the
derived functor f! is exact. Since f ‚àóis Quillen right adjoint to f!, the derived functor
f ‚àóis right adjoint to f! and is therefore also exact; see, for example, [131, 3.9]. If X
is in DA, then f!X is compact in Ho GSB, as we see from commutation relations
between relevant Quillen left adjoints given in Remark 11.4.7. It follows formally
that f ‚àópreserves coproducts, by [132, 5.1] or [62, 7.4].
‚ñ°
Remark 13.1.19. For composable maps f and g, there is a natural equivalence
g‚àó‚ó¶f‚àó‚âÉ(g ‚ó¶f)‚àóon homotopy categories since f ‚àó‚ó¶g‚àó‚âÉ(g ‚ó¶f)‚àó.
Exactly as for ex-spaces in Theorem 9.3.5, we apply change of base along the
diagonal map ‚àÜ: B ‚àí‚ÜíB √ó B to obtain internal smash product and function
spectra functors in Ho GSB.
Theorem 13.1.20. DeÔ¨Åne ‚àßB and FB on Ho GSB to be the composite (derived)
functors
X ‚àßB Y = ‚àÜ‚àó(X ‚äºY ) and FB(X, Y ) = ¬ØF(X, ‚àÜ‚àóY ).
Then
[X ‚àßB Y, Z]G,B ‚àº= [X, FB(Y, Z)]G,B
for X, Y and Z in Ho GSB.
Proof. The displayed adjunction is the composite of the adjunction for the
external smash product and function spectra functors given by Corollary 12.6.6 and
the adjunction (‚àÜ‚àó, ‚àÜ‚àó).
