13. ADJUNCTIONS AND COMPATIBILITY RELATIONS
13.2. The category GEB of excellent prespectra over B
We must still prove that Ho GSB is a closed symmetric monoidal category un-
der the derived internal smash product, that the derived functor f ‚àóis closed sym-
metric monoidal, and that various compatibility relations that hold on the point-set
level descend to homotopy categories. In particular, since our right adjoints f‚àó, ‚àÜ‚àó,
and therefore FB come from Brown‚Äôs representability theorem, it is not at all obvi-
ous how to prove that they are well-behaved homotopically. In Chapter 9, we solved
the corresponding ex-space level problems by proving that Ho GKB is equivalent
to the more classical and elementary homotopy category hGWB. Here GWB is the
category of ex-Ô¨Åbrations over B whose total spaces are compactly generated and of
the homotopy types of G-CW complexes, and hGWB is obtained from GWB simply
by passage to homotopy classes of maps. This equivalence allowed us to exploit the
ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation functor P of ¬ß8.3 to resolve the cited problems.
We shall resolve our spectrum level problems similarly, and the following deÔ¨Å-
nitions give the appropriate analogues of GWB and hGWB. However, to keep closer
to the ex-space level, it is essential to work with parametrized prespectra rather
than parametrized spectra. It is safe to do so in view of the Quillen equivalence
(P, U) of Theorem 12.3.12 relating GPB and GSB.
Definition 13.2.1. Let X be a G-prespectrum over B.
(i) X is well-structured if each level X(V ) is in GWB.
(ii) X is Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant if it is well-grounded and each structure map
œÉ: Œ£W
B X(V ) ‚àí‚ÜíX(V ‚äïW)
is an fp-coÔ¨Åbration and therefore an f-coÔ¨Åbration.
We can now give the deÔ¨Ånition of excellent G-prespectra over B and of the
associated classical homotopy category. Working with classical nonequivariant and
nonparametrized coordinatized prespectra {En}, it has been known since the 1960‚Äôs
that the following deÔ¨Ånition gives the simplest quick and dirty rigorous construction
of the stable homotopy category.
Definition 13.2.2. The category GEB of excellent G-prespectra over B is the
full subcategory of GPB whose objects are the well-structured Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant ‚Ñ¶-G-
prespectra over B.
Let hGEB denote the classical homotopy category obtained
from GEB by passage to homotopy classes of maps.
We comment on the conditions we require of excellent prespectra over B. We
require that they be well-structured so that we can exploit levelwise our equivalence
of homotopy categories on the ex-space level. We require that they be Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant
since that provides ‚Äúhomotopical glue‚Äù that is necessary for the transition from
the known equivalence on the ex-space level to the desired equivalence on the pre-
spectrum level. We shall make this idea precise shortly, in Proposition 13.2.5. We
require that they be ‚Ñ¶-prespectra over B since it is clearly sensible to restrict at-
tention to s-Ô¨Åbrant objects in GSB if we hope to compare homotopy categories.
Recall that X is an ‚Ñ¶-prespectrum if it is a level qf-Ô¨Åbrant prespectrum over B
whose adjoint structure maps
ÀúœÉ: X(V ) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶W ‚àíV
B
X(W)

13.2. THE CATEGORY GEB OF EXCELLENT PRESPECTRA OVER B
201
are q-equivalences. Since excellent prespectra over B are required to be level ex-
Ô¨Åbrations, they are automatically level qf-Ô¨Åbrant. The condition on the adjoint
structure maps is stronger than it appears on the surface.
Lemma 13.2.3. For excellent G-prespectra X over B, the adjoint structure
maps
ÀúœÉ: X(V ) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶W
B X(V ‚äïW)
are fp-equivalences.
Proof. The ÀúœÉ are q-equivalences between G-CW homotopy types and are
therefore h-equivalences. Since they are maps between ex-Ô¨Åbrations, they are fp-
equivalences by Proposition 5.2.2.
‚ñ°
This implies, for example, that homotopy-preserving functors GEB ‚àí‚ÜíGPB
that may not preserve level q-equivalences nevertheless do preserve the equivalence
property required of the adjoint structure maps.
Remark 13.2.4. Our deÔ¨Ånition of excellent parametrized prespectra is close to
that used by Clapp and Puppe [31,32], who in turn were inÔ¨Çuenced by deÔ¨Ånitions
in [112]. Curiously, while Clapp [31] focuses on ex-Ô¨Åbrations, Clapp and Puppe
[32] never mention Ô¨Åbration conditions. These papers are nonequivariant, but the
second is written in terms of what the authors call ‚Äúcoordinate-free spectra‚Äù over
B. These are the same as our nonequivariant prespectra over B, except that their
adjoint structure maps ÀúœÉ are required to be closed inclusions, which holds automat-
ically for Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant prespectra. Clapp and Puppe [32] use the term ‚ÄúcoÔ¨Åbrant‚Äù
for our notion of Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant.
A crucial result of Clapp and Puppe makes the idea of homotopical glue precise.
It is stated nonequivariantly in [32, 6.1], but it works just as well equivariantly.
Translated to our language, it reads as follows.
Proposition 13.2.5 (Clapp-Puppe). If f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a level fp-equivalence
between Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant prespectra over B, then f is a homotopy equivalence of pre-
spectra over B. Therefore, if f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a level h-equivalence between well-
structured Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant prespectra over B, then f is a homotopy equivalence of pre-
spectra over B.
Sketch proof. The proof is analogous to the proof that a ladder of homotopy
equivalences connecting sequences of coÔ¨Åbrations induces a homotopy equivalence
on passage to colimits. The point is that, for Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant parametrized prespectra
Y , we can carry out inductive arguments just as if Y were such a colimit. Using stan-
dard coÔ¨Åbration arguments, carried over to the parametrized case, we can extend
an fp-homotopy inverse of Œ£Wi
B X(Vi) ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£Wi
B Y (Vi) to an fp-homotopy inverse
of X(Vi+1) ‚àí‚ÜíY (Vi+1) and proceed inductively. The last statement follows by
Corollary 5.2.6(i), which shows that a level h-equivalence between well-structured
prespectra over B is a level fp-equivalence.
‚ñ°
Remark 13.2.6. The category GEB inherits many of the preservation proper-
ties for ex-Ô¨Åbrations that are catalogued in ¬ß8.2 and are inherited by GWB. The
condition of being well-structured is deÔ¨Åned levelwise, so that any construction that
takes GWB to itself will preserve well-structured G-prespectra over B. By the re-
tract characterization of fp-coÔ¨Åbrations, any functorial construction that commutes

202
13. ADJUNCTIONS AND COMPATIBILITY RELATIONS
with Œ£B will preserve Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant prespectra over B. Any homotopy-preserving
functorial construction that commutes with ‚Ñ¶B will preserve ‚Ñ¶-G-prespectra over
B. For example, base change functors f ‚àópreserve excellent G-prespectra. Functors
that take excellent G-prespectra to well-structured G-prespectra can be composed
with the approximation functor T = KE deÔ¨Åned in ¬ß13.4 below to rectify them to
functors that preserve excellent G-prespectra.
13.3. The level ex-Ô¨Åbrant approximation functor P on prespectra
We seek an approximation functor to play the role on the parametrized pre-
spectrum level that the functor P played on the ex-space level functor. We shall
introduce three approximation functors, P, E and K, that successively build in the
properties of being well-structured, being an ‚Ñ¶-prespectrum, and being Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant,
each preserving the properties already obtained. We deÔ¨Åne P in this section and
E and K in the next.
Lifting the ex-space level functor P of ¬ß8.3 to the prespectrum level requires
care. Recall that P is the composite of the whiskering functor W and the Moore
mapping path space functor L, together with the natural zig-zag of h-equivalences
(13.3.1)
K
WK
œÅ
o
W Œπ / WLK = PK
of DeÔ¨Ånition 8.3.4 for ex-spaces K over B. The functors W and L do not com-
mute with tensors with based spaces, hence cannot be enriched over GKB, by
Lemma 11.3.4. There is therefore no canonical way of inducing structure maps
after applying P levelwise to a prespectrum, as one might at Ô¨Årst hope. We shall
resolve this by constructing by hand certain non-canonical but natural maps
(13.3.2)
Œ±V : WK ‚àßB SV ‚àí‚ÜíW(K ‚àßB SV )
and
(13.3.3)
Œ≤V : LK ‚àßB SV ‚àí‚ÜíL(K ‚àßB SV )
such that Œ±0 = id, Œ≤0 = id and the following associativity diagram commutes,

The deÔ¨Ånitions of these maps and the proofs that these diagrams commute
depend on chosen decompositions of V and V ‚Ä≤ as direct sums of indecomposable
representations, and we cannot choose compatible decompositions for all represen-
tations V and V ‚Ä≤ at once. For this reason, and for other reasons that will become
apparent later, we must switch gears and work with sequentially indexed prespectra.
Thus, to be precise about the constructions in this section and the next, we
restrict our original collection V of indexing representations to a countable coÔ¨Ånal
sequence W of expanding representations in our given universe U. More precisely,
W consists of representations Vi for i ‚â•0 such that V0 = 0 and Vi ‚äÇVi+1. We set
Wi = Vi+1‚àíVi. Such a sequence can be chosen in any universe. We could just as well
start with representations Wi and deÔ¨Åne Vi inductively by Vi+1 = Vi ‚äïWi. There is

13.3. THE LEVEL EX-FIBRANT APPROXIMATION FUNCTOR P ON PRESPECTRA
203
no need to use orthogonal complements. We shall write in terms of complements,
but on the understanding that that is just a notational convenience.
Remark 13.3.5. There is a small quibble here since we originally deÔ¨Åned our
categories of parametrized prespectra only on collections of representations that
are closed under Ô¨Ånite direct sums, which W clearly is not. However, if we let
W ‚Ä≤ consist of all Ô¨Ånite sums of the Wi, then we recover such a collection. As in
¬ß11.3 (or [106, ¬ß2]), we can interpret GPW ‚Ä≤
B
as a diagram category indexed on a

as a diagram category indexed on the full subcategory DW

B that is right adjoint
to a prolongation functor P [106, ¬ß3], and (P, U) induces an adjoint equivalence
of homotopy categories. We shall study such ‚Äúchange of universe‚Äù adjunctions in
¬ß14.2. They allow us to lift all results we prove about the categories of parametrized
prespectra indexed on coÔ¨Ånal sequences to our usual ones indexed on collections of
representations closed under direct sums.
Definition 13.3.6. Let X be a prespectrum over B indexed on the countable
coÔ¨Ånal sequence W = {Vi}, where V0 = 0 and Vi+1 = Vi‚äïWi. Let X have structure
maps œÉi : Œ£Wi
B X(Vi) ‚àí‚ÜíX(Vi+1). Then the maps
WœÉi ‚ó¶Œ±: WX(Vi) ‚àßB SWi ‚àí‚ÜíWX(Vi+1)
and
LœÉi ‚ó¶Œ≤ : LX(Vi) ‚àßB SWi ‚àí‚ÜíLX(Vi+1)
specify structure maps for prespectra WX and LX over B. Therefore PX = WLX
is a prespectrum over B.
Unfortunately, as will be clear from the following construction, the maps in the
zig-zag (13.3.1) do not lift to the prespectrum level. They only induce weak maps
of prespectra, that is, levelwise maps that only commute with the structure maps
up to (canonical) fp-homotopy. Fortunately, the last approximation functor K,
which arranges Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrancy and will be discussed in the next section, turns weak
maps into honest ones.

13.4. THE AUXILIARY APPROXIMATION FUNCTORS K AND E
205
13.4. The auxiliary approximation functors K and E
We begin with the parametrized ‚Ñ¶-prespectrum approximation functor E. This
is a folklore construction when B is a point.
In the parametrized context, the
construction makes essential use of StasheÔ¨Ä‚Äôs theorem, Theorem 3.5.2.
Proposition 13.4.1. There is a functor E : GPB ‚àí‚ÜíGPB and a natural
map Œ±: X ‚àí‚ÜíEX with the following properties.
(i) The functor E preserves level fp-equivalences and well-grounded prespectra.
(ii) If X is well-structured, then EX is a well-structured ‚Ñ¶-prespectrum and the
map Œ±: X ‚àí‚ÜíEX is an s-equivalence.
Proof. DeÔ¨Åne EX by letting EX(Vi) be the telescope over j ‚â•i of the ex-
spaces ‚Ñ¶Vj‚àíVi
B
X(Vj) with respect to the adjoint structure maps
‚Ñ¶Vj‚àíVi
B
ÀúœÉ: ‚Ñ¶Vj‚àíVi
B
X(Vj) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶Vj‚àíVi
B
‚Ñ¶Wj
B X(Vj+1) ‚àº= ‚Ñ¶Vj+1‚àíVi
B
X(Vj+1).
Since the functor ‚Ñ¶Wi
B commutes with telescopes, ‚Ñ¶Wi
B EX(Vi+1) is isomorphic to the
telescope over j ‚â•i+1 of the ex-spaces ‚Ñ¶Vj‚àíVi+1
B
X(Vj). The adjoint structure map
EX(Vi) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶Wi
B EX(Vi+1) is induced by the maps ‚Ñ¶Vj‚àíVi
B
ÀúœÉj for j ‚â•i. The map
Œ±: X ‚àí‚ÜíEX is given by the inclusion of the bases of the telescopes. If f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY
is a level fp-equivalence, then Ef : EX ‚àí‚ÜíEY is a level fp-equivalence since a
standard inductive argument (applicable in any topologically bicomplete category)
shows that the telescope of a ladder of fp-equivalences is an fp-equivalence.
If X is well-grounded or level ex-Ô¨Åbrant, then so is EX since the construction
clearly stays in the category of compactly generated spaces and since it preserves
the conditions of being well-sectioned or level ex-Ô¨Åbrant by results in ¬ß8.2.
To
show that E preserves well-structured prespectra, it remains to show that if X has
total spaces of the homotopy types of G-CW complexes, then so does EX. By
StasheÔ¨Ä‚Äôs theorem (Theorem 3.5.2), the Ô¨Åbers X(V )b = Xb(V ) have the homotopy
types of Gb-CW complexes. We have the analogous construction E in the category
of Gb-prespectra and, by Milnor‚Äôs theorem (Theorem 3.4.5) and standard facts
about telescopes, the (E(Xb))(V ) have the homotopy types of Gb-CW complexes.
It is clear from the deÔ¨Ånition of E that (E(Xb))(V ) = ((EX)(V ))b. That is, the
Gb-prespectrum E(Xb) is the Ô¨Åber (EX)b of the G-prespectrum EX over B. By
StasheÔ¨Ä‚Äôs theorem again, it follows that the (EX)(V ) have the homotopy types of
G-CW complexes.
To check that the adjoint structure maps are q-equivalences when X is well-
structured, it suÔ¨Éces to check that they induce q-equivalences on the Ô¨Åbers over
b for all b ‚ààB. That holds by inspection of the homotopy groups of the colimits
that deÔ¨Åne (EX)b ‚àº= E(Xb). Similarly, we see that Œ± is a œÄ‚àó-equivalence when X
is well-structured by Ô¨Åberwise comparison of the colimits of homotopy groups of
Ô¨Åbers that deÔ¨Åne the homotopy groups of X and EX.
‚ñ°
To approximate parametrized prespectra by level fp-equivalent Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant pre-
spectra, we use the elementary cylinder construction K that was Ô¨Årst deÔ¨Åned in
[108] and has been used in various papers since. We recall the construction and
its main properties from [98, 6.8], which carries over verbatim to the parametrized
context. A more sophisticated but less convenient treatment is given in [61].
Proposition 13.4.2. There is a functor K : GPB ‚àí‚ÜíGPB and a natural
level fp-equivalence œÄ: KX ‚àí‚ÜíX. Therefore K preserves level fp-equivalences.

206
13. ADJUNCTIONS AND COMPATIBILITY RELATIONS
If X is well-grounded, then KX is Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant. If X is well-structured, then KX is
well-structured. If X is a well-structured ‚Ñ¶-prespectrum, then so is KX and thus
KX is excellent. There is a natural weak map Œπ: X ‚àí‚ÜíKX that is a right inverse
of œÄ, and K takes weak maps f to honest maps Kf such that Œπ ‚ó¶f = Kf ‚ó¶Œπ.
Proof. DeÔ¨Åne KX, a level inclusion Œπ: X ‚àí‚ÜíKX, and a level fp-deformation

Œπ(0) = œÄ(0) = id. Inductively, suppose given KX(Vi), an inclusion Œπ(Vi): X(Vi) ‚àí‚Üí

KX(Vi+1) be the double mapping cylinder in GKB of the pair of maps

If X is well-grounded, then KX is clearly also well-grounded and thus KX is
Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant. If X is well-structured, then so is KX by Propositions 8.2.1 and 8.2.3.

that KX is also an ‚Ñ¶-prespectrum. Alternatively, since ‚Ñ¶V

The composite approximation functor T = KEP has various good preservation
properties. The ex-space level properties of P recorded in ¬ß8.4 are inherited on the
prespectrum level, and we have the following sample result for E and K.
Lemma 13.4.3. For a G-map f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB, a prespectrum Y over B and a
prespectrum X over A, there are natural isomorphisms
f ‚àóEY ‚àº= Ef ‚àóY,
f ‚àóKY ‚àº= Kf ‚àóY
and Kf!X ‚àº= f!KX.
Proof. The relevant telescopes commute with f ‚àósince it is a symmetric
monoidal left adjoint and with f! since it is a left adjoint and the projection formula
(2.2.6) holds.
‚ñ°

13.5. THE EQUIVALENCE BETWEEN Ho GPB AND hGEB
207
13.5. The equivalence between Ho GPB and hGEB
We can now extend the results of ¬ß9.1 to parametrized prespectra. As in the
previous section, our parametrized prespectra are indexed on a countable coÔ¨Ånal
sequence of expanding representations in our given universe. We begin by collating
the results of the previous two sections.
Theorem 13.5.1. Let X be a well-grounded G-prespectrum over B whose total
spaces are of the homotopy types of G-CW complexes and deÔ¨Åne TX = KEPX.
(i) TX is an excellent G-prespectrum.
(ii) T takes level q-equivalences between G-prespectra over B that satisfy the hy-
potheses on X to homotopy equivalences of G-prespectra.
(iii) There is a zig-zag of s-equivalences between X and TX.
(iv) If X is an excellent G-prespectrum over B, then the zig-zag consists of level
fp-equivalences, and it gives rise to a zig-zag of homotopy equivalences of
G-prespectra over B connecting X and TX.
Proof. We have that PX is well-structured by Theorem 13.3.8, EPX is a
well-structured ‚Ñ¶-prespectrum by Proposition 13.4.1, and TX is excellent by Propo-
sition 13.4.2. In (ii), a level q-equivalence is a level h-equivalence. By the results
just quoted, P takes level h-equivalences to level fp-equivalences, which are pre-
served by E, and K takes level fp-equivalences to homotopy equivalences. Since
K converts weak maps to genuine maps, we have the following diagram of maps of
G-presepectra over B.
(13.5.2)
KX
œÄ

KWX
KœÅ
o
œÄ

WKX
W œÄ

W KŒπ/ WKLX
W œÄ

KEPX
œÄ

X
WX
WX
WLX
Œ±
/ EPX
The vertical maps œÄ, hence also the vertical maps WœÄ, are level fp-equivalences.
The map œÅ is a level f-equivalence. The map Œπ is a level h-equivalence, hence so is
WKŒπ. The map Œ± is an s-equivalence because PX is well-structured. Since level
q-equivalences are also s-equivalences, the diagram displays a zig-zag of s-equiva-
lences between X and TX.
For the last statement, observe that all prespectra in the diagram are well-
structured ‚Ñ¶-prespectra over B.
Moreover, Œ± is a level q-equivalence by Theo-
rem 12.3.8. It is therefore a level h-equivalence since our total spaces have the
homotopy types of G-CW complexes. Since all prespectra in our diagram are well-
structured, our level h-equivalences are level fp-equivalences, by Proposition 8.3.2.
Applying K where needed, we can expand the diagram to a zig-zag of level fp-
equivalences between Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant prespectra. By Proposition 13.2.5, this gives a
zig-zag of homotopy equivalences connecting X and TX.
‚ñ°
We introduce a category that is intermediate between GPB and GEB.
Definition 13.5.3. DeÔ¨Åne GQB to be the full subcategory of GPB consisting
of the well-grounded ‚Ñ¶-prespectra over B whose total spaces are of the homotopy
types of G-CW complexes. DeÔ¨Åne HoGQB to be the homotopy category obtained
by inverting the s-equivalences in GQB; by the proof of the next theorem, there are
no set-theoretic problems in deÔ¨Åning HoGQB. DeÔ¨Åne T = KEP : GQB ‚àí‚ÜíGEB.

208
13. ADJUNCTIONS AND COMPATIBILITY RELATIONS
Since the ‚Ñ¶-prespectra over B are the s-Ô¨Åbrant prespectra over B and since
s-coÔ¨Åbrant spectra are well-grounded and have total spaces of the homotopy types
of G-CW complexes, all G-prespectra over B that are s-coÔ¨Åbrant and s-Ô¨Åbrant are
in GQB. We prove that HoGPB is equivalent to hGEB by proving that these
categories are both equivalent to HoGQB.
Theorem 13.5.4. The canonical s-coÔ¨Åbrant and s-Ô¨Åbrant approximation func-
tor RQ and the composite approximation functor T = KEP, together with the
forgetful functors, induce the following equivalences of homotopy categories.
Ho GPB
RQ / Ho GQB
T
/
I
o
hGEB
J
o
Proof. For X in GPB, we have a natural zig-zag of s-equivalences in GPB
X
QX
o
/ RQX.
Therefore X and IRQX are naturally s-equivalent in GPB. If X is in GQB, then
it is s-Ô¨Åbrant and therefore so is QX. Then the above zig-zag is in GQB, hence X
and RQIX are naturally s-equivalent in GQB.
By Theorem 12.3.8, s-equivalences in GQB are level q-equivalences, and T takes
level q-equivalences to homotopy equivalences by Theorem 13.5.1. Conversely, since
homotopy equivalences are s-equivalences, the forgetful functor J induces a functor
in the other direction.
For X in GQB we have the natural zig-zag of s-equivalences displayed in
(13.5.2). Applying s-Ô¨Åbrant approximation, we get a natural zig-zag of s-equivalences
in GQB so X and JTX are naturally s-equivalent in GQB. Starting with X in
GEB, the last statement of Theorem 13.5.1 shows that X and TJX are naturally
homotopy equivalent in GEB.
‚ñ°
13.6. Derived functors on homotopy categories
With P replaced by T, the discussion of derived functors in ¬ß9.2 carries over
from the level of ex-spaces to the level of parametrized prespectra indexed on coÔ¨Ånal
sequences. In ¬ß13.7 and ¬ß14.2 we will discuss how to pass from there to conclusions
on the level of parametrized spectra indexed on our usual collections of represen-
tations closed under direct sums.
We must show that if V is a Quillen left or
right adjoint, then its model theoretic left or right derived functor agrees under our
equivalences of categories with the functor obtained simply by passing to homotopy
classes of maps from the composite TV . As on the ex-space level, we need some
mild good behavior for this to work.
Definition 13.6.1. A functor V : GPA ‚àí‚ÜíGPB is good if it is continu-
ous, preserves well-grounded parametrized prespectra, and takes prespectra over
A whose levelwise total spaces are of the homotopy types of G-CW complexes to
prespectra over B with that property. Since V is continuous, it preserves homo-
topies. There are evident variants for functors V with source or target GK‚àó: V
must be continuous, preserve well-grounded objects, and preserve G-CW homotopy
type conditions on objects.
Note that a good functor V need not take ‚Ñ¶-G-prespectra to ‚Ñ¶-G-prespectra
and recall that a Quillen right adjoint must preserve Ô¨Åbrant objects and thus, in
our context, must preserve ‚Ñ¶-G-prespectra.

13.7. COMPATIBILITY RELATIONS FOR SMASH PRODUCTS AND BASE CHANGE
209
Proposition 13.6.2. Let V : GPA ‚àí‚ÜíGPB be a good functor that is a part
of a Quillen adjoint pair. If V is a Quillen left adjoint, assume further that it pre-
serves level q-equivalences between well-grounded objects. Then the derived func-
tor Ho GPA ‚àí‚ÜíHo GPB, induced by V Q or V R, is equivalent to the functor
TV J : hGEA ‚àí‚ÜíhGEB under the equivalence of categories in Theorem 13.5.4
Proof. If V is a Quillen right adjoint, then it preserves s-equivalences between
s-Ô¨Åbrant objects. If V is a Quillen left adjoint, then it preserves s-equivalences be-
tween well-grounded objects by Proposition 12.6.3. Therefore, since GQA consists
of well-sectioned s-Ô¨Åbrant objects, the functor V : GQA ‚àí‚ÜíGPB passes straight
to homotopy categories to give V : HoGQA ‚àí‚ÜíHoGPB in both cases.
If V is a Quillen right adjoint, then it takes an s-equivalence f in GQA to
an s-equivalence since the objects of GQA are s-Ô¨Åbrant. Then V f is a level q-
equivalence by Theorem 12.3.8 and, since V is good, it is a level h-equivalence. On
the other hand, if V is a Quillen left adjoint, then Theorem 12.3.8 gives that f is
a level q-equivalence and, by assumption, V f is then a level q-equivalence. Since
V is good, V f is actually a level h-equivalence. In both cases it follows that V
takes s-equivalences to level h-equivalences and therefore TV passes to a functor
Ho GQA ‚àí‚ÜíhGEB.
To show that TV J and either V Q or V R agree under the equivalence of cate-
gories, it suÔ¨Éces to verify that the following diagram commutes.

Clearly Q and R preserve s-equivalences. If V is a Quillen left adjoint, then we

have zig-zags of level h-equivalences. Applying T, we obtain a zig-zag of homotopy
equivalences in GEB by Theorem 13.5.1.
‚ñ°
Remark 13.6.3. If V preserves excellent parametrized prespectra, then TV
is naturally homotopy equivalent to V on excellent parametrized prespectra. The
derived functor of V can then be obtained directly by applying V and passing to
homotopy classes of maps.
13.7. Compatibility relations for smash products and base change
This section is parallel to ¬ß9.3. The main change is just that we must replace
the functor P used there with the functor T = KEP that we have here. This

13. ADJUNCTIONS AND COMPATIBILITY RELATIONS
gives us results for the categories GPW
B of parametrized prespectra indexed on
a collection W consisting of a coÔ¨Ånal sequence in some universe U. In order to
obtain statements about GS V
B , where V = V (U), we have two pairs of Quillen
equivalences, both of which can be viewed as consisting of a prolongation functor
left adjoint to a forgetful functor that creates the weak equivalences; see [105, 1.2].
GPW
B

/GPV

We postpone until ¬ß14.2 consideration of the pair (j‚àó, j‚àó) and the extension from
GPW

B in this section.
One general remark is in order, though. The forgetful functors j‚àóand U create
weak equivalences and therefore pass directly to homotopy categories. If they com-
mute on the point set level with a functor V which is deÔ¨Åned and part of a Quillen
adjoint pair (on each of our three categories), then they will also commute with its
derived functor on the level of homotopy categories. It follows formally that the
derived prolongation functors P and j‚àóthen also commute with the derived functor
V and its adjoints. This holds in particular for the base change functor V = f ‚àó.
Extending commutation results for such functors from GPW
B to GS V
B is therefore
easy. However, some of the functors V that we need to consider only exist on some
of the categories in the above display, and such functors require special care. These
include the change of universe functors that we discuss in ¬ß14.2, which don‚Äôt exist
on the level of GPW
B , and the smash product ‚àßB, which we have only speciÔ¨Åed on
the spectrum level and which we now discuss on the prespectrum level.
Remark 13.7.1. Because the domain category for the diagram category of
(equivariant and parametrized) prespectra is only monoidal, not symmetric mon-
oidal, we cannot use left Kan extension to internalize ‚Äúexternal‚Äù smash products of
prespectra; see [106, 4.1]. Here ‚Äúexternal‚Äù is understood in the sense of indexing on
pairs of representations. Therefore, on the equivariant parametrized prespectrum
level, when we write X ‚äºY for prespectra X over A and Y over B, we should
understand the external external smash product, in the sense of Remark 11.1.7.
When passing from prespectrum level arguments to spectrum level conclusions using
(P, U), we are implicitly using composites of the general form PV U, and similarly
for functors of several variables involving smash products. We can carry out the
several variable arguments externally on the prespectrum level, only internalizing
with left Kan extension after passage to spectra, where we have good homotopical
control by Corollary 12.6.6.
Alternatively, we can make use of classical ‚Äúhandicrafted smash products‚Äù of
prespectra, which are deÔ¨Åned by use of arbitrary choices of sequences of representa-
tions. As discussed on the nonequivariant nonparametrized level in [106, ¬ß11], hand-
icrafted smash products of prespectra agree under the adjoint equivalence (P, U)
with the internalized smash products. Provided that we use external parametrized
handicrafted smash products over varying base spaces, only internalizing along
diagonal maps at the end, the discussion there adapts readily to give the same con-
clusion for homotopy categories of equivariant parametrized prespectra and spectra.
The advantage of handicrafted smash products is that their deÔ¨Ånition involves only
direct use of ex-space level constructions that enjoy good preservation properties
with respect to ex-Ô¨Åbrations. This often allows direct transposition of ex-space level
arguments in hGWB to parametrized prespectrum level arguments in hGEB.

For emphasis, we repeat a remark that we made after the analogous ex-space
level result. This innocent looking result packages highly non-trivial and important
information. In particular, it gives that FB(X, Y )b ‚âÉF(Xb, Yb) in Ho GbS for
X, Y ‚ààHo GSB, where the Ô¨Åber and function object functors are understood in
the derived sense. This reassuring consistency result is central to our applications
in Part IV, where parametrized duality is studied Ô¨Åberwise.


CHAPTER 14
Module categories, change of universe, and change
of groups
Introduction
We Ô¨Årst give a discussion of module categories of parametrized spectra over
nonparametrized ring spectra. One motivation is to set up the homotopical foun-
dations for studying the special properties of generalized homology and cohomology
theories on parametrized spectra that are represented by such nonparametrized ring
spectra. The good behavior of the external smash product GS √ó GSB ‚àí‚ÜíGSB
makes it easy to do this. While the mathematics here is evident, it deserves em-
phasis since the ideas are likely to have future applications.
In the rest of the chapter, we focus on problems that are special to the equi-
variant context. We give the parametrized generalization of some of the work in
[105] concerning change of universe, change of groups, and Ô¨Åxed point and orbit
spectra. As usual, an essential point is to determine which of the standard adjunc-
tions are given by Quillen adjoint pairs and to prove that other adjunctions and
compatibilities that are evident on the point set level also descend to homotopy
categories.
We discuss change of universe in ¬ß14.2. Here the use of prespectra indexed on
coÔ¨Ånal sequences in the previous chapter introduces some minor diÔ¨Éculties that
were not studied in the nonparametrized theory of [105, V¬ß1] and are already rel-
evant nonequivariantly. We study subgroups and Ô¨Åxed point spectra in ¬ß14.3. We
study quotient groups and orbit spectra in ¬ß14.4. Aside from some analogues for
parametrized spectra of earlier results for parametrized spaces, these sections are
precisely parallel to [105, V¬ß¬ß2 and 3]. We have not written down the parametrized
analogue of [105, V¬ß4], which gives the theory of geometric Ô¨Åxed point spectra,
since it would be tedious to repeat the constructions given there. It will be appar-
ent to the interested reader that, mutatis mutandis, the deÔ¨Ånitions and results in
[105, V¬ß4] generalize directly to the parametrized context.
14.1. Parametrized module G-spectra
We can deÔ¨Åne a parametrized (strict) ring G-spectrum R over B to be a monoid
in the symmetric monoidal category GSB, and we can then deÔ¨Åne parametrized
R-modules and R-algebras in the usual way, as has become standard in stable
homotopy theory [61, 77, 105, 106]. However, even though the smash product ‚àßB
in GSB gives a point-set level symmetric monoidal structure, we cannot expect to
obtain Quillen model structures on the categories of such R-modules or R-algebras,
as was done for orthogonal G-spectra in [105, III¬ß¬ß7,8]. To do that, we would need
better homotopical behavior than we can prove here. We have only set up adequate
foundations for the classical style theory of up to homotopy parametrized module
215

216
14. MODULE CATEGORIES, CHANGE OF UNIVERSE, AND CHANGE OF GROUPS
spectra over up to homotopy parametrized ring spectra. From that point of view,
our homotopical foundations are entirely satisfactory. The source of the problem is
Warning 6.1.7, which implies that X ‚àßB (‚àí) in GSB cannot be a Quillen functor.
However, in applications, it is natural to start with a nonparametrized orthog-
onal ring G-spectrum R. We are then interested in understanding the R-homology
and R-cohomology theories of G-spectra over B and their relationships with the
R-homology and R-cohomology of the Ô¨Åbers. For this study, just as in the non-
parametrized work of [61,77,105,106], one is interested in the theory of R-modules.
The external smash product ‚äº: GS √ó GSB ‚àí‚ÜíGSB has enough of the good
properties of the nonparametrized smash product GS √ó GS ‚àí‚ÜíGS to give us
homotopical control over parametrized module spectra over nonparametrized ring
spectra. We devote this section to developing the relevant theory, which is parallel
to [105, III¬ß7]. Let R be a ring spectrum in GS which is well-grounded when viewed
as a spectrum, meaning that each R(V ) is well-based and compactly generated.
Definition 14.1.1. A (left) R-module over B is a G-spectrum M over B to-
gether with a left action R ‚äºM ‚àí‚ÜíM satisfying the usual associativity and unit
conditions. The category GRMB of left R-modules over B consists of the G-spectra
M over B and the maps of G-spectra over B that preserve the action by R.
Since (R ‚äºX)b = R ‚àßXb, a parametrized R-module over B is precisely that:
each Xb is an R-module Gb-spectrum.
More formally, we have the G-category
(RMG,B, GRMB), as discussed in ¬ß1.4 and ¬ß10.2, and the following result is clear.
Proposition 14.1.2. The G-category (RMG,B, GRMB) is G-topologically bi-
complete in the sense of DeÔ¨Ånition 10.2.1.
All of the required limits, colimits,
tensors, and cotensors are constructed in the underlying G-category (SG,B, GSB)
and then given induced R-module structures in the evident way. A cyl-coÔ¨Åbration
of R-modules is a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration of underlying G-spectra over B.
The last statement holds by the retract of mapping cylinders characterization of
cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations. This immediately implies that GRMB inherits a ground structure
from GSB, in the sense of DeÔ¨Ånition 5.3.2. Recall that the well-grounded G-spectra
over B are those that are level well-grounded (well-sectioned and compactly gener-
ated) and that the g-coÔ¨Åbrations of G-spectra over B are the level h-coÔ¨Åbrations;
see DeÔ¨Ånition 12.1.2 and Proposition 12.1.4.
Definition 14.1.3. An R-module over B is well-grounded if its underlying G-
spectrum over B is well-grounded. A map of R-modules over B is a g-coÔ¨Åbration,
level q-equivalence, or s-equivalence if its underlying map of G-spectra over B is
such a map.
Also recall the notion of a subcategory of well-grounded weak equivalences
from DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1.
Since colimits and tensors for R-modules are deÔ¨Åned in
terms of the underlying G-spectra over B, the following theorem is immediate from
its counterpart for G-spectra over B, which is given by Proposition 12.1.4 and
Theorem 12.4.3.
Theorem 14.1.4. DeÔ¨Ånition 14.1.3 speciÔ¨Åes a ground structure on GRMB
such that the level q-equivalences and the s-equivalences both give subcategories of
well-grounded weak equivalences.

14.1. PARAMETRIZED MODULE G-SPECTRA
217
Finally, recall the deÔ¨Ånition of a well-grounded model structure from DeÔ¨Åni-
tion 5.5.4. Such model structures are compactly generated, and we must deÔ¨Åne the
generators of GRMB. The free R-module functor FR = R ‚äº‚àí: GSB ‚àí‚ÜíGRMB
is left adjoint to the forgetful functor U: GRMB ‚àí‚ÜíGSB. Adjunction arguments
from the deÔ¨Ånitions show that FR preserves cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations and cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations.

(i) a level qf-Ô¨Åbration or an s-Ô¨Åbration if it is one in GSB,
(ii) an s-coÔ¨Åbration if it satisÔ¨Åes the LLP with respect to the level acyclic qf-
Ô¨Åbrations,
Theorem 14.1.6. The category GRMB is a well-grounded model category with
respect to the level q-equivalences, the level qf-Ô¨Åbrations, and the s-coÔ¨Åbrations.
The sets FRFIf
B and FRFJf
B give the generating s-coÔ¨Åbrations and generating level
acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbrations. All s-coÔ¨Åbrations of R-modules over B are s-coÔ¨Åbrations of
G-spectra over B.
We omit the proof since it is virtually the same as the proof of the following
theorem, which gives the starting point for serious work on the homology and
cohomology theory of parametrized G-spectra.
Theorem 14.1.7. The category GRMB is a well-grounded model category with
respect to the s-equivalences, the s-Ô¨Åbrations, and the s-coÔ¨Åbrations; FRFKf
B gives
the generating acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbrations.
Proof. The compatibility condition in Theorem 5.5.1 is automatic by adjunc-
tion from the parametrized spectrum level, and we have already observed that the
free R-module functor FR preserves cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations. It also preserves the relevant
‚ñ°-products, and FRFV K = (R‚àßFV S0)‚äºK is well-grounded if K is a well-grounded
ex-space. Only the acyclicity condition remains. If R is s-coÔ¨Åbrant as a ring spec-
trum, then R is also s-coÔ¨Åbrant as a spectrum, by [105, III.7.6(iv) and (v)]. In that
case, the functor R ‚äº(‚àí) = UFR is a Quillen left adjoint by Corollary 12.6.6 and
therefore preserves level acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbrations. It follows that the maps in FRKf
B
are s-equivalences. The case of a general well-grounded R reduces to the coÔ¨Åbrant
case by use of the next result; compare Proposition 14.1.9 below.
‚ñ°
Proposition 14.1.8. The following statements hold.
(i) For an s-coÔ¨Åbrant spectrum X over B, the functor ‚àí‚äºX : GS ‚àí‚ÜíGSB
preserves s-equivalences between well-grounded spectra in GS .
(ii) If Y is well-grounded in GS , j : A ‚àí‚ÜíX is an acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbration in GSB,
and A is well-grounded, then Y ‚äºj : Y ‚äºA ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚äºX is an s-equivalence.
Proof. Let œÜ: Y ‚àí‚ÜíZ be an s-equivalence between well-grounded spectra.
By parts (ii)‚Äì(iv) of DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1, it suÔ¨Éces to show that œÜ ‚äºFV K is an s-
equivalence if K is the source or target of a map in If
B. This map is isomorphic to
the map (œÜ‚àßFV S0)‚àßB K, where FV S0 is the shift desuspension in GS , not GSB.
Here œÜ ‚àßFV S0 is an s-equivalence by the nonparametrized analogue [105, III.7.3],
and the conclusion follows from Lemma 12.5.3. (The comment on the notations ‚äº
and ‚àßB above DeÔ¨Ånition 12.5.1 is relevant: the former is an external smash product
and the latter is a tensor).

218
14. MODULE CATEGORIES, CHANGE OF UNIVERSE, AND CHANGE OF GROUPS
For (ii), we apply an argument from [106, 12.5]. We let Z = X/BA, which
is s-coÔ¨Åbrant, and we let QY ‚àí‚ÜíY be an s-coÔ¨Åbrant approximation. Since j is
an s-coÔ¨Åbration, it is a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration and Cj is homotopy equivalent to Z. Since
A is well-grounded, we can apply the long exact sequence of homotopy groups of
Theorem 12.4.2 to conclude that Z is s-acyclic. The map Z ‚àí‚Üí‚àóB is then an
s-equivalence between s-coÔ¨Åbrant spectra over B. Since QY ‚äº‚àíis a Quillen left
adjoint, by Proposition 12.2.3, QY ‚äºZ ‚àí‚ÜíQY ‚äº‚àóB ‚àº= ‚àóB is an s-equivalence. Since
QY ‚äºZ ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚äºZ is an s-equivalence by part (i), Y ‚äºZ is s-acyclic. Since the
functor Y ‚äº‚àípreserves coÔ¨Åber sequences, another application of Theorem 12.4.2
shows that Y ‚äºj is an s-equivalence.
‚ñ°
Proposition 14.1.9. If œÜ: Q ‚àí‚ÜíR is an s-equivalence of well-grounded ring
spectra, then the functors
œÜ‚àó= R ‚àßQ (‚àí): GQMB ‚àí‚ÜíGRMB and œÜ‚àó: GRMB ‚àí‚ÜíGQMB
given by extension of scalars and restriction of action deÔ¨Åne a Quillen equivalence
(œÜ‚àó, œÜ‚àó) between the categories of Q-modules and of R-modules over B.
Proof. Since s-Ô¨Åbrations and s-equivalences are created in the underlying
category of spectra over B, it is clear that they are preserved by œÜ‚àó, so that we
have a Quillen pair. If M is an s-coÔ¨Åbrant Q-module, then, by the previous result,
the unit map œÜ ‚àßid: M ‚àº= Q ‚àßQ M ‚àí‚ÜíœÜ‚àó(R ‚àßQ M) of the adjunction is an s-
equivalence of spectra over B. Therefore, if N is an s-Ô¨Åbrant R-module, then a
map M ‚àí‚ÜíœÜ‚àóN of Q-modules is an s-equivalence if and only if its adjoint map
R ‚àßQ M ‚àí‚ÜíN of R-modules is an s-equivalence.
‚ñ°
Implicitly, we have been studying modules over the sphere spectrum S in earlier
chapters, and we can redo all of our model theoretic work with S replaced by R.
The results of ¬ß12.6 and ¬ß13.1 carry over directly. For f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB, base change
preserves R-modules, (f!, f ‚àó) gives a Quillen adjoint pair relating the categories of
R-modules over A and over B, and we obtain a Quillen equivalence if f is a q-
equivalence. If f is a bundle with cellular Ô¨Åbres, we obtain a Quillen pair (f ‚àó, f‚àó),
and we can apply the triangulated category version of Brown representability to
construct a right adjoint f‚àóin general.
However, we do not know how to generalize the rest of Chapter 13 to the
module context since we have not worked out a theory of excellent R-modules with
an accompanying excellent R-module approximation functor. In view of the retreat
to prespectra with their primitive handicrafted smash products in that theory, it
seems unlikely to us that any such construction can be expected.
We also have the notion of a right R-module over a nonparametrized ring
spectrum R. If M and N are right and left R-modules over A and B and L is a left
R-module over A √ó B, then we deÔ¨Åne spectra M ‚äºR N over A √ó B and ¬ØFR(N, L)
over A by the usual coequalizer
M ‚äºR ‚äºN
// M ‚äºN
/ M ‚äºR N
and equalizer
¬ØFR(N, L)
/ ¬ØF(N, L)
// ¬ØF(R ‚äºN, L).
If R is commmutative, then M ‚àßR N and FR(N, L) are naturally R-modules.
We have good homotopical control over these external constructions, as in
Propositions 12.2.3 and 12.6.5. For example, if we take A = ‚àó, then we have good

14.2. CHANGE OF UNIVERSE
219
homotopical control over the smash product spectrum M ‚àßR N over B and the
non-parametrized function spectrum FR(N, L), where M is a non-parametrized
right R-module and N and L are left R-modules over B.
However, if we take
A = B and internalize M ‚äºR N along the diagonal ‚àÜ: B ‚àí‚ÜíB √ó B by setting
M ‚àßRN = ‚àÜ‚àóM ‚äºRN and FR(M, N) = ¬ØFR(M, ‚àÜ‚àóN), we lose homotopical control.
Similarly, when R is commutative, RMB has the structure of a closed sym-
metric monoidal category, and that allows us to deÔ¨Åne (commutative) R-algebras
over B to be (commutative) monoids in RMB. However, because of the lack of
homotopical control, in the absence of the theory of Chapter 13, we cannot give the
categories of R-algebras and of commutative R-algebras over B model structures.
Remark 14.1.10. There are interesting examples of rings and modules that
allow varying base spaces and are deÔ¨Åned in terms of the external smash product.
We shall work out one rather surprising way of realizing this idea in Chapter 23,
but it seems likely that there are others.
For example, one might consider G-
spectra Rn over Bn with products Rm ‚äºRn ‚àí‚ÜíRm+n, or one might consider
‚Äúglobally deÔ¨Åned‚Äù parametrized ring spectra R consisting of spectra RB over B for
all B together with appropriate products RA ‚äºRB ‚àí‚ÜíRA√óB. The RB would in
particular be module spectra over the nonparametrized ring spectrum R‚àó. As in
the nonparametrized theory, one must use the positive stable model structures to
study such ring objects model theoretically when R‚àóis commutative. The essential
point is that the external smash product is suÔ¨Éciently well-behaved homotopically
that there is no obstacle to passage from point-set level constructions to homotopy
category level conclusions.
14.2. Change of universe
Recall that G-spectra over B are deÔ¨Åned in terms of a chosen collection V of
representations of G. As usual in equivariant stable homotopy theory, we must
introduce functors that allow us to change the collection V .
Such functors are
usually referred to as ‚Äúchange of universe‚Äù functors, since V is often given as the
collection V (U) of all representations that embed up to isomorphism in a given
G-universe U. However, it is often convenient to restrict V to be a coÔ¨Ånal subcol-
lection of V (U) that is closed under direct sums, and when we dealt with excellent
prespectra it became essential to restrict V further to a countable coÔ¨Ånal sequence
of expanding representations in U. In both cases, it is usual to insist that the trivial
representation R be included in V . Observe that such change of universe functors
are already essential nonequivariantly. In order to deal with the change functors
in all of the above cases at once, we adopt a slightly diÔ¨Äerent approach from the
one that was used in [105, V.¬ß1]. We then explain how it specializes to the more
explicit approach given there.
Let GS V
B denote the category of G-spectra over B indexed on V .
If V is
not closed under direct sums, then we are thinking of GS V
B as the restriction of
the diagram category corresponding to GS V ‚Ä≤
B , where V ‚Ä≤ is the closure of V under
sums, as discussed in Remark 13.3.5.
Let i: V ‚äÇV ‚Ä≤ be the inclusion of one collection of representations in another.
Thinking of parametrized spectra as diagram ex-spaces, we see that the evident
forgetful functor
i‚àó: GS V ‚Ä≤ ‚àí‚ÜíGS V

coÔ¨Ånal sequence of representations in some universe U. Recall that J V

In particular, it is homotopy preserving and therefore induces equivalences of the
classical homotopy categories.
Unfortunately, however, the functors IV
V ‚Ä≤ are as
poorly behaved on the homotopy level as they are well behaved on the point set level.
They do not preserve either level q-equivalences or s-equivalences in general, and
the point set level relations above do not descend to the model theoretic homotopy

221
categories that we are interested in. Furthermore, these functors IV
V ‚Ä≤ do not exist if

Returning to our original context, let i: V ‚äÇV ‚Ä≤. The adjoint pair (i‚àó, i‚àó) has
good homotopical properties.
Theorem 14.2.4. Let i: V ‚äÇV ‚Ä≤. Then i‚àópreserves level q-equivalences, level
qf-Ô¨Åbrations, s-Ô¨Åbrations, and s-acyclic s-Ô¨Åbrations. Therefore (i‚àó, i‚àó) is a Quillen
adjoint pair in the level qf-model structure and in the s-model structure. Moreover,
i‚àóon homotopy categories is symmetric monoidal. If V is coÔ¨Ånal in V ‚Ä≤, then i‚àó
creates the weak equivalences and (i‚àó, i‚àó) is a Quillen equivalence.
Proof. It is clear from its levelwise deÔ¨Ånition that i‚àópreserves level q-equi-
valences and level qf-Ô¨Åbrations.
It follows that its left adjoint i‚àópreserves s-
coÔ¨Åbrations and level acyclic s-coÔ¨Åbrations. This in turn implies that i‚àópreserves
s-acyclic s-Ô¨Åbrations, since those are the maps that satisfy the RLP with respect
to the s-coÔ¨Åbrations. The levelwise description of s-Ô¨Åbrations in Proposition 12.5.6
implies that i‚àópreserves s-Ô¨Åbrations. The last statement follows from the deÔ¨Åni-
tion of homotopy groups and the fact that the unit id ‚àí‚Üíi‚àói‚àóis an isomorphism.
The functor i‚àócommutes with ‚äºon the point set level, by [105, I.2.14], and this
commutation relation descends directly to homotopy categories. Applying Propo-
sition 14.2.8 below to the diagonal map of B, it follows that the derived functor i‚àó
is symmetric monoidal.

Lemma 14.2.7. Let i: V ‚äÇV ‚Ä≤ and let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a G-map.

f‚àó, and i‚àócommutes up to natural isomorphism with f! and f‚àó.
Proof. The Ô¨Årst statement is clear from the levelwise constructions of the
base change functors, and the second statement follows by conjugation since i‚àó, f!,
and f ‚àóare left adjoints of i‚àó, f ‚àó, and f‚àó.

14.3. Restriction to subgroups
Let Œ∏: G‚Ä≤ ‚àí‚ÜíG be a homomorphism and let Œ∏‚àóV be the collection of G‚Ä≤-
representations Œ∏‚àóV for V ‚ààV , where V is our chosen collection of indexing G-
representations. We have implicitly used the following result in our earlier results
on change of groups.
Proposition 14.3.1. The functor Œ∏‚àó: GSB ‚àí‚ÜíG‚Ä≤S Œ∏‚àóV
Œ∏‚àóB preserves level q-
equivalences, level qf-Ô¨Åbrations, s-Ô¨Åbrations, and s-equivalences provided that the
model structures are deÔ¨Åned with respect to generating sets CG and CG‚Ä≤ of G-cell
complexes and G‚Ä≤-cell complexes such that Œ∏!C = G √óG‚Ä≤ C ‚ààCG for C ‚ààCG‚Ä≤.
Proof. Since (Œ∏‚àóA)H = AŒ∏‚àó(H) for a G-space A and a subgroup H of G‚Ä≤, this
is clear from the deÔ¨Ånitions of homotopy groups and from the characterizations of
Ô¨Åbrations given in DeÔ¨Ånition 7.2.7 and Proposition 12.5.6. Note in particular that
Œ∏‚àópreserves the level qf-Ô¨Åbrant approximations that are used in the deÔ¨Ånition of
the stable homotopy groups.
‚ñ°

224
14. MODULE CATEGORIES, CHANGE OF UNIVERSE, AND CHANGE OF GROUPS
For the remainder of this section Ô¨Åx a subgroup H of G and consider the
inclusion Œπ: H ‚äÇG.
For an H-space A, we simplify notation by letting HS V
A
denote the category of H-spectra over A indexed on Œπ‚àóV . Clearly, we then have
the restriction of action functor
Œπ‚àó: GS V
B ‚àí‚ÜíHS V
Œπ‚àóB.
For i: V ‚äÇV ‚Ä≤, we have Œπ‚àói‚àó= i‚àóŒπ‚àósince with either composite we are just re-
stricting from the representations in V ‚Ä≤ to the representations in V and viewing all
G-spaces in sight as H-spaces.
When V = V (U) for a G-universe U, there is a quibble here (as was discussed
in [105, V.10]).
We are using Œπ‚àóV as the corresponding indexing collection for
H. However, if V is an irreducible representation of G, Œπ‚àóV is generally not an
irreducible representation of H and we should expand Œπ‚àóV to include all represen-
tations that embed up to isomorphism in Œπ‚àóU to Ô¨Åt the deÔ¨Ånitions into our usual
framework. However, there is a change of universe functor associated to the inclu-
sion i: Œπ‚àóV (U) ‚äÇV (Œπ‚àóU) that Ô¨Åxes this. The functor i‚àópreserves all s-equivalences
and descends to an equivalence on homotopy categories. We can and should use
these rectiÔ¨Åcations when restricting to H-spectra over Œπ‚àóB for a Ô¨Åxed chosen H.
Remark 14.3.2. Consider passage to Ô¨Åbers and recall Proposition 12.6.12.
(i) Applied to inclusions of orbits, Proposition 14.2.8 implies that the functors i‚àó
for i: V ‚äÇV ‚Ä≤ are compatible with passage to Ô¨Åbers, in the sense that

for i: Œπ‚àóV (U) ‚äÇV (Œπ‚àóU). However, these change of universe functors must be
used with caution since they are not compatible as b and therefore Gb vary.
Recall from Propositions 12.6.10 and 13.7.9 that the equivalence of categories

14.4. Normal subgroups and quotient groups
We now turn to quotient homomorphisms and associated orbit and Ô¨Åxed point
functors. The material of this section generalizes a number of results from ¬ß2.4,
¬ß7.3, and ¬ß9.5 to the level of parametrized spectra.
Just as we have been using Œπ generically for inclusions of subgroups, we shall use
Œµ generically for quotient homomorphisms. In particular, for an inclusion Œπ: H ‚äÇG,
we let WH = NH/H, where NH is the normalizer of H in G, and we have the
quotient homomorphism Œµ: NH ‚àí‚ÜíWH. We can study this situation by Ô¨Årst
restricting from G to NH, thus changing the ambient group. Therefore, there is no
loss of generality if we focus attention on a normal subgroup N of G with quotient
group J = G/N, as we do throughout this section.

Part IV
Parametrized duality theory


Introduction
We put the foundations of Part III to work in this part. Unless otherwise stated,
we work in derived homotopy categories, and all functors should be understood in
the derived sense. For example, we have the derived Ô¨Åber functor
(‚àí)b : Ho GSB ‚àí‚ÜíHo GbS .
Since passage to Ô¨Åbers is a Quillen right adjoint, this means that we replace G-
spectra X over B by s-Ô¨Åbrant approximations before taking point-set level Ô¨Åbers.
For emphasis, and to make the notation Xb clear and unambiguous, we may some-
times assume explicitly that X is s-Ô¨Åbrant, but this hypothesis is always implicit. A
map f in Ho GSB is an equivalence if and only if fb is an equivalence for all b ‚ààB,
and that allows us to transfer information back and forth between the parametrized
and nonparametrized homotopy categories with impunity. Here we use the word
‚Äúequivalence‚Äù to mean an isomorphism in Ho GSB, and we use the notation ‚âÉfor
this relation. We reserve the symbol ‚àº= to mean an isomorphism that already holds
on the point set level.
We have proven that the basic structure enjoyed by the category GSB of
parametrized spectra descends coherently to the homotopy category Ho GSB. In
particular, Ho GSB is a closed symmetric monoidal category, and the derived Ô¨Åber
functor is closed symmetric monoidal. In any symmetric monoidal category, we
have standard categorical notions of dualizable and invertible objects. Early work
in parametrized stable homotopy theory of Clapp, Puppe, Becker, and Gottlieb
[9,10,31,32] was aimed at the understanding of Ô¨Åberwise duality, viewed primarily
as a tool for the study of transfer maps in the nonparametrized setting. We rework
and generalize results of this sort in Chapter 15. A particularly interesting new
construction explains precisely how to deÔ¨Åne bundles of spectra rigorously.
Classically, categorical duality in the symmetric monoidal category of spec-
tra gives the deÔ¨Ånitively right context for the study of Spanier-Whitehead duality
and duality between homology and cohomology theories. Categorical duality in
symmetric monoidal categories of parametrized spectra is related Ô¨Åberwise to this
classical duality theory. However, this Ô¨Åberwise duality theory is not the right con-
text for the study of parametrized Spanier-Whitehead duality and duality between
parametrized homology and cohomology theories.
The right duality theory was discovered by Costenoble and Waner [41], and
we therefore call it Costenoble-Waner duality. To place it in context, we proceed
from the general to the particular. We develop categorical duality theory in closed
symmetric bicategories in Chapter 16. This chapter gives category theory that has
applications to many other subjects, and it can be read independently of anything
else in this book.
231

232
INTRODUCTION
We construct a closed symmetric bicategory of parametrized spectra with vary-
ing base spaces in Chapter 17, and we relate duality to base change using ‚Äúbase
change spectra‚Äù in that bicategory. In Chapter 18, we focus on the category of
G-spectra over a Ô¨Åxed B and explain Costenoble-Waner duality. We reiterate how
diÔ¨Äerent this is from Ô¨Åberwise duality. Nonequivariantly, the sphere spectrum over
B, which is invertible and thus Ô¨Åberwise dualizable, can only be Costenoble-Waner
dualizable when B is dualizable, that is, when B is equivalent to a Ô¨Ånite CW com-
plex. Parametrized Ô¨Ånite cell spectra are generally not Ô¨Åberwise dualizable, but
we show that they are Costenoble-Waner dualizable. We also give a self-contained
proof of a parametrized version of Atiyah duality for smooth G-manifolds. This
version implies the classical version since the functor r! from spectra over B to
spectra preserves dualizability.
In Chapter 19, we show how to insert parametrized Costenoble-Waner duality
Ô¨Åberwise into bundles of equivariant spectra. The result gives what we think of as a
Ô¨Åberwise version of Costenoble-Waner duality. The proof of the result is of consid-
erable conceptual interest. We generalize the symmetric bicategory of parametrized
spectra to a symmetric bicategory of parametrized spectra over spaces over a given
base space B. With appropriate equivariance, the bundle construction obtained
from a Ô¨Åxed principal bundle P ‚àí‚ÜíB maps the bicategory of parametrized spec-
tra to this bicategory of parametrized spectra over spaces over B. The construction
preserves dual pairs, and Ô¨Åberwise Costenoble-Waner duality is obtained by start-
ing from dual pairs in the bicategory of spectra, applying the bundle construction
to obtain dual pairs of parametrized spectra over spaces over B, and then applying
base change to obtain dual pairs of spectra over B. Hiding here is the use of a
version of tricategories, but we shall not make that point of view explicit.
We emphasize that Ô¨Åberwise Costenoble-Waner duality, like the earlier results
in this chapter, is of considerable interest nonequivariantly. However, it can also
be thought of as a Ô¨Åberwise generalization of the Wirthm¬®uller isomorphism in non-
parametrized equivariant stable homotopy theory.
In fact, parametrized Atiyah
duality specializes directly to give a generalization of the Wirthm¬®uller isomorphism
from orbits to arbitrary G-manifolds, and the Ô¨Åberwise version specializes directly
to give the Adams isomorphism in equivariant stable homotopy theory.

CHAPTER 15
Fiberwise duality and transfer maps
Introduction
In ¬ß15.1, we prove the Ô¨Åberwise duality theorem, which says that a G-spectrum
X over B is dualizable or invertible if and only if each Ô¨Åber Xb is dualizable or in-
vertible. This allows us to recognize dualizable or invertible G-spectra over B when
we see them, and it gives a powerful tool for using parametrized stable homotopy
theory for studying classical stable homotopy theory.
We recall the deÔ¨Ånition and properties of trace maps in symmetric monoidal
categories in ¬ß15.2, and in ¬ß15.3 we explain how the Ô¨Åberwise duality theorem leads
to a simple conceptual deÔ¨Ånition of transfer maps for Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations.
We
regard a Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration p: E ‚àí‚ÜíB with stably dualizable Ô¨Åbers as a space
over B. We adjoin a copy of B to obtain a section, and we suspend to obtain a
G-spectrum over B. It is dualizable since its Ô¨Åbers are dualizable, hence it has
a transfer map deÔ¨Åned by categorical nonsense. Pushing down to G-spectra by
base change along the map r: B ‚àí‚Üí‚àó, we obtain the transfer map of G-spectra
Œ£‚àûB+ ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£‚àûE+.
This deÔ¨Ånition of transfer maps is a direct generalization of various earlier ones
[9,10,28,31,170], most of which restrict to Ô¨Ånite dimensional base spaces and are
nonequivariant. The properties of the transfer now follow immediately from the gen-
eral properties of trace maps in symmetric monoidal categories. An essential point
is that the homotopy category of G-spectra over B is closed symmetric monoidal
with a ‚Äúcompatible triangulation‚Äù, in the sense speciÔ¨Åed in [124] and recalled later;
see ¬ß¬ß16.6, 16.7, and 17.5. This point implies that our traces and transfers satisfy
additivity relations as well as the more elementary standard properties.
Some of the classical constructions of the transfer work only for bundles, but
have various properties that are inaccessible to the more general construction and
are important in calculations. These transfers also admit a perhaps more satisfying
construction. Rather than relying on duality on the level of parametrized spectra,
they are obtained by inserting duality maps for Ô¨Åbers Ô¨Åberwise into bundles. In the
literature, the construction again usually requires Ô¨Ånite dimensional base spaces
and is nonequivariant.
We give a general conceptual version of this alternative
construction in ¬ß15.6.
As a Ô¨Årst preliminary, in ¬ß15.4 we show how to insert parametrized spectra
Ô¨Åberwise into the standard construction of bundles associated to principal bundles.
The construction on the ex-space level was studied in ¬ß3.3, and we show that the
properties proven there remain true on the spectrum level. The construction is
likely to have many further applications, and it is basic to twisted homology and
cohomology theories. It is of considerable interest nonequivariantly, but we develop
233

234
15. FIBERWISE DUALITY AND TRANSFER MAPS
it the context of equivariant bundles with structure group Œ† and ambient group G
related by an extension 1 ‚àí‚ÜíŒ† ‚àí‚ÜíŒì ‚àí‚ÜíG ‚àí‚Üí1.
As a second preliminary, in ¬ß15.5 we develop the theory of Œ†-free parametrized
Œì-spectra. This is a direct generalization of the nonparametrized theory and is
important in many contexts. In particular, it will play a role in our proof of the
Adams isomorphism in ¬ß19.7.
The application to transfer maps in ¬ß15.6 can be described as follows. It is a
special case of a more general construction that uses the full strength of the bundle
construction functor PF of ¬ß15.4. For the special case, we take F = ‚àóand use
P = P‚àó. To avoid confusion with the general case, we rename the Ô¨Åber M and
assume that it is dualizable. We then have a transfer map œÑ : SŒì ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£‚àû
Œì M+ of
(nonparametrized) Œì-spectra. We insert this into the functor P to obtain a map
PœÑ : PSŒì ‚àí‚ÜíPŒ£‚àû
Œì M+
of G-spectra over B. Again pushing down to a map of G-spectra along r: B ‚àí‚Üí‚àó,
we obtain the transfer G-map Œ£‚àû
G B+ ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£‚àû
G E+.
This description hides a subtlety.
The construction of P involves composi-
tion with a change of universe functor i‚àó. Although i‚àóis not in general symmet-
ric monoidal, it restricts to a symmetric monoidal equivalence between categories
of parametrized Œ†-free Œì-spectra.
This allows us to prove that P is symmetric
monoidal in general. Since transfer maps are natural with respect to symmetric
monoidal functors, this fact makes it transparent that the Ô¨Åberwise transfer map
of a bundle agrees with its transfer map as a Hurewicz Ô¨Åbration.
We assume throughout that all given groups G are compact Lie groups and all
given base G-spaces B are G-CW complexes. This ensures that (r‚àó, r‚àó) is a Quillen
adjunction, r: B ‚àí‚Üí‚àó, but only a few details of proofs would be changed if we
allowed B just to have the homotopy type of a G-CW complex.
15.1. The Ô¨Åberwise duality theorem
We characterize the dualizable and invertible G-spectra over B. A recent expo-
sition of the general theory of duality in closed symmetric monoidal categories ap-
pears in [123], to which we refer the reader for discussion of the relevant categorical
deÔ¨Ånitions and arguments. It is based on the more thorough and topological treat-
ment of [98], which is carried further in [63]. The following theorem is a substantial
generalization of various early results of the same nature about ex-Ô¨Åbrations. Re-
sults of this form were proven, for example, by Becker and Gottlieb [9, ¬ß4], Clapp
[31, 3.5], and Waner [170, 4.6].
Theorem 15.1.1 (The Ô¨Åberwise duality theorem). Let X be an (s-Ô¨Åbrant) G-
spectrum over B. Then X is dualizable (respectively, invertible) if and only if Xb
is dualizable (respectively, invertible) as a Gb-spectrum for each b ‚ààB.
Proof. By deÔ¨Ånition, X is dualizable if and only if the natural map
ŒΩ : DBX ‚àßB X ‚àí‚ÜíFB(X, X)
in Ho GSB is an equivalence, where DBX = FB(X, SB). Passing to (derived) Ô¨Åbers
(DBX)b ‚âÉDXb, this holds if and only if the resulting map
DXb ‚àßXb ‚âÉ(DBX ‚àßB X)b
ŒΩb
/ FB(X, X)b ‚âÉF(Xb, Xb)

15.1. THE FIBERWISE DUALITY THEOREM
235
in Ho GbS is an equivalence for all b ‚ààB. By the categorical coherence observation
Remark 2.2.10, the latter map is the corresponding natural map ŒΩ in Ho GbS .
Again by deÔ¨Ånition, that map is an equivalence if and only if Xb is dualizable.
Similarly, X is invertible if and only if the evaluation map
ev: DBX ‚àßB X ‚àí‚ÜíSB
in Ho GSB is an equivalence. Passing to (derived) Ô¨Åbers, this holds if and only if
the resulting map
DXb ‚àßXb ‚âÉ(DBX ‚àßB X)b
evb / (SB)b ‚âÉS
in Ho GbS is an equivalence for all b ‚ààB. Again by Remark 2.2.10, the latter map
is the evaluation map for Xb in Ho GbS , and that map is an equivalence if and
only if Xb is invertible.
‚ñ°
Therefore, to recognize parametrized dualizable and invertible G-spectra, it
suÔ¨Éces to recognize nonparametrized dualizable and invertible G-spectra. As we
now recall from [63], these are well understood.
Recall that a G-space X is dominated by a G-space Y if X is a retract up
to homotopy of Y , so that the identity map of X is homotopic to a composite
X ‚àí‚ÜíY ‚àí‚ÜíX. If Y has the homotopy type of a G-CW complex, then so does X.
We say that X is Ô¨Ånitely dominated if it is dominated by a Ô¨Ånite G-CW complex.
This does not imply that X has the homotopy type of a Ô¨Ånite G-CW complex, even
when X and all of its Ô¨Åxed point spaces XH are simply connected and therefore,
since they are Ô¨Ånitely dominated, homotopy equivalent to Ô¨Ånite CW complexes.
For example, a G-space X is a G-ENR (Euclidean neighborhood retract) if it
can be embedded as a retract of an open subset of some representation V . Such
open subsets are triangulable as G-CW complexes, so X has the homotopy type of
a G-CW complex. A compact G-ENR is a retract of a Ô¨Ånite G-CW complex and is
thus Ô¨Ånitely dominated, but it need not have the homotopy type of a Ô¨Ånite G-CW
complex.
Non-smooth topological G-manifolds give examples of such non-Ô¨Ånite
compact G-ENRs.
The following result is [63, 2.1].
Theorem 15.1.2. Up to equivalence, the dualizable G-spectra are the G-spectra
of the form Œ£‚àíV Œ£‚àûX where X is a Ô¨Ånitely dominated based G-CW complex and
V is a representation of G.
Definition 15.1.3. A generalized homotopy representation X is a Ô¨Ånitely dom-
inated based G-CW complex such that, for each subgroup H of G, XH is equivalent
to a sphere Sn(H). A stable homotopy representation is a G-spectrum of the form
Œ£‚àíV Œ£‚àûX, where X is a generalized homotopy representation and V is a represen-
tation of G.
The following result is [63, 0.5].
Theorem 15.1.4. Up to equivalence, the invertible G-spectra are the stable
homotopy representations.
Combining results, we obtain the following conclusion about ex-G-Ô¨Åbrations.
Theorem 15.1.5. Let E be an ex-G-Ô¨Åbration over B. If each Ô¨Åber Eb is a
Ô¨Ånitely dominated Gb-space, then Œ£‚àû
B E is a dualizable G-spectrum over B. If each

236
15. FIBERWISE DUALITY AND TRANSFER MAPS
Eb is a generalized homotopy representation of Gb, then Œ£‚àû
B E is an invertible G-
spectrum over B.
Proof. Since the derived suspension spectrum functor commutes with passage
to derived Ô¨Åbers, by Theorem 13.7.10, the derived Ô¨Åber (Œ£‚àû
B E)b is equivalent to
Œ£‚àûEb. The conclusion follows from Theorems 15.1.1, 15.1.2, and 15.1.4.
‚ñ°
In particular, sphere G-bundles and, more generally, spherical G-Ô¨Åbrations over
B, have invertible suspension G-spectra over B.
15.2. Duality and trace maps in symmetric monoidal categories
Since the stable homotopy category Ho GSB is closed symmetric monoidal, we
have the following generalized trace maps at our disposal. We state the deÔ¨Åni-
tion and recall its properties in full generality in this section, and we specialize to
show how it gives a simple conceptual deÔ¨Ånition of the transfer maps associated to
equivariant Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations in the next.
Definition 15.2.1. Let C be any closed symmetric monoidal category with
unit object S. For a dualizable object X of C with a ‚Äúcoaction‚Äù map ‚àÜX : X ‚àí‚Üí
X ‚àßCX for some object CX ‚ààC , deÔ¨Åne the trace œÑ(f) of a self map f of X by the
diagram

Remark 15.2.2. Such a categorical description of generalized trace maps was
Ô¨Årst given by Dold and Puppe [51], where they showed that it gives the right
framework for trace maps in algebra, the transfer maps of Becker and Gottlieb
[9,10], and the Ô¨Åxed point theory of Dold [50]. These early constructions of transfer
maps had Ô¨Åniteness conditions that were Ô¨Årst eliminated by Clapp [31,32]. Indeed,
she gave an early construction of a parametrized stable homotopy category and
proved a precursor of our Ô¨Åberwise duality theorem. The equivariant analogue of
the attractive space level treatment of Spanier-Whitehead duality given by Dold
and Puppe was worked out in [98], and a recent categorical exposition of duality
has been given in [123].
Two cases are of particular interest. The Ô¨Årst is when CX = S and ‚àÜX is the
unit isomorphism. Then œÑ(f) is called the Lefschetz constant of f and is denoted
by œá(f); in the special case when f = id it is called the Euler characteristic of X
and denoted by œá(X). The second is when CX = X. We then think of ‚àÜX as a
diagonal map, and œÑX = œÑ(id) is called the transfer map of X.
Remark 15.2.3. If CX comes with a ‚Äúcounit‚Äù map Œæ : CX ‚àí‚ÜíS such that the
composite

is the identity, then œá(f) = Œæ ‚ó¶œÑ(f) by a little diagram chase. The reason for
the terminology ‚Äúcoaction‚Äù and ‚Äúcounit‚Äù for the maps ‚àÜX and Œæ is that in many
situations CX is a comonoid and ‚àÜX is a coaction of CX on X.

where CF X = FCX and ‚àÜF X = F‚àÜX.
(ii) (Unit property) If f is a self map of the unit object, then œá(f) = f.
(iii) (Fixed point property) If (f, Œ±) is a self map of (X, ‚àÜX), then
Œ± ‚ó¶œÑ(f) = œÑ(f).

œÑ(f ‚àßg) = œÑ(f) ‚àßœÑ(g),
where ‚àÜX‚àßY = (id ‚àßŒ≥ ‚àßid) ‚ó¶(‚àÜX ‚àß‚àÜY ) with Œ≥ the transposition.

œÑ(Œ£f) = ‚àíœÑ(f)
for all self maps f, where ‚àÜŒ£X = Œ£‚àÜX.

The additivity of traces was studied in [98, III¬ß7] in the equivariant stable homotopy
category, but the proof there is incorrect. A thorough investigation of precisely what
is needed to prove the additivity of traces is given in [124], where the axioms for
a ‚Äúcompatible triangulation‚Äù are formulated. These axioms hold in all situations
previously encountered in algebraic topology and algebraic geometry. Although the
veriÔ¨Åcation is a little more subtle, they also hold here. Since it would be digressive
at this point, we defer discussion of triangulated categories and the proof of the
following theorem to ¬ß¬ß16.6, 16.7, and 17.5.
Theorem 15.2.6. The category Ho GSB is a closed symmetric monoidal cat-
egory with a compatible triangulation.
15.3. Transfer maps of Hurewicz Ô¨Åbrations
With these foundations in place, we can now generalize the classical construc-
tion of transfer maps. The results above specialize to give more information about
them than is to be found in the literature. If X is a dualizable G-spectrum over
B with a diagonal map ‚àÜX : X ‚àí‚ÜíX ‚àßB X, then we have the transfer map
œÑX : SB ‚àí‚ÜíX.
We shall apply this to suspension G-spectra associated to G-
Ô¨Åbrations p: E ‚àí‚ÜíB, but we do not assume that p has a section. Recall that
(E, p)+ denotes (E, p) with a disjoint section, and observe that (E, p)+ is an ex-G-
Ô¨Åbration if p is a Hurewicz G-Ô¨Åbration.
Recall the desription of the base change functors associated to r: B ‚àí‚Üí‚àó
from Example 2.1.8. As we have said before, the spectrum level versions of these
functors are central to the deduction of results in classical stable homotopy theory
from results in parametrized stable homotopy theory. Many such deductions start
from the following observation.

15.4. The bundle construction on parametrized spectra
The construction of the transfer in the previous section works ‚Äúglobally‚Äù, start-
ing on the parametrized spectrum level. We now give a Ô¨Åberwise construction of
‚Äústable bundles‚Äù that leads to an alternative Ô¨Åberwise perspective. However, it is
natural to work in greater generality than is needed for the construction of the
transfer. The extra generality will be needed in Chapter 19 and later. The relevant
bundle theoretic background was recalled in ¬ß3.2 and the basic properties of the
point-set level bundle construction were developed in ¬ß3.3.
Let Œ† be a normal subgroup of a compact Lie group Œì such that Œì/Œ† = G and
let q: Œì ‚àí‚ÜíG be the quotient homomorphism. Let p: E ‚àí‚ÜíB be a (Œ†; Œì)-bundle
with Ô¨Åber a Œì-space F and with associated principal (Œ†; Œì)-bundle œÄ: P ‚àí‚ÜíB.
Then P is a Œ†-free Œì-space, œÄ is the quotient map to the orbit G-space B = P/Œ†,
and p is the associated G-bundle E ‚àº= P √óŒ† F ‚àí‚ÜíB. To simplify the homotopical
analysis, we assume for the rest of this section that F and P are Œì-CW complexes
such that P is Œ†-free. We let E = P √óŒ† F and B = P √óŒ† ‚àó. Note that B is a
G-CW complex. We are thinking of the cases when F is a point or when F is a
smooth Œì-manifold.
Recall the bundle construction of ¬ß3.3:
PF = P √óŒ† (‚àí): ŒìKF ‚àí‚ÜíGKE.
We can extend the functor PF from ex-spaces to ex-spectra. Change of universe
must enter since Œì-spectra are indexed on representations of Œì and G-spectra are
indexed on representations of G. We view representations of G as Œ†-trivial repre-
sentations of Œì. This gives i: q‚àóVG ‚àí‚ÜíVŒì. It is important to keep track of which
universe we are working in, and we introduce the following notations.
Notation 15.4.1. DeÔ¨Åne PF = PF ‚ó¶i‚àó: ŒìSF ‚àí‚ÜíGSB, where
i‚àó: ŒìSF = ŒìS VŒì

Therefore, for a Œì-spectrum X over F, the ex-G-spaces PF X(V ) over E inherit
structure maps from X, so that PF X is a well-deÔ¨Åned G-spectrum over E and the
functor PF makes sense.
Except where explicitly indicated otherwise, we index both G-spectra and Œì-
spectra on VG for the rest of this section, working with PF . We return to PF in
the following sections. In fact, the functors PF and PF are of independent interest.
The latter is essential in this chapter and in Chapter 19. However, only the former
will be relevant for the study of twisted homology, and, when indexing on Œ†-trivial
representations, there is no need to restrict Œ† and Œì to be compact Lie groups. The
case Œì = Œ† √ó G, with G but not necessarily Œ† a compact Lie group is of particular
interest.
The functor PF is exceptionally well-behaved, as the following result shows.

to prove the analogue for PF . Recall the factorization ‚àÜE = ŒπE ‚ó¶Œ¥E of (3.3.3).

Proof. On the point-set level, these isomorphisms follow levelwise from Propo-

posites of left Quillen adjoints, the second is between composites of right Quillen

15.5. Œ†-free parametrized Œì-spectra
We retain the notations of the previous section in this section and the next.
In the next section, we show that the bundle construction on parametrized spectra
leads to a Ô¨Åberwise generalization of the restriction to bundles of the trace and
transfer maps for Ô¨Åbrations that we described in ¬ß15.2. The deÔ¨Ånition depends on
a result that is proven by use of the theory of Œ†-free Œì-spectra that we present here.
We Ô¨Årst recall what it means to say that a Œì-spectrum X (indexed on any
universe) is Œ†-free.
Let F(Œ†; Œì) be the family of subgroups Œõ of Œì such that

15.5. Œ†-FREE PARAMETRIZED Œì-SPECTRA
243
Œõ ‚à©Œ† = e.
A Œì-CW complex T is Œ†-free if and only if the only orbit types
Œì/Œõ that appear in its construction have Œõ ‚ààF(Œ†; Œì). We then say that T is
an F(Œ†; Œì)-CW complex. We can make the same deÔ¨Ånitions for Œì-CW spectra,
and in general we say that a Œì-spectrum is Œ†-free if it is isomorphic in Ho ŒìS to
an F(Œ†; Œì)-CW spectrum. There is a more conceptual homotopical reformulation
that is the one relevant to the parametrized point of view and that does not depend
on the theory of Œì-CW spectra.
Let E(Œ†; Œì) be the universal Œ†-free Œì-space, so that E(Œ†; Œì)Œõ is contractible
if Œõ ‚à©Œ† = e and is empty otherwise. We may take E(Œ†; Œì) to be an F(Œ†; Œì)-CW
complex. Let B(Œ†; Œì) = E(Œ†; Œì)/Œ† and observe that B is a G-CW complex and
therefore also a Œì-CW complex. We note parenthetically that the quotient map
p : E(Œ†; Œì) ‚àí‚ÜíB(Œ†; Œì) is the universal principal (Œ†; Œì)-bundle. That is, pullback
along p gives a bijection
[X, B(Œ†; Œì)]G ‚àí‚ÜíB(Œ†; Œì)(X),
where B(Œ†; Œì)(X) denotes the set of equivalence classes of principal (Œ†; Œì)-bundles
over the G-space X; see [92] or [118, VII¬ß2].
Definition 15.5.1. Let r: E(Œ†; Œì) ‚àí‚Üí‚àóbe the projection and let œÉ be the
counit of the (derived) adjunction (r!, r‚àó). A Œì-spectrum X is said to be Œ†-free if
œÉ: r!r‚àóX ‚àí‚ÜíX is an equivalence.
The deÔ¨Ånition should seem reasonable since r!r‚àóT ‚àº= E(Œ†; Œì)+ ‚àßT for a Œì-
space T. It is equivalent to the original deÔ¨Ånition in terms of an equivalence in
Ho GS to an F(Œ†; Œì)-CW spectrum; see [98, II.2.12] or [105, VI¬ß4]. This deÔ¨Ånition
generalizes readily to the parametrized context.
Definition 15.5.2. Let œÄ: E(Œ†; Œì) √ó F ‚àí‚ÜíF be the projection and let œÉ be
the counit of the (derived) adjunction (œÄ!, œÄ‚àó). An ex-Œì-space or Œì-spectrum X
over a Œì-space F is said to be Œ†-free if œÉ: œÄ!œÄ‚àóX ‚àí‚ÜíX is an equivalence.
Since the Ô¨Åber (œÄ!œÄ‚àóX)f is E(Œ†; Œì)+ ‚àßXf, the deÔ¨Ånition should seem reason-
able. Since equivalences are detected Ô¨Åberwise, we have the following results.
Lemma 15.5.3. A Œì-spectrum X over F is Œ†-free if and only if each of its Ô¨Åbers
Xf is a (Œ† ‚à©Œìf)-free Œìf-spectrum.
Proof. The Ô¨Åber of E(Œ†; Œì)√óF ‚àí‚ÜíF over f ‚ààF is the Œì-space E(Œ†; Œì) with
the action restricted along Œπ: Œìf ‚àí‚ÜíŒì. It is a model of the universal (Œ† ‚à©Œìf)-free
Œìf-space E(Œ† ‚à©Œìf, Œìf). Applying (‚àí)f to the counit œÄ!œÄ‚àóX ‚àí‚ÜíX and using
Theorem 13.7.7 we obtain the counit r!r‚àóXf ‚àí‚ÜíXf where r: Œπ‚àóE(Œ†; Œì) ‚àí‚Üí‚àó.
‚ñ°
Lemma 15.5.4. If P is a Œ†-free Œì-space and X is any ex-Œì-space or Œì-spectrum
over F, then P √ó X is a Œ†-free ex-Œì-space or Œì-spectrum over P √ó F.
A useful slogan asserts that ‚ÄúŒ†-free Œì-spectra live in the Œ†-trivial universe‚Äù.
To explain it, consider the inclusion i: q‚àóVG ‚àí‚ÜíVŒì of the complete G-universe VG
as the universe of Œ†-trivial representations in the complete Œì-universe VŒì. Then
the slogan is given meaning by the following result. In the nonparametrized case
F = ‚àó, it is proven in [98, II¬ß2] and is discussed further in [105, VI¬ß4]. Since the
parametrized case presents no complications and the proof is quite easy, we only
give a sketch.

Proposition 15.5.5. The change of universe adjunction (i‚àó, i‚àó) descends to
a symmetric monoidal equivalence between the homotopy categories of Œ†-free Œì-

VŒì, there is a natural equivalence i‚àó(E(Œ†; Œì)+ ‚àßi‚àóX) ‚âÉX.
Sketch Proof. If Œõ ‚à©Œ† = e, then the quotient map q: Œì ‚àí‚ÜíG maps Œõ
isomorphically onto a subgroup of G. Any representation V of Œõ is therefore of
the form q‚àóW for a representation W of q(Œõ). It follows that the restrictions to
Œõ of the universes VŒì and q‚àóVG have the same representations.
Therefore, on
Œ†-free Œì-spectra over F, the unit and counit of the adjunction (i‚àó, i‚àó) are F(Œ†; Œì)-
equivalences, in the sense that they are Œõ-equivalences for any Œõ in F(Œ†; Œì).
Smashing the unit and counit with E(Œ†; Œì)+, which has trivial Ô¨Åxed point sets
for subgroups not in F(Œ†; Œì), we obtain natural equivalences, and it follows from
DeÔ¨Ånition 15.5.1 that the unit and counit are themselves equivalences when ap-
plied to Œ†-free Œì-spectra. Alternatively, restricting to s-Ô¨Åbrant Œì-spectra over F,
the conclusion follows Ô¨Åberwise from its nonparametrized precursor. Since i‚àóis
symmetric monoidal, by Theorem 14.2.4, so is the equivalence. The last statement
holds since
i‚àó(E(Œ†; Œì)+ ‚àßi‚àóX) ‚âÉE(Œ†; Œì)+ ‚àßi‚àói‚àóX ‚âÉX.

15.6. The Ô¨Åberwise transfer for (Œ†; Œì)-bundles

p: E = P √óŒ† F ‚àí‚ÜíP √óŒ† ‚àó= B.
We have the inclusion i: q‚àóVG ‚àí‚ÜíVŒì of the complete G-universe VG as the universe
of Œ†-trivial representations in the complete Œì-universe VŒì.
The change of universe functor i‚àó: ŒìSF ‚àí‚ÜíŒìS Œ†‚àítriv

These trace maps are maps of G-spectra over E, rather than over B. We can
apply r!, r: E ‚àí‚Üí‚àó, to obtain trace maps of nonparametrized spectra. This kind of
trace map can be viewed as a Ô¨Åberwise generalization of the kind of nonparametrized
trace map that is deÔ¨Åned bundle theoretically in the literature. To connect up with
the latter, we specialize and change our point of view so as to arrive at bundle
theoretic trace maps over B. Specializing further to transfer maps, we obtain the
promised comparison with the transfer maps of DeÔ¨Ånition 15.3.3.
With these goals in mind, we now focus on the case F = ‚àó, so that E above
becomes B, with p the identity map, and our trace maps are parametrized over B.
We study our original Ô¨Åxed given (Œ†; Œì)-bundle p: E ‚àí‚ÜíB in a diÔ¨Äerent fashion.
We rename its Ô¨Åber M to avoid confusion with respect to the role that space is
playing. In the theory above, F was a base space for paramentrized spectra and
there was no need for F to be dualizable. We now consider the case when M is
stably dualizable, so that Œ£‚àûM+ is dualizable, and we write œÑM for the transfer
map S ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£‚àûM+ in ŒìS , as deÔ¨Åned in and after DeÔ¨Ånition 15.2.1. We apply
Theorem 15.6.2 with F = ‚àóand X = Œ£‚àûM+ to obtain the following special case.
