At precisely this point in the cited proof of [124, ¬ß7], where a model for Œæ has
just been obtained, the notation D‚Ä≤X is introduced for F(X, T). We instead deÔ¨Åne
D‚Ä≤(V) = ¬ØF(V, U) for V ‚ààGSB√óB. Now we carry out our diagram chasing exactly
as in [124, ¬ß7], but working in GSB√óB with our new functor D‚Ä≤. After constructing
all of the diagrams of the proof on the point-set level there and passing to homotopy
categories, we apply ‚àÜ‚àó, remembering that it is an exact functor. The diligent
reader will see that the argument then goes through verbatim to give (TC5b).

CHAPTER 18
Costenoble-Waner duality
Introduction
We specialize the theory of duality from Chapters 16 and 17 to the theory
of Costenoble-Waner duality in the category of G-spectra over B in ¬ß18.1. The
similarity with Spanier-Whitehead duality will be evident. The essential point is to
identify dual parametrized spectra in the Costenoble-Waner sense. We show in ¬ß18.2
that retracts of Ô¨Ånite cell spectra over B (in the s-model structure) are dualizable
and that the compact spectra over B are precisely the dualizable spectra over B.
As we shall explain, we do not know how to prove conversely that a dualizable
spectrum is a retract of a Ô¨Ånite cell spectrum.
We also do not have a direct proof that the single-cell spectra over B are
Costenoble-Waner dualizable, which of course is the starting point for the inductive
proof that all Ô¨Ånite cell spectra over B are dualizable.
However, parametrized
Atiyah duality implies that they are. We recall that single-cell spectra arise from
(non-Ô¨Åbrant) sphere spaces over B and that the (invertible) sphere spectrum SB
over B is not among them. For this reason, intuition from the classical case is
misleading. Equivariantly, duality of single-cell spectra is in any case non-trivial
since Atiyah duality specializes to give the dualizability of orbit spectra.
We prove parametrized Atiyah duality for smooth G-manifolds in ¬ß18.6. This
reproves the classical Atiyah duality theorem since the functor r! preserves dual
pairs. In fact, as advertised in Example 0.0.3, we give a relative version that appears
to be new even in the non-parametrized case. It gives an explicit description of the
Spanier-Whitehead dual of M/L, where M is a smooth closed manifold and L is a
smooth closed submanifold. We treat the more usual relative case of manifolds with
boundary in ¬ß18.7. In both versions, Atiyah duality is a special case of a general
space level Costenoble-Waner duality theorem for G-ENR pairs that we explain
in ¬ß18.5 and prove in ¬ß18.8, following Costenoble and Waner [41, 4.2.8].
Their
proof relies for details on the non-parametrized treatment given in [98, III.¬ß4], and
we give a more self-contained account. We begin work in ¬ß18.3 by showing how
to deduce spectrum level Costenoble-Waner duality from space level Costenoble-
Waner duality, and we give preliminaries on relative mapping cones in ¬ß18.4.
Equivariance adds no extra diÔ¨Éculties in this chapter. We assume that a given
compact Lie group G acts on all of our spaces and spectra, and we generally omit
G from the notations except for occasional emphasis.
We assume that all base
G-spaces have the homotopy types of G-CW complexes. Here again, ‚Äúequivalence‚Äù
means isomorphism in the relevant stable homotopy category and is denoted by ‚âÉ.
285

286
18. COSTENOBLE-WANER DUALITY
18.1. The two notions of duality in Ho GSB
In ¬ß15.1 we discussed Ô¨Åberwise duality for parametrized spectra X in Ho GSB
and deÔ¨Åned the Ô¨Åberwise dual of X to be
DBX = FB(X, SB) ‚âÉ¬ØF(X, ‚àÜ‚àóSB).
There is another notion of duality in Ho GSB. Costenoble and Waner discovered
it in [41], and we therefore name it after them. The Costenoble-Waner dual of X
in Ho GSB is
DCW
B
X = ¬ØF(X, ‚àÜ!SB).
In this section, we describe both notions of duality as special cases of duality in the
bicategory E x of parametrized spectra.
Recall that, by the conventions of Notations 17.4.1, we implicitly view a para-
metrized spectrum X over B as a 1-cell X : B ‚àí‚Üí‚àóin the bicategory E x, writing
tX for the opposite 1-cell tX : ‚àó‚àí‚ÜíB.
Here the spaces ‚àóand B are 0-cells,
but we also write ‚àóand B for the unit 1-cells S in GS = E x(‚àó, ‚àó) and ‚àÜ!SB in
GSB√óB = E x(B, B). We have four duals with respect to these 1-cells. The ones
with respect to ‚àóare
D‚ÑìX = ‚àó‚óÅX : ‚àó‚àí‚ÜíB
and
DrtX = tX ‚ñ∑‚àó: B ‚àí‚Üí‚àó,
and the ones with respect to B are
D‚ÑìtX = B ‚óÅtX : B ‚àí‚Üí‚àó
and
DrX = X ‚ñ∑B : ‚àó‚àí‚ÜíB.
First we consider the duals with respect to ‚àó. We have that tX is right dualiz-
able if and only if X is left dualizable, and tD‚ÑìX ‚âÉDrtX. Therefore, these duals
have the same underlying spectrum over B, which by Proposition 17.1.4 is
FB(X, r‚àóS) ‚âÉFB(X, SB).
Said another way, (tX, Y ) is a dual pair if and only if (tY, X) is a dual pair, and
then the underlying spectrum of Y is equivalent to FB(X, SB). The evaluation and
coevaluation maps of the two pairs correspond under application of the involution
t in our symmetric bicategory. By the following result, this notion of duality in E x
is equivalent to Ô¨Åberwise duality.
Proposition 18.1.1. Let X and Y be spectra over B. Then a pair of maps
Œ∑: ‚àÜ!SB ‚àí‚ÜítX ‚äôY
and
Œµ: Y ‚äôtX ‚àí‚ÜíS,
represent (tX, Y ) as a dual pair if and only if their adjoint maps
¬ØŒ∑: SB ‚àí‚ÜíX ‚àßB Y
and
¬ØŒµ: Y ‚àßB X ‚àí‚ÜíSB,
represent (X, Y ) as a Ô¨Åberwise dual pair.
Proof. The respective adjoints are taken with respect to the adjunctions
(‚àÜ!, ‚àÜ‚àó) and (r!, r‚àó). This makes sense since tX‚äôY = X‚äºY and thus ‚àÜ‚àó(tX‚äôY ) =
X ‚àßB Y and since Y ‚äôtX = r!(Y ‚àßB X) and SB = r‚àóS. Expanding everything out
in terms of external smash products and base change maps associated to r and ‚àÜ,
we Ô¨Ånd by easy but laborious diagram chases that the deÔ¨Åning triangle identities
are equivalent. Alternatively, we can check that Œµ satisÔ¨Åes the condition required
of a coevaluation map if and only if ¬ØŒµ does, and similarly for Œ∑ and ¬ØŒ∑. For the for-
mer, let W be a spectrum over B, let Z be a spectrum, and consider the following
diagram, in which C stands for Ho GS and CB stands for Ho GSB.

We now turn to the duals with respect to B. We have that X is right dualizable
if and only if tX is left dualizable, and D‚ÑìtX ‚âÉtDrX. Therefore, the two duals have
the same underlying spectrum over B which we identify using Proposition 17.1.4.
Definition 18.1.2. Let X be a spectrum over B. DeÔ¨Åne the Costenoble-Waner
dual spectrum of X in Ho GSB to be
DCW
B
X = ¬ØF(X, ‚àÜ!SB).
Viewed in two ways as a 1-cell in E x,
DCW
B
X ‚âÉB ‚óÅtX = D‚ÑìtX : B ‚àí‚Üí‚àó
and
tDCW
B
X ‚âÉX ‚ñ∑B = DrX : ‚àó‚àí‚ÜíB.

18. COSTENOBLE-WANER DUALITY
We say that X is Costenoble-Waner dualizable with dual Y if (X, tY ), or equiv-
alently (Y, tX), is a dual pair in E x, and then the underlying spectrum of Y is
equivalent to DCW
B
X.
Note for consistency with Proposition 17.1.4 that Lemma 2.5.5 gives
œÄ1‚àóFB√óB(œÄ‚àó
2X, ‚àÜ!SB) ‚âÉ¬ØF(X, ‚àÜ!SB) ‚âÉœÄ2‚àóFB√óB(œÄ‚àó
1X, ‚àÜ!SB).
Remark 18.1.3. To reiterate, let us be precise about the specializations of
right and left duality that are visible to us now. For two spectra X and Y over
B to be Costenoble-Waner duals, or equivalently for (X, tY ) to be a dual pair of
1-cells, we must have maps
Œ∑: S ‚àí‚ÜíX ‚äôtY
and
Œµ: tY ‚äôX ‚àí‚Üí‚àÜ!SB
such that the appropriate diagrams commute. However, for two spectra X and Y
to be Ô¨Åberwise duals, or equivalently for (tX, Y ) to be a dual pair of 1-cells, we
must have maps
Œ∑: ‚àÜ!SB ‚àí‚ÜítX ‚äôY
and
Œµ: Y ‚äôtX ‚àí‚ÜíS
such that the appropriate diagrams commute. As we have seen in the case of SB
and tSB, these are wholly diÔ¨Äerent conditions.
Propositions 16.4.6 and 16.4.12 give three ways of thinking about the following
formal consequence of the deÔ¨Ånition.
Proposition 18.1.4. A spectrum X over B is Costenoble-Waner dualizable
with dual Y if and only if Y is Costenoble-Waner dualizable with dual X, and then
DCW
B
DCW
B
X is equivalent to X.
Of course, the analogue for Ô¨Åberwise duality also holds. We record the most
important consequence of Costenoble-Waner duality. In view of Proposition 17.4.2,
it is an immediate reinterpretation of Proposition 16.4.12.
Proposition 18.1.5. If X is a Costenoble-Waner dualizable spectrum over B
and J is any spectrum over B, then
¬µ: r!(J ‚àßB DCW
B
X) ‚âÉJ ‚äôtDCW
B
X ‚àí‚ÜíX ‚ñ∑J ‚âÉr‚àóFB(X, J)
is an equivalence of spectra.
Our general duality theory in E x reduces in the case A = B = ‚àóto Spanier-
Whitehead duality theory in the stable homotopy category HoGS , and Theo-
rem 17.3.3 specializes to give the following result.
Corollary 18.1.6. If the sphere spectrum SB over B is Costenoble-Waner
dualizable, then Œ£‚àûB+ is dualizable in the classical sense.
Proof. As noted in Lemma 15.3.1, r!SB ‚âÉŒ£‚àûB+.
‚ñ°
18.2. Costenoble-Waner dualizability of Ô¨Ånite cell spectra
We explain the proof of the following two results in this section.
Theorem 18.2.1. If a spectrum X over B is a wedge summand in HoGSB of
a Ô¨Ånite cell spectrum, then X is Costenoble-Waner dualizable.
Recall the notion of a compact object in a triangulated category from DeÔ¨Åni-
tion 13.1.8.

18.2. COSTENOBLE-WANER DUALIZABILITY OF FINITE CELL SPECTRA
289
Theorem 18.2.2. A spectrum X over B is compact if and only if it is Coste-
noble-Waner dualizable.
Putting these results together, we obtain the following immediate consequence.
Corollary 18.2.3. A retract of a Ô¨Ånite cell spectrum over B is a compact
object of Ho GSB.
This result may seem obvious at Ô¨Årst sight, but in view of Warning 7.5.16 it
is actually rather surprising. We would not know how to prove it directly, without
use of the theory of dualizable objects. One might ask whether the converse of
Theorem 18.2.1 (or equivalently Corollary 18.2.3) is true, and we will return to
that question after proving the theorems.
It is convenient to use the following
shorthand language.
Definition 18.2.4. An ex-space K over B is said to be Costenoble-Waner
dualizable if Œ£‚àû
B K is Costenoble-Waner dualizable in Ho GSB.
The Ô¨Årst and main step in the proof of Theorem 18.2.1 is a special case of the
parametrized Atiyah duality theorem, which we will explain in a more precise form
than is needed here in ¬ß18.5 below.
Theorem 18.2.5. If M is a smooth compact G-manifold, then the sphere ex-
space S0
M over M is Costenoble-Waner dualizable.
Corollary 18.2.6. For H ‚äÇG and n ‚â•0, S0
G/H√óSn is Costenoble-Waner
dualizable.
To generalize from spheres S0
M to ex-spaces over general base spaces, we use
a quick trick that we learned from Costenoble and Waner [41]. It is based on the
following elementary observation.
Lemma 18.2.7. For a space (K, p) over B, (K, p)+ is isomorphic to p!S0
K.
Proposition 18.2.8. If S0
K is Costenoble-Waner dualizable and (K, p) is a
space over B, then (K, p)+ is Costenoble-Waner dualizable.
Proof. We apply Theorem 17.3.3 with A = ‚àóand f = p.
‚ñ°
Since the domains and targets of our generating s-coÔ¨Åbrations are of the form
(G/H √ó Sn, p)+ and (G/H √ó Dn, p)+, they are Costenoble-Waner dualizable.
Proposition 18.2.9. The coÔ¨Åber of a map of Costenoble-Waner dualizable
spectra over B is Costenoble-Waner dualizable, and a retract of a Costenoble-Waner
dualizable spectrum over B is Costenoble-Waner dualizable.
Proof. This is implied by Proposition 16.8.1, which says that the full subcat-
egory of right dualizable objects in a triangulated symmetric bicategory is thick,
but of course it could also be proven directly by specializing the proof there.
‚ñ°
Applying this to generating coÔ¨Åbrations and then proceeding by induction on
the number of cells, this implies Theorem 18.2.1. Since the compact spectra over B
are the objects of the thick subcategory generated by a subset DB of the collection
of compact single-cell spectra over B, by Lemma 13.1.11 and Theorem 13.1.14,
Theorem 18.2.2 is a special case of the general result Proposition 16.8.3.
That
result gives a further characterization of the thick subcategory of Costenoble-Waner

290
18. COSTENOBLE-WANER DUALITY
dualizable spectra over B as the category of ‚ñ∑-compact spectra over B. Since the
generating set DB consists of single-cell spectra over B, another characterization is
that this is the thick subcategory generated by the Ô¨Ånite cell spectra over B.
Remark 18.2.10. The converse of Theorem 18.2.1 is equivalent to the assertion
that the retracts up to isomorphism of Ô¨Ånite cell spectra over B are themselves the
objects of a thick subcategory of Ho GSB. However, a map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY in Ho GSB
between Ô¨Ånite cell spectra over B can only be realized on the point set level after
Ô¨Åbrant approximation of its target, using [X, Y ] ‚àº= œÄ(X, RY ). While RY is a cell
spectrum over B, it is hardly ever a Ô¨Ånite one, and we see no reason to believe that
the coÔ¨Åber of f is isomorphic in HoGSB to a Ô¨Ånite cell spectrum.
We can see the same problem diÔ¨Äerently by trying to adapt the proof that a
dualizable spectrum is a retract of a Ô¨Ånite CW spectrum, [118, XVI.7.4], to the
parametrized context. Thus suppose that X is Costenoble-Waner dualizable with
right dual Y and coevaluation map Œ∑: S ‚àí‚ÜíX ‚äôY . We may assume that X and
Y are s-Ô¨Åbrant cell spectra over B. We ask whether X is a retract in HoGSB of
a Ô¨Ånite cell spectrum over B. Since X is the colimit of its Ô¨Ånite subcomplexes W
(although these need not be s-Ô¨Åbrant) and S is compact, it might seem clear that
Œ∑ factors through W ‚äôtY for some Ô¨Ånite subcomplex W of X. Assuming that it
does, we have the following commutative diagram whose bottom composite is the
identity map.
W ‚äôtY ‚äôX
id‚äôŒµ /




Œ∑‚äôid /
6n

n

n

X ‚äôtY ‚äôX
id‚äôŒµ / X ‚äôB ‚àº= X.
Therefore X is a retract up to homotopy and thus a wedge summand up to ho-
motopy of W. However, Œ∑ is only given in HoGSB. Its target there is X ‚äôtY =
r!‚àÜ‚àó(X‚äºY ), and this must be understood in the derived sense. Now ‚àÜ‚àóis a Quillen
right adjoint, r! is a Quillen left adjoint, and S is coÔ¨Åbrant, so Œ∑ is represented by
a point-set level map S ‚àí‚ÜíRr!Q‚àÜ‚àóR(X ‚äºY ), where Q and R denote coÔ¨Åbrant
and Ô¨Åbrant approximations (in GSB or GS ). The Ô¨Åbrant approximations throw a
monkey wrench into the proposed use of the compactness of S to prove the desired
factorization.
One interest of this discussion is that we do not yet know the answer to the
following question.
Question 18.2.11. Let M be a smooth G-manifold.
Is SM equivalent in
HoGSM to a retract of a Ô¨Ånite cell spectrum over M?
A general conclusion of this discussion is that, in a compactly generated topo-
logical model category whose objects are not Ô¨Åbrant, one cannot expect to work
with Ô¨Ånite complexes with any degree of facility. The relevant Ô¨Åbrant approxima-
tions are blind to Ô¨Ånite cell structures. We shall discuss other problems of this
nature in Chapter 24.

18.4. Preliminaries on unreduced relative mapping cones
There are several constructions on unsectioned parametrized spaces that nat-
urally give rise to ex-spaces and that we make heavy use of in this chapter. We
collect the main results here, following [51] and [98, III¬ß4] in the nonparametrized
context. Recall from Remark 2.1.9 that we still have base change adjunctions in
this setting. We are interested in the relative theory, and we let GU 2/B denote
the category of pairs (K, L) over B, where L is a closed subspace of a compactly
generated space K. We restrict to U and assume that L is closed in K to avoid
irrelevant point-set pathology and to ensure that the inclusion i: L ‚àí‚ÜíK is an
f-coÔ¨Åbration if and only if it is an ¬Øf-coÔ¨Åbration.
Construction 18.4.1. We describe quotients and coÔ¨Åbers in GU 2/B.

18.4. PRELIMINARIES ON UNREDUCED RELATIVE MAPPING CONES
293
(i) Let K/BL be the Ô¨Åberwise quotient over B. It is constructed as the pushout
in GU /B of the diagram
B
L
o
/ K.
The map from B into the pushout gives a canonical section; explicitly, the
Ô¨Åber over b is the based space Kb/Lb, and the base points give the section.
(ii) Let CB(K, L) be the (unreduced) Ô¨Åberwise coÔ¨Åber of i. It is the Ô¨Åberwise
double mapping cylinder of i and the projection p: L ‚àí‚ÜíB and can be
constructed as the pushout in GU /B of the evident diagram
K ‚®øB
L ‚®øL
o
/ L √ó I.
Equivalently, it is the quotient MB(K, L)/BL of the (unreduced) Ô¨Åberwise
mapping cylinder of i.
The cone points specify a section, allowing us to
regard CB as a functor GU 2/B ‚àí‚ÜíGUB.
(iii) We write CB(K) = CB(K, ‚àÖ). It can be identiÔ¨Åed with (k, p)+, where p is the
projection of K.
Standard arguments, Proposition 8.2.1, and inspection of deÔ¨Ånitions give the
following three results.
Proposition 18.4.2. If i: L ‚àí‚ÜíK is an f-coÔ¨Åbration over B or, equivalently,
(K, L) is an f-NDR pair over B, then the Ô¨Åberwise collapse of CBL is an fp-
equivalence
CB(K, L) ‚àí‚ÜíK/BL
Proposition 18.4.3. The ex-space CB(K, L) is always well-sectioned, and it
is an ex-Ô¨Åbration if both K and L are h-Ô¨Åbrant. If (K, L) is an f-NDR pair, then
K/BL is well-sectioned.
Proposition 18.4.4. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a map of base spaces, let (K, L) be a
pair over A, and let (M, N) be a pair over B. Then
f!CA(K, L) ‚àº= CB(f!K, f!L)
and
f ‚àóCB(M, N) ‚àº= CA(f ‚àóM, f ‚àóN).
We emphasize that, here in the unsectioned context, f!K is just K with pro-
jection fp, where p is the projection of K. Taking f to be the inclusion of a point
b: ‚àó‚àí‚ÜíB, the second part recovers that the Ô¨Åber CB(K, L)b is C(Kb, Lb). If Lb
is empty, this is Kb with a disjoint basepoint.
Proposition 18.4.5 (Excision). Let U ‚äÇL ‚äÇK be spaces over B.
The
inclusion K ‚àíU ‚àí‚ÜíK induces a homeomorphism
(K ‚àíU)/B(L ‚àíU) ‚àí‚ÜíK/BL.
Therefore, if (K ‚àíU, L ‚àíU) and (K, L) are f-NDR pairs, the inclusion induces an
fp-equivalence
CB(K ‚àíU, L ‚àíU) ‚âÉCB(K, L).
Proof. For the Ô¨Årst statement, the displayed quotient map is a continuous
bijection. By examining the relevant subspace and quotient topologies we see that
the map is in fact a homeomorphism.
When we have f-NDR pairs, the Ô¨Åber-
wise coÔ¨Åbers are fp-equivalent to the corresponding Ô¨Åberwise quotients by Propo-
sition 18.4.2.
‚ñ°

there is a natural homeomorphism
K/AL ‚äºM/AN ‚àº= (K √ó M)/A√óB(L √ó M ‚à™K √ó N).
Therefore, if (K, L) and (M, N) are f-NDR pairs over A and B, there is a canonical
fp-equivalence
CA(K, L) ‚äºCB(M, N) ‚âÉCA√óB(K √ó M, L √ó M ‚à™K √ó N).
Proof. The Ô¨Åberwise quotient on the right is the pushout displayed in the
outer rectangle of the diagram

‚ñ°
In view of the previous lemma, the notation
(K, L) √ó (M, N) = (K √ó M, L √ó M ‚à™K √ó N)
is as convenient as it is categorically incorrect. Using this notation, we endow the
categories of parametrized pairs GU 2/(B √ó A) with the horizontal composition
speciÔ¨Åed by
(M, N) ‚äô(K, L) = œÄC√óA!‚àÜ‚àó
B((M, N) √ó (K, L)),
where (K, L) is a pair over B √ó A and (M, N) is a pair over C √ó B. The Ô¨Åberwise
cone construction preserves this composition.
Proposition 18.4.7. For f-NDR pairs (K, L) and (M, N) of G-spaces over
B √ó A and C √ó B, respectively, there is a canonical fp-equivalence
CC√óA ((M, N) ‚äô(K, L)) ‚âÉCC√óB(M, N) ‚äôCB√óA(K, L).
Proof. This follows directly from Propositions 18.4.4 and 18.4.6.
‚ñ°
Proposition 18.4.8. The functor CB : GU 2/B ‚àí‚ÜíGUB preserves q-equi-
valences.
Proof. This is immediate from the gluing lemma and the deÔ¨Ånition of CB as
a double mapping cylinder.
‚ñ°
Of course, pushforward functors f! do not change total spaces in the unsectioned
context, so they also preserve q-equivalences. These facts give the information we
need to pass from the point-set level to the derived homotopy category level in our
use of the functor CB in the arguments to follow.

18.5. V -DUALITY OF G-ENRS
295
18.5. V -duality of G-ENRs
In this section we provide a large class of Costenoble-Waner V -dualizable para-
metrized ex-spaces (K, p)+ over B. By Proposition 18.2.8, if S0
K is Costenoble-
Waner dualizable, then so is p!S0
K ‚âÉ(K, p)+, and we therefore focus on S0
K.
Throughout this section, (K, L) will be a compact G-ENR pair. This means
that (K, L) is an h-NDR pair such that K can be embedded as a G-subspace of a
representation V in such a way that there is a G-retraction q: N ‚àí‚ÜíK of an open
neighborhood N of K in V . We view (N, q) as a space over K; the example to keep
in mind is that of a tubular neighborhood of a G-manifold.
Theorem 18.5.1 (Costenoble-Waner duality theorem). If (K, L) is a compact
G-ENR pair, then the ex-space CK(K, L) over K is Costenoble-Waner V -dualizable
with dual CK(N ‚àíL, N ‚àíK).
The proof will be given in ¬ß18.6. This implies the general result that we are
really after. For the absolute case, recall that (K, p)+ = CB(K, ‚àÖ) ‚â°CB(K).
Theorem 18.5.2. If (K, p) is a G-space over B and (K, L) is a compact G-ENR
pair, then CB(K, L) is Costenoble-Waner V -dualizable with dual CB(N‚àíL, N‚àíK).
In particular, (K, p)+ is V -dual to CB(N, N ‚àíK).
Proof. In the statement, we view N and K as spaces over B with projec-
tions pq and p, which means that we Ô¨Årst consider them as spaces over K with
projections q and idK and then apply p!.
Theorem 18.5.1 gives that CK(K, L)
and CK(N ‚àíL, N ‚àíK) are V -duals over K. Using Proposition 18.4.4, it follows
from Proposition 18.2.8 that p!CK(K, L) ‚àº= CB(K, L) and p!CK(N ‚àíL, N ‚àíK) ‚àº=
CB(N ‚àíL, N ‚àíK) are V -duals over B.
‚ñ°
Remark 18.5.3. In the original nonparametrized version of Dold and Puppe
[51] and its equivariant generalization of [98, III¬ß4], C(N ‚àíL, N ‚àíK) is replaced
by its excisive equivalent C(V ‚àíL, V ‚àíK). However, the parametrization forces
us to focus on N rather than V .
Returning to Theorem 18.5.1, we compare its absolute and relative cases, but
Ô¨Årst we introduce some notation. Let i: L ‚àí‚ÜíK be the inclusion. Since i is an
h-coÔ¨Åbration, we have a neighborhood deformation retraction d: K ‚àí‚ÜíK which
restricts to a retraction j : U ‚àí‚ÜíL deÔ¨Åned on some open neighborhood U of L in
K. Let Œπ: L ‚àí‚ÜíU and Œ∫: U ‚àí‚ÜíK be the inclusions, so that i = Œ∫Œπ and dŒ∫ = ij.
We display these maps in the commutative diagram
(18.5.4)

Since we are working on the space and not the spectrum level in this section,
the desuspension in the following result should be interpreted as appearing after
stabilization. We have written the result in the form most convenient for our later
applications.

(L, i)+ ‚àí‚Üí(K, id)+ ‚àí‚ÜíCK(K, L) ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£K(L, i)+
and
Œ£‚àí1
K CK(N, N ‚àíL) ‚àí‚ÜíCK(N ‚àíL, N ‚àíK) ‚àí‚ÜíCK(N, N ‚àíK) ‚àí‚ÜíCK(N, N ‚àíL)
are V -dual, where i: L ‚àí‚ÜíK is the inclusion.
Proof. The Ô¨Årst coÔ¨Åber sequence is
CK(L) ‚àí‚ÜíCK(K) ‚àí‚ÜíCK(K, L) ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£KCK(L).
We recognize from Theorem 18.5.1 that the second and third terms in the sec-
ond sequence are V -dual to the third and second terms, respectively, in the Ô¨Årst
sequence. Recall the maps displayed in (18.5.4). We deÔ¨Åne
(18.5.6)
NL = j!j‚àói‚àóN = j!Œ∫‚àód‚àóN.
This is a space over L whose projection is a retraction of an open neighborhood of
L in V . In the next section, we will take L to be a closed submanifold of a closed
manifold, and in that context NL will be the normal bundle ŒΩL of L. We have a
canonical inclusion
i!NL = i!j!Œ∫‚àód‚àóN = i!j!j‚àói‚àóN ‚àí‚ÜíN
over K. By excision, Proposition 18.4.5, it induces an equivalence
i!CL(NL, NL ‚àíL) ‚àº= i!CL(j!Œ∫‚àód‚àóN, j!Œ∫‚àód‚àóN ‚àíL) ‚àí‚ÜíCK(N, N ‚àíL).
We conclude that the fourth (and Ô¨Årst) term in the second sequence is V -dual to
the Ô¨Årst (and fourth) term in the Ô¨Årst sequence since CK(L) ‚âÉi!CL(L) and i!
preserves dual pairs. That the maps in the second sequence are the V -duals of the
maps in the Ô¨Årst sequence will follow from Proposition 16.4.7 and the deÔ¨Ånition
of the coevaluation maps ¬ØŒ∑ in (18.8.1). In fact, the direction of argument will be
reversed in the last subsection of ¬ß18.7, where we use this comparison of coÔ¨Åbration
sequences to deduce the relative case of Theorem 18.5.1 from the absolute case.
‚ñ°
18.6. Parametrized Atiyah duality for closed manifolds
The results of the previous section specialize to lift the familiar Atiyah dual-
ity theorem to a statement in the parametrized world. In the absolute case, the
conclusion reads as follows. We remind the reader that everything is equivariant.
Theorem 18.6.1 (Parametrized Atiyah duality theorem). Let M be a smooth
closed manifold embedded in a representation V . Then (SM, SŒΩM ) is a Costenoble-
Waner V -dual pair.
We have two natural relative versions of Theorem 18.6.1. The Ô¨Årst concerns
a closed submanifold L of a smooth closed manifold M. The second concerns a
smooth compact manifold M with non-empty boundary. There presumably is a
more general context giving both of these as special cases, where L is allowed to
be a submanifold of a smooth compact manifold M such that the boundary of L is
the intersection, assumed transverse, of L with the boundary of M. However, we
have not pursued that idea.
We deal with the relative case for closed manifolds in this section. As we have
mentioned, the non-parametrized implication of this relative version does not seem
to appear in the literature. In fact, it is harder to see the non-parametrized version

18.6. PARAMETRIZED ATIYAH DUALITY FOR CLOSED MANIFOLDS
297
directly than to deduce it from the parametrized version. The non-parametrized
implication in the case when M is a manifold with boundary, which we deal with
in the next section, is standard.
Thus, specializing the notations of the previous section, let K = M be a smooth
closed manifold embedded in a representation V and let L be a closed submanifold
of M with inclusion i: L ‚àí‚ÜíM. We take U to be the normal bundle ŒΩM,L of L
embedded as a tubular neighborhood in M, N to be the normal bundle ŒΩM of M
in V , and NL to be the normal bundle ŒΩL = i‚àóŒΩM ‚äïŒΩM,L of L in V . Then (18.5.4)
takes the form
(18.6.2)

Here Œπ is the inclusion of the zero section in ŒΩM,L, Œ∫ is the embedding of ŒΩM,L in
M, and d is a deformation of M that restricts on ŒΩM,L to the projection j of this
relative normal bundle. More explicitly, we may take U to be the open disc bundle
in a larger tubular neighborhood W. Then j is the projection of the disk bundle,
and we can take d to agree with j on U, to be the identity on M ‚àíW, and to send
w to œÜ(|w|)w for |w| ‚â•1 in W, where œÜ is any continuous function on [1, ‚àû) such
that œÜ(1) = 0 and œÜ(t) ‚Üí1 as t ‚Üí‚àû.
As usual, if Œæ is a bundle, we let SŒæ denote the Ô¨Åberwise one-point compactiÔ¨Å-
cation of Œæ with section given by the points at inÔ¨Ånity.
Construction 18.6.3. We construct a map tM : SŒΩM ‚àí‚Üíi!SŒΩL over M which

i!SŒΩM,L is obtained from SŒΩM,L by gluing M ‚àíi(L) to the section. Let ŒΩM,L be the
closure of ŒΩM,L in M. The identity map of ŒΩM,L extends to give a continuous map
ŒΩM,L ‚àí‚ÜíSŒΩM,L over L that sends a point on the boundary to the corresponding
point in the section of SŒΩM,L. Identifying i(L) with the section, this map agrees on
the boundary with the restriction of d to M ‚àíŒΩM,L. These two maps glue together
to give the required map Œ±.

18.7. Parametrized Atiyah duality for manifolds with boundary
We now turn to the case when the smooth manifold M is compact but has a
non-empty boundary ‚àÇM. Let i: ‚àÇM ‚àí‚ÜíM be the inclusion and embed M in a
representation V . We can arrange that V = V ‚Ä≤ ‚äïR and that M embeds in the half
space V ‚Ä≤ √ó [0, ‚àû) in such a way that ‚àÇM embeds in V ‚Ä≤ and M ‚àí‚àÇM embeds in
V ‚Ä≤ √ó (0, ‚àû). The manifold M has a normal bundle ŒΩM which one can think of as
a neighborhood of M in V ‚Ä≤ √ó [0, ‚àû) (but not as a neighborhood of M in all of V ).
Its restriction to ‚àÇM is the normal bundle ŒΩ‚àÇM of ‚àÇM in V ‚Ä≤ (but not in V ). Note
in particular that if ‚àÇM Ã∏= ‚àÖ, then the normal bundle of M cannot be identiÔ¨Åed
with a tubular neighborhood of M (considered as embedded in all of V ). A simple
example to keep in mind is M = {(x, y) ‚ààR2 | x2 + y2 = 1, y ‚â•0}, the upper half
of the unit circle in the plane, with V ‚Ä≤ the x-axis.
Warning 18.7.1. We emphasize the diÔ¨Äerence in the meaning of ŒΩ‚àÇM here and
of ŒΩL in the previous section. In both cases, we have submanifolds, ‚àÇM and L, of a
manifold M embedded in a representation V . In the previous section, ŒΩL referred
to the normal bundle of L in V . In this section, ŒΩ‚àÇM refers to the normal bundle of
‚àÇM in V ‚Ä≤. The relation with ŒΩM is therefore quite diÔ¨Äerent in the two cases. Here
we have that i‚àóSŒΩM ‚àº= SŒΩ‚àÇM and we have an inclusion i!SŒΩ‚àÇM ‚àí‚ÜíSŒΩM , whereas
there we had i‚àóSŒΩM ‚àßL SŒΩM,L ‚àº= SŒΩL and we had a map tM : SŒΩM ‚àí‚Üíi!SŒΩL.
Theorem 18.7.2 (Parametrized Atiyah duality theorem‚Äîboundary version).
Let M be a smooth compact manifold with boundary ‚àÇM. The quotient map

Proof. As we have already remarked, the normal bundle of M cannot be
identiÔ¨Åed with a tubular neighborhood of M in V when ‚àÇM Ã∏= ‚àÖ. We begin by
making the relation precise in a way that will be convenient for the proof of the
theorem. We glue an exterior boundary collar ‚àÇM √ó [‚àí2, 0] to ‚àÇM = M ‚à©(V ‚Ä≤ √ó 0)
to obtain a manifold M2 with boundary ‚àÇM2 embedded in V ‚Ä≤ √ó [‚àí2, ‚àû). We let
M1 = M2‚à©(V ‚Ä≤√ó[‚àí1, ‚àû)), with boundary ‚àÇM1. We sometimes also write (M0, ‚àÇM0)
for (M, ‚àÇM). Let q2 : M2 ‚àí‚ÜíM be the identity on M and retract ‚àÇM √ó [‚àí2, 0]
to ‚àÇM. Let qi : Mi ‚àí‚ÜíM, i = 0 and i = 1 be the restrction of q2 to Mi, so that
q0 = id. Let N be a tubular neighborhood of M2 in V and let œÅ: N ‚àí‚ÜíM2 be
the retraction corresponding to the bundle projection. Let Ni ‚äÇN2, i = 0 and
i = 1, be the restriction of (N, œÅ) to Mi ‚äÇM2. Although N cannot be identiÔ¨Åed
with the normal bundle of M2, we can identify Ni with the normal bundle of Mi,
i = 0 and i = 1, and the restrictions N‚àÇMi to the boundaries can be identiÔ¨Åed with

Recall that N1 is the inverse image of M1 in N and N‚àÇM1 is its restriction to ‚àÇM1.

to the inclusion i!SŒΩ‚àÇM ‚àí‚ÜíSŒΩM .

and the Ô¨Årst horizontal map becomes excision by U = N ‚àí(N‚àÇM1 ‚à™DM2) since
(N ‚àíDM2) ‚àíU = N‚àÇM1 ‚àíD‚àÇM1,
(N ‚àí(D‚àÇM2‚à™M0)) ‚àíU = N‚àÇM1 ‚à™DM√ó(‚àí2,0) ‚âÉN‚àÇM1.
This concludes the proof that (18.7.4) is equivalent to the second displayed coÔ¨Åber
sequence in the statement of the theorem.
‚ñ°
Again, we can apply base change functors p! to these V -dual pairs to obtain
new ones. Taking p = r: M ‚àí‚Üí‚àó, this gives the V -dual pairs (M/‚àÇM, TŒΩM),
(M+, TŒΩM/TŒΩ‚àÇM) and (‚àÇM+, Œ£TŒΩ‚àÇM).
For consistency, note that the dual of
‚àÇM+ is Œ£‚àíV +1TŒΩ‚àÇM ‚âÉŒ£V ‚Ä≤TŒΩ‚àÇM.
Corollary 18.7.6. Let M be a compact smooth manifold M with boundary
‚àÇM. The quotient map
TŒΩM ‚àí‚ÜíTŒΩM/TŒΩ‚àÇM
is V -dual to the quotient map M+ ‚àí‚ÜíM/‚àÇM, and these maps give rise to Spanier-
Whitehead dual coÔ¨Åber sequences
Œ£‚àû‚àÇM+ ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£‚àûM+ ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£‚àûM/‚àÇM ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£‚àûŒ£‚àÇM+
and
Œ£‚àíV TŒΩ‚àÇM ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£‚àíV TŒΩM ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£‚àíV TŒΩM/TŒΩ‚àÇM ‚àí‚ÜíŒ£‚àíV +1TŒΩ‚àÇM.
18.8. The proof of the Costenoble-Waner duality theorem
This section is devoted to the proof of Theorem 18.5.1 and we retain the nota-
tion introduced at the beginning of ¬ß18.5. We begin with an explicit description of
the structure maps of the V -dual pair when K = M is a compact G-manifold and
L is empty. Keeping this description in mind will aid in understanding the proof
that follows.
We then deÔ¨Åne the structure maps in the general case and proceed with the
proof of Theorem 18.5.1. To begin with, we work on the point-set level in categories
of pairs of G-spaces over the base G-spaces ‚àó, K and K √óK and the corresponding
categories of ex-G-spaces. To Ô¨Åt diagrams on the page, instead of (X, W) we will
often use the more compact notation
␀X
W

for objects in categories of pairs. We will
make frequent use of the properties of the unreduced cone construction that we
discussed in ¬ß18.4. Since K ‚äÇV is compact, we can assume that its neighborhood
N is contained in a closed disc D about the origin in V .
The geometric structure maps. As usual, M is embedded with tubular
neighborhood N in a G-representation V . We identify N with the normal bundle
ŒΩ of M. Then CM(M) = S0
M and CM(N, N ‚àíM) ‚âÉSŒΩ. Under this equivalence,
the coevaluation map is given by the Pontryagin-Thom construction
Œ∑: SV ‚àí‚ÜíTŒΩ = r!SŒΩ ‚àº= r!(S0
M ‚àßM SŒΩ) ‚âÉS0
M ‚äôtSŒΩ.
To construct the evaluation map we use the zero section of ŒΩ to embed M as the
diagonal in ŒΩ √óM ‚àº= N √óM, which we view as a space over M √óM with projection

18.8. THE PROOF OF THE COSTENOBLE-WANER DUALITY THEOREM
303
q √óid. A normal bundle Œì of this embedding is given by the subspace (q √óid)‚àí1(U)
sitting over a tubular neighborhood U of the diagonal in M √ó M. Now U can be
identiÔ¨Åed with the tangent bundle of M. Such an identiÔ¨Åcation can be given by
shrinking œÑ to a neighborhood of the zero-section and then using an exponential
function so that the point (x, m) determines a unique geodesic from x to m. This
geodesic determines a tangent vector based at x. Thus a point of U is thought of
both as a point (x, m) ‚ààM √ó M and a tangent vector at x. A point (n, m) in Œì
can thus be thought of as specifying the normal vector n at q(n) together with the
tangent vector (q(n), m) at q(n). This identiÔ¨Åes Œì with the sum of the normal and
tangent bundles and therefore with the trivial bundle M √ó V . Note, however, that
when we think of Œì as a space over M √ó M, then we are remembering how (n, m)
splits into the normal and tangent vectors, but when we look at œÄ1!Œì, then we have
forgotten about the splitting.
In essence, we can now deÔ¨Åne Œµ to be the Pontryagin-Thom construction of the
embedding M ‚àí‚ÜíŒΩ √ó M. However, since this must be a map over M √ó M, we
specify it more precisely as the zig-zag
tSŒΩ ‚äôS0
M ‚âÉSŒΩ √ó M ‚àí‚ÜíŒì/M√óM‚àÇŒì ‚àí‚Üí(M I, p)+ ‚àßSV ‚Üê‚àí‚àÜ!SV
M.
Here the Ô¨Årst map is given by the Pontryagin-Thom construction and Œì is the
closure of Œì in V . The projection p: M I ‚àí‚ÜíM √ó M is given by evaluation at
0 and 1. The second map sends (n, m) to (œâq(n),m, v) where œâq(n),m is a geodesic
from q(n) to m and v is the sum of the normal vector n and the tangent vector
(q(n), m). The third (wrong way pointing) map is the equivalence induced from
the constant path map c: M ‚àí‚Üí(M I, p) over the diagonal ‚àÜ: M ‚àí‚ÜíM √ó M by
adjoining the identity map on the disjoint sections and taking the Ô¨Åberwise smash
product with the identity map of SV . Thus it sends a point (m, v) ‚àà‚àÜ!SV
M that is
not in the section to (cm, v).

The evaluation map. To deÔ¨Åne the evaluation map, we need the analogue of
the tubular neighborhood Œì we described in the manifold case at the end of ¬ß18.5.
By the compactness of K, there is a Lebesgue number Œµ > 0 such that any Œµ-ball
centered on a point of K is contained in N. We agree to replace N with the smaller

18. COSTENOBLE-WANER DUALITY
neighborhood of K that is the union of all such Œµ-balls. We deÔ¨Åne
Œì = {(n, x) ‚àà(N ‚àíL) √ó K | ‚à•q(n) ‚àíx‚à•< Œµ}.

Note that the parametrized line segment œâ(q(n),x) is contained in N if (n, x) ‚ààŒì.

the image of the projection is a neighborhood of ‚àÜK‚àíL in K √ó K. By analogy
with the manifold case, we think of the image of the projection of Œì as a tubular
neighborhood of the diagonal in K √ó K, and we think of points (n, x) ‚ààŒì as
specifying a ‚Äúnormal vector‚Äù n and a ‚Äútangent vector‚Äù (q(n), x), both based at the
point q(n).

To complete our proof that (CK(K, L), CK(N ‚àíK, N ‚àíL)) is a dual pair with
structure maps (Œ∑, Œµ), it suÔ¨Éces to show that Œ∑ is the coevaluation map of a dual
pair. Indeed, since we have already shown that (Œ∑, Œµ) satisÔ¨Åes one of the V -duality
diagrams, it will follow that Œµ must be the evaluation map of the duality.
By
Proposition 16.4.6(iii‚Äô), it suÔ¨Éces to show that
(18.8.5)
Œ∑# : E x(W ‚äôCK(K, L), Z) ‚àí‚ÜíE x(W, Z ‚äôCK(N ‚àíK, N ‚àíL))
is a bijection for all 1-cells W : ‚àó‚àí‚ÜíC and Z : B ‚àí‚ÜíC, where C is any tar-
get space.
We have corresponding maps for the pairs (S0
K, C(N, N ‚àíK)) and
(i!S0
L, CK(N, N ‚àíL)), which by the absolute case we already know to be isomor-
phisms. Since both sides of the maps Œ∑# are exact in the relevant variables, the
result will follow from the Ô¨Åve-lemma once we show that the maps Œ∑# are compat-
ible with the coÔ¨Åber sequences (18.8.3) and (18.8.4), so that (18.8.4) is the V -dual
of (18.8.3). Thus the conclusion will follow by Proposition 16.4.7 once we verify the
commutativity of the following three diagrams.

CHAPTER 19
Fiberwise Costenoble-Waner duality
Introduction
It is often the case that a given functor will have a relatively familiar left adjoint,
like induction, and a relatively mysterious right adjoint, like coinduction. Results
that prove an equivalence of the right adjoint with a shift of the left adjoint are
common and are studied categorically in [62].
Let F be a G-space such that SF is a Costenoble-Waner dualizable G-spectrum
over F and let TF be dual to SF . For example, F could be a smooth G-manifold.
We show in ¬ß19.1 that Costenoble-Waner duality for the pair (SF , TF ) specializes to
such a comparison between the left adjoint r! (quotient out sections) and the right
adjoint r‚àó(take global sections) of the pullback functor r‚àóassociated to r: F ‚àí‚Üí‚àó.
Specialized to orbits G/H, this result translates under the equivalence between the
category of G-spectra over G/H and the category of H-spectra to the Wirthm¬®uller
isomorphism in the form proven by Lewis and May in [98, II¬ß6]. However, the
general result is already of fundamental importance nonequivariantly. In partic-
ular, specialization of this result to smooth manifolds will give the parametrized
homotopical version of Poincar¬¥e duality that we advertised in Example 0.0.2.
In ¬ß19.5, we show that the comparison between r! and r‚àóin ¬ß19.1 is a special
case of a general Ô¨Åberwise comparison between left and right adjoints p! and p‚àó
associated to bundles p: E ‚àí‚ÜíB with Ô¨Åber F. The bundles we consider are of
the type introduced in ¬ß3.2 and studied in ¬ß15.3. The Ô¨Åber F is now a Œì-space,
where Œì is an extension of the ambient group G by the structural group Œ†. When
Œì = Œ†, G is trivial and we are considering nonequivariant bundles.
Fiberwise
Costenoble-Waner duality computes the right adjoint p‚àó: HoGSE ‚àí‚ÜíHoGSB as
a suitable shift of the left adjoint p!. As we observe in ¬ß19.6, this result specializes
to a Ô¨Åberwise variant of our homotopical Poincar¬¥e duality theorem.
The proofs are based on a generalization of the foundations.
In ¬ß19.2, we
construct a symmetric bicategory GE xB for any base G-space B. The bicategory
E x, or GE x to indicate the ambient group, is the case when B is a point. In ¬ß19.3,
we obtain an oplax functor Œπ! : GE xB ‚àí‚ÜíGE x by use of pushforward functors
associated to inclusions of the form Œπ: E2 √óB E1 ‚àí‚ÜíE1 √ó E2.
We also show
how the bicategories GE xB behave with respect to base change and change of
groups. In ¬ß19.4, we show that the bundle construction gives rise to a pseudo-
functor P: ŒìE x ‚àí‚ÜíGE xB. The composite Œπ!P carries the dual pair (SF , tTF ) to a
dual pair (Sp, tTp). Costenoble-Waner duality for this pair specializes to give the
claimed comparison between p! and p‚àó. Moreover, this comparison restricts on Ô¨Åbers
to a comparison of the form given in ¬ß19.1 relating r! and r‚àó. In earlier drafts, we
called Ô¨Åberwise Costenoble-Waner duality the Ô¨Åberwise Wirthm¬®uller isomorphism,
but the new point of view gives more information. It is also reasonable to call the
311

312
19. FIBERWISE COSTENOBLE-WANER DUALITY
result Hu duality since, when Œì = G√óŒ† and M is a smooth manifold, it specializes
to a version of the main result of Po Hu‚Äôs monograph [78].
In ¬ß19.7, we show that the Adams isomorphism relating orbit spectra and
Ô¨Åxed point spectra in the form given by Lewis and May in [98, II¬ß8] is a virtually
immediate special case of Ô¨Åberwise Costenoble-Waner duality.
Since the results of this chapter subsume a number of results with a substan-
tial history and since earlier versions were proven quite diÔ¨Äerently, we give some
background discussion and comparison of methods in ¬ß19.8. In particular, we show
that a general map from right adjoints to left adjoints that featured prominently in
earlier proofs of some of our results gives inverse equivalences to the natural duality
maps that appear in our framework.
19.1. Costenoble-Waner duality and homotopical Poincar¬¥e duality
We assume that F is a G-space such that SF is a Costenoble-Waner dualizable
G-spectrum over F with (right) dual TF , so that we have a dual pair (SF , tTF ) in
GE x. Thus tTF is equivalent to the right dual DrSF . Therefore the map
(19.1.1)
¬µX : X ‚äôtTF ‚àí‚ÜíSF ‚ñ∑X
of Proposition 18.1.5 is an equivalence for all 1-cells X : F ‚àí‚ÜíA, where A is any G-
space. Taking A = ‚àó, so that X is a G-spectrum over F, and using the dictionaries
Proposition 17.4.2 and Corollary 17.4.4 to translate from the bicategory notation,
this equivalence takes the form
(19.1.2)
r!(X ‚àßF TF ) ‚âÉr‚àóX.
Thus it calculates the right adjoint r‚àóin terms of a shift of the left adjoint r!.
Taking F to be the simplest kind of G-manifold, an orbit G/H, recall from
Corollary 11.5.4 that the category of H-spectra is equivalent to the category of
G-spectra over G/H. The equivalence is given in one direction by applying the
functor G√óH (‚àí), and in the other by taking the Ô¨Åber over the identity coset. This
equivalence preserves all structure in sight, including the symmetric monoidal and
model structures. Under this equivalence, r‚àócorresponds to the restriction of group
action functor associated to the inclusion Œπ: H ‚àí‚ÜíG, and its left and right adjoints
r! and r‚àótherefore correspond to induction and coinduction. By Proposition 11.5.2,
TG/H = Œπ!S‚àíL, where L is the tangent representation at the identity coset in G/H.
Translated to the nonparametrized context, (19.1.2) gives a natural equivalence
(19.1.3)
G+ ‚àßH (X ‚àßS‚àíL) ‚âÉFH(G+, X)
for all H-spectra X. In this form, the result is known as the Wirthm¬®uller isomor-
phism. Previous proofs were quite diÔ¨Äerent.
Heading towards Poincar¬¥e duality, but still working equivariantly, take F to
be a smooth closed G-manifold and write it M. Then TM = Œ£‚àíV
M SŒΩ is not just
dualizable in the symmetric monoidal category HoGSM, it is invertible with inverse
Œ£‚àû
MSœÑ. Precisely,
(19.1.4)
Œ£‚àû
MSœÑ ‚àßM TM ‚âÉŒ£‚àíV (SœÑ ‚àßM SŒΩ) ‚âÉSM
since œÑ ‚äïŒΩ is the trivial bundle and so SœÑ ‚àßM SŒΩ ‚àº= SV
M. This leads to the following
result, which in turn will lead to the usual homological Poincar¬¥e duality theorem
in ¬ß20.5 and, equivariantly, in ¬ß21.4.

19.1. COSTENOBLE-WANER DUALITY AND HOMOTOPICAL POINCAR¬¥E DUALITY
313
Theorem 19.1.5 (Homotopical Poincar¬¥e duality). Let M be a smooth closed
G-manifold and let k be a non-parametrized G-spectrum. Then there is a canonical
equivalence of G-spectra
k ‚àßM+ ‚âÉSM ‚ñ∑(k ‚àßSœÑ).
Proof. The smash product on the left is just the nonparametrized tensor of
a spectrum and a space. That on the right is the (external) smash product of a
spectrum and an ex-space over M, and can be written in several equivalent ways:
k ‚àßSœÑ ‚âÉk ‚àßŒ£‚àû
MSœÑ ‚âÉr‚àók ‚àßM Œ£‚àû
MSœÑ,
where the middle term is the (external) smash product of a spectrum and a spec-
trum over M, and the right term is a smash product of spectra over M. We have
the chain of equivalences
k ‚àßM+ ‚âÉr!(k ‚àßM SM)
by r!SM = M+ and the projection formula,
‚âÉr!(k ‚àßM SœÑ ‚àßM TM)
since TM is invertible with inverse SœÑ,
‚âÉr‚àó(k ‚àßM SœÑ)
by Costenoble-Waner duality (19.1.2),
‚âÉSM ‚ñ∑(k ‚àßM SœÑ)
by SM = Sr and Corollary 17.4.4.
‚ñ°
We have relative versions of this result, both for compact manifolds with bound-
ary and for pairs of closed manifolds.

‚ñ°
19.2. The bicategories E xB
At the end of ¬ß16.2, we mentioned that there is a categorical structure, not a
tricategory but similar in Ô¨Çavor, of commutative rings, algebras, bimodules, and
maps of bimodules that better encodes the full structure present in the algebraic
situation. Analogously, we have the same categorical structure made up of spaces,
spaces over spaces, spectra over spaces over spaces, and maps of such parametrized
spectra. This idea might seem esoteric, were it not that, at least implicitly, it plays
a fundamental role in our work.
We shall not make the full structure explicit.
However, in analogy with the bicategories BR parametrized by commutative rings

19.2. THE BICATEGORIES E XB
315
R, we shall construct and use a collection of closed symmetric bicategories E xB
parametrized by G-spaces B. The idea is that the implicit use of a point (the ana-
logue of the integers) in the deÔ¨Ånition of E x can be replaced by use of B throughout
chapter 17.
Instead of the external smash product and function spectra functors of (17.1.1)
and (17.1.2), the starting point for the deÔ¨Ånition is given by external smash product
and function spectra functors
(19.2.1)
‚äºB : HoSK √ó HoSL ‚àí‚ÜíHoSK√óBL
and
(19.2.2)
¬ØFB : HoS op
L √ó HoSK√óBL ‚àí‚ÜíHoSK
for (unsectioned) G-spaces K and L over B. Letting
Œπ: K √óB L ‚àí‚ÜíK √ó L
be the inclusion, these functors are speciÔ¨Åed by
(19.2.3)
X ‚äºB Y = Œπ‚àó(X ‚äºY )
and
¬ØFB(Y, Z) = ¬ØF(Y, Œπ‚àóZ).
With this deÔ¨Ånition, we have the expected equivalence
(19.2.4)
¬ØFB(X ‚äºB Y, Z) ‚âÉ¬ØFB(X, ¬ØFB(Y, Z))
and adjunction
(19.2.5)
HoSK√óBL(X ‚äºB Y, Z) ‚àº= HoSK(X, ¬ØFB(Y, Z)).
Definition 19.2.6. DeÔ¨Åne a bicategory E xB as follows. The 0-cells are the
G-spaces K = (K, p) over B. The category E xB(K, L) is the category HoGSL√óBK
of G-spectra over the pullback L √óB K over B. We denote its objects, that is the

From here, generalizations of other results in ¬ß17.1 hold with nearly identical
proofs. The results of ¬ß¬ß17.2‚Äì17.5 also generalize, but we shall not go into detail.
19.3. Comparisons of bicategories
We shall use GE xB as a tool for studying GE x, and for that we need functors
that relate these bicategories as B and G vary. We especially need the following
comparison functor.

Remark 19.3.5. We would like to say that change of groups induces an equiv-
alence GE xÔ¨Åb
G/H ‚àº= HE x.

the equivalence is given in terms of vertical 1-cells rather than the horizontal 1-cells
that appear in the deÔ¨Ånition of a biequivalence of bicategories. We will develop the
relevant category theory elsewhere, but we can explain the proof without giving
the categorical speciÔ¨Åcation of what it is proving. On 0-cells, we send an H-space

19.4. The bundle construction pseudo-functor
We Ô¨Åx notations as in ¬ß3.3 and ¬ß15.4, letting P be a Œ†-free Œì-space for an
extension Œì of G by Œ†, these being compact Lie groups. We let B = P/Œ†. For a
Œì-space F, we deÔ¨Åned the bundle construction PF on ex-Œì-spaces over F in ¬ß3.3.
We extended the construction to Œì-spectra over F in ¬ß15.4. There we have two
variants, PF and PF , the latter being needed to deal with Œì-spectra over F indexed
on complete universes. In ¬ß15.6, we showed that PF carries Ô¨Åberwise dual pairs of
spectra over F to Ô¨Åberwise dual pairs of spectra over E, where E is the associated
bundle P √óŒ† F. Analogously, we prove here that PF carries Costenoble-Waner dual
pairs of spectra over F to Costenoble-Waner dual pairs of spectra over E.
The essential point is to switch focus from the bundle construction PF for a
Ô¨Åxed Ô¨Åber Œì-space F to a pseudo-functor P between symmetric bicategories that is
obtained from such PF by letting F run over cartesian products F1 √óF2 of Œì-spaces
and E run over cartesian products E1 √óB E2 in the category K /B of spaces over
B. Recall from Lemma 3.3.4 that the functor P √óŒ† (‚àí) from spaces to spaces over
B is cartesian.
Thus, to begin with, we have the functors
(19.4.1)
PF : HoŒìSF ‚àí‚ÜíHoGSE.
Here we are regarding E = P √óŒ† F just as a G-space, ignoring the fact that it has
the projection p = P √óŒ† r: E ‚àí‚ÜíB. The key point in assembling such functors
into a pseudo-functor between bicategories is to remember the implicit projections.
As in ¬ß15.6, there are two layers of structure to consider, and we shall proceed
in two stages. The description given above refers to the more elementary Ô¨Årst stage.
Construction 19.4.2. We deÔ¨Åne a pseudo-functor
P: ŒìE x ‚àí‚ÜíGE xB
between symmetric bicategories. Write F for a typical 0-cell of ŒìE x, so that F is
a Œì-space. We deÔ¨Åne PF = (E, p), where E = P √óŒ† F and p = P √óŒ† r: E ‚àí‚ÜíB,
r: F ‚àí‚Üí‚àó. We deÔ¨Åne P on 1-cells and 2-cells by letting
P: ŒìE x(F1, F2) ‚àí‚ÜíGE xB(E1, E2),
Ei = P √óŒ† Fi, be the functor
PF2√óF1 : HoŒìSF2√óF1 ‚àí‚ÜíHoGSE2√óBE1.

320
19. FIBERWISE COSTENOBLE-WANER DUALITY
The unit isomorphism 2-cell
UPF = Œ¥!SPF ‚àí‚ÜíP‚àÜ!SF = PUF
is obtained by specialization of equivalences in Propositions 15.4.4 and 15.6.1. The
horizontal composition isomorphism 2-cell
PY ‚äôPX ‚àí‚ÜíP(Y ‚äôX)
is obtained by using Propositions 3.3.8 and 15.6.1 to commute P past the functors
that deÔ¨Åne the horizontal composition in ŒìE x.
In the previous construction, F was a variable. We now change our point of
view and generalize the previous construction to one whose starting point is some
Ô¨Åxed F; the previous construction is the case F = ‚àóof the generalized verion.
Construction 19.4.3. Fix a base Œì-space F with associated G-bundle E =
P √óŒ† F. We deÔ¨Åne a pseudo-functor
P/F : ŒìE xF ‚àí‚ÜíGE xE.
Write (L, q) for a 0-cell of ŒìE xF ; thus (L, q) is a Œì-space over F. We deÔ¨Åne
P/F (L, q) = (P √óŒ† L, P √óŒ† q),
which is a G-space over E. We deÔ¨Åne
P/F : ŒìE xF (L1, L2) ‚àí‚ÜíGE xE(N1, N2),
Ni = P √óŒ† Li, to be the functor
PL2√óF L1 : HoŒìSL2√óF L1 ‚àí‚ÜíHoGSN2√óEN1.
The coherence isomorphism 2-cells are deÔ¨Åned as in the previous construction.
Here we use the notation P/F rather than PF to avoid confusion. The symmetric
monoidal functor PF of (19.4.1) preserves Ô¨Åberwise dual pairs, whereas the pseudo-
functor P/F preserves all Costenoble-Waner dualizable pairs.
Corollary 19.4.4. If (X, Y ) is a dual pair in ŒìE x, then (PX, PY ) is a
dual pair in GE xB.
More generally, if (X, Y ) is a dual pair in ŒìE xF , then
(P/F X, P/F Y ) is a dual pair in GE xE.
19.5. The Ô¨Åberwise Costenoble-Waner duality theorem
Again, Ô¨Åx an extension Œì of G by Œ† and a Œ†-free Œì-space P with base space
B = P/Œ†. Fix a Œì-space F and let E = P√óŒ†F. We assume that SF is a Costenoble-
Waner dualizable Œì-spectrum over F with (right) dual TF , so that (SF , tTF ) is a
dual pair. We Ô¨Åx this context throughout the section. With these hypotheses, we
now generalize (19.1.2) from r: F ‚àí‚Üí‚àóto the G-bundle p: E ‚àí‚ÜíB with Ô¨Åber F.
Note that we will use Construction 19.4.2 here, not Construction 19.4.3. That is,
we will use the ambient bicategory GE xB to inform us about GE x. A more general
analogue can be obtained using Construction 19.4.3.
Theorem 19.5.1. Let TE be the G-spectrum PF TF over E. Then (Sp, tTp) is
a dual pair in GE x, where
Sp ‚â°Œπ!PSF ‚âÉ(p, id)!SE
and
Tp ‚â°Œπ!PTF = (p, id)!TE.

The unlabelled equivalences in the top and bottom rectangle are given by the
dictionary Proposition 17.2.4. The equivalences Œ± and œà are obtained from the left
and right pullback faces of (19.5.5). The equivalences œÉ and œÑ are commutation
relations induced from the top and bottom faces. The map œÜ is obtained from the
front face (as in Proposition 2.2.11), starting with TE over the E in the upper right
corner, and the maps Œæ are obtained from the back face. We shall prove shortly
that œÜ and therefore also the left map Œæ is an equivalence, and the right map Œæ is
an equivalence since the right vertical composite agrees with the evident composite
of unit equivalences. The middle left hexagon commutes by a diagram chase from
the commutative diagram (19.5.5), and the lower middle rectangle is a naturality
diagram. We must explain the remaining three rectangles.

map for the dual pair (SF , tTF ) may be identiÔ¨Åed with œÄ‚àó
1TF , and similarly for

the equivalent dual pair (Sr, tTr).

at the top of (19.5.5) is the inclusion Eb √ó Eb = (E √óB E)b ‚àí‚ÜíE √óB E of the Ô¨Åber
over b. Recall from Corollary 19.3.6 that base change functors along inclusions of

and applying k to its evaluation map PŒµ recovers the evaluation map for the Ô¨Åber

in the diagram. This gives the upper middle rectangle. Finally, the equivalence œà

commutativity of the bottom rectangle is obtained by applying (id √ó j)‚àóto the

19.6. Fiberwise Poincar¬¥e duality
Just as (19.1.2) led to the homotopical version of Poincar¬¥e duality formulated
in (Theorem 19.1.5), so 19.5.4 leads to a Ô¨Åberwise homotopical Poincar¬¥e duality
theorem. We retain the context of the previous section, except that we now take
F to be a smooth closed Œì-manifold and rename it M. Thus we have the ex-G-
space (E, p)+ over B, where B = P/Œ† and E = P √óŒ† M. Since the Œì-spectrum
TM = Œ£‚àíV

Proof. In the Ô¨Årst statement, the smash product on the left is the tensor of a
spectrum over B and an ex-space over B. That on the right is the smash product
of spectra over E and is equivalent to the tensor p‚àóJ ‚àßE PMSœÑ. The following chain

that on the right pairs a spectrum with a spectrum over E to obtain a spectrum
over E and is equivalent to p‚àóJ ‚àßE PMSœÑ.

If we apply ¬Ør! to the above result, taking J = ¬Ør‚àók, the left side becomes
k ‚àßŒ£‚àûE+, whose homotopy groups are k‚àó(E). We would like to understand the
right side in cohomological terms. In general, the right side is hard to interpret since

then ¬Ør!(X) ‚âÉ¬Ør‚àó(X ‚àßB SœÑB) for any G-spectrum X over B, since SœÑB is inverse to
TB, and the right side begins to look cohomological. We still need to commute p‚àó
past smash products, but the following general observation achieves that.
Remark 19.6.2. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a map such that there is a natural isomor-
phism f‚àóX ‚âÉf!(X ‚àßA I), where I is invertible with (homotopical) inverse I‚àí1 so
that we also have f!X ‚âÉf‚àó(X ‚àßA I‚àí1). Then the projection formula for f! formally
implies the projection formula for f‚àó. That is, f‚àó(f ‚àóY ‚àßA X) ‚âÉY ‚àßB f‚àóX for
G-spectra X over A and Y over B.

k ‚àßE+ ‚âÉSE ‚ñ∑(k ‚àß(PMSœÑM ‚àßE p‚àóSœÑB)).

In fact, the previous result is a rather elaborate consistency check on our general
theory. There is a bundle theoretic reinterpretation that allows it to be viewed
as a special case of Theorem 19.1.5. Assuming that P is completely regular, so
that P ‚àí‚ÜíB is locally trivial in the appropriate equivariant sense [92, p. 267], the
smooth structures on B, Œì, and M induce smooth structures on P and E. Therefore
both ordinary and Ô¨Åberwise Costenoble-Waner duality apply to E. It is clear by
inspection that the tangent G-bundle of E is isomorphic to the Whitney sum of the
bundle of tangents along the Ô¨Åbers and the pullback of the tangent bundle of B:
(19.6.4)
œÑE ‚àº= (P √óŒ† œÑM) ‚äïp‚àóœÑB.

k ‚àßE+ ‚âÉSE ‚ñ∑(k ‚àßSœÑE).
which is the homotopical Poincar¬¥e duality of Theorem 19.1.5.
19.7. The Adams isomorphism
Let N be a normal subgroup of G and let Œµ: G ‚àí‚ÜíJ be the quotient by N. The
conjugation action of G on N induces an action of G on the tangent space of N at
the identity element, giving us the adjoint representation A = A(N; G). Let (i‚àó, i‚àó)
be the change of universe adjunction associated to the inclusion i: q‚àóVJ ‚àí‚ÜíVG
of the complete J-universe VJ as the universe of N-trivial representations in the
complete G-universe VG.
Recall the discussion of N-free G-spectra from ¬ß15.5, where Œ† and Œì played
the roles of N and G.
Theorem 19.7.1 (Adams isomorphism). For N-free G-spectra X in GS N-triv,
there is a natural equivalence
X/N ‚âÉ(i‚àóŒ£‚àíAi‚àóX)N
in Ho JS N-triv.
We shall derive this by applying Theorem 19.5.2 to the quotient G-map
p: E(N; G) ‚àí‚ÜíB(N; G),

327
where E(N; G) is the universal N-free G-space and B(N; G) = E(N; G)/N. To
place ourselves in the required bundle theoretic context, we give another description
of p, following [118, II¬ß7]. It is formal and would similarly identify p: E ‚àí‚ÜíE/N
for any N-free G-space E. Let Œì = G ‚ãâN be the semi-direct product of G and N,
where G acts by conjugation on N. Write Œ† for the normal subgroup {e} ‚ãâN of

for the map E(N; G) ‚àí‚Üí‚àó.
Proposition 19.7.2. The G-spectrum Tp over E(N, G) is equivalent to r‚àóS‚àíA.
Proof. The tangent bundle of Œì/G ‚àº= N is the trivial bundle N √óA [98, p. 99].
Indeed, let Œì act on A via the projection Œµ: Œì ‚àí‚ÜíG, Œµ(n, g) = g. We obtain a
Œì-trivialization of the tangent bundle of Œì/G by sending (n, a) ‚ààN √óA to deLn(a),
where deLn is the diÔ¨Äerential at e of left translation by n.
It follows that the
tangent bundle along the Ô¨Åbers of p is also trivial:
Œ∏‚àóE(N; G) √óN (Œì/G √ó A) ‚àº= (Œ∏‚àóE(N; G) √óN Œì/G)) √ó A ‚àº= E(N; G) √ó A.
Thus the spherical bundle of tangents along the Ô¨Åber is E(N; G) √ó SA = r‚àóSA. Its
inverse is the bundle construction on the spherical Ô¨Åbration of the normal bundle
of Œì/G, which of course is also trivial. Its G-spectrum over E(N; G) is r‚àóS‚àíA.

19.8. Some background and comparisons
Aside from acknowledgment of the essential precursor [41] of Costenoble and
Waner, it is hard for us to give precise antecedents for our homotopical versions of
Poincar¬¥e duality in ¬ß19.1 and ¬ß19.5. There are various hints in the literature that
something like our results should be true but, to the best of our knowledge, the
present formulations are new.
The Wirthm¬®uller and Adams isomorphisms, in their appropriately general ver-
sions as isomorphisms between certain left and right adjoint functors on G-spectra,
were the most diÔ¨Écult results in Lewis and May‚Äôs work on the foundations of
equivariant stable homotopy theory [98]. The proofs there always seemed unsatis-
factory, but the results have since been used in many applications. With our new
perspective, these results are just very special cases of parametrized Atiyah duality
and its Ô¨Åberwise generalization. The new proofs complete the program begun in
[105] of reproving conceptually all of the basic foundational results that were Ô¨Årst
proven in a less satisfactory ad hoc way in [98].
Historically, the Wirthm¬®uller isomorphism, viewed as a statement about the
behavior of equivariant homology theories on orbit G-spaces, is a key result in
Wirthm¬®uller‚Äôs early paper [171]. Shortly afterwards, he recognized it both as a
duality theorem on orbits and as a special case of equivariant Atiyah duality [172].
The Adams isomorphism was Ô¨Årst proven in [3, 5.4], but only for Ô¨Ånite groups and
only in the equivariant Spanier-Whitehead suspension category. Adams knew and
cited the Lewis-May result for G-free spectra, which had not yet appeared, but
Lewis and May called the result the Adams isomorphism in their published version
[98] because Adams was the Ô¨Årst to formulate the result in proper generality as a
statement about general normal subgroups, rather than just the trivial subgroup.
The basic idea that parametrized G-spectra should clarify and simplify the
Wirthm¬®uller and Adams isomorphisms was explained in an e-mail from Gaunce
Lewis to Po Hu [97]. In her monograph [78], Hu Ô¨Årst formulated and proved a
Ô¨Åberwise version of the Wirthm¬®uller isomorphism, and she used it to prove the
Adams isomorphism. Our results in this chapter include variant versions of all of
her results, and our original arguments were inspired by those in her work.
Remark 19.8.1. Taking the Ô¨Åber F in ¬ß19.5 to be a smooth manifold M and
taking Œì = G√óŒ† with only Œ† acting on M, one can think of p: E ‚àí‚ÜíB as a topo-
logical G-bundle with a reduction of its structural group to a suitably large compact
subgroup Œ† of the group of diÔ¨Äeomorphisms of M. That case of Theorem 19.5.2
is a variant of the main theorem, [78, 4.8], of Hu‚Äôs monograph. She worked with
DiÔ¨Ä(M) itself as an implicit structure group, without use of an auxiliary group
Œ† and without an ambient group Œì. That bundle theoretic framework leads to

19.8. SOME BACKGROUND AND COMPARISONS
329
formidable complications, hence her arguments are much more diÔ¨Écult than ours.
Her result is both more and less general than the specialization of ours to the case
Œì = G √ó Œ†: it allows bundles that might not admit a single compact structure
group Œ†, but it requires the base spaces to be G-CW complexes with countably
many cells, requires smooth manifolds as Ô¨Åbers, and does not handle more general
group extensions.
Remark 19.8.2. In outline, our proof of the Adams isomorphism is an alterna-
tive implementation of the argument that Hu gave in [78, pp 81‚Äì99]. However, in
her restricted bundle theoretic context, the argument, although more conceptual,
is technically more diÔ¨Écult than the original proof in [98, pp 96‚Äì102]. The context
supplied by our bundle construction eliminates the need for most of her work.
A general categorical study of isomorphisms between left and right adjoints
was given by Fausk, Hu, and May in [62], and a simpliÔ¨Åed proof of the Wirthm¬®uller
isomorphism from that perspective was given in [125]. It is a curious feature of those
papers, and the earlier work cited above, that they start with a general natural
map from the right adjoint to the left adjoint and then explain when that map is
an equivalence. Specializing their categorical context, take p and the spectrum TE
as in ¬ß19.5, so that there is an equivalence
Œ±p : p!TE ‚àí‚ÜíDB(p!SE).
For a G-spectrum X over E, their deÔ¨Ånitions specialize to give a canonical candidate
map
œâp : p‚àóX ‚àí‚Üíp!(X ‚àßE TE)
for an equivalence, namely the composite displayed in the commutative diagram
(19.8.3)
p‚àóX ‚âÉp‚àóX ‚àßB DB(SB)
œâp

id‚àßBDB(œÉ) / p‚àóX ‚àßB DB(p!SE)
p‚àóX ‚àßB p!TE
id‚àßBŒ±p
‚âÉ
O
p!(X ‚àßE TE)
p!(p‚àóp‚àóX ‚àßE TE).
‚âÉ
O
p!(œµ‚àßEid)
o
The maps œÉ: p!SE ‚âÉp!p‚àóSB ‚àí‚ÜíSB and œµ: p‚àóp‚àóX ‚àí‚ÜíX are given by the counits
of the adjunctions (p!, p‚àó) and (p‚àó, p‚àó). The lower right equivalence is given by the
projection formula. We took the same perspective in earlier versions of this book.
Note however that the deÔ¨Ånition of œâp relies on having the equivalence Œ±p, which
from our present perspective already depends on knowing that SF is Costenoble-
Waner dualizable. In contrast, we now start from a canonical duality map from the
left adjoint to the right adjoint that always exists, without any further assumptions.
The following comparison is only to be expected. Specialize the deÔ¨Ånition of
œâp to the case when p is r: F ‚àí‚Üí‚àófor a G-space F and write œâX instead of œâr to
emphasize the dependence on X, where X is a G-spectrum over F. The following
result shows that œâX is a left inverse of the map ¬µX of (19.1.1). The analogue for
the map ¬µX used in Theorem 19.5.2 follows Ô¨Åberwise.
