CHAPTER 22
Twisted theories and spectral sequences
Introduction
This chapter has two goals. We describe certain general types of ‚Äútwisted‚Äù
parametrized homology and cohomology theories, and we give further spectral se-
quences for the calculation of parametrized homology and cohomology.
In particular, we shall locate twisted K-theory as a special case of a twisted co-
homology theory. There is already a substantial body of work in twisted K-theory,
and our work is not a contribution to that subject, but rather a contextualization
that makes many of its properties transparent. It is well-known that this example
belongs to parametrized cohomology theory and that it requires more adequate
foundations than were previously available. Our exposition makes folklore precise
and is in large part based on Atiyah and Segal [5], especially the sketch at the end
of their ¬ß3. In the equivariant case, we rely on details in the general stack-theoretic
treatment of Tu, Xu, and Laurent-Gengoux [164]. We make no claim to originality.
We specialize our general framework to homology and cohomology theories that
are represented by bundles of spectra in ¬ß22.1. We give some relevant remarks on
automorphism monoids of spectra in ¬ß22.2. In particular, we give some observations
about the ‚Äúunit monoid‚Äù GL1(k) for a symmetric or orthogonal ring ‚Ñ¶-spectrum
k.
Especially for commutative ring spectra k, there is quite a bit of confusion
in the literature about this space. Remarks here and in ¬ß23.6 help to sort this
out. We show how naturally twisted K-theory appears as a twisted parametrized
cohomology theory in ¬ß22.3. It will be apparent that this is indeed a very special
case. There are many analogous examples that await exploration.
In ¬ß22.4, we give a spectral sequence associated to a simplicial parametrized
space.
Actually, to illustrate ideas, we show how this works in general in any
well-grounded topological model category. It is folklore that the spectral sequence
applies to Reedy coÔ¨Åbrant simplicial objects in any good model category, but focus
on the Reedy model structure is overly restrictive in topological situations. Using
base change functors to describe a sheaf theoretic perspective, we specialize this
spectral sequence to obtain ÀáCech type local to global, or descent, spectral sequences
for the calculation of parametrized homology and cohomology theories in ¬ß22.5.
Douglas [52] used a Rothenberg-Steenrod type spectral sequence to give com-
putations in twisted K-theory. We show how to construct such spectral sequences
in general in ¬ß22.6. This is another specialization of the simplicial spectral sequence
of ¬ß22.4.
The Eilenberg-Moore spectral sequence is a kind of dual to the Rothenberg-
Steenrod spectral sequence. It was viewed by Hodgkin [74] and Smith [153,154] as a
K¬®unneth spectral sequence in parametrized homology. In ¬ß22.7, we use parametrized
spectra to give a new and generalized version of their construction. It is related
373

374
22. TWISTED THEORIES AND SPECTRAL SEQUENCES
to theirs in much the same way that versions of the Adams spectral sequence con-
structed using spectra are related to the original construction using spaces, before
the introduction of the stable homotopy category. The new construction raises in-
teresting questions of convergence, but we will not pursue them here. It is also so
closely parallel to the construction of the Adams spectral sequence as to suggest a
common generalization (perhaps generalizing [102]), but we shall not pursue that
idea either.
22.1. Twisted homology and cohomology theories
Let G be a compact Lie group. The reader may take G to be the trivial group,
but there is no gain in simplicity. We restrict our general bundle theoretic context
to the most important special case by taking Œì = G √ó Œ† (and, in the context of
¬ß15.3, F = ‚àó). Let k be a Œì-spectrum indexed on a Œ†-trivial Œì-universe. As we
noted in ¬ß15.3, when working in a Œ†-trivial universe there is no reason to restrict
Œ† to be a compact Lie group. It can be any topological group, say locally compact
and well-based, as always holds in practice. The generality is important in twisted
K-theory, where the relevant group is an appropriate model for K(Z, 2), namely
the projective unitary group.
We have a theory of principal (G, Œ†)-bundles, where the ‚Äústructural group‚Äù is
Œ† and the ‚Äúambient group‚Äù is G. Such a bundle is just a proper (G √ó Œ†)-space,
with free action by Œ†; see ¬ß3.2 and [91]. Now take P in our bundle construction to
be a universal principal (G, Œ†)-bundle, denoting it by EGŒ†. This means that the
Ô¨Åxed point space (EGŒ†)Œõ is contractible for all closed subgroups Œõ of G √ó Œ† such
that Œõ‚à©Œ† is trivial; such subgroups are all of the form Œõ = HœÅ = {(h, œÅ(h) | h ‚ààH}
for some subgroup H of G and homomorphism œÅ: H ‚àí‚ÜíŒ†. Then the orbit G-
space BGŒ† = EGŒ†/Œ† is a classifying space for principal (G, Œ†)-bundles. Of course
some models for EG(Œ†) and hence BG(Œ†) may be more convenient than others
in particular examples. In the nonequivariant case G = e, we are starting with a
universal principal Œ†-bundle EŒ† ‚àí‚ÜíBŒ†.
Definition 22.1.1. DeÔ¨Åne kŒ† to be the G-spectrum EGŒ† √óŒ† k over BGŒ†. It
is a parametrized G-spectrum indexed on a complete G-universe and represents
parametrized (unreduced) RO(G)-graded homology and cohomology theories on
the homotopy category HoGK /BGŒ† of G-spaces over BGŒ†. We write k‚àó(X, p)
and k‚àó(X, p) for the values of this theory on a G-space (X, p) over BGŒ†.
We use unreduced theories on spaces over B, rather than reduced theories on
ex-spaces, to conform with the literature.
It seems natural to do so since our
focus here is on spaces, in particular manifolds, rather than spectra.
However,
an unreduced theory determines and is determined by the corresponding reduced
theory, and the full panoply of stable techniques is available to us.
Note that p is an actual G-map p: X ‚àí‚ÜíB, not a homotopy class. We may
think of p as a principal (G, Œ†)-bundle over X, namely the pullback of EGŒ† along
p. If we call the resulting bundle P and write
(22.1.2)
kP
‚àó(X) = k‚àó(X, p)
and
k‚àó
P (X) = k‚àó(X, p),
then our notations agree with those of Atiyah and Segal [5] (except that they
did not consider homology). It is reasonable to think of p as the homotopy class
that determines the equivalence class of P. This makes sense since the twisted

22.2. AUTOMORPHISM MONOIDS OF SPECTRA AND GL1(k)
375
k-homology or k-cohomology of (X, p) depends only on the homotopy class of p (by
construction or the weak equivalence axiom).
The altered notations lead to an altered viewpoint. We may view X as a space
over itself, and then p!X = (X, p) as a space over B. By Proposition 20.2.6(ii),
read equivariantly and in the unreduced sense, we then have
(22.1.3)

and

is a bundle of spectra over X twisted by P. To conform with (22.1.2), we could
denote it alternatively by kP when considering homology or kP when considering
cohomology. Unravelling the deÔ¨Ånitions, we see that k0
P (X) is just the set of ho-
motopy classes of sections of the bundle P √óŒ† k0 over X. Note that from this
point of view there is no need to insist on using all maps X ‚àí‚ÜíBGŒ†. It may be
more sensible to restrict attention to a preferred class of principal (G, Œ†)-bundles,
as seems to be appropriate in the equivariant case of twisted K-theory.
We think of our original deÔ¨Ånition as extrinsic, given by theories represented by
a G-spectrum over BGŒ† that is independent of X. We think of (22.1.3) as giving
the intrinsic form of the theory, susceptible of direct geometric analysis starting
with X. To see the idea, think of classical nonequivariant K-theory. It is given
extrinsically as a represented theory with values given by homotopy classes of maps
into BU √ó Z, which is the zeroth space of the K-theory spectrum.
It is given
intrinsically by starting with the Grothendieck group of vector bundles over X. We
remark that, as in this example, the extrinsic version of homology can be most
convenient even when cohomology admits an intrinsic description.
Applying Remark 20.4.2 to (22.1.3), but using the notations here, we obtain
the following version of the Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence for the calculation
of these twisted theories in the nonequivariant case.
Proposition 22.1.5. Let X be a CW complex. Then there are spectral se-
quences

22.2. Automorphism monoids of spectra and GL1(k)
We change our point of view slightly. We start with a nonparametrized G-
spectrum k and ask what it means to have an action by Œ† on k. As before, G is a
compact Lie group but Œ† can be general. We view such an action as a ‚Äútwisting‚Äù of
k by Œ†. Since we are using naive Œ†-spectra, such an action consists of a continuous
family of automorphisms of the G-spectrum k by elements of Œ†. It is given by
a homomorphism, usually taken to be a monomorphism, t: Œ† ‚àí‚ÜíIso(k), where
Iso(k) is the topological group of G-equivariant automorphisms of k.
It is natural to ask how sensitive this is to the choice of one‚Äôs category of spectra
and to the choice of a spectrum within its homotopy type (or weak homotopy type).
Since reasonable categories of spectra have a faithful forgetful functor to prespectra
and Ô¨Åbrant prespectra are ‚Ñ¶-prespectra, it seems reasonable to work in the category
of excellent (nonparametrized) G-prespectra of DeÔ¨Ånition 13.2.2, since those can

376
22. TWISTED THEORIES AND SPECTRAL SEQUENCES
be expected to have the largest automorphism groups. We recall that excellent
G-spectra are ‚Ñ¶-G-prespectra whose structure maps are h-coÔ¨Åbrations and whose
spaces are well-based, compactly generated, and of the homotopy types of G-CW
cmplexes. A weak equivalence between such prespectra is a homotopy equivalence,
by Proposition 13.2.5.
There is an evident monoid that is more sensible from a homotopical point of
view than the group Iso(k) and is homotopy invariant. In any reasonable topological
category with a subcategory of weak equivalences, we can form the topological
monoid Aut(X) of weak self-equivalences of any object X, which we shall write as
HX for the moment. In [113, ¬ß3], it is proven in the context of based or unbased
spaces that if f : X ‚àí‚ÜíY is a weak equivalence, then there is a natural zigzag
BHX ‚àí‚ÜíBHf ‚Üê‚àíBHY
of weak equivalences, where Hf is a certain topological category with two objects
constructed from f. It follows that HX, ‚Ñ¶BHX, ‚Ñ¶BHY , and HY are weakly
equivalent as A‚àû-spaces and therefore that HX and HY are weakly equivalent as
topological monoids. Inspection of the argument in [113, ¬ß3] shows that it applies to
quite general topological categories and in particular applies to prove the following
result, in which Aut(k) denotes the monoid of self-equivalences of an excellent G-
prespectrum k.
Theorem 22.2.1. Let f : k ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñìbe a weak equivalence of excellent G-prespectra.
Then there is a natural zigzag of weak equivalences connecting BAut(k) to BAut(‚Ñì).
Suppose we have a topological group Œ† of the homotopy type of a CW complex,
a homomorphism of topological monoids Œ† ‚àí‚ÜíM (for example M = Aut(k))
and a zigzag of weak equivalences connecting BM to BN for another topological
monoid N (for example N = Aut(‚Ñì)). Then BŒ† has the homotopy type of a CW
complex and, by Whitehead‚Äôs theorem, we obtain a map BŒ† ‚àí‚ÜíBN, unique up
to homotopy, which is compatible with our zigzag.
We cannot conclude that t
lifts to a homomorphism of monoids Œ† ‚àí‚ÜíM, but it is clear that no homotopical
information is lost by working with N instead of M.
If we have a twisting t: Œ† ‚àí‚ÜíIso(k) ‚äÇAut(k), we can use it to construct
twisted homology and cohomology theories as in the previous section. We cannot
necessarily lift t to a twisting Œ† ‚àí‚ÜíIso(‚Ñì) or even to a twisting Œ† ‚àí‚ÜíAut(‚Ñì) when k
is equivalent to ‚Ñì, but we can lift the classifying map of t to a map BŒ† ‚àí‚ÜíBAut(‚Ñì).
If we consider general maps k ‚àí‚Üík, not necessarily weak equivalences, we
obtain End(k). It is natural to give it the trivial map as basepoint, rather than
the identity map as for Aut(k). The homotopy group œÄn(End(k)) is the group of
homotopy classes of maps of spectra Œ£nk ‚àí‚Üík and therefore gives the cohomology
operations of degree ‚àín on the cohomology theory represented by k. This is clearly
invariant with respect to equivalences k ‚âÉ‚Ñì.
Now suppose that k is a ring ‚Ñ¶-prespectrum in the classical naive homotopical
sense (as in [121, p. 218]). Thus, using sequential indexing for deÔ¨Åniteness, we have
pairings km ‚àßkn ‚àí‚Üíkm+n and unit maps Sn ‚àí‚Üíkn that make the appropri-
ate diagrams commute up to homotopy. In particular, k0 is a ring space (in the
homotopical sense).

22.2. AUTOMORPHISM MONOIDS OF SPECTRA AND GL1(k)
377
Definition 22.2.2. The space GL1(k) of unit components of a ring ‚Ñ¶-prespec-
trum k is the pullback in the diagram
GL1(k)

/ k0
Œ¥

œÄ0(k)√ó
/ œÄ0(k),
where Œ¥ is the discretization map (which is a Ô¨Åbration). The pairing k0 ‚àßk0 ‚àí‚Üík0
restricts to give a product GL1(k) √ó GL1(k) ‚àí‚ÜíGL1(k) because, in the ring œÄ0,
the product of units is a unit. The unit S0 ‚àí‚Üík0 restricts to give a basepoint
1 ‚ààGL1(k). With this product and unit, GL1(k) is a homotopy associative H-
space. The component SL1(k) of 1 is a sub H-space.
With appropriate rigidiÔ¨Åcation, we can think of GL1(k) as a monoid acting
on k and thus as a submonoid of Aut(k). The actions of groups Œ† that are used
in practice are thought of as factoring through maps of monoids Œ† ‚àí‚ÜíGL1(k).
However, the literature on this topic is quite imprecise. We explain some general
results that allow this intuition to be made rigorous. The following material should
be folklore, but it does not seem to appear in the literature.
We shall recall the deÔ¨Ånitions of functors with smash product (FSP‚Äôs) and
of their associated ring spectra in the Ô¨Årst two sections of the next chapter. We
assume here that the reader is familiar with these notions. We can work with either
symmetric or orthogonal ring spectra, with their two variant kinds of associated
FSP‚Äôs. For deÔ¨Åniteness, we focus on symmetric ring spectra, but orthogonal ring
spectra are better suited to the equivariant context. In either case, we work with
FSP‚Äôs with their external products, rather than with the internal products of their
associated ring spectra. In the symmetric case, the product structure on k is given
by pairings ¬µ: km ‚àßkn ‚àí‚Üíkm+n and unit maps Œ∑: Sn ‚àí‚Üíkn that that make the
appropriate diagrams commute strictly; see DeÔ¨Ånition 23.1.5.
Proposition 22.2.3. If k is a symmetric or orthogonal ring spectrum and an
‚Ñ¶-prespectrum, then GL1(k) is a topological monoid and is a submonoid of the
topological monoid Aut(k) of weak self-equivalences of k.
Proof. It is immediate from the commutative diagrams in DeÔ¨Ånition 23.1.5
that the product on GL1(k) is associative and unital. Fix x ‚ààR0. Then y 7‚Üí¬µ(x, y)
gives a map Rn ‚ÜíRn for each n. It is again immediate from the given diagrams
that these maps specify a map of symmetric spectra, and this map is a weak self-
equivalence because, on passage to homotopy groups, it gives multiplication by a
unit. Since Aut(k) is topologized as a subspace of the product of the spaces of maps
kn ‚àí‚Üíkn, it follows directly that GL1(k) is a topological submonoid of Aut(k).
‚ñ°
The following two remarks are vital to understanding what this result says.
Remark 22.2.4. The categories of symmetric and orthogonal ring spectra are
given Quillen equivalent model structures in [106]. The Ô¨Åbrant objects in these
model structures are precisely those ring spectra which are ‚Ñ¶-prespectra. Thus
Proposition 22.2.3 applies to a Ô¨Åbrant approximation of any ring spectrum. If k
is coÔ¨Åbrant and Ô¨Åbrant as a ring spectrum, then it is coÔ¨Åbrant as a spectrum and
its self-equivalences are therefore homotopy equivalences. Moreover, if k ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñìis
a weak equivalence of coÔ¨Åbrant and Ô¨Åbrant symmetric or orthogonal ring spectra,

378
22. TWISTED THEORIES AND SPECTRAL SEQUENCES
then its map of zeroth spaces restricts to a map GL1(k) ‚ÜíGL1(‚Ñì) of monoids
that is a homotopy equivalence in the strong sense that the relevant homotopies
are through maps of monoids.
Remark 22.2.5. The only subtlety is in the commutative case. If k is a commu-
tative symmetric or orthogonal ring spectrum and an ‚Ñ¶-prespectrum, then GL1(k)
is a grouplike commutative monoid and is therefore equivalent to a product of
Eilenberg-Mac Lane spaces. We conclude that there are no interesting examples of
such commutative ring ‚Ñ¶-prespectra. In the previous remark, if we start with a
commutative ring spectrum and take a Ô¨Åbrant approximation as a ring spectrum,
the result is no longer commutative. The categories of commutative symmetric and
orthogonal ring spectra are also given Quillen equivalent model structures in [106],
but in those model structures the Ô¨Åbrant objects k are not ‚Ñ¶-prespectra but only
positive ‚Ñ¶-prespectra, so that the zeroth spaces k0 are no longer well related to the
homotopy groups of k. In fact, if k is both coÔ¨Åbrant and Ô¨Åbrant as a commutative
ring spectrum, then k0 = S0. As we will recall in ¬ß23.6, we can construct an inÔ¨Ånite
loop space version of GL1(k) when k is commutative, but no known construction
simultaneously gives a submonoid of Aut(k), and it is the latter structure that is
relevant to the theory in this chapter.
Remark 22.2.6. In the context of Lewis‚ÄìMay spectra (considered in ¬ß24.3),
the topological monoid F of self-homotopy equivalences of spheres and its identity
component SF play a special role. They are exactly GL1(S) and SL1(S), where
S is the Lewis‚ÄìMay sphere spectrum with zeroth space QS0 = colim ‚Ñ¶nSn. Lewis-
May spectra k are ‚Ñ¶-prespectra in the strong sense that their adjoint structure
maps kn ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶kn+1 are homeomorphisms. The monoids F and SF act from the
right on the zeroth space k0 of any Lewis-May spectrum k and, when k is a ring
spectrum, F acts from the right on the subspace GL1(k) of k0 and SF acts on
SL1(k). This fact plays a central role in relating highly structured ring spectra to
orientation theory; see [98,112].
22.3. Twisted K-theory
There are several reasonable models for the spectrum K that represents com-
plex K-theory. In any model, the unit space GL1(K) is homotopy equivalent to
Z/2√óK(Z, 2)√óBSU‚äó; the third component, and usually the Ô¨Årst, are ignored when
deÔ¨Åning twisted K-theory. For the moment, we take G = e. There are several quite
diÔ¨Äerent group structures on models for K(Z, 2). For example, as BS1, it is a topo-
logical Abelian group.
However, for purposes of twisted K-theory, the relevant
models for K see K(Z, 2) as the projective unitary group, which we denote by Œ†
in this section. Note that diÔ¨Äerent topological groups whose underlying spaces are
K(Z, 2)‚Ä≤s have bundle theories that look similar homotopically but can be quite
diÔ¨Äerent geometrically.
While there are several variants, the usual deÔ¨Ånition of
twisted K-theory is just our twisted theory represented by the spectrum KŒ† over
BŒ† for a suitable twisting t: Œ† ‚àí‚ÜíAut(K) that factors (at least homotopically)
through the second component of GL1(K).
The standard foundational reference is Atiyah and Segal [5], and we shall not
repeat their arguments. Rather, we shall say just enough to make it clear that
their deÔ¨Ånition does indeed Ô¨Åt into our framework. They start with an inÔ¨Ånite
dimensional Hilbert space H with the norm topology.
The space Fred(H ) of

22.3. TWISTED K-THEORY
379
Fredholm operators in H is a model for BU √ó Z, so that
K0(X) = [X+, Fred(H )].
The projective unitary group PU(H ) with the norm topology clearly acts on
Fred(H ). However, it is preferable to take Œ† to be PU(H ) with the compact-open
topology and to replace Fred(H ) with a homotopy equivalent space Fred‚Ä≤(H ) on
which Œ† acts, as explained in [5, 3.2]. With either topology, the unitary group
U(H ) is contractible and therefore Œ† is a K(Z, 2).
Let P be a principal Œ†-bundle over a space X, say a CW complex. Atiyah and
Segal use the notation P for the associated bundle with Ô¨Åber the projective space
P(H ), which is more in line with classical K-theory but does not aÔ¨Äect the details
to follow. Under either interpretation, P is classiÔ¨Åed by a map Œ±P : X ‚àí‚ÜíBŒ†,
which can be viewed as an element of H3(X; Z). The principal bundle P has an
associated bundle Fred‚Ä≤(P) with Ô¨Åber Fred‚Ä≤(H ). Atiyah and Segal deÔ¨Åne K0
P (X)
to be the set of homotopy classes of sections of Fred‚Ä≤(P).
The bundle P can be thought of as a cocycle; with other choices of details,
it is a cocycle, often denoted œÑ, and then the notations œÑK‚àó(X) and œÑK‚àó(X) are
often used. Whatever the notation, the idea is that P (or œÑ) speciÔ¨Åes a twisting
that gives rise to a twisted version of K‚àó(X) and K‚àó(X).
The intuition is to
mimic local systems, and we have seen in our discussion of Poincar¬¥e duality that
parametrized homotopy theory makes these homotopical. Therefore parametrized
homotopy theory provides a natural way to make this intuition precise.
Actually, Atiyah and Segal work more generally with bundles P with an involu-
tion, which splits the bundle as P +‚®øP ‚àíand induces a double cover of X. The latter
is classiÔ¨Åed by an element ŒæP ‚ààH1(X; Z/2). The set of such bundles P with invo-
lution over X is in bijective correspondence with H1(X, Z/2) √ó H3(X; Z), but the
multiplicative structure is twisted by the Bockstein Œ≤ : H2(X; Z/2) ‚àí‚ÜíH3(X; Z)
applied to products of 1-dimensional classes; see [5, 2.3, 3.3].
For this version, they start with a Ô¨Åxed mod 2 graded Hilbert space ÀÜ
H and a
modiÔ¨Åed representing space that they denote Fred(0)( ÀÜ
H ) and we abbreviate to K0,
since it is the zeroth space of their model for the K-theory spectrum. They also
replace their bundle P (not our principal bundle) by ÀÜP = P ‚äóP( ÀÜ
H ) before taking
the associated bundle with Ô¨Åber K0. RedeÔ¨Åning K0
P (X) in these terms facilitates
analysis of products and the extension to a periodic Z-graded theory. They explain
how to construct Œ†-equivariant homotopy equivalences K0 ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶2nK0 in [5, ¬ß4].
DeÔ¨Åning the K theory spectrum by letting K2n = K0 and K2n‚àí1 = ‚Ñ¶K2n, this
gives K the Œ†-action needed to deÔ¨Åne KŒ† = EŒ† √óŒ† K, and it is then clear that
their groups Ki
P (X) coincide with those given by our general theory. Their spectral
sequence of [5, 4.1] is the evident specialization of the spectral sequence given in
Proposition 22.1.5. It is studied in considerably more detail in their sequel [6] and
was already introduced in Rosenberg‚Äôs early paper [141].
The equivariant generalization is similar, but there are bundle theoretical sub-
tleties. Here we Ô¨Ånd the alternative treatment of [164] illuminating. We shall not
go into detail but just mention some key points. The class of equivariant bundles
with Hilbert space Ô¨Åbers that Atiyah and Segal consider seems not to have an ob-
vious classifying G-space, but Atiyah and Segal give an ad hoc construction and
prove that it is equivalent to Map(EG, BŒ†) [5, 6.3(iv)]. Thus the set of equivalence

380
22. TWISTED THEORIES AND SPECTRAL SEQUENCES
classes of such bundles over a G-space X is in bijective correspondence with the
third Borel cohomology group H3
G(X; Z).
Passage from the bundles they consider to principal (G, Œ†) bundles is subtle
and cannot work naively with the norm topology on the structural group Œ†, since
with that topology the associated nonequivariant principal Œ†-bundles do not have
continuous actions by G. In the relevant specialization of the general theory of [164],
the focus is on principal (G, Œ†)-bundles rather than on bundles with projective
Hilbert space Ô¨Åbers, and in particular they prove the following result.
Theorem 22.3.1. [164, 2.41]
Let G be a Lie group that acts properly on a
smooth manifold M. Then there is a canonically split surjection from the set of
isomorphism classes of principal (G, Œ†)-bundles over M to the group H3
G(M, Z).
Thus, if we are given a cohomology class Œ± ‚ààH3
G(M, Z), we have a canonical
principal (G, Œ†)-bundle PŒ± that gives rise to it. We can deÔ¨Åne
(22.3.2)
Ki
Œ±(M) = (PŒ± √óŒ† K)‚àó(M)
as in (22.1.3) and (22.1.4). The discussions in [5, ¬ß6] and [164, 3.15‚Äì3.17] make
clear that this gives the same answer as the deÔ¨Ånitions in those sources.
Remark 22.3.3. We note parenthetically that, as explained in [116, Thm 5],
passage from principal (G, Œ†)-bundles to principal G-bundles via the Borel con-
struction is represented homotopically by a canonical map of classifying G-spaces
BG(Œ†) ‚âÉMap(EG, EŒ†)/Œ† ‚àí‚ÜíMap(EG, BŒ†).
Theorem 22.3.1 suggests that this map has a canonical section when G is a Lie
group and Œ† is the projective unitary group.
22.4. The simplicial spectral sequence
In this section, we recall the spectral sequences associated to simplicial objects
that were Ô¨Årst constructed for simplicial spaces by Segal [147]. It is sensible and
convenient to work in the generality of a well-grounded model category C . We
focus on the based case to Ô¨Åx notations, but the unbased case works the same
way. We write Y ‚àßT for the tensor of an object Y of C with a based topological
space T, and we write F(T, Y ) for the cotensor. By a (reduced) homology theory
on C , we mean a sequence of covariant functors Jq from C to the category of
Abelian groups together with natural suspension isomorphisms Jq(X) ‚àº= Jq+1(Œ£X),
Œ£X = X ‚àßS1, that satisfy the exactness, additivity, and weak equivalence axioms
of DeÔ¨Ånition 20.1.2. In the context of equivariant parametrized spectra, we could
just as well work with RO(G)-gradings instead of the integer gradings that we use
here.
The Reedy model category structure gives the category sC of simplicial objects
in C a topological model structure. See for example [75, Ch. 5] or [73, Ch. 15];
although the enrichment in such sources is simplicial, the arguments we quote work
equally well with topological enrichment. Using the tensors and cotensors in C , the
geometric realization functor
| ‚àí|: sC ‚àí‚ÜíC
is speciÔ¨Åed by
|X| =
Z n‚àà‚àÜ
Xn ‚àß‚àÜn
+

22.4. THE SIMPLICIAL SPECTRAL SEQUENCE
381
and the singular functor
S : C ‚àí‚ÜísC
is speciÔ¨Åed by
(SY )n = F(‚àÜn
+, Y ).
The pair (S, | ‚àí|) is a Quillen adjunction with respect to the given model structure
in C and the Reedy model structure in sC .
Remark 22.4.1. It follows directly from the deÔ¨Ånition of Reedy coÔ¨Åbrations
that any Quillen adjoint pair between well-grounded model categories lifts naturally
to a Quillen adjoint pair on the associated simplicial categories. In particular, in
the context of parametrized spaces or spectra, the base change pair (f!, f ‚àó) gives a
Quillen adjoint pair on the associated simplicial categories.
For a simplicial object X in C , we have latching maps
Œªn : LnX ‚àí‚ÜíXn
for n ‚â•0. These should be thought of intuitively as the inclusion of the union
of the images of all degeneracy operations si : Xn‚àí1 ‚àí‚ÜíXn (or the initial map
‚àó‚àí‚ÜíX0 when n = 0). The formal deÔ¨Ånition gives the latching object LnX as the
colimit over degeneracy operators of the maps under n in the standard simplicial
category ‚àÜ, the colimit taking account of the relations sisj = sj+1si for i ‚â§j;
see [75, 5.1.2]. The simplicial object X is Reedy coÔ¨Åbrant exactly when each Œªn,
n ‚â•0, is a coÔ¨Åbration in the model structure on C . However, in our topological
situation, it is too restrictive to focus only on coÔ¨Åbrant objects in sC when studying
the spectral sequence associated to the skeletal Ô¨Åltration on |X|. In well-grounded
model categories, every model coÔ¨Åbration is a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration between well-grounded
objects in C and is therefore a bicoÔ¨Åbration in the sense of DeÔ¨Ånitions 5.3.2 and
5.3.3.
BicoÔ¨Åbrations suÔ¨Éce to give the gluing lemma and its consequences; see
DeÔ¨Ånitions 5.4.1 and 5.5.4 and Theorem 5.5.1. That is all that is needed to study
the spectral sequence. We use the following language adapted from the case of
simplicial spaces studied in [109, ¬ß11].
Definition 22.4.2. An object X of sC is proper if each Xn is well-grounded
and each latching map Œªn is a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration. It follows that each LnX is well-
grounded and each Œªn is a bicoÔ¨Åbration. All Reedy coÔ¨Åbrant objects are proper.
Remark 22.4.3. If each degeneracy si : Xn‚àí1 ‚àí‚ÜíXn is a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration, then
so is Œªn : LnX ‚àí‚ÜíXn. To see that, one uses the description of LnX as a colimit
and veriÔ¨Åes directly that Œªn satisÔ¨Åes the required left lifting property.
Theorem 22.4.4. Let X be a proper simplicial object in C and let J‚àóand J‚àó
be a homology theory and a cohomology theory on C .
Then there is a strongly
convergent spectral sequence

which converges strongly if the derived E‚àûterms RE‚àûvanish.

Before giving the proof, we explain the E2 and E2 terms. If we apply Jq for a
Ô¨Åxed q to the objects Xp, we obtain a simplicial Abelian group Jq(X). Taking its
associated chain complex and passing to homology, we obtain the homology groups
Hp(Jq(X)). Similarly, the Jq(Xp) give a cosimplicial Abelian group. Taking its
cochains and passing to cohomology gives the cohomology groups Hp(Jq(X)).
Proof. Our proof is a generalization and clariÔ¨Åcation of the argument in [109,
11.4], where details are given for simplicial spaces. We Ô¨Ålter |X| by Fp|X| = |skpX|.

22.5. ÀáCech type spectral sequences
We apply the simplicial spectral sequence of the previous section to give a ÀáCech
type local to global descent spectral sequence, starting from a sheaf theoretic point
of view on parametrized homology and cohomology. This approach seems partic-
ularly relevant when our parametrized coeÔ¨Écient spectra come from the bundle
construction, so that they trivialize over the open sets of a Ô¨Åne enough cover. We
described the behavior of parametrized homology and cohomology with respect to
base change in Proposition 20.2.6. Using that result, we see that the counits of
base change adjunctions give rise to the following comparison maps. They will lead
to appropriate restrictions of our theories over open subsets of the base space.
Proposition 22.5.1. Let f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB be a map and let J and X be spectra
over B.
Then the counit f!f ‚àó‚àí‚Üíid of the adjunction (f!, f ‚àó) induces natural
corestriction and restriction homomorphisms
(f ‚àóJ)n(f ‚àóX) ‚àº= (f!f ‚àóJ)‚àó(X) ‚àí‚ÜíJn(X)
and
Jn(X) ‚àí‚ÜíJn(f!f ‚àóX) ‚àº= (f ‚àóJ)n(f ‚àóX).
If f is a q-equivalence, then these maps are isomorphisms.
Proof. The last statement holds since (f!, f ‚àó) is a Quillen equivalence when
f is a q-equivalence.
‚ñ°
Definition 22.5.2. For an open subset U of B, let jU : U ‚àí‚ÜíB be the inclu-
sion. For spectra J and X over B, deÔ¨Åne
Œì(U; J‚àóX) = (j‚àó
UJ)‚àó(j‚àó
UX)
and
Œì(U; J‚àóX) = (j‚àó
UJ)‚àó(j‚àó
UX).
For U ‚äÇV , let iU,V be the inclusion. Since jU = jV iU,V , the corestriction and
restriction maps give that Œì(‚àí; J‚àóX) is a covariant functor and Œì(‚àí; J‚àóX) is a
contravariant functor from the category OB of open subsets of B to graded Abelian
groups.
We call these functors the copresheaf of parametrized homology groups
and the presheaf of parametrized cohomology groups.
The previous result gives
compatible families of maps
Œì(U; J‚àóX) ‚àí‚ÜíJ‚àó(X) and J‚àó(X) ‚àí‚ÜíŒì(U; J‚àóX).

Reverting to spaces over B and unreduced theories, this leads to ÀáCech type

(X, p) over B. Observe that in this situation

We Ô¨Årst recall the ÀáCech complex. Let B be a base space and let U be an open
cover of B indexed on a totally ordered set I. DeÔ¨Åne a simplicial set U‚Ä¢ by letting
the set Un of n-simplices be the set of ordered (n + 1)-tuples S = (Ui0, . . . , Uin)
(possibly with repeats) of sets in U that have non-empty intersection, denoted US.
The qth face operator deletes the qth set, and the qth degeneracy operator repeats
the qth set in each S. We obtain a simplicial space ÀáC(U ) over B by setting
ÀáC(U )n =
a
S‚ààUn
US.
The face and degeneracy maps are induced by UdiS ‚äÇUS and UsiS = US. While
it would be unreasonable to introduce cellularity conditions, so that ÀáC(U ) is not
Reedy coÔ¨Åbrant, it is obviously proper since Ln ÀáC(U ) is the disjoint union of the

inclusions jUS : US ‚äÇB give a map

j = |j‚Ä¢|: | ÀáC(U )| ‚àí‚ÜíB
on passage to geometric realization; see [45,147].

(jn!, j‚àó

22.6. The twisted Rothenberg‚ÄìSteenrod spectral sequence
We construct a twisted Rothenberg‚ÄìSteenrod spectral sequence in this section.
A version of it has been used by Douglas [52] to calculate the twisted K-theory of
simply connected simple Lie groups.
We return to the context of ¬ß22.1, except that we take G to be the trivial
group.
As there, we let Œ† be any (locally compact and well-based) topological
group, and we let k be a Œ†-spectrum indexed on a Œ†-trivial universe. As in ¬ß22.2,
we are thinking of a prespectrum k together with a map of topological monoids
Œ† ‚àí‚ÜíAut(k). We again assume that k is an excellent prespectrum, for deÔ¨Åniteness
of context. In particular, k is a well-grounded ‚Ñ¶-prespectrum.
Let Œõ be a (locally compact and well-based) topological group and Œ±: Œõ ‚àí‚ÜíŒ†
be a homomorphism of topological groups. Its classifying map BŒ±: BŒõ ‚àí‚ÜíBŒ†
will play the role here that p: X ‚àí‚ÜíBŒ† played in ¬ß22.1.
We are thinking of
Œ† as Ô¨Åxed and canonical and Œõ as varying. We assume familiarity with the bar
construction B(Y, Œõ, X), where Y is a right Œõ-space and X is a left Œõ-space. It is
deÔ¨Åned and studied in [111, ¬ß7]. We shall only use the case Y = ‚àóin this section,
and we abbreviate notation to B(Œõ, X). This space is the geometric realization of
a simplicial space B‚Ä¢(Œõ, X) whose space of q-simplices is Œõq √ó X. The last face
operator is determined by the action of Œõ on X. We then have
BŒõ = B(Œõ, ‚àó),
EŒõ = B(Œõ, Œõ) and B(Œõ, X) ‚àº= EŒõ √óŒõ X.
Moreover, by [111, 7.8], we have the following pullback diagram, where X is a left

We may think of k as a Œõ-spectrum by pullback along Œ±. We could view Œõq √ók

the latching maps are cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations.

Remark 22.6.5. At least when k is a symmetric or orthogonal ring spectrum,
the spectral sequence is multiplicative, as we see from the commutation of the bar
construction with products; see [111, 7.4] or (23.4.2) below. We omit the details.
Remark 22.6.6. Let G be a simply connected simple Lie group and let Œõ = ‚Ñ¶G,
regarded as a topological group with product induced pointwise from the product
on G. Then BŒõ is homotopy equivalent to G, and H2(Œõ) ‚àº= Z. When a cohomology
class is represented by a homomorphism
Œ±: Œõ ‚àí‚ÜíPU(H ) ‚âÉK(Z, 2)
of topological groups, the resulting spectral sequence for twisted K-theory takes

p,q = TorK‚àó(‚Ñ¶G)

(K‚àó, KŒ±
‚àó) =‚áíKp+q(G, BŒ±).
Thus the target is the K-theory of G twisted by BŒ±. In that form, the spectral
sequence agrees with the one described and studied calculationally by Douglas [52].
As pointed out to us by Douglas, one approach to representing cohomology classes
by homomorphisms as we require is to view ‚Ñ¶G as a subgroup of the unbased
loop group LG and to use the work of Pressley and Segal [137] to show that LG
has appropriate projective representations and therefore group homomorphisms
LG ‚àí‚ÜíPU(H ). We have not checked details.
22.7. The parametrized K¬®unneth spectral sequence
We use parametrized spectra to give a quick conceptual construction of Eilen-
berg-Moore type spectral sequences.
We only give the basic formal properties
here. Use of parametrized spectra substantially simpliÔ¨Åes the geometric (as opposed
to chain level) construction of the spectral sequence. Surprisingly, this also has
the eÔ¨Äects of recasting the convergence and ‚Äúrelevance‚Äù questions, which appear
in diÔ¨Äerent guises than in some other geometric constructions, and clarifying the
identiÔ¨Åcation of E2. This approach deserves further study since the literature on
the Eilenberg-Moore spectral sequence is still in a quite unsatisfactory state.
Throughout, we Ô¨Åx a map f : B ‚àí‚ÜíA of base spaces.
The only case we
know to be important and useful is that of f = r: B ‚àí‚Üí‚àó, but the general case
adds no diÔ¨Éculty. We Ô¨Åx a spectrum k over A, using the notation k because we
have the case A = ‚àóin mind, and we let J = f ‚àók be the resulting spectrum
over B.
The essential idea is to use a K¬®unneth theorem for the homology or
cohomology theory represented by k on spectra over A to derive a parametrized
K¬®unneth theorem for the homology or cohomology theory represented by J on
spectra over B. To that end, we consider variable spectra X and Y over B. For
homotopical control, we can work with excellent prespectra or with Ô¨Åbrant and
coÔ¨Åbrant spectra. Formally, we are working in one of our two equivalent versions of
the parametrized stable homotopy categories of spectra over A and B. Recall that
this category is triangulated. With these notations, Proposition 20.2.6(ii) and the
projection formula (both originally stated with the roles of A and B reversed) give
(22.7.1)
J‚àó(X ‚àßB Y ) ‚àº= k‚àó(f!(X ‚àßB Y )) and J‚àó(X ‚àßB Y ) ‚àº= k‚àó(f!(X ‚àßB Y ))
(22.7.2)
J‚àó(f ‚àóf!X ‚àßB Y ) ‚àº= k‚àó(f!(f ‚àóf!X ‚àßA Y )) ‚àº= k‚àó(f!X ‚àßA f!Y )
(22.7.3)
J‚àó(f ‚àóf!X ‚àßB Y ) ‚àº= k‚àó(f!(f ‚àóf!X ‚àßB Y )) ‚àº= k‚àó(f!X ‚àßA f!Y ).

than decreasing positive indices, since that better Ô¨Åts the relevant grading, but the
opposite choice works equally well mathematically.

conditions hold is desirable, but we will not consider such issues here.

390
22. TWISTED THEORIES AND SPECTRAL SEQUENCES
Remark 22.7.5. In some approaches to the Eilenberg-Moore spectral sequence,
the convergence problem appears more as a problem of relevance than of conver-
gence. That is, even when the spectral sequence converges strongly, it need not
converge to the groups that one wants to compute.
We next identify the E2-term in the cohomological spectral sequence. We focus
on cohomology only because we do not want to assume familiarity with cotensor
products, but it is standard that the identiÔ¨Åcation works more generally in homol-
ogy. For example, this is where Ô¨Ånite type hypotheses enter in ordinary cohomology,
although they are not required in ordinary homology. We need a few observations.
Lemma 22.7.6. Let k be a commutative ring spectrum in Ho SA. Then k‚àó(SA)
is a graded ring and k‚àóis a lax monoidal functor from Ho SA to the category of
k‚àó(SA)-modules.
Proof. For spectra W and Z over A we have natural pairings
[Sn
A, W]A ‚äó[Sm
A , Z]A ‚àí‚Üí[Sn+m
A
, W ‚àßA Z]A
and
FA(W, k) ‚àßA FA(Z, k) ‚àí‚ÜíFA(W ‚àßA Z, k ‚àßA k) ‚àí‚ÜíFA(W ‚àßA Z, k).
Since kn(W) = [S‚àín
A , FA(W, k)]A, it follows that k‚àóis lax monoidal when considered
as taking values in graded Abelian groups. The statement follows since the objects
of Ho SA are SA-modules.
‚ñ°
Returning to spectra over B we have the following observation.
Lemma 22.7.7. For a spectrum X over B, f!X is a comodule over the coalgebra
f!SB. For a commutative ring spectrum k in Ho SA, the k‚àó(SA)-module k‚àó(f!X)
is a module over the k‚àó(SA)-algebra k‚àó(f!SB).
Proof. This follows from the unit equivalences X ‚âÉX‚àßBSB together with the
facts that f! is op-lax monoidal (since f ‚àóis monoidal) and k‚àóis lax monoidal.

k‚àó(W) ‚äók‚àó(SA) k‚àó(Z) ‚àí‚Üík‚àó(W ‚àßA Z)
is an isomorphism.
We can now identity the E2-term.

Remark 22.7.11. The construction we started with is analogous to the canon-
ical resolution used in the construction of the Adams spectral sequence. As in that
context, we can develop a general theory of resolutions. To prove that the spec-
tral sequence is multiplicative, we can form the smash products of resolutions and
prove that they are again resolutions. We omit the details here, but we recommend
Bruner‚Äôs treatment of the products in the Adams spectral sequence, [27, IV¬ß4], for
details that can be adapted to our context. The axiomatization of a compatibly
triangulated symmetric monoidal category that we described in ¬ß16.7 and ¬ß17.5,
especially (TC3) and (TC4), encodes common features of the two situations.
Remark 22.7.12. Taking f to be r: B ‚àí‚Üí‚àó, k = HF to be the Eilenberg-
Mac Lane spectrum for a Ô¨Åeld F, and passing to unreduced cohomology, we obtain
a version of the classical Eilenberg-Moore spectral sequence. In detail, let (K, p)
and (L, q) be spaces over B, where q, say, is a Ô¨Åbration. Let (P, œÄ) be the pullback
K √óB L over B. Then
(K, p)+ ‚àßB (L, q)+ ‚àº= (P, œÄ)+
as ex-spaces over B. Applying Œ£‚àû
B and using Proposition 13.7.5, this gives
Œ£‚àû
B (K, p)+ ‚àßB Œ£‚àû
B (L, q)+ ‚àº= Œ£‚àû
B (P, œÄ)+

392
22. TWISTED THEORIES AND SPECTRAL SEQUENCES
as spectra over B.
Applying r! to this, we obtain Œ£‚àûP+.
Assuming that the
cohomologies of the given spaces are of Ô¨Ånite type, so that we have a K¬®unneth
isomorphism in cohomology, our spectral sequence takes the expected form
Ep,q
2
= Torp,q
H‚àó(B,F)(H‚àó(K, F), H‚àó(L, F)) =‚áíH‚àó(P, F).
This may appear too strong to be plausible since we have made no connectivity
or nilpotence assumptions.
With this approach, these can only be relevant to
determining when the colimit that enters into our convergence statement is zero.
A similar remark applies when k is a Morava K-theory spectrum.
We close with a few comments on the literature.
Remark 22.7.13. The original chain level construction of Eilenberg and Moore
[59] (see also [71]) gives a spectral sequence that, in the case of ordinary homol-
ogy and cohomology, looks formally the same as the ones later constructed more
geometrically, but there is no proof in the literature that these diÔ¨Äerent construc-
tions give isomorphic spectral sequences. Each type of construction has its advan-
tages. For example, with geometric constructions it is clear how to put Steenrod
operations in the spectral sequence, as was Ô¨Årst done by Rector [140].
On the
other hand, the chain level construction is essential to the calculational results
of [71, 126], for example.
The proofs of convergence with the various construc-
tions vary considerably.
Comparisons among them are needed.
Comparison of
Remark 22.7.12 with known convergence results for ordinary cohomology under
nilpotency conditions suggests that there are real diÔ¨Äerences. The geometric con-
structions in the literature focus on cosimplicial spaces, parametrized spaces, or a
blend of the two, and there is an extensive literature. An incomplete list would
include [53,54,74,85,140,149,151,153,154,163]. For non-nilpotent situations and
non-connective generalized theories, there are a number of partial results and some
illuminating counterexamples, but the complete picture is still quite unclear.

CHAPTER 23
Parametrized FSP‚Äôs and generalized Thom spectra
Introduction
Because the passage from spherical Ô¨Åbrations to their Thom complexes is an ap-
plication of the functor r!, Thom spaces and Thom spectra are intrinsically part of
parametrized homotopy theory. In this chapter, we reinterpret standard construc-
tions in a parametrized way and use the new point of view to construct a variety
of new commutative orthogonal ring spectra that are of the same general type as
Thom spectra. We recall from [105] that commutative orthogonal ring spectra are
equivalent to commutative S-algebras in the sense of [61] and therefore to E‚àûring
spectra.
The constructions are simple and conceptual. Commutative orthogonal ring
spectra are equivalent to commutative I -FSP‚Äôs, where FSP stands for ‚Äúfunctor
with smash product‚Äù. We have already used these in the non-commutative case in
¬ß22.2, but in this chapter we focus on the commutative case. The FSP structure is
deÔ¨Åned with respect to the external smash product, and its internalization is the
product of the associated orthogonal ring spectrum. There is an analogous notion
of an I -FCP, where FCP stands for ‚Äúfunctor with cartesian product‚Äù, which is
deÔ¨Åned in terms of cartesian products rather than smash products. We shall deÔ¨Åne
the new notion of a parametrized I -FSP, to be abbreviated I -PFSP.
In fact, as we will carry further elsewhere, these constructions are the specializa-
tion to the domain category I of diagram objects that can be deÔ¨Åned starting from
various other domain categories D, notably the domain category Œ£ for symmetric
sequences (or collections). Since we shall focus primarily on I , we shall gener-
ally omit I from the notation, writing FCP, FSP, and PFSP instead of I -FCP,
I -FSP, or I -PFSP.
Our PFSP‚Äôs are functors that take values in the symmetric monoidal category
UU of retracts that we deÔ¨Åned in ¬ß2.5. Passage to base spaces gives a forgetful func-
tor from PFSP‚Äôs to FCP‚Äôs, and application of r! gives a ‚ÄúThom spectrum functor‚Äù
from PFSP‚Äôs to FSP‚Äôs. The deÔ¨Ånition of a PFSP codiÔ¨Åes and generalizes familiar
structure that we see in nature. For example, consider the Ô¨Åberwise one-point com-
pactiÔ¨Åcation of a good model EO(V ) √óO(V ) V for the universal vector bundle over
BO(V ), where O(V ) is the orthogonal group of an inner product space V . This
construction gives a functor, RO say, from our category I of Ô¨Ånite dimensional
inner product spaces to the cited category of retracts. The direct sum pairing
O(V ) √ó O(W) ‚àí‚ÜíO(V ‚äïW)
passes to classifying spaces, where it gives the map
BO(V ) √ó BO(W) ‚àí‚ÜíBO(V ‚äïW)
393

394
23. PARAMETRIZED FSP‚ÄôS AND GENERALIZED THOM SPECTRA
on base spaces of a pairing
¬µ: RO(V ) ‚äºRO(W) ‚àí‚ÜíRO(V ‚äïW)
in the category of retracts. The Ô¨Åbers over the basepoints of the BO(V ) give maps
Œ∑: SV ‚àí‚ÜíRO(V ). The spaces r!RO(V ) are the Thom spaces TO(V ). Together
with the induced external pairing
TO(V ) ‚àßTO(W) ‚àí‚ÜíTO(V ‚äïW)
and unit map SV ‚àí‚ÜíTO(V ), they specify the Thom spectrum MO as an FSP.
The internalization of the pairing gives the product MO ‚àßMO ‚àí‚ÜíMO of the
orthogonal ring spectrum MO. The triple (RO, ¬µ, Œ∑) is an example of a PFSP.
Our generalization of this familiar structure leads to the promised new way of
constructing commutative orthogonal ring spectra. In fact, the construction works
more generally to construct commutative algebras over a commutative orthogonal
ring spectrum R. The starting point is then the notion of an R-PFSP. With this
notion, passage to base spaces still gives an FCP, but application of r! now gives
an R-FSP, which is the external equivalent of a commutative R-algebra.
We shall use the two-sided bar construction to show how to construct many ex-
amples of R-PFSP‚Äôs. Conceptually, the procedure is analogous to the construction
of twisted theories in the previous chapter. Instead of starting with a group Œ†, we
start with a group-valued or monoid-valued FCP Œ†. We replace the bundle con-
struction EŒ† √óŒ† (‚àí) with a parametrized two-sided bar construction B(‚àí, Œ†, ‚àí).
We abbreviate this to B(Œ†, ‚àí) when the Ô¨Årst variable is trivial, and we obtain a
family of universal principal bundles EŒ† = B(Œ†, Œ†). When Œ† acts on the left on
a FCP Y , we obtain a family B(Œ†, Y ) = EŒ† √óŒ† Y of associated bundles given by
the Borel construction. The analogy should be clear.
In the last two sections, we switch gears. In the theory above, we never pass
to colimits on the base space level but rather focus on a Ô¨Åxed base FCP. We
end the chapter with the bare beginnings of a study of the relationship between
parametrized theory and colimits of base spaces. In particular, we show how Thom
prespectra of maps X ‚àí‚ÜíBF can be interpreted conceptually as a construction in
parametrized homotopy theory. This too will be carried further elsewhere, in joint
work with Andrew Blumberg.
We work nonequivariantly, for simplicity, but the constructions of this chapter
apply verbatim equivariantly. We describe diagram functors with products in full
categorical generality in ¬ß23.1, and we specialize topologically to deÔ¨Åne FCP‚Äôs, R-
FSP‚Äôs, and R-PFSP‚Äôs in ¬ß23.2. We deÔ¨Åne group, monoid, and module FCP‚Äôs in
¬ß23.3. As an interesting example, we observe that an FSP R gives rise to an FCP
of units GL1(R) and an FCP of special units SL1(R).
We deÔ¨Åne the two-sided bar construction in the category of FCP‚Äôs in ¬ß23.4 and
show how to construct examples of R-FSP‚Äôs by replacing the righthand variable
FCP in B(‚àí, Œ†, ‚àí) by an FSP R. When R is the sphere FSP, the classical Thom
spectra appear as special cases, but now these themselves can sometimes be used in
place of R, as we show in ¬ß23.5. In particular, we construct iterated Thom spectra
such as M qU, starting with M 0U = S and M 1U = MU; M qU is a commutative
M q‚àí1U algebra. This is a tantalizing construction, but we have barely begun the
study of these new commutative algebras.
Switching to the consideration of colimits, we recall how I -FCP‚Äôs give rise
to spaces with actions by the linear isometries operad L and thus to E‚àûspaces

23.1. D-FUNCTORS WITH PRODUCTS IN SYMMETRIC MONOIDAL CATEGORIES
395
and therefore spectra in ¬ß23.6. We also comment on the analogous inÔ¨Ånite loop
space theory starting from Œ£-FCP‚Äôs. We show in ¬ß23.7 that parametrized methods
simplify the construction of Thom prespectra of maps. The point is to construct a
universal spherical Ô¨Åbration prespectrum Sph(F) over BF. The Thom prespectrum
of a map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíBF is then just r!f ‚àóSph(F). The original deÔ¨Ånition is due to
Mahowald [101], and such Thom spectra were Ô¨Årst studied in detail by Lewis [94,98].
We leave the relationship between this construction of Thom prespectra of maps
and the theory of E‚àûring spectra to work in progress of Blumberg and the authors.
Some of our constructions are spelled out in more detail but under diÔ¨Äerent
names in [112], and a good deal of related work has taken place in the intervening
thirty years. We give a dictionary and some historical background in ¬ß23.8.
Aside from basic deÔ¨Ånitions, this chapter is almost completely independent of
everything that has come before in this book. In particular, we make no mention of
model structures, and parametrized spectra only appear in ¬ß23.7. Our focus is on
the use of parametrized methods to construct new non-parametrized objects, and
the passage from the point-set level to homotopy categories is routine.
23.1. D-functors with products in symmetric monoidal categories
It seems best to start oÔ¨Äin complete generality. The material to follow was
Ô¨Årst considered categorically by Day [43]. We follow the treatment of [106, ¬ß¬ß1,
22], which gives details in the context of topological diagram spectra. We let V be
a cocomplete symmetric monoidal category and let C be a V -enriched cocomplete
symmetric monoidal category, where cocompleteness and the symmetric monoidal
structure are understood in the enriched sense.
We write ‚äó, I, and œÑ for the
product, unit object, and commutativity isomorphism in both C and V . In some
cases C = V , but not in the new case that we are most interested in, where V = U
and C = UU . We let D be a skeletally small symmetric monoidal category enriched
over V , and we write ‚äï, 0, and œÑ for its product, unit object, and commutativity
isomorphism.
Definition 23.1.1. A D-object is a V -functor X : D ‚àí‚ÜíC . A map of D-
objects is a V -natural transformation between them. Let D[C ] be the category of
D-objects in C .
Henceforward, we take the enrichment for granted. When V is U or T , this
just means that we consider only continuous functors and natural transformations.
Definition 23.1.2. A lax monoidal functor D ‚àí‚ÜíC is called a D-functor
with products, or D-FP. A lax symmetric monoidal functor D ‚àí‚ÜíC is called a
commutative D-functor with products.
A strong symmetric monoidal functor is
said to be a spherical (or idempotent) D-FP.
Thus, for a D-FP R, we are given a unit map Œª: I ‚àí‚ÜíR(0) and product maps
œÜ: R(d) ‚äóR(e) ‚àí‚ÜíR(d ‚äïe) such that appropriate diagrams (as in the case A = R
and Œ∑ = id of DeÔ¨Ånition 23.1.5 below) commute. If R is spherical, Œª and œÜ are
isomorphisms. Spherical D-FP‚Äôs are not unique, but there is usually an obvious
preferred choice, which will be denoted SD and made explicit in the examples.
Implicitly, the deÔ¨Ånition above uses an external product of diagram objects.

396
23. PARAMETRIZED FSP‚ÄôS AND GENERALIZED THOM SPECTRA
Definition 23.1.3. The external product of D-objects X and Y is the evident
D √ó D-object X ¬Ø‚äóY given on objects d and e of D by
(X ¬Ø‚äóY )(d, e) = X(d) ‚äóY (e).
This product is unital, associative, and commutative in the sense that the symmetric
monoidal structure of C induces coherent natural isomorphisms
X(d)¬Ø‚äóI ‚àº= X(d) ‚àº= I ¬Ø‚äóX(d),
(X ¬Ø‚äóY )¬Ø‚äóZ ‚àº= X ¬Ø‚äó(Y ¬Ø‚äóZ),
and
X ¬Ø‚äóY ‚àº= Y ¬Ø‚äóX,
where the second and third are isomorphisms of (D √óD √óD)-objects and (D √óD)-
objects, respectively.
Conceptually, this gives part of the stucture of a graded symmetric monoidal
category on ` Di[C ]; here D0 is the trivial category, the unit object I lives in
C = D0[C ], and the Ô¨Årst isomorphism above is one of D-objects.
Since we have assumed that C is cocomplete, we can use left Kan extension to
internalize the product ¬Ø‚äóto obtain a product ‚äóon D[C ] such that
D(X ‚äóY, Z) ‚àº= (D √ó D)[V ](X ¬Ø‚äóY, Z ‚ó¶‚äï).
The category D[C ] is symmetric monoidal with unit the represented object 0‚àó
speciÔ¨Åed by 0‚àó= D(0, ‚àí), and the concepts in DeÔ¨Ånition 23.1.2 internalize as
follows.
Proposition 23.1.4. The category of D-FP‚Äôs is equivalent to the category of
monoids in D[C ]. The category of commutative D-FP‚Äôs is equivalent to the category
of commutative monoids in D[C ].
Thinking of a commutative monoid R in a symmetric monoidal category as
an analogue of a commutative ring, the analogue of an R-algebra is an R-monoid
A, that is, a monoid A together with a central map of monoids Œ∑: R ‚àí‚ÜíA. The
unit of A is then the composite Œ∑ ‚ó¶Œª. We spell out the external equivalent in the
following deÔ¨Ånition.
Definition 23.1.5. Let R be a commutative D-FP. A D-functor with products
over R, abbreviated R-D-FP, is a D-object A together with a unit map Œ∑ : R ‚àí‚ÜíA
of D-objects and a product map ¬µ : A ‚äºA ‚àí‚ÜíA ‚ó¶‚äïof D √ó D-objects such that
the composite

Proposition 23.1.6. The category of R-monoids in D[C ] is equivalent to the
category of D-FP‚Äôs over R. The category of commutative R-monoids in D[C ] is
equivalent to the category of commutative D-FP‚Äôs over R.
For monoids R and for R-monoids A (R commutative) in symmetric monoidal
categories, we have the evident notions of (left or right) R-modules and of A-
modules, and these too have evident external analogues in the case of our diagram
categories D[C ].
23.2. The specialization of D-FP‚Äôs to spaces and ex-spaces
We now let V be either U with its cartesian monoidal structure or T with its
monoidal structure under ‚àß, but otherwise we retain the notations of the previous
section. As usual, when our given D is U -enriched but we are considering functors
into a T -enriched target category C , we implicitly add disjoint basepoints to enrich
D over T .
First we take C = V = U and let ‚àóbe the terminal D-FP, which of course is
spherical.
Definition 23.2.1. A D-FCP is a D-FP over ‚àó(or ‚àó-D-FP) in U .
Remark 23.2.2. A D-FCP R = (R, œâ, Œª) necessarily takes values in T . The
basepoint of R(d) is given by the unit map Œª: ‚àó‚àí‚ÜíR, and the unit condition says
that œâ(x, ‚àó) = x in R(d ‚äï0) ‚àº= R(d) for x in R(d) and ‚àóin R(0). In fact, a D-FCP
is exactly the same structure as a D-FP in T . From the latter point of view, the
given basepoints prescribe the unit map Œª.
We now take C = V = T and let SD be a chosen sphere D-FP associated to
D. There is usually a standard choice.
Definition 23.2.3. A D-FSP is a D-FP over SD (or SD-D-FP) in T . For a
commutative D-FSP R, a D-FSP over R, or R-D-FSP, is a D-FP over R in T .

398
23. PARAMETRIZED FSP‚ÄôS AND GENERALIZED THOM SPECTRA
Suitable choices of D for constructing stable categories of spectra are discussed
in detail in [106]. The internalized versions of R-FSP‚Äôs are then called R-algebras.
We focus on I , with its standard sphere FP SI ; thus SI (V ) = SV . Another im-
portant choice is Œ£, the category with objects the natural numbers and morphisms
the symmetric groups viewed as automorphism groups Œ£n : n ‚àí‚Üín; its standard
sphere FP SŒ£ has values the Œ£n-spaces Sn. In these cases, a D-spectrum is deÔ¨Åned
to be a right SD-module. An SD-algebra (R, ¬µ, Œ∑) is a right SD-module via the
composite
R ‚àßSD
id‚àßŒ∑ /R ‚àßR
¬µ
/R,
and these are the orthogonal and symmetric ring spectra.
We can deÔ¨Åne analogous parametrized orthogonal ring spectra, but, as noted in
¬ß14.1, we would not have homotopical control over that notion. However, allowing
varying base spaces and using external smash products (in the sense of allowing
products of base spaces), we obtain a useful notion over which we do have homo-
topical control. To specify this notion, we take V = U and we take C to be the
category of retracts UU , viewed as symmetric monoidal with unit S0
‚àóunder the
external smash product ‚äº. The following deÔ¨Ånitions work just as well for D = Œ£
as for D = I ; we delete D from the notation but allow either choice, continuing
to use the letters d and e for typical objects of D. Recall that, for any B, UB is
embedded in UU . In particular T = U‚àóis embedded as a symmetric monoidal
subcategory of UU ; we write ‚äºrather than ‚àßfor its smash product.
Definition 23.2.4. Let R be a (nonparametrized) commutative FSP. A PFSP

Definition 23.2.5. A parametrized FSP, or PFSP, is an S-PFSP in UU , and
similarly for commutative PFSP‚Äôs.
With the evident morphisms, we have categories of all objects that we have
deÔ¨Åned, and the following three results are immediate from the deÔ¨Ånitions.
Proposition 23.2.6. Passage to base spaces deÔ¨Ånes a forgetful functor from
the category of R-PFSP‚Äôs to the category of FCP‚Äôs.
Proposition 23.2.7. The Ô¨Åbers A(d)‚àóover the unit basepoints ‚àó‚ààB(d) inherit
a structure of FSP from A, and A‚àóis an R-FSP via Œ∑. This gives a Ô¨Åber functor
from the category of R-PFSP‚Äôs to the category of R-FSP‚Äôs.
In practice, Œ∑: R ‚àí‚ÜíA‚àóis often an isomorphism.
Theorem 23.2.8. Application of r! to all ex-spaces deÔ¨Ånes a Thom spectrum
functor from the category of R-PFSP‚Äôs to the category of R-FSP‚Äôs.
Proof. The D-space r!A is given by (r!A)(d) = r!(A(d)) = A(d)/sB(d). The
functoriality on D is evident. The required unit Œ∑ and product ¬µ are induced from
those of A. For Œ∑, notice that A‚àó‚äÇr!A. For ¬µ, notice that
r!(A(d)) ‚àßr!(A(e)) ‚àº= (r √ó r)!(A(d) ‚äºA(e)) = r!(A(d) ‚äºA(e)).

23.3. Group, monoid, and module FCP‚Äôs; examples
Let FCP[U ] denote the category of I -FCP‚Äôs. We describe groups, monoids,
and modules in this category and give various examples. In all of our examples,
the underlying FCP is commutative, and we will not reiterate this point. In this
section and the next, the basic deÔ¨Ånitions apply equally well with I replaced by
Œ£, but we focus attention on I for speciÔ¨Åcity.

400
23. PARAMETRIZED FSP‚ÄôS AND GENERALIZED THOM SPECTRA
Lemma 23.3.1. The category FCP[U ] has products. The product of FCP‚Äôs
(B, ŒΩ) and (C, œâ) is (B √ó C, ŒΩ √ó œâ), where (B √ó C)(V ) = B(V ) √ó C(V ) and where
(ŒΩ √ó œâ)(V, W) is the composite
B(V ) √ó C(V ) √ó B(W) √ó C(W)
id√ót√óid

B(V ) √ó C(W) √ó B(V ) √ó C(W)
ŒΩ√óœâ

B(V ‚äïW) √ó C(V ‚äïW).
Definition 23.3.2. A monoid (or group) FCP is a monoid (or group) (Œ†, œâ)
in the cartesian monoidal category FCP[U ]. Thus Œ† is a monoid-valued functor
such that the following diagrams commute.
(23.3.3)
Œ†(V ) √ó Œ†(V ) √ó Œ†(W) √ó Œ†(W)
prod√óprod /
id√ót√óid

A right Œ†-FCP (D, ŒΩ) is a right Œ†-module in FCP[U ]; this means that there are
right actions D(V ) √ó Œ†(V ) ‚àí‚ÜíD(V ) such that the evident analogue of (23.3.3)
commutes. Left Œ†-FCP‚Äôs are deÔ¨Åned similarly.
We recall some examples. For a based space X, let F(X) be the monoid of
based homotopy equivalences X ‚àí‚ÜíX, let SF(X) be the submonoid of maps ho-
motopic to the identity map of X, let Top(X) be the subgroup of F(X) consisting
of the based homeomorphisms, and let STop(X) be the subgroup of based homeo-
morphisms in SF(X). Letting X run through the spheres SV , we obtain monoid
FCP‚Äôs F and SF and group FCP‚Äôs Top and STop. On F, the pairing
œâ: F(V ) √ó F(W) ‚àí‚ÜíF(V ‚äïW)
is obtained by identifying SV ‚äïW with SV ‚àßSW and taking the smash product of
homotopy equivalences. It restricts to give œâ on SF, Top, and STop. Restricting
further to linear isometries and linear isometries of determinant 1, we obtain group
FCP‚Äôs O and SO. Using complex inner product spaces rather than real ones, we
obtain group FCP‚Äôs U and SU. In all cases, we must not confuse these monoid-
valued FCP‚Äôs, which are functors and have external pairings, with the monoids of
the same names that are obtained by taking colimits over V and have composition
products that make no reference to the external pairings; compare Remark 22.2.6.
Remark 23.3.4. It seems preferable to think in terms of the theory of ‚Äúunitary
spectra‚Äù, the reworking of the theory of orthogonal spectra from the starting point
of complex inner product spaces, rather than to think in terms of functors deÔ¨Åned
on real inner product spaces by Ô¨Årst complexifying. That is, we think in terms of
realiÔ¨Åcation U(n) ‚àí‚ÜíSO(2n) rather than complexiÔ¨Åcation O(n) ‚àí‚ÜíU(n). Using

23.3. GROUP, MONOID, AND MODULE FCP‚ÄôS; EXAMPLES
401
their underlying real inner products, the complex inner product spaces embed in
the real ones. Then ‚Äúchange of universe‚Äù, as in ¬ß14.2, shows that the two choices
give canonically equivalent homotopy categories of spectra.
There are further classical examples Spin and Spinc, and a newer example
String, which can be made as precise as we need using the construction in [7].
As explained in [112, Ch. I], which gives more details, all of the usual classical
homogeneous spaces Œ†/Œ†‚Ä≤, deÔ¨Åned in terms of right cosets, are right Œ†-module
FCP‚Äôs.
We end this section by showing how a commutative FSP R gives rise to a unit
right F-module GL1(R).
Definition 23.3.5. For an I -space T, let Œõ(T) be the induced I -space such
that Œõ(T)(V ) = ‚Ñ¶V T(V ). The evaluation maps of the functor Œõ(T) are the maps
I (V, W) √ó ‚Ñ¶V T(V ) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶W T(W)
that send (Œ±, f) to the composite
SW
Œ±‚àí1 /SV
f
/T(V )
T (Œ±) /T(W).
Since F(V ) is the space of homotopy equivalences SV ‚àí‚ÜíSV and ‚Ñ¶V T(V ) is the
space of maps SV ‚àí‚ÜíT(V ), composition gives a right action of the monoid F(V )
on the space Œõ(T)(V ).
To avoid confusion in the following example, recall Remark 22.2.5.
Proposition 23.3.6. Let R be a commutative FSP whose underlying orthogonal
spectrum is positive Ô¨Åbrant and satisÔ¨Åes R0 = S0. Then Œõ(R) restricts to a right
F-module GL1(R) of units and a right SF-module SL1(R) of special units.
Proof. The homotopy group œÄ0(R) is a commutative ring and, since R is
positive Ô¨Åbrant, we may use the adjoint structural equivalences to identify œÄ0(R)
with œÄ0(‚Ñ¶V R(V )) for all V of positive dimension.
We let GL1(R)(0) = 1 and
let GL1(R)(V ) be the subspace of ‚Ñ¶V R(V ) consisting of the components of the
units in œÄ0(R); we let SL1(R)(V ) be the component of the identity element. Since
the points of F(V ) are homotopy equivalences of SV and the points of SF(V ) are
homotopic to the identity, our action map restricts to give a right action of F(V )
on GL1(R)(V ) and a right action of SF(V ) on SL1(R)(V ). Moreover, the product
¬µ on R gives rise to pairings
œâ: ‚Ñ¶V R(V ) √ó ‚Ñ¶W R(W) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶V ‚äïW R(V ‚äïW).
For f : SV ‚àí‚ÜíR(V ) and g: SW ‚àí‚ÜíR(W), œâ(f, g) is the composite
SV ‚äïW ‚àº= SV ‚àßSW
f‚àßg /R(V ) ‚àßR(W)
¬µ
/R(V ‚äïW).
Considering homotopy groups, we see that these maps restrict to pairings that give
FCP‚Äôs (GL1(R), œâ) and (SL1(R), œâ). The required commutativity of the module
analogue of the diagram (23.3.3) is clear by inspection.
‚ñ°

402
23. PARAMETRIZED FSP‚ÄôS AND GENERALIZED THOM SPECTRA
23.4. The two-sided bar construction on FCP‚Äôs
The following old observation, which is [112, I.2.2], is central to the new con-
structions in this chapter.
Proposition 23.4.1. If Œ† is an FCP, D is a right Œ†-FCP, and E is a left
Œ†-FCP, then B(D, Œ†, E) is a FCP. It is commutative if its inputs D, Œ†, and E are
all commutative (that is, commutative as FCP‚Äôs).
The deÔ¨Ånition and properties of the two-sided bar construction are discussed
in [111, ¬ß7], and we are taking
B(D, Œ†, E)(V ) = B(D(V ), Œ†(V ), E(V )).
Since the two-sided bar construction preserves products, in the sense that
(23.4.2)
B(D, Œ†, E) √ó B(D‚Ä≤, Œ†‚Ä≤, E‚Ä≤) ‚àº= B(D √ó D‚Ä≤, Œ† √ó Œ†‚Ä≤, E √ó E‚Ä≤)
for monoids Œ† and Œ†‚Ä≤ acting from the right on D and D‚Ä≤ and from the left on E
and E‚Ä≤, it is clear that the space B(D, Œ†, E) inherits a product œâ from those of D,
Œ†, and E.
Notations 23.4.3. When D = ‚àóis constant at a point, we abbreviate B(‚àó, Œ†, E)
to B(Œ†, E). Similarly, at the price of a little ambiguity, we abbreviate B(D, Œ†, ‚àó)
to B(D, Œ†) and B(‚àó, Œ†, ‚àó) to BŒ†.
We see considerable resemblence between FCP‚Äôs and orthogonal spectra. We
now show how to to exploit the comparison. We replace the input Œ†-FCP E of the
two-sided bar construction B(D, Œ†, E) with a Œ†-FSP R and we obtain as output
an R-FSP with base FCP B(D, Œ†). We need an observation and a deÔ¨Ånition before
we can implement this idea.
Lemma 23.4.4. Let Œõ and Œ† be topological monoids that act through based maps
on based spaces X and Y . Then the formula
(Œ±, Œ≤)(x ‚àßy) = (Œ±x) ‚àß(Œ≤y)
for Œ± ‚ààŒõ, Œ≤ ‚ààŒ†, x ‚ààX, and y ‚ààY gives an action of Œõ √ó Œ† on X ‚àßY .
We assume from now on in this section that Œ† is a monoid FCP together with a
map Œ† ‚àí‚ÜíF of monoid FCP‚Äôs. We say that Œ† is a monoid mapping to F. Since F
acts from the left on the sphere FCP S via the evaluation maps F(V )√óSV ‚àí‚ÜíSV ,
this ensures that Œ† acts on S.
Definition 23.4.5. Let (Œ†, œâ) be a monoid FCP mapping to F. A left action
of Œ† on an orthogonal spectrum X, is a left action of Œ† on the underlying I -space
X such that the following diagrams commute.
(23.4.6)
Œ†(V ) √ó Œ†(W) √ó (X(V ) ‚àßSW )
action

A left action of Œ† on an FSP R is a left action of Œ† on the I -space R such that
the following diagrams commute.
(23.4.7)
