Observe that (23.4.7) and (23.4.8) imply (23.4.6), so that R is a Œ†-spectrum with
additional structure.
Theorem 23.4.9. Let Œ† be a monoid FCP mapping to F, let D be a right
Œ†-FCP, and let R be a commutative left Œ†-FSP. Assume that Œ† and D are com-
mutative as FCP‚Äôs. Then B(D, Œ†, R) is a commutative R-PFSP with base FCP
B(D, Œ†). Therefore r!B(D, Œ†, R) is a commutative R-algebra.
Proof. We deÔ¨Åne B(D, Œ†, R)(V ) = B(D(V ), Œ†(V ), R(V )).
As in Propo-
sition 23.4.1, B(D, Œ†, R) is an I -space.
The evident maps of Œ†-spaces ‚àó‚àí‚Üí
R(V ) ‚àí‚Üí‚àóinduce projections and sections
B(D, Œ†)(V ) ‚àí‚ÜíB(D, Œ†, R)(V ) ‚àí‚ÜíB(D, Œ†)(V ).
Thus gives a functor I ‚àí‚ÜíUU . The basepoint of D(V ) gives the basepoint of
B(D(V ), Œ†(V )), in the simplicial zero skeleton, and the Ô¨Åber over the basepoint is
R(V ). This gives an identiÔ¨Åcation Œ∑ of R with the Ô¨Åber B(D, Œ†, R)‚àó. Using the
identiÔ¨Åcation (23.4.2), we see that the products ŒΩ on D, œâ on Œ† and ¬µ on R induce
pairings
¬µ: B(D, Œ†, R)(V ) ‚äºB(D, Œ†, R)(W) ‚àí‚ÜíB(D, Œ†, R)(V ‚äïW)
over and under the pairing
œâ: B(D, Œ†)(V ) √ó B(D, Œ†)(W) ‚àí‚ÜíB(D, Œ†)(V ‚äïW)
induced by the given ŒΩ and œâ. The unit, associativity, and commutativity conditions
are all inherited from the input pairings.
This proves the result, with the last
statement following from Theorem 23.2.8.
‚ñ°
23.5. Examples: iterated Thom spectra
Examples of base FCP‚Äôs B(D, Œ†) abound. The case D = ‚àó, written B(Œ†), is
already of obvious interest. A particularly interesting non-trivial choice for D is to
consider a second FSP Q, generally not R, and take D = GL1(Q) when Œ† maps to
F and D = SL1(Q) when Œ† maps to SF; see Example 23.6.5 below. The obvious
choice of R, which works for any Œ† mapping to F, is R = S.
Definition 23.5.1. The classical Thom spectra are the commutative ring spec-
tra MŒ† = r!B(Œ†, S).
The generalized Thom spectra are the commutative ring
spectra M(D, Œ†) = r!B(D, Œ†, S).

404
23. PARAMETRIZED FSP‚ÄôS AND GENERALIZED THOM SPECTRA
We use analogous notation in the general case, but remembering R.
Notation 23.5.2. For a right Œ†-I -FSP D and a left Œ†-I -FSP R, we deÔ¨Åne
M(D, Œ†, R) = r!B(D, Œ†, R).
When D = ‚àó, we omit it from the notation, writing M(Œ†, R).
To give examples, we need to construct actions of Œ† on interesting R. We give
a simple way to do this. Its starting point is the following observation.
Proposition 23.5.3. Let Œ† be a topological group and X and Y be a right and
a left Œ†-space. Then B(X, Œ†, Y ) is naturally a left Œ†-space.
Proof. B(X, Œ†, Y ) is the geometric realization of a simplicial space whose
space of q-simplices is X √ó Œ†q √ó Y [111, p. 31]. Let Œ† act on this space by
Œ± ¬∑ (x, Œ≤1, . . . , Œ≤q, y) = (xŒ±‚àí1, Œ±Œ≤1Œ±‚àí1, . . . , Œ±Œ≤qŒ±‚àí1, Œ±y).
Inspection shows that the action commutes with faces and degeneracies. Since the
geometric realization of a simplicial Œ†-space is a Œ†-space, this proves the result.
More conceptually, we are using that Œ† acts on itself through conjugation and that
left and right actions are suitably equivariant.
‚ñ°
In the remainder of the section, we assume that Œ† is a group FCP with a
map to F. It could be O, SO, U, SU, Top or STop, for example. The notions
of commutative R-FSP and commutative R-algebra are interchangeable, and we
prefer to use the latter term for clarity. We assume that all given FCP‚Äôs and FSP‚Äôs
are commutative in the following results.
Theorem 23.5.4. For a right Œ†-FCP D and a left Œ†-FSP R, M(D, Œ†, R) is
both a Œ†-FSP and a commutative R-algebra.
Proof. We have M(D, Œ†, R)(V ) = r!B(D(V ), Œ†(V ), R(V )), where r! collapses
the section sB(D(V ), Œ†(V )) to a point. Since Œ†(V ) acts trivially on the basepoint
of R(V ), the section is a sub-Œ†(V )-space of the Œ†(V )-space B(D(V ), Œ†(V ), R(V )).
Therefore we have an induced action of Œ†(V ) on the quotient. Using the diagrams
(23.3.3) for Œ†, their analogues for D, and diagrams (23.4.7) and (23.4.8) for R, we
see that diagrams (23.4.7) and (23.4.8) for M(D, Œ†, R) commute. This gives that
M(D, Œ†, R) is a Œ†-FSP, and it is a commutative R-algebra by Theorem 23.4.9.
‚ñ°
Corollary 23.5.5. For any two right Œ†-FCP‚Äôs C and D and any left Œ†-
FSP R, M(C, Œ†, M(D, Œ†, R)) is deÔ¨Åned and is both a Œ†-FSP and a commutative
M(D, Œ†, R)-algebra.
Taking C and D to be trivial and removing them from the notation, we obtain
M(Œ†, R)-algebras M(Œ†, M(Œ†, R)). This allows the following deÔ¨Ånition of iterated
Thom spectra. The case Œ† = U should be of particular interest.
Definition 23.5.6. DeÔ¨Åne M 0Œ† = S and M 1Œ† = MŒ†. Assume inductively
that we have constructed a Œ†-FSP and commutative M q‚àí1Œ†-algebra M qŒ†. DeÔ¨Åne
M q+1Œ† = M(Œ†, M qŒ†). It is a Œ†-FSP and a commutative M qŒ†-algebra.

23.6. Ic-FCP‚ÄôS AND L -SPACES
405
23.6. Ic-FCP‚Äôs and L -spaces
Changing focus, we here recall from [112, I¬ß1] the relationship between I -
FCP‚Äôs and inÔ¨Ånite loop spaces. At the end of the section we brieÔ¨Çy describe the
analogous theory that starts with Œ£-FCP‚Äôs instead of I -FCP‚Äôs.
Let Ic be the symmetric monoidal category of Ô¨Ånite or countably inÔ¨Ånite di-
mensional real inner product spaces and linear isometries, not necessarily isomor-
phisms. We write U = R‚àû. In the equivariant case, we would take U to be a
complete G-universe, so the notation may serve as a reminder that everything can
be done equivariantly. We can take the domain category D to be Ic in our deÔ¨Åni-
tion of an FCP, but it is sensible to add some point-set topological restrictions.
Definition 23.6.1. We deÔ¨Åne Ic-FCP‚Äôs exactly as we deÔ¨Åned I -FCP‚Äôs, but
with the additional requirement that their underlying Ic-spaces T satisfy the fol-
lowing two properties.
(i) The map T(V ) ‚àí‚ÜíT(W) induced by an isometry V ‚àí‚ÜíW is a homeomor-
phism onto a closed subset.
(ii) Each F(W) is the colimit of the F(V ), where V runs over the Ô¨Ånite dimen-
sional subspaces of W and the colimit system runs over the inclusions V ‚äÇV ‚Ä≤.
We emphasize that the colimit runs only over the inclusions, not over all linear
isometries. With this modiÔ¨Åed deÔ¨Ånition, we have the following result from [112,
1.9]. Observe that the inclusion I ‚àí‚ÜíIc induces a forgetful functor from the
category Ic-FCP[U ] of Ic-FCP‚Äôs to the category I -FCP[U ] of I -FCP‚Äôs.
Proposition 23.6.2. The forgetful functor Ic-FCP[U ] ‚àí‚ÜíI -FCP[U ] is an
equivalence of categories that restricts to give equivalences between the respective
subcategories of structured FCP‚Äôs (monoids, groups, right Œ†-modules, etc).
Proof. As explained in detail in [112, 1.9], an I -FCP (T, œâ) extends to an
Ic-FCP, uniquely up to isomorphism. For a linear isometry f : V ‚àí‚ÜíW, where V
is Ô¨Ånite dimensional, W is the sum of f(V ) and its orthogonal complement f(V )‚ä•.
When W is also Ô¨Ånite dimensional, we deÔ¨Åne T(f): T(V ) ‚àí‚ÜíT(W) by composing
T(f): T(V ) ‚àí‚ÜíT(f(V )) with the map T(f(V )) ‚àí‚ÜíT(W) that sends x to œâ(x, ‚àó),
where ‚àóis the basepoint in T(f(V )‚ä•). When W is inÔ¨Ånite dimensional, we can and
must deÔ¨Åne T(W) to be the colimit of the T(V ) for Ô¨Ånite dimensional V ‚äÇW. The
passage to colimits preserves all structure in sight.
‚ñ°
We have an operad L , called the linear isometries operad, whose jth space is
L (j) = Ic(U j, U). It is an E‚àûoperad since each L (j) is contractible [112, I.1.3].
The following observation is [112, 1.6].
Proposition 23.6.3. Passage from T to T(U) gives a functor from Ic-FCP[U ]
to the category L [U ] of L -spaces.
Proof. The action maps L (j) √ó T(U)j ‚àí‚ÜíT(U) are deÔ¨Åned by Ô¨Årst using œâ
to map T(U)j to T(U j) and then using the evaluation map of the functor T.
‚ñ°
Notation 23.6.4. We sometimes abbreviate T(U) to T, relying on context to
determine whether T is intended to mean an Ic-FCP or an L -space.
The previous two results show how to pass from I -FCP‚Äôs to L -spaces and
therefore, by an inÔ¨Ånite loop space machine, to spectra. As explained in [114, ¬ß5¬ß6]
and [105, I.8.3], the output of May‚Äôs machine actually takes values in orthogonal

406
23. PARAMETRIZED FSP‚ÄôS AND GENERALIZED THOM SPECTRA
spectra. In fact, it gives a functor E from L -spaces X to orthogonal ‚Ñ¶-spectra EX
such that the zeroth space (EX)(0) is a group completion of X. By composition,
we obtain a functor E that starts with I -FCP‚Äôs and ends with orthogonal spectra.
Example 23.6.5. Passing to the associated L -spaces from Proposition 23.3.6,
we obtain unit inÔ¨Ånite loop spaces GL1(R) and SL1(R) with right actions by the
monoid L -spaces F and SF. Because the right actions come from maps of FCP‚Äôs,
the action maps are maps of L -spaces. Taking D = GL1(Q) in DeÔ¨Ånition 23.5.1,
the associated L -space B(GL1(Q), Œ†) classiÔ¨Åes Q-oriented spherical Ô¨Åbrations [112,
Ch. 3] and is denoted B(Œ†; Q); similarly we denote the associated Thom spectrum
by M(Œ†; Q). Work of Sullivan [161] (see also [100,112]) shows that, when localized
away from 2, B(SF; ko) is equivalent to BSTop and M(SF; ko) is equivalent to
MSTop.
For results like this, it seems essential to consider the Lewis-May E‚àûring
spectrum MR that we obtain by passage to colimits from the orthogonal spectrum
R, as explained in detail in [105, ¬ß I.7]. With that construction, GL1(R) is exactly
the unit space GL1(MR), as speciÔ¨Åed in DeÔ¨Ånition 22.2.2, and there is a general
result that often applies to compute localizations of the inÔ¨Ånite loop space SL1(R)
in terms of more directly accessible data [115, 8.7] (or [112, VII¬ß5]). As explained
in Remark 22.2.5, it is intrinsically impossible to have commutative symmetric or
orthogonal ‚Ñ¶-spectra whose actual unit spaces have analogous properties.
Finally, we consider analogues that start from Œ£-FCP‚Äôs rather than from I -
FCP‚Äôs. We shall just sketch the ideas. Some details are just like those in the case
of I -FCP‚Äôs, and the rest are given in Schlichtkrull‚Äôs paper [142, ¬ß2.3 and ¬ß5].
Remark 23.6.6. Let T be a commutative Œ£-FCP. There are two ways to con-
struct associated inÔ¨Ånite loop spaces. We can apply a prolongation functor as in
[106] to construct I -FCP‚Äôs from Œ£-FCP‚Äôs, and we can then use the constructions
that we have already described.
Alternatively, we can use the category I of Ô¨Ånite (unbased) sets and injections
as a kind of analogue of the category Ic that we used above. (In [142], our I-
FCP‚Äôs are called I-monoids, which is reasonable in a context where monoid-valued
I-FCP‚Äôs are not considered). The category I contains Œ£, and the forgetful functor
from I-FCP‚Äôs to Œ£-FCP‚Äôs has a left adjoint extension functor, in precise analogy
with Proposition 23.6.2.
For an analogue of Proposition 23.6.3, we consider the homotopy colimit, ex-
pressed in the notations of [111, ¬ß12] as the categorical bar construction ThI =
B(‚àó, I, T) for an I-FCP T. The identiÔ¨Åcation
B(‚àó, I, T) √ó B(‚àó, I, T) ‚àº= B(‚àó, I √ó I, T √ó T)
and the product pairings of T give ThI a structure of topological monoid. Even when
the I-FCP T is commutative, this monoid is non-commutative. Under convergence
hypotheses, its homotopy type is identiÔ¨Åed by a lemma of B¬®okstedt ([15] or [142,
2.1]). For example, for a convergent commutative symmetric ring spectrum R, one
might redeÔ¨Åne GL1(R) to be the homotopy colimit of the unit I-FCP obtained
from the unit Œ£-FCP denoted GL1(R) in Proposition 23.3.6 (taking R there to
be symmetric rather than orthogonal). Note that this monoid is not contained in
Aut(R).
Finally, as explained in [142, ¬ß5], if T is a commutative I-FCP, then we can
construct a Œì-space from it and apply Segal‚Äôs inÔ¨Ånite loop space machine [147]

23.7. UNIVERSAL SPHERICAL FIBRATION SPECTRA
407
to construct an associated inÔ¨Ånite loop space. We have not checked details, but
it seems to us that the methods of May and Thomason [127] can be adapted to
compare these two passages from commutative Œ£-FCP‚Äôs to inÔ¨Ånite loop spaces.
23.7. Universal spherical Ô¨Åbration spectra
Let A be an R-PFSP over the FCP B. In Theorem 23.2.8 we deÔ¨Åned a Thom
spectrum functor that associates an R-FSP r!A to A by applying r! to the ex-spaces
that comprise A. It would be desirable to perform an equivalent construction in
two steps. The Ô¨Årst would associate a parametrized R-spectrum U(A) to A, and
the second would apply r!. The base space of U(A), which we denote B, should be
obtained from B by passing to the associated colimit L -space as in the previous
section. Such a two step approach would allow us to deÔ¨Åne Thom spectra of maps
f : X ‚àí‚ÜíB as follows.
Definition 23.7.1. The Thom spectrum associated to the R-PFSP A and the
map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíB is
r!f ‚àóU(A) ‚àº= r!f!f ‚àóU(A).
The map r on the left maps X to ‚àó, that on the rightmaps B to ‚àó. The unit of the
adjunction (f!, f ‚àó) induces a canonical map r!f!f ‚àóU(A) ‚àí‚Üír!U(A).
There are several diÔ¨Éculties in carrying out this idea. First of all, we have not
deÔ¨Åned parametrized ring spectra over a Ô¨Åxed base space, for reasons explained in
¬ß14.1. But in fact it is not even clear how to construct U(A) as a parametrized
orthogonal spectrum. This stems from the discrepancy of point of view between
the passage to L -spaces in ¬ß23.6 and the use of diagram structures everywhere
else. Looking back at ¬ß23.6, one‚Äôs Ô¨Årst thought is to pass to colimits, starting for
example from the I -indexed diagram of ex-spaces B(Œ†, S) over the I -space BŒ†.
Conceptually, this would be analogous to constructing Ic-spaces from I -spaces
by passage to colimits. Since B(Œ†, S) is an I -PFSP with base I -FCP BŒ†, this
would seem to lead to a highly structured spectrum over the space BŒ†.
This
idea is very close to the original deÔ¨Ånition and construction of E‚àûring spectra in
[112]. It seems to lead inexorably to a parametrized version of the kinds of highly
structured spectra developed in [61,98]. We shall say a little about that approach
to parametrized spectra in the next chapter, but it is not the right approach in our
context of parametrized orthogonal spectra.
We shall not resolve these issues here, but we intend to treat them elsewhere.
We can however give a quick construction of U(A) as a prespectrum.
Construction 23.7.2. Let A be a PFSP over the FCP B. We have a map
A(V ) ‚äºSW
id‚äºŒ∑ / A(V ) ‚äºA(W)
¬µ
/ A(V ‚äïW)
in UU whose map on base spaces is
B(V ) ‚àº= B(V ) √ó ‚àó
id√óŒ∑ / B(V ) √ó B(W)
œâ
/ B(V ‚äïW).
We denote the map on base spaces by j(V, W) and obtain a map
(23.7.3)
j(V, W)!(A(V ) ‚àßSW ) ‚àí‚ÜíA(V ‚äïW)

408
23. PARAMETRIZED FSP‚ÄôS AND GENERALIZED THOM SPECTRA
over B(V ‚äïW). Let B be the colimit of the B(V ), as in ¬ß23.6. There are compatible
maps i(V ): B(V ) ‚àí‚ÜíB such that i(V ) = i(V ‚äïW) ‚ó¶j(V, W). We deÔ¨Åne
U(A)(V ) = i(V )!A(V ).
The structure maps
i(V )!A(V ) ‚àßSW ‚àí‚Üíi(V ‚äïW)!A(V ‚äïW)
are obtained by applying i(V ‚äïW)! to (23.7.3). It is not possible to retain functoral-
ity in the indexing spaces V with this construction, so we only obtain a prespectrum.
Observe that B is an L -space, although the deÔ¨Ånition does not make use of
that structure. These ideas are of particular interest for the R-PFSP‚Äôs B(D, Œ†, R)
constructed in Theorem 23.4.9. Specializing to R = S, we write Sph(D, Œ†) for
U(B(D, Œ†, S)) and call it the universal spherical Ô¨Åbration prespectrum over B(D, Œ†).
We state this case separately for emphasis.
Definition 23.7.4. The Thom spectrum Mf associated to a map f : X ‚àí‚Üí
B(D, Œ†) is
r!f ‚àóSph(D, Œ†) ‚àº= r!f!f ‚àóSph(D, Œ†),
where Sph(D, Œ†) is the universal spherical Ô¨Åbration spectrum over B(D, Œ†). With
M(D, Œ†) deÔ¨Åned to be r!Sph(D, Œ†), the unit Œµ: f!f ‚àó‚àí‚ÜíId of the adjunction
(f!, f ‚àó) induces a canonical map Mf ‚àí‚ÜíM(D, Œ†).
Thus Mf is obtained by Ô¨Årst pulling back the universal spherical Ô¨Åbration
spectrum over BŒ† to a spherical Ô¨Åbration spectrum over X and then pushing
forward along r to obtain an ordinary spectrum. With Blumberg, we intend to
study the multiplicative properties of spectra constructed in this fashion and to
relate them to THH in a later paper.
We conclude this section by showing how Sph(D, Œ†) can be constructed as an
excellent prespectrum. When Œ† is a monoid FCP, the projections in Sph(D, Œ†) are
only quasi-Ô¨Åbrations. It is sensible to replace them by (Hurewicz) Ô¨Åbrations, while
preserving sections and structure maps, using the approximation functor P of ¬ß13.3.
The prespectrum Sph(Œ†) over BŒ† is well-structured and Œ£-coÔ¨Åbrant, in the sense
of DeÔ¨Ånition 13.2.1, and the level ex-Ô¨Åbrant prespectrum PSph(Œ†) over BŒ† inherits
these properties by Theorem 13.3.8. When Œ† is a group FCP, the projections in
Sph(Œ†) are already bundles and we can use it as it stands. It is technically desirable
to go further and apply the functor T = KEP of Theorem 13.5.1, or KE in the
bundle case, to Sph(Œ†), so as to preserve the cited properties while obtaining an
excellent ‚Ñ¶-prespectrum over BŒ†, in the sense of DeÔ¨Ånition 13.2.2; it can be viewed
as giving a well-behaved Ô¨Åbrant replacement of Sph(Œ†) in the stable model structure
of spectra over BŒ†. The spectrum TSph(Œ†) is our universal spherical Ô¨Åbration
prespectrum Sph(Œ†) over BŒ†, and r!Sph(Œ†) gives a model for the classical Thom
spectrum MŒ†. In practice, however, to retain algebraic structure, it is sometimes
better to replace f by an equivalent Ô¨Åbration, use Sph(Œ†) directly, and only then
pass to ‚Ñ¶-prespectra.
23.8. Some historical background
The framework for our construction of iterated Thom spectra is quite close to
the framework developed in [112], where E‚àûring spaces and E‚àûring spectra were
Ô¨Årst introduced. The use of the category I and the operad L (under the name

23.8. SOME HISTORICAL BACKGROUND
409
PROP) goes back to the still earlier work of Boardman and Vogt [14]. Both I -
FCP‚Äôs and I -FSP‚Äôs were deÔ¨Åned in [112], but with diÔ¨Äerent names. Since we have
referred to that source for details, we give a dictionary in Remark 23.8.1 below. The
classical Thom spectra were described as I -FSP‚Äôs in [112, IV¬ß2], and the two-sided
bar construction on I -FCP‚Äôs was deÔ¨Åned in [112, I.2.2].
The notions of I -FCP and I -FSP are obviously related, but it has never been
clear precisely how. Our work explains and exploits the connection, but only by
virtue of recent progress in our understanding of the foundations of stable homotopy
theory. Orthogonal spectra were not deÔ¨Åned until the early 1980‚Äôs [114, ¬ß5], under a
diÔ¨Äerent name, and they were only recognized as a foundation for stable homotopy
theory in the late 1990‚Äôs [106]. Their use greatly clariÔ¨Åes the original concepts and
their interrelationships.
The acronym FSP comes from B¬®okstedt‚Äôs well-known but unpublished work
[15] on topological Hochschild homology (THH), and the acronym FCP is a suitable
companion. The understanding of the comparison between internal and external
versions of diagram ring spectra is due to JeÔ¨ÄSmith and was developed by Hovey,
Shipley, and Smith [77] in the context of symmetric spectra. As we have seen, com-
mutative I -FCP‚Äôs lead to E‚àûspaces and hence to spectra, whereas commutative
I -FSP‚Äôs lead to E‚àûring spectra. This is also true with I replaced by Œ£, but
the mechanism for passing from Œ£-FCP‚Äôs to spectra is diÔ¨Äerent, as we observed in
Remark 23.6.6. The noncommutative case leads to A‚àûspaces and A‚àûring spectra.
Remark 23.8.1. We give a dictionary of nomenclature.
(i) In [112, I¬ß1], our I was denoted I‚àóand our Ic was denoted I . For these D,
our D-FCP‚Äôs were there called D-functors. The new term seems preferable.
(ii) Our FSP‚Äôs, or I -FSP‚Äôs, were deÔ¨Åned in [112, IV.2.1], where they were called
I‚àó-prefunctors. B¬®okstedt‚Äôs later term FSP is much to be preferred.
(iii) In [112, p. 54], where they were Ô¨Årst introduced and proven to be inÔ¨Ånite
loop spaces, our GL1(R) and SL1(R) were called FR and SFR (with E used
instead of R). Waldhausen later introduced versions of GLn(R) for n ‚â•1
[167], leading to the currently standard notations.
(iv) In [112], Œ£‚àûand ‚Ñ¶‚àûhad diÔ¨Äerent meanings than are now standard; there,
Œ£‚àûwas the suspension prespectrum functor and ‚Ñ¶‚àûwas the spectriÔ¨Åcation
functor, now called L; its role will be recalled in Chapter 24.
(v) In [114, ¬ß¬ß5,6], our orthogonal spectra were called I‚àó-prespectra.


CHAPTER 24
Epilogue: cellular philosophy and alternative
approaches
Introduction
So far in this book, CW objects, as opposed to more general cellular objects,
have rarely been mentioned. Even classically, there is a clear distinction between
CW theory and the model theoretic cellular theory that we have focused on. It
is a general feature of model category theory that it does not know about CW
complexes, and the current emphasis on model category theory can obscure the
arguably more basic and certainly more calculationally relevant CW theory. Model
theoretic cell complexes X come with a Ô¨Åltration whose terms bear no relationship
to the dimensions of cells.
For example, in the Quillen model category of spaces, CW complexes are cell
complexes such that cells are attached only to cells of lower dimension. When this
holds, one can superimpose the skeletal Ô¨Åltration, but that is not possible in general.
In the nonparametrized world, one can circumvent the diÔ¨Éculty, up to homotopy,
by using the cellular approximation theorem. That result ensures that any cell
complex is homotopy equivalent to a CW complex.
This also works for G-CW
complexes, provided that one works with spheres with trivial G-action. There are
algebraic model categories leading to derived categories in which cell theory works
but the cellular approximation theorem fails hopelessly [90, III¬ß2]. Topologically,
the distinction is far more important in the parametrized setting than in the classical
setting. We say what we can about CW spaces over B in ¬ß24.1, where we obtain
partial versions of the Whitehead and cellular approximation theorems.
We discuss the divergence of the theory of CW objects from the theory of cel-
lular objects in stable situations in ¬ß24.2, heading towards discussion of alternative
constructions of the stable homotopy category of parametrized spectra.
Stably,
the equivariant theory raises new distinctions that are not present unstably. These
highlight philosophical diÔ¨Äerences between the alternative approaches to model cat-
egories of spectra mentioned in the introduction to Part III. We have focused on
the ‚Äúdiagram spectrum‚Äù approach to the stable homotopy category. In the non-
parametrized theory, there is an alternative ‚Äústructured spectrum‚Äù approach that
oÔ¨Äers a closer parallel to the calculational world of CW complexes than is obtain-
able from the diagram spectrum approach [61, 98, 105, 108]. A leisurely intuitive
summary of this approach, which focuses on CW theory to the exclusion of model
category theory, is given in [118, Ch. 12]. We describe how this theory Ô¨Åts into the
framework of well-grounded model categories in ¬ß24.3. This works startlingly well
in the EKMM [61] context, where the ground structure can be ignored: the EKMM
category of SG-modules is better behaved than any category of spaces.
411

412
24. EPILOGUE: CELLULAR PHILOSOPHY AND ALTERNATIVE APPROACHES
We return to the parametrized setting in ¬ß24.4. As we noted earlier, a model
theoretic approach to parametrized spectra based on structured spectra seems to
present more diÔ¨Éculties than one based on diagram spectra. An approach based
directly on CW spectra is still more problematic. Nevertheless, there would be
advantages to such alternative foundations. In ¬ß24.4, we start towards such a theory
by giving a construction of the parametrized equivariant stable homotopy category
based on structured G-spectra. Rather than solve the model categorical or CW
problems, we just build on the work that we have already done with parametrized
G-prespectra. We point out the beginnings of an EKMM type elaboration of this
parametrized theory in ¬ß24.5, but we shall not pursue the details here.
24.1. CW spaces over B
It is usual in axiomatic homology and cohomology theory to express the alter-
native cellular axioms in terms of CW objects rather than the more general cellular
objects that we used in Chapter 20. However, as we shall explain here, we have
not yet worked out enough of the theory of CW spaces over B or of CW ex-spaces
over B to allow such an axiomatization. Nevertheless, up to a point, we can mimic
the theory of CW complexes as developed, for example, in [121]. We sketch what is
involved in order to emphasize the fundamental points of diÔ¨Äerence. It seems likely
that this theory can be developed further by more elaborate techniques.
One point of diÔ¨Äerence from the classical case is that we have both the kinds of
cells dictated by the q-model structure and the kinds of cells dictated by the more
useful qf-model structure. Recall that a main point of the qf-model structure is
to ensure that cell complexes of ex-spaces are well-grounded. We surely want CW
complexes of ex-spaces to have that property.
However, the importance of this
distinction is diminished by the fact that we do not yet know how to prove much
about CW ex-spaces over B, as opposed to CW spaces over B. Moreover, it is
technically and conceptually helpful to realize that much of what we can prove
goes through using the more general q-cells, but specializes to results valid upon
restriction to CW complexes deÔ¨Åned in terms of qf-cells. Thus we have both a
q-CW theory and a qf-CW theory. We write CW complex ambiguously for results
that work equally well with either deÔ¨Ånition, but when we consider homology we
always have qf-CW complexes in mind.
The deÔ¨Ånition of CW complexes X over B works exactly like the deÔ¨Ånition of
CW complexes. We take X0 to be a disjoint union of points over B and construct
Xn from Xn‚àí1 by attaching cells Dn over B along attaching maps over B deÔ¨Åned
on their boundary spheres Sn‚àí1 over B. For ex-spaces, we take X0 to be a wedge
over B of ‚Äúex-points‚Äù ‚àó‚®øB over B and construct Xn from Xn‚àí1 by attaching
cells Dn ‚®øB over B along attaching ex-maps deÔ¨Åned on Sn‚àí1 ‚®øB. Relative CW
complexes are deÔ¨Åned similarly. Some of the treatment in [121, Ch. 10] carries over
verbatim. The treatment there is organized around the Homotopy Extension and
Lifting Property. Unfortunately, we do not know how to prove an ex-space analogue
of this result, hence we focus on spaces over B. Although we are interested in
CW complexes, the notion of dimension makes sense for cell complexes and HELP
applies to them as well.
Theorem 24.1.1 (HELP). Let (X, W) be a relative q-cell complex over B of
dimension ‚â§n and let e : Y ‚àí‚ÜíZ be a map over B that is an n-equivalence, where
Y and Z are q-Ô¨Åbrant (or just qf-Ô¨Åbrant if (X, W) is a relative qf-cell complex).

A second point of diÔ¨Äerence is that we cannot expect a result such as HELP
to hold without Ô¨Åbrancy conditions. This means, for example, that the usual im-
mediate consequence that an n-equivalence between CW complexes of dimension
less than n is a homotopy equivalence is no longer valid in general. The following
version of the Whitehead theorem, which refers to the homotopy category HoK /B
does follow directly.
Theorem 24.1.2 (Whitehead). If X is a CW complex over B and e: Y ‚àí‚ÜíZ
is an n-equivalence over B, then e‚àó: [X, Y ]B ‚àí‚Üí[X, Z]B is a bijection if dim(X) <
n and a surjection if dim(X) = n.
The point is that we can compute morphisms in the homotopy category by
Ô¨Årst applying q-Ô¨Åbrant approximation to e: Y ‚àí‚ÜíZ and then passing to homotopy
classes of maps. The requirement of Ô¨Åbrancy in the Whitehead theorem is a serious
drawback, as the following proposition and question make clear.
Proposition 24.1.3. The following CW approximation statements hold.
(i) For any space X over B, there is a weak equivalence ŒìX ‚àí‚ÜíX over B, where
ŒìX is a CW complex over B.
(ii) For any pair (X, W) of spaces over B,
there is a weak equivalence
Œ≥ : (ŒìX, ŒìW) ‚àí‚Üí(X, W), where (ŒìX, ŒìW) is a CW pair over B.
(iii) For any excisive triad (X; W, V ) of spaces over B, there is a CW triad
(ŒìX; ŒìW, ŒìV ) and a map of triads Œ≥ : (ŒìX; ŒìW, ŒìV ) ‚àí‚Üí(X; W, V ) such that
Œ≥ : ŒìW ‚à©ŒìV ‚àí‚ÜíW ‚à©V , Œ≥ : ŒìW ‚àí‚ÜíW, Œ≥ : ŒìV ‚àí‚ÜíV , and Œ≥ : ŒìX ‚àí‚ÜíX
are all weak equivalences.

24.2. CW SPECTRA AND STABLE HOMOTOPY CATEGORIES
415
On homotopy categories, Œì is the object function of a functor such that Œ≥ is natu-
ral, and ŒìX, (ŒìX, ŒìW), and (ŒìX; ŒìW, ŒìV ) are unique up to isomorphism in the
respective homotopy categories.
Proof. For (i), we build ŒìX by successive cell attachment as in [121, ¬ß10.5].
The essential point is that we are considering the homotopy groups of the total
spaces and can work in the nonparametrized context. We give the cells that we
attach the projections induced from that of X, and we then use Lemmas 6.3.1 and
6.3.2 to replace the constructed q-cells over B by qf-cells over B. For (ii), we start
from a CW approximation Œ≥ : ŒìW ‚àí‚ÜíW and attach cells to ŒìW to construct
ŒìX together with a weak equivalence Œ≥ : ŒìX ‚àí‚ÜíX that extends the given Œ≥ on
ŒìW, as in [121, ¬ß10.6]. For (iii), let M = W ‚à©V , construct a weak equivalence
Œ≥ : ŒìM ‚àí‚ÜíM as in (i), and construct weak equivalences Œ≥ : (ŒìW, ŒìM) ‚àí‚Üí(W, M)
and Œ≥ : (ŒìV, ŒìM) ‚àí‚Üí(V, M) as in (ii).
Then let ŒìX = ŒìW ‚à™ŒìM ŒìV and let
Œ≥ : ŒìX ‚àí‚ÜíX be obtained by passage to pushouts; it is a weak equivalence by[121,
¬ß10.7]. In the last sentence, we are just applying the Whitehead theorem formally.
‚ñ°
One problem with this result is that it too does not go over to ex-spaces. There
is no problem building projections starting from the given ones, but we cannot
also build up sections that way.
Another problem is that, due to the Ô¨Åbrancy
condition in HELP, we cannot use the Whitehead theorem to deduce that our
CW approximations are functorial up to homotopy (rather than just functorial on
homotopy categories) and that Œì is unique up to homotopy equivalence, as was
done in [121, ¬ß¬ß10.5-10.7]. This raises the following question.
Question 24.1.4. Is every space X over B weakly equivalent to a Ô¨Åbrant CW
complex over B?
Conceptually, a great virtue of coÔ¨Åbrantly generated model categories is that
they allow Ô¨Åbrant approximation by cell complexes. However, since Ô¨Åbrations are
determined by the RLP with respect just to the generating acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations,
Ô¨Åbrancy conditions are blind to the reÔ¨Ånement of cell complexes to CW complexes.
Of course, this problem is not signiÔ¨Åcant in the classical examples, where every
object is Ô¨Åbrant. The conclusion is that, in the parametrized context, we can apply
CW approximation to objects but not, in general, to maps. For example, we only
have the following version of the cellular approximation theorem.
Theorem 24.1.5 (Cellular Approximation). Any map f : (X, W) ‚àí‚Üí(Y, V )
between relative CW complexes over B such that Y and its skeleta are Ô¨Åbrant is
homotopic relative to W to a cellular map over B.
Proof. The inclusion in : Y n ‚àí‚ÜíY is an n-equivalence. We apply HELP to
the pair (X0, W) to start an inductive construction and proceed cell by cell at later
stages, as in [121, ¬ß10.4].
‚ñ°
24.2. CW spectra and stable homotopy categories
Nonequivariantly, CW spectra work more or less in the same way as CW com-
plexes and can be developed in any reasonable model category of spectra. However,
the existing literature of diagram spectra does not consider CW spectra, and there
is a quirk that we shall explain shortly. Equivariantly, the situation is diÔ¨Äerent.

416
24. EPILOGUE: CELLULAR PHILOSOPHY AND ALTERNATIVE APPROACHES
Whether or not one can restrict model categorical G-cell spectra to obtain a good
theory of G-CW spectra based on spheres G/H+ ‚àßSn depends on the choice of the
model category of G-spectra, as we shall explain shortly.
Even nonequivariantly, there is a subtle discrepancy between cell spectra and
CW spectra, quite apart from the obvious dimensional restriction on attaching
maps. In all categories of diagram spectra in the literature, both simplicial and
topological, cell objects are constructed from generating sets FdSq
+ ‚àí‚ÜíFdDq
+,
where Fd is left adjoint to evaluation at d for an object d of the domain category.
This construction of cell spectra has as its underlying space level model the based
spaces that are cell complexes in the unbased sense. On the space level, using the
Sq
+ as domains of attaching maps is clearly sensible since the disjoint basepoint
must go to the basepoint and one is only looking at an unbased map deÔ¨Åned on Sq.
The corresponding deÔ¨Ånition of based Serre Ô¨Åbrations is similar: they are maps of
based spaces that satisfy the RLP with respect to the maps i0 : Dq
+ ‚àí‚Üí(Dq √óI)+;
that is, they are based maps that are Serre Ô¨Åbrations in the unbased sense.
Stably, thinking about CW spectra, that approach does not give the calcula-
tionally right notion of a cell complex. In any stable category, we have
FnSq
+ ‚âÉŒ£‚àí1FnŒ£Sq
+ ‚âÉŒ£‚àí1Fn(Sq+1 ‚à®S1) ‚âÉFnSq ‚à®FnS0.
Thus, homotopically, the attaching maps of cells are given by a pair of homotopy
classes, not just one.
Looking in terms of the adjoints relating spectra, based
spaces, and unbased spaces, the point is that for a loop space X, the set of unbased
homotopy classes of unbased maps Sq ‚àí‚ÜíX is in bijective correspondence with
œÄq(X) √ó œÄ0(X). Clearly, a pair of attaching maps for each cell does not give the
notion of a cell spectrum that a working homotopy theorist has in mind.
This is related to the distinction in DeÔ¨Ånition 7.5.5 between detecting sets and
generating sets. It would seem more natural in the based context to use the based
spheres Sn as the domains of attaching maps for based CW complexes, but then
the only based CW complexes that we could construct would be the disjoint unions
of a set of points with a connected based CW complex.
With Lewis-May spectra and EKMM S-modules [61,98], this discrepancy does
not appear.
The attaching maps of cells are deÔ¨Åned on good models of sphere
spectra, with no disjoint basepoints in sight. The relevant space level precursor is
given by based cell complexes, which are deÔ¨Åned in terms of the based generating
coÔ¨Åbrations Sq ‚àí‚ÜíCSq and have based attaching maps. Since the model structure
on Lewis-May spectra does not require these cell complexes to be the cell complexes
of a model structure on based spaces, there is no problem.
One might try to reconcile the diagram spectrum setting by reworking the
diagram category model theory in terms of such cell complexes, and one can cer-
tainly superimpose a treatment of CW-spectra by directly mimicking [98, ¬ßI.5], read
nonequivariantly. However, no such approach works in the parametrized setting,
for the simple reason that while spheres can be given basepoints, spheres over a
given base space cannot be given base sections. Moreover, such an approach would
not address the deeper equivariant issues, which we now explain. A leisurely expla-
nation devoid of model category theory is given in [118, Ch. XII]. However, these
issues are interwoven conceptually with the question of whether or not all objects
in one‚Äôs model category are Ô¨Åbrant.

24.2. CW SPECTRA AND STABLE HOMOTOPY CATEGORIES
417
Of course, in a topological model category in which not all objects are Ô¨Åbrant,
cellular objects are not generally Ô¨Åbrant. This is why the most naive cellular ob-
jects may not be suÔ¨Écient to capture the entire homotopy category. Here we must
carefully distinguish between a minimal set of generating coÔ¨Åbrations for a stable
topological model category C and a minimal set of generating objects (or, equiva-
lently, detecting objects) for its derived triangulated homotopy category HoC . The
coÔ¨Åbers of a minimal set of generating coÔ¨Åbrations for C give a generating set of
objects for HoC , but this generating set of objects need not be not minimal.
A naive approach to a stable cellular theory is to take objects in a well chosen
minimal generating set for HoC as the allowed domains of attaching maps for cells
of the form i: T ‚àí‚ÜíCT, where CT is the cone on T. Thus a naive cell complex is
the colimit of a sequence Xi, where X0 = ‚àóand Xi+1 is the pushout of a coproduct
of cells T ‚àí‚ÜíCT along attaching maps T ‚àí‚ÜíXi.
When the objects T have
dimensions, we deÔ¨Åne the n-skeleton Xn of a cell complex X to be the union of the
cells of dimension at most n, and we deÔ¨Åne a CW complex to be a cell complex
whose attaching maps with domain of dimension n land in the relevant n-skeleton
(Xi)n. Note that such complexes have two Ô¨Åltrations, the sequential one, {Xi},
and the skeletal one, {Xn}. That is essential to an adequate theory in the presence
of negative dimensions. When the cellular approximation theorem applies to show
that any map T ‚àí‚ÜíXi is homotopic to a map with image in the subcomplex (Xi)n,
where n = dim(T), any cell complex is equivalent to a CW complex.
In the Lewis-May or EKMM equivariant stable categories, this naive theory
gives exactly the right theory of G-CW spectra. The well-chosen objects T are
suitable coÔ¨Åbrant G-spheres Sn
H = G/H+ ‚àßSn, n ‚ààZ. All of the formal properties
work exactly as for G-spaces, the cellular approximation theorem works in exactly
the same way as it does nonequivariantly, and every G-spectrum is weakly equiv-
alent to a G-CW spectrum [98, ¬ßI.5]. Model theoretically, the coÔ¨Åbrations are the
retracts of the naive relative cell complexes.
In the nonequivariant stable categories of symmetric or orthogonal spectra, CW
theory can be developed similarly, except that, as we have seen, the basic cells T
should be the coÔ¨Åbers rather than the domains of the generating coÔ¨Åbrations. How-
ever, this fails to work in the equivariant stable categories of symmetric or orthogo-
nal G-spectra. Restricting to orthogonal G-spectra for simplicity, the G-spheres Sn
H
still detect weak equivalences, but they cannot be the domains (or coÔ¨Åbers) of the
generating coÔ¨Åbrations of an appropriate model structure. Cell spectra constructed
from these spheres give rise only to naive orthogonal G-spectra, not to the genuine
G-spectra that represent RO(G)-graded cohomology theories. Model theoretically,
these spheres only ‚Äúsee‚Äù the right homotopy groups after Ô¨Åbrant approximation,
and one cannot use them to construct such approximations.
It is the fact that all objects are Ô¨Åbrant in the Lewis-May and EKMM categories
that makes equivariant G-CW theory work there with integer spheres. The point
is that homotopical information about non-trivial representations of G is packaged
into the sphere spectra that are the domains of attaching maps. Explicitly, the
Lewis-May sphere G-spectrum SG has 0th G-space QS0, which is the colimit over
all representations V of the equivariant loop G-spaces ‚Ñ¶V SV . This allows one to
restrict to ‚Äútrivial‚Äù G-sphere spectra G/H+ ‚àßSn for n ‚ààZ, rather than using
G-sphere spectra G/H+ ‚àßSŒ± for Œ± ‚ààRO(G), as domains of attaching maps.

418
24. EPILOGUE: CELLULAR PHILOSOPHY AND ALTERNATIVE APPROACHES
These issues are discussed further in [105, IV¬ß1], where the reader can Ô¨Ånd a
discussion of the Quillen equivalences that nevertheless relate all of the relevant
model categories. Even nonequivariantly, it is advantageous to have Ô¨Åbrant CW
objects, and of course it is essential to have CW-spectra such that each cell has a
single attaching map. In diagram categories, the cell objects with dimensionally
appropriate attaching maps do not have these properties, and we conclude that the
theory of CW spectra there is more divergent from the model theoretic theory of
cell spectra and less convenient than in the Lewis-May category.
Rather than think about these issues in the context of diagram spectra, we can
exploit the web of Quillen equivalences of model categories that has been developed
in [105,106,145]. It is eÔ¨Äortless and automatic to take information developed in the
Lewis-May and EKMM context and apply it in the diagram category context, and
vice versa. Thus, implicitly, we already have a fully developed theory of diagram
G-CW spectra, just by moving back and forth between Quillen equivalent model
categories. It is harder work setting up the Lewis-May and EKMM foundations, but
they package useful information that is diÔ¨Écult or impossible to obtain directly in
the diagram spectrum setting, especially in their relationship to inÔ¨Ånite loop spaces
and to equivariant stable homotopy theory.
This discussion applies with comparable force in the parametrized setting, but
here Ô¨Åbrancy is more critical and we have not obtained a satisfactorily complete
theory based on structured (or ‚Äúgenuine‚Äù) parametrized spectra.
24.3. Structured spectra and well-grounded model categories
We Ô¨Årst compare the deÔ¨Ånitions of model categories of diagram spectra and
model categories of structured spectra and then describe how the latter theory Ô¨Åts
in with our theory of well-grounded model categories. The discussion will pinpoint
the problems involved in obtaining a parametrized generalization of the theory of
structured spectra.
In the theory of diagram spectra, one bootstraps one‚Äôs way up to the appro-
priate model structure, using the level model structure on categories of diagram
spectra as a pivotal intermediary between the model structure on spaces and the
stable model structure on spectra.
From the point of view of [61, 98], diagram
spectra are themselves intermediate objects between spaces and spectra. They are
of course diagrams of spaces, and their levelwise constituent spaces are taken more
seriously than are the constituent spaces of the spectra and S-modules of [61,98].
In either approach, the basic philosophy is that spectra are the objects of intrinsic
interest in their own right, and their underlying families of spaces are generally to
be ignored when doing stable homotopy theory. This philosophy is carried further
in the structured spectrum approach. The key value of the underlying spaces of
structured spectra is that they are inÔ¨Ånite loop spaces, on the nose, which is not
true for even the Ô¨Åbrant objects in any category of diagram spectra and is usually
not relevant when focusing only on stable homotopy theory.
This diÔ¨Äerence in philosophy plays out in major technical diÔ¨Äerences. In its
naive sequential form, as Ô¨Årst deÔ¨Åned in [111], a Lewis-May spectrum E is just a
sequence of based spaces Ei and based homeomorphisms Ei ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶Ei+1. We recall
and emphasize that this notion of spectrum is incompatible with the structure
incorporated by diagram spectra. If E admits a structure of symmetric spectrum,
for example, then E is the trivial spectrum: Ei cannot be a Œ£i-space homeomorphic

24.3. STRUCTURED SPECTRA AND WELL-GROUNDED MODEL CATEGORIES
419
as a Œ£i √ó Œ£2-space to ‚Ñ¶2Ei+2 unless it is a point. In the coordinate-free setting,
the same contradiction applies to orthogonal spectra.
There is an adjoint pair of functors (L, ‚Ñì) relating prespectra, which for the
moment we think of as sequences of based spaces Ti and based maps Ti ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶Ti+1,
to spectra. The category P of prespectra is clearly topologically bicomplete, with
colimits and tensors constructed levelwise. The category S of spectra is so as well,
but colimits and tensors are constructed by Ô¨Årst applying the forgetful functor
‚Ñì, then applying the prespectrum level construction, and Ô¨Ånally applying L. For
example, E ‚àßK = L(‚ÑìE ‚àßK). Homotopies and Cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations are deÔ¨Åned in
terms of E ‚àßI+. If a map T ‚àí‚ÜíT ‚Ä≤ of prespectra is a Cyl-coÔ¨Åbration, then it is
obvious that each Ti ‚àí‚ÜíT ‚Ä≤
i is a Cyl-coÔ¨Åbration of based spaces. In sharp contrast,
it is not known that if a map E ‚àí‚ÜíE‚Ä≤ is a Cyl-coÔ¨Åbration, then each Ei ‚àí‚ÜíE‚Ä≤
i
is a Cyl-coÔ¨Åbration. These maps are closed inclusions [98, A.3.9], but even that is
not at all obvious. Therefore, spacewise h-coÔ¨Åbrations have no useful role to play
in this category of spectra.
In our parametrized setting, the key technical result is Theorem 12.4.2, which
gives the long exact sequences of Ô¨Åberwise homotopy groups associated to a coÔ¨Åber
sequence of orthogonal spectra over B.
The theory leading to that was based
on implementing a boot strap argument that is based ultimately on the space
level gluing lemma, in its implied levelwise version. For that, it was crucial that
Cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations are bicoÔ¨Åbrations, and our axiomatization of the theory of well-
grounded model categories is a careful conceptualization of how such arguments
might go in a variety of contexts.
Since spacewise h-coÔ¨Åbrations are no longer
useful in a Lewis-May approach, we need a diÔ¨Äerent way of getting at such long exact
sequences, and the axiomatization is not directly relevant. CoÔ¨Åbers of parametrized
spectra are not nicely related to levelwise coÔ¨Åbers of total spaces, and it is not clear
to us how to set up the parametrized theory this way.
In the nonparametrized setting, there is no distinction between the level and
stable model structures on Lewis-May or EKMM spectra [61, VII¬ß5] since a map
of spectra (or, more generally, of ‚Ñ¶-prespectra) is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism if and only if
it is a level weak equivalence. Nonequivariantly, this is true tautologically. Equiv-
ariantly, it is a non-trivial theorem; see [98, I.7.12] or [105, III.3.4]. Because the
level and stable model structures coincide, the acyclicity of relative cell complexes
built up from the generating acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations is straightforward, as is clear from
comparison of Remark 4.5.12 with the proof of [61, VII.5.6]. There is no direct
analogue of this in the parametrized version of the Lewis-May setting. That is
one reason that the over and under Quillen model structure on ex-spaces is an in-
suÔ¨Écient starting point: we cannot prove the relevant acyclicity starting from the
candidates for generating acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations to which that model structure leads
us. This may work starting from the qf-model structure, but we do not have a
proof.
Despite this discussion, it is reasonable to ask whether or not the non-parame-
trized Lewis-May and EKMM categories of spectra are well-grounded topological
model categories. For the Lewis-May spectra, the answer seems to be no. For the
EKMM L-spectra and S-modules, the answer is yes, and in a surprisingly simple
way, as we will explain shortly. An indication of the diÔ¨Äerence was pointed out
in [105, IV.2.10]. The Lewis-May category of spectra, which we denote S in this
chapter, is not known to be left proper under its stable model structure, whereas

420
24. EPILOGUE: CELLULAR PHILOSOPHY AND ALTERNATIVE APPROACHES
the EKMM categories are left proper. Of course, our axioms force well-grounded
model categories to be proper. The theory of ‚Äútame‚Äù spectra developed in EKMM
gets around this problem in S by giving a large class of spectra for which coÔ¨Åber
sequences have long exact sequences of homotopy groups [61, I.3.4]. Precisely, a
spectrum is tame if it is homotopy equivalent to one of the form LT, where the
structure maps of T are coÔ¨Åbrations of based spaces.
In contrast, by a kind of technical miracle [61, I.6.4], all coÔ¨Åber sequences of
L-spectra have long exact sequences of homotopy groups. We have the following
strange result, the gist of which is that EKMM L-spectra, or its even better behaved
Quillen equivalent full subcategory of S-modules, is better behaved than any known
category of based spaces. We focus on S-modules and generalize to the equivariant
context, where the sphere G-spectrum is denoted SG.
Theorem 24.3.1. For any compact Lie group G, the category MG of SG-
modules is a well-grounded G-topological model category with its stable model struc-
ture.
Proof. In the contexts of [98] and [61], all spaces are compactly generated, and
we retain that convention. We then decree that every SG-module is well-grounded
and every map of SG-modules is a ground coÔ¨Åbration.
The closure properties
required of subcategories of well-grounded objects and of coÔ¨Åbrations hold trivially,
and the cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations coincide with the bicoÔ¨Åbrations. Thus we take our ground
structure to be the obvious one present in any topologically bicomplete category.
We must show that the weak equivalences, which are the œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms, are
well-grounded in the sense of DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1. We emphasize that the homotopy
groups are deÔ¨Åned directly on the spectrum level, without use of prespectra or
colimits. That is, œÄH
n (M) is the set of homotopy classes of maps G/H+ ‚àßSn ‚àí‚Üí
M of SG-modules,where Sn is the canonical coÔ¨Åbrant n-sphere SG-module; see
[61, p. 33] and [105, p. 63]. Certainly a homotopy equivalence is a œÄ‚àó-isomorphism.
Any coÔ¨Åber sequence of SG-modules has a long exact sequence of homotopy groups
for each subgroup H, by the equivariant analogue of [61, I.6.4]. It follows by use of
split coÔ¨Åber sequences that Ô¨Ånite wedges of œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms are œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms.
Since sphere SG-modules are compact [61, p. 53], the conclusion for arbitrary wedges
follows by passage to colimits. Pushouts of œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms along cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations
are œÄ‚àó-isomorphisms by [61, I.6.5], and the classical mapping cylinder construction
factors any map as the composite of a cyl-coÔ¨Åbration and a homotopy equivalence.
Therefore the gluing lemma holds by Lemma 5.4.3. The homotopy groups of a
colimit of a sequence of cyl-coÔ¨Åbrations are the colimits of the homotopy groups
of the terms, so the colimit lemma holds. Finally, the pushout product condition
of DeÔ¨Ånition 5.4.1(v), with K and L restricted to be CW complexes, holds by
Lemma 5.4.5 and the proof of [61, I.6.6].
‚ñ°
24.4. The stable category of parametrized spectra
While an alternative approach to parametrized spectra that is modelled on
[61,98] is desirable, we have not worked one out in detail. We sketch what we know
in the rest of this chapter. A Ô¨Årst step in this direction was taken by Po Hu [78],
but from the Ô¨Çawed starting point of the over and under Quillen model structure.
As emphasized at the start of Chapter 12, everything there applies verbatim
to the category GPB of G-prespectra over B, where G is a compact Lie group

24.4. THE STABLE CATEGORY OF PARAMETRIZED SPECTRA
421
and B is a compactly generated G-space. We modify the discussion there slightly
by restricting attention to indexing inner product spaces contained in a Ô¨Åxed G-
universe U.
We ignore orthogonal G-spectra in this section, freeing us to use
notations duplicatively.
Definition 24.4.1. A G-spectrum over B is a G-prespectrum X over B such
that each adjoint structure map ÀúœÉ: X(V ) ‚àí‚Üí‚Ñ¶W ‚àíV
B
X(W) is a homeomorphism
(isomorphism in GKB). Let SG,B and GSB denote the full subcategories of G-
spectra over B in PG,B and GPB.
Theorem 24.4.2. Let ‚Ñì: GSB ‚àí‚ÜíGPB be the inclusion functor. Then ‚Ñìhas
a left adjoint L.
Proof. This is proven exactly as in [98, App ¬ß1].
The functor L factors
through the full subcategory GQB of inclusion spectra, whose adjoint structure
maps ÀúœÉ are inclusions. The left adjoint GPB ‚àí‚ÜíGQP is obtained by Freyd‚Äôs
adjoint functor theorem or an explicit (and fairly unilluminating) transÔ¨Ånite induc-
tion. The left adjoint GQP ‚àí‚ÜíGSP is obtained by an evident passage to colimits
over inclusions induced by the ÀúœÉ, so that (LX)(V ) = colimW ‚äÉV ‚Ñ¶W ‚àíV X(W).
‚ñ°
Proposition 24.4.3. The category GSB is topologically bicomplete.
Proof. This is proven exactly as in the nonparametrized case. Limits and
cotensors are created in the category GPB, and colimits and tensors are constructed
by Ô¨Årst applying ‚Ñì, then the relevant construction, and Ô¨Ånally L.
‚ñ°
For a map f : A ‚àí‚ÜíB, we have base change functors f ‚àó, f‚àó, and f‚àóas in ¬ß2.1.
The pushout used to construct f! must be carried out using the adjunction (L, ‚Ñì),
but f ‚àóand f‚àóare constructed levelwise. Similarly, all of the other formal point-set
level structure developed in Chapter 2 carries over directly to these categories of
equivariant parametrized spectra.
There is also a shift desuspension functor Œ£‚àû
V from ex-G-spaces over B to G-
spectra over B that is left adjoint to the V th ex-G-space over B functor. It is
constructed from our prespectrum level analogue by use of the adjunction (L, ‚Ñì).
Remark 24.4.4. Let LFIf
B and LFJf
B be the sets of maps of G-spectra over
B obtained by applying the functor L to the sets speciÔ¨Åed in DeÔ¨Ånition 12.1.6. A
standard argument [73, 11.3.2] shows that if ‚Ñìtakes relative LFJf
B-cell complexes
to weak equivalences, then these sets give the generating coÔ¨Åbrations and generat-
ing acyclic coÔ¨Åbrations for a compactly generated level model structure on GSB
such that (L, ‚Ñì) is a Quillen adjunction. Here a map f in GSB would be a weak
equivalence or level qf-Ô¨Åbration if and only if ‚Ñìf were a level weak equivalence or
level qf-Ô¨Åbration. Since the weak equivalences between Ô¨Åbrant objects would be the
Ô¨Åberwise weak equivalences and since ‚Ñìwould take level Ô¨Åbrations to s-Ô¨Åbrations,
by Proposition 12.5.6, it would follow that (L, ‚Ñì) induces an equivalence between the
resulting homotopy category HoGSB and the stable homotopy category HoGPB.
However, we have not been able to prove the required levelwise acyclicity of total
spaces of relative LFJf
B-cell complexes. Of course, since the level total spaces of a
spectrum over B do not form an nonparametrized spectrum, we cannot just reduce
to the spectrum level analogue.
Nevertheless, we can use G-spectra over B to obtain a model for the parame-
trized stable homotopy category.

24. EPILOGUE: CELLULAR PHILOSOPHY AND ALTERNATIVE APPROACHES
Definition 24.4.5. A G-spectrum X is h-Ô¨Åbrant if each X(V ) is an h-Ô¨Åbrant
ex-G-space; q-Ô¨Åbrant, qf-Ô¨Åbrant, and quasi-Ô¨Åbrant G-spectra are deÔ¨Åned similarly.
A map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíX‚Ä≤ of quasi-Ô¨Åbrant G-spectra is a weak equivalence if its restriction
fb : Xb ‚àí‚ÜíX‚Ä≤
b is a weak equivalence of Gb-spectra for each b ‚ààB.
Let GS f
B
denote the category of h-Ô¨Åbrant G-spectra over B and let HoGS f
B be the homotopy
category obtained by formally inverting the weak equivalences.
The deÔ¨Ånition works equally well if we replace h-Ô¨Åbrant by q or qf-Ô¨Åbrant in
our deÔ¨Ånition of the objects of HoGS f
B. With any choice, we have the following
result. As indicated at the end of the proof, we skimp on a few easily Ô¨Ålled in
details.
Theorem 24.4.6. The category HoGS f
B is equivalent to the category HoGPB.
Proof. A map f : X ‚àí‚ÜíX‚Ä≤ is a weak equivalence if and only if ‚Ñìf is a weak
equivalence, and ‚Ñìtakes qf-Ô¨Åbrant G-spectra to Ô¨Åbrant G-prespectra. Using that
the functor L preserves homotopy equivalences because it preserves cylinders and
that homotopy equivalences are weak equivalences, it is easy to see that any mor-
phism X ‚àí‚ÜíY in HoGS f
B(X, Y ) is represented by a diagram X ‚Üê‚àíLQ‚ÑìX ‚àí‚ÜíY
of G-spectra, where Q is s-coÔ¨Åbrant approximation in GPB. In particular, we have
a well-deÔ¨Åned hom set HoGS f
B(X, Y ) between any pair of h (or q, or qf)-Ô¨Åbrant
G-spectra X and Y . Either using that L is homotopy preserving or arguing for-
mally from the adjunction, we Ô¨Ånd that ‚Ñìinduces a bijection of hom sets between
any pair of objects. Thus ‚Ñìinduces a full and faithful functor on homotopy cate-
gories, and it suÔ¨Éces to show that it is essentially surjective, meaning that every
G-prespectrum Y is isomorphic in HoGPG to ‚ÑìX for some h-Ô¨Åbrant G-spectrum
X.
Certainly, using the excellent approximation functor T, Y is isomorphic in
HoGPG to an excellent G-prespectrum and so may be assumed to be excellent.
Recall from Proposition 8.2.7 that each ‚Ñ¶W ‚àíV
B
Y (W) is an ex-Ô¨Åbration over B.
Since the structure maps œÉ are f-coÔ¨Åbrations, their adjoints are closed inclusions,
as in the proof of [94, A.8.3]. In fact, with a minor additional condition in our
deÔ¨Ånition of excellent G-prespectra, these adjoints are f-coÔ¨Åbrations.
Precisely,
we must require that B and all total spaces Y (V ) of excellent G-prespectra Y be
G-LEC (locally equiconnected), which just means that their diagonal maps are
h-coÔ¨Åbrations. Then the proofs given by Lewis in [95] apply to prove the claim;
compare [61, ¬ßX.4]. This additional requirement causes no diÔ¨Éculty in the theory
of Chapter 13. Now (LY )(V ) is the colimit of a sequence of f-coÔ¨Åbrations that are
fp-equivalences, by Lemma 13.2.3, and Proposition 8.2.1(iv) gives that each LY (V )
is an ex-Ô¨Åbration. Therefore LY is an h-Ô¨Åbrant G-spectrum and the natural map
Y ‚àí‚Üí‚ÑìLY is a weak equivalence, giving the conclusion.

Remark 24.4.7. Returning to the discussion of CW-spectra in ¬ß24.2, one is
tempted to consider the naive approach sketched there, starting from the spectrum
over B version of the detecting set DB = {Sn,b
H } speciÔ¨Åed in DeÔ¨Ånition 13.1.1. As
explained in Theorem 13.1.14 and Remark 13.1.16, the localizing subcategory of the
triangulated category HoGSB generated by DB is all of HoGSB. However, on the
level of spectra over B, the resulting cell spectra all consist of Ô¨Åbers glued together
trivially, just as in Remark 13.1.16, and these cannot satisfy any reasonable levelwise
Ô¨Åbrancy condition. In particular, one cannot hope to prove the factorization axioms
by use of the small object argument.

24.5. TOWARDS PARAMETRIZED SG-MODULES
423
24.5. Towards parametrized SG-modules
The construction of smash products and the theory of SG-modules of [61] de-
pends on the twisted half-smash product functor.
This construction is used to
internalize external smash products and is thus the analogue in [61,98] of internal-
ization via left Kan extension in the theory of diagram spectra. It is considerably
more useful calculationally, but is less categorically conceptual.
The treatment
of twisted half-smash product functors developed by Michael Cole, nonequivari-
antly in [61, App] and equivariantly in [118, Ch. XXII], carries over directly to the
parametrized setting, as was noted by Po Hu [78, pp 12‚Äì19]. We give a brief sketch.
Let U and U ‚Ä≤ be G-universes and let I (U, U ‚Ä≤) be the G-space of linear isome-
tries U ‚àí‚ÜíU ‚Ä≤, with G acting by conjugation. Working with G-spaces and ex-G-
spaces over B where Cole uses unbased and based G-spaces and with G-spectra
over B where Cole uses G-spectra, there are no substantive changes in the parallel
nonequivariant and equivariant constructions of [61, App] and [118, Ch. XXII].
Following Cole, we deÔ¨Åne a category GSB(U ‚Ä≤; U) whose objects E consist of
families of G-spectra EV ‚ààGSBU ‚Ä≤ over B indexed on U ‚Ä≤, one for each indexing
G-space V ‚äÇU, together with isomorphisms Œ£W ‚àíV
B
EW ‚àí‚ÜíEV whenever V ‚äÇW.
For each ex-G-space K over B, we deÔ¨Åne an object E (K) ‚ààGSB(U; U) such that
E (K)V = Œ£‚àû
V (K). More generally, for a G-linear isometry f : U ‚àí‚ÜíU ‚Ä≤ we deÔ¨Åne
an object Ef(K) ‚ààGSB(U ‚Ä≤; U) such that Ef(K)V = Œ£‚àû
f(V )(K). There are smash

to internalize the external smash product which takes G-spectra X and X‚Ä≤ over
B and B‚Ä≤, both indexed on U, to a G-spectrum X ‚äºX‚Ä≤ over B √ó B‚Ä≤ indexed on
U 2 = U ‚äïU. When B = B‚Ä≤, pulling back along the diagonal of B gives the internal
smash product X ‚àßB X‚Ä≤ in this context. Since the problems with base change along
the diagonal are intrinsic, the limitations of the internal smash product and the use
of Brown representability to construct internal function spectra would remain as in
the approach using orthogonal spectra.
Using the linear isometries operad L , we can operadically parametrize the
internalization (over cartesian products) of external smash products. This leads to
parametrized versions of the basic deÔ¨Ånitions of EKMM [61], but we leave further
development along these lines to the interested reader.
